DNA Precipitation Protocol

 ~Action~  ~Action~ well.
Let sit on ice 15-30 minutes.  
 ~Action~ at max speed, 20 minutes.
Carefully  ~Action~ supernatant and  ~Action~ tube halfway with 70% ethanol. 
 ~Action~ at max speed for 2 minutes.
Repeat the above step one time (2nd 70% wash).
 ~Action~ as much ethanol as possible without disturbing the pellet  ~Action~ tube  ~Action~ on bench ~ 15 minutes.   
Large Volume Marine Cyanophage Phage Purification
 ~Action~ cells in large volumes (1-2L) to yield ~1011 - 1012 cells using 'microbubbling' technique.
 ~Action~ Rnase A (10ug ml-1 = for 2L, 250µl of Qiagen's 100mg/ml stock) and DNase1 (0.25 SU ml-1 =2L, add 50µl of stock).
 ~Action~ 12,500 rpm (23,975xg) in Beckman Ja-14 for 15 minutes at 4°C  ~Action~ the supernatant through a Kim Wipe tissue paper.
 ~Action~ in polyethylene glycol (PEG 8,000; 100g L-1) by gentle stirring.
 ~Action~ overnight at 4°C.
Collect PEG-phage precipitate by centrifuge (6 tubes at a time for the 2L volumes) at 12,500rpm (23,975xg) in Beckman Ja-14 for 15 minutes at 4°C.
 ~Action~ supernatant.
Gently  ~Action~ pellet into ~1/150 volume Pro99 (~1-2 ml).
 ~Action~ in resuspension media - ~Action~ the tube on its side in syrofoam cut-outs so that it rests at an angle.
 ~Action~ orbital shaker (150 rpm) in cold room for overnight re-suspension.
 ~Action~ resuspended PEG concentrated phage into a single tube (now ready for layering onto a CsCl gradient).
 ~Action~ a CsCl step gradient (1.3, 1.4, 1.5, 1.65 bands) in ultracentrifuge tubes.  
 ~Action~ concentrated phage sample at top.
 ~Action~ 28,000 rpm for 4 hours at 4°C in SW28 swinging bucket rotor.
 ~Action~ purified phage band (interface of ρ = 1.4 and 1.5 bands on step gradient). 
 ~Action~ in Slide-A-Lyzer dialysis cassettes (Pierce #66425; 10K MWCO, 0.5-3.0 ml volume) - 30 minutes against 5xNaCl (3M), 3xNaCl (1.8M), two changes of 1xNaCl buffer [MTM100 = 600 mM NaCl, 100 mM TrisHCL (pH = 7.5), 100 mM MgCl2].  
 ~Action~ dialyzed particles at 4°C until needed. 
 ~Action~ for 1 hour at room temperature. 
 ~Action~ 116g NaCl per Liter of lysate (thus 2M addition + seawater yields final concentration ~2.6M).
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ in large volumes ( ~Amount~  to yield  ~Numerical~  ~Reagent~ using  ~Method~ 
Isolation of cyanophages by liquid enrichment assay
 ~Action~ at least 3 L water sample through a glass fiber filter.
 ~Action~ sample through 0.2 µm or 0.45 µm low protein binding PVDF filter.
 ~Action~ the filtered water samples (e.g., 0.5 L or more) into culture vessels, e.g., 1 L or larger Erlenmeyer flasks.
 ~Action~ nutrients to the filtered water to support growth of the target cells.
 ~Action~ the filtered water with 1% to 10% v/v of host culture.
As a control, replace the filtered environmental sample with virus-free (0.02 µm filtered or heat-killed) water sample.
 ~Action~ the flasks at the temperature and light conditions appropriate for the cyanobacteria and look for signs of lysis.
 ~Action~ an aliquot of the enrichment culture, and pellet remaining cells by centrifugation (e.g., 20 minutes at 6000g).
 ~Action~ the supernatant through a 0.22 µm or 0.45 µm PVDF filter.
 ~Action~  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~ through a  ~Modifier~  ~Device~ 
Filter  ~Reagent~ through  ~Size~ or  ~Size~  ~Modifier~  ~Device~ 
Dispense the  ~Modifier~  ~Reagent~ (e.g., 0.5 L or more) into  ~Location~  e.g., 1 L or larger Erlenmeyer flasks.
Glass Bead Transformation of Chlamydomonas
 ~Action~ cell culture to an OD750 of 0.15 to 0.4. 
 ~Action~ at 400g for 5 minutes at room temperature. 
 ~Action~ in 1/100th the original volume of TAP. 
Add the following: 8000, PEG to 5% final conc., 3 ug of DNA, 0.3g of 500, micron glass beads 0.4mL, Chlamy cell suspension. 
 ~Action~ with a pipette  ~Action~ at max speed for 15 seconds. 
 ~Action~ 25uL of the cell suspension and  ~Action~ to 100uL of TAP with an appropriate antibiotic. 
 ~Action~ on a TAP or YA plate, with an appropriate antibiotic, using large glass beads. 
Allow the liquid to dry while avoiding light. 
 ~Action~ the plates with parafilm. 
Allow the colonies to  ~Action~  ~Action~ while avoiding light. 
Seal the plates with parafilm. 
Allow the colonies to grow (colonies will appear in 1-3 weeks). 
 ~Action~ the remaining cell/vortex culture to a 125mL flask with 20mL of TAP. 
w/o antibiotic  ~Action~ for 6 hours on an orbital shaker at 70rpm. 
PNGase F Protocol, Denaturing Conditions

 ~Action~ denatured glycoprotein on ice. 
 ~Action~ 10 seconds. 
 ~Action~ the following (bringing total reaction volume to 20 µl):  
 ~Action~ PNGase F,  1 µl. 
 ~Action~ gently. 
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ by heating  ~Reagent~ at  ~Temperature~ for  ~Temperature~ 
Chill  ~Reagent~ on  ~Location~  
Nitrite reagent for dissolved cobalt analyses
 ~Action~ 12.9 g of sodium nitrite per 125 mL of Milli-Q, by weighing the sodium nitrite directly into a large trace metal clean bottle.
 ~Action~ 125 mL of Milli-Q to the bottle by weight.
 ~Action~ clean Chelex-100 resin to the bottle and  ~Action~ it on a shaker overnight to ensure the Chelex mixes throughout the solution.
The following morning, slowly  ~Action~ the solution through an HPLC column with a frit in order to filter the chelex and allow the solution to  ~Action~  ~Amount~ of  ~Reagent~ per  ~Amount~ of  ~Reagent~  by weighing the  ~Reagent~  ~Modifier~ into a  ~Modifier~ trace metal  ~Modifier~  ~Modifier~ clean  ~Location~  ~Modifier~ 125 mL of Milli-Q, by  ~Action~ the sodium nitrite directly into a large trace metal clean bottle.

OmniPrep™ For High Quality Genomic DNA Extraction From Paraffin-Embedded Tissue
 ~Action~ 100µl xylene or safe xylene substitute and  ~Action~ at room temperature for 5 minutes with constant mixing.
(wash 1/3)  ~Action~ at 14,000xg for 2 minutes and  ~Action~ xylene or xylene substitute.
(wash 1/3)  ~Action~ 100µl xylene or safe xylene substitute and  ~Action~ at room temperature for 5 minutes with constant mixing.
(wash 2/3)  ~Action~ at 14,000xg for 2 minutes and  ~Action~ xylene or xylene substitute.
(wash 3/3)  ~Action~ 100µl 100% ethanol and  ~Action~ for 5 minutes at room temperature with constant mixing.
(wash 1/2) Allow the sample to cool to room temperature.
 ~Action~ 200µl chloroform and  ~Action~ by inverting the tube several times.
 ~Action~ for 10 minutes at 14,000xg and carefully  ~Action~ the upper phase to a clean microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ 50µl DNA Stripping Solution to the sample and  ~Action~ several times to mix.
 ~Action~ the sample for 5-10 minutes at 60°C.
 ~Action~ 100µl Precipitation Solution and  ~Action~ by inverting the tube several times.
 ~Action~ the sample at 14,000xg for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ the supernatant to a clean tube and  ~Action~ the genomic DNA with 500µl isopropanol.
 ~Action~ the tubes 10 times to precipitate the DNA.
OPTIONAL: For increased DNA recovery,  ~Action~ 2µl Mussel Glycogen as a DNA carrier.
 ~Action~ at 14,000xg for 5 minutes to pellet genomic DNA.
 ~Action~ the supernatant.
 ~Action~ 700µl 70% ethanol to the tube and  ~Action~ several times to wash the DNA pellet.
 ~Action~ for 1 minute at 14,000xg.
 ~Action~ or  ~Action~ the ethanol wash.  
 ~Action~ the tube on a clean absorbent surface for several minutes to allow any excess ethanol to drain away.
 ~Action~ 50µl TE Buffer to the pellet.
 ~Action~ at room temperature for at least 15 minutes to rehydrate.
OPTIONAL: 1µl LongLife™ RNase for every 100µl TE Buffer can be added at this stage.
 ~Action~ DNA at 4°C, for long term storage store at -20°C or -80°C.
 ~Action~ at 14,000xg for 2 minutes and  ~Action~ xylene or xylene substitute.
(wash 2/3)  ~Action~ 100µl xylene or safe xylene substitute and  ~Action~ at room temperature for 5 minutes with constant mixing.
(wash 3/3)  ~Action~ at 14,000xg for 2 minutes and  ~Action~ ethanol.
(wash 1/2)  ~Action~ 100µl 100% ethanol and  ~Action~ for 5 minutes at room temperature with constant mixing.
(wash 2/2)  ~Action~ at 14,000xg for 2 minutes and  ~Action~ ethanol.
(wash 2/2)  ~Action~ 100µl Genomic Lysis Buffer and  ~Action~ the sample with a microfuge pestle until a homogenous suspension is acquired, approximately 30-60 strokes.
 ~Action~ the sample at 55-60°C for 15-60 minutes.
 ~Action~ higher than 60°C. 
OPTIONAL: For maximum DNA recovery,  ~Action~ 1µl Proteinase K solution for every 100µl Lysis Buffer and  ~Action~ at 60°C for 1-2 hours.
 ~Action~ the tube periodically each hour.
This step will digest hard to handle tissues and significantly improve the yield.
Finely  ~Action~ 0.5-2mg paraffin-embedded tissue and  ~Action~  ~Action~ to room temperature.

Screening Recombinant Clones by PCR. 
 ~Action~ the transformed clones to a stock LB-Amp or other appropriate plated media.
 ~Action~ for 24 hr at 37°C.
 ~Action~ forward and reverse primers for the vector used for transformation at 100 ng/μl in DDH2O.
See table in guidelines for recommended primers to use with pUC18 vector.
 ~Action~ thin-walled tubes.
 ~Action~ 1 ml of Master Mix:
ABI Reagents  PGC Scientific Reagents  Final Concentration       DDH2O690 µl DDH2O833.5 µl -----10x Buffer II100 µl 10x Buffer w/MgCl2100 µl 1x BufferdNTP mix80 µl dNTP mix20 µl 200 µM each25mM MgCl280 µl    2mMPrimer F20 µl Primer F20 µl 0.33 µMPrimer R20 µl Primer R20 µl 0.33 µMAmpliTaq Gold10 µl Taq Polymerase6.5 µl 1U/20 µl rxn.

Grow for 24 hr at 37°C.
Conjugation on filters. 
 ~Action~ small (2 or 3 ml) cultures of your donor and recipient strains, with appropriate antibiotics, in lysogeny broth (LB).
Do this late in the day, the day before you want to do the conjugation.
Take 1 ml of donor and recipient culture and  ~Action~ at 10,000 rcf for 2 minutes to pellet the bacteria.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the supernatant and  ~Action~ the bacterial pellet in fresh LB with no antibiotics.
First thing in the morning on the day of the conjugation, place sterilised 0.2 um pore size filters on an L-agar plate without antibiotics.
Use aseptic technique.
You will need one filter for each conjugation you're setting up, plus one for each strain on its own as a control.
 ~Action~ 10 ul of the resuspended donor and recipient strains in the same place on a filter, sitting on the agar plate.
Do the same for each strain on its own as a control.
 ~Action~ the plate upside down (agar suface facing up) at 37 degrees Celsius.
Near the end of your work day, take the plate out of the incubator.
Using aseptic technique, pick each filter off the plate using forceps and place it in a 1.5 ml tube containing 1 ml of sterile PBS.
 ~Action~ the tubes to free the bacteria from the filter.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the filters from the tubes using aseptic technique.
 ~Action~ desired volumes of the bacterial suspension on selective agar medium and  ~Action~  ~Amount~ of donor and recipient culture and centrifuge at  ~Speed~  ~Action~ 1 ml of  ~Reagent~ and centrifuge at 10,000 rcf for  ~Time~  ~Amount~ (2 or 3 ml)  ~Reagent~  with appropriate antibiotics, in lysogeny broth (LB).
Cryopreservation
 ~Action~ 100% Glycerol to 50% Glycerol.
In a sterile 50ml Falcon tube  ~Action~ 25ml 100% glycerol.
 ~Action~ 25ml autoclaved MilliQ and  ~Action~ thoroughly.
 ~Action~ into sterile reservoir.
In sterile 500ml deep 96 well plate  ~Action~ 240μl of 50% glycerol to each well using an 8 channel pipet. 
 ~Action~ pore film off of 2ml deep 96 well plate.
Using a 12 channel 200μl pipet,  ~Action~ up and down from bottom of wells 3 times, then  ~Action~ 160μl from each well to the plate with glycerol.
 ~Action~ up and down in glycerol 5 times.
Repeat step 4 for all rows/wells. 
 ~Action~ 500ml deep 96 well plate (glycerol plate) with foil.
 ~Action~ in shaker for 30 minutes.
 ~Action~ 2ml deep 96 well plate with pore film and  ~Action~ in refrigerator.
After 30 minutes on shaker,  ~Action~  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~ to  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~ 
Detecting Fungal Infections in Almonds
Manually  ~Action~ almond kernel samples that are pasteurized and shelled.
As mentioned in the 'Before Start Instructions', the almond kernels should be collected from multiple harvest cycles.
These particular samples were obtained from the 2012 and 2013 almond seasons.
The samples should be shelled and should not have any type of physical damage or any marks.
 ~Action~ weight and size of almond kernels. 
 ~Action~  ~Modifier~ select  ~Reagent~ that are  ~Modifier~ and  ~Modifier~ 
As mentioned in the 'Before Start Instructions', the almond kernels should be collected from multiple harvest cycles.
These particular samples were obtained from the 2012 and 2013 almond seasons.
The samples should be shelled and should not have any type of physical damage or any marks.
Record  ~Measure-Type~ of  ~Reagent~  
Separate the  ~Reagent~ into two groups.
Out of the 550 almond kernels collected 460 of those will be infected with two types of fungi that commonly affect almond crops.
230 will be infected with A. flavus and another 230 will be infected with A. parasiticus.
The remaining 90 kernels will remain uninfected and will serve as a control group.
Obtain A. flavus and A. parasiticus isolates to infect almonds.
These two types of fungi were chosen due to their well known colonization on the surface of almond kernels.
Prior to inoculation, take the fungi isolates and grow them in culture.
Use 5% reconstituted tomato juice agar, in this case it will be V8 juice agar, and grow each isolate for 6 days at a temperature of 31 °C in a dark environment.
Once fungal isolates have been grown, conidia is collected using a sterilized cotton swab and is deposited in sterile deionized water.
A haemocytometer will be used to quantify the water solution with conidia and it will then be diluted to a concentration of 105 spores per ml-1.
Create incision on the bottom right of almond kernels using a B-D® 16G1 PrecisionGlide®Needle.
This incision serves as the point of infection where the conidia in water would be placed.
After making the incision on the surface of the almond, the kernels will be sterilized by submerging them in 10% bleach solution for a period of 7 minutes.
The kernels will then be rinsed three times with sterile deionized water and will be submerged a second time into a Dichloran solution for 2 seconds.
Remove moisture from surface of almonds by blotting them and move them to a biological safety cabinet for a period of 10 to 15 minutes.
Inoculate each almond with 5 μl of the fungi solution.As mentioned earlier, almonds will be in two separate groups: infected and control.
The infected almonds will be inoculated with either A. flavus or A. parasiticus.
Once the almonds have been inoculated, add deionized water to the container where they are located and incubate them for a period of 7 days at a temperature of 31° in a dark place.
Once the incubation period is over, wash almonds with deionized water to remove any traces of fungi spores from the surface.
Vitamin Solution for ESAW Media for Marine Phytoplankton
Thiamine Vitamin B12 Biotin After mixing,  ~Action~ with 0.2 μm filter and  ~Action~ in dark at -20ºC.
 ~Action~  ~Size~  ~Device~ and store in  ~Location~ at  ~Temperature~ 
MojoSort™ Human CD14 Selection Kit Protocol
 ~Action~ cells from your tissue of interest without lysing erythrocytes.
In the final wash of your sample preparation,  ~Action~ the cells in MojoSort™ Buffer by adding up to 4mL in a 5 mL (12 x 75 mm) polystyrene tube.
Note: Keep MojoSort™ Buffer on ice throughout the procedure.
 ~Action~ the cells with a 70 μm cell strainer,  ~Action~ at 300 x g for 5 minutes, and  ~Action~ in an appropriate volume of MojoSort™ Buffer.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the cell concentration to 1 x 108 cells/mL.
 ~Action~ 100 μL of cell suspension (107 cells) into a new tube.
 ~Action~ 10 μL of the biotin anti-human CD14,mix well and  ~Action~  ~Action~ well and incubate on ice for 15 minutes.
 ~Action~ the volume accordingly if separating more cells.
For example,  ~Action~ 100 μL for 1 x 108 cells.
When working with less than 107 cells, use indicated volumesfor 107 cells.
Optional: Keep unused cells, or take an aliquot before  ~Action~ the cocktail to  ~Action~ purity and yield.
 ~Action~ the beads by  ~Action~  maximum speed, 5 touches.
Without washing,  ~Action~ 10 μL of Streptavidin Nanobeads.
 ~Action~ well and incubate on ice for 15 minutes.
 ~Action~ the volume accordingly if separating more cells.
For example,  ~Action~ 100 μL for 1 x 108 cells.
When working with less than 107 cells, use indicated volumes for 107 cells.
 ~Action~ the cells in 3 mL of MojoSort™ Buffer.
Note: If you observe aggregates,  ~Action~ the suspension.
To maximize yield, you can  ~Action~ the aggregates by  ~Action~ the solution up and down.
 ~Action~ the tube in the magnet for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the liquid.
These are your cells of interest; DO NOT DISCARD.
If needed,  ~Action~ 3 mL of MojoSort™ Buffer and  ~Action~ steps 10 and 11 with the magnetically labeled fraction up to two times, and then  ~Action~ the unlabeled fractions.
Note: Repeating the magnetic separation increases the yield, without a strong impact on the purity.
The yield will typically increase about 8 – 10% with a second separation, and about 2 – 5% with a third separation.
The purity may decrease 1 – 2% with each separation.
Optional: Take a small aliquot before  ~Action~ the tube in the magnet to  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ from your  ~Reagent~  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ 
Quick Fungal DNA Extraction
 ~Action~ fungal material into 300 µL rich growth medium in a 2 mL micro-centrifuge tube.Grow at RT for 3-4 days.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ at RT for 3-4 days.
Freeze culture tubes in LN2Freeze dry over night. 
 ~Action~ 50 µL 0.6mm glass beads to freeze-dried sample in 2 mL tube and  ~Action~ using Tissue-Lyser LT for 5 mins at 50 Hz. 
 ~Action~ 500 µL lysis buffer to pulverised sample.
 ~Action~ to  ~Action~ Heat to 45 ˚C for 5 mins,  ~Action~ at 1200 rpm.
 ~Action~ 0.5 vol (250 µL) 3 M Potassium Acetate to lysis mix.
 ~Action~ to mix.
 ~Action~ at 12 K rpm for a minimum of 15 minutes @ 4˚C.
 ~Action~ supernatant (~ 650 µL) to fresh 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ 1 vol chilled Isopropanol ( ~ 700 µL ) to the supernatant, mix well, incubate -20˚C for 1hr.
 ~Action~ at 12 K rpm for a minimum of 15 minutes at 4°C.
 ~Action~ gently or aspirate supernatant.
To the pellet add 500 µL 70% ethanol stored at -20°C.
 ~Action~ at 12 K rpm for a minimum of 3 minutes at 4°C.
 ~Action~ supernatant.
 ~Action~ wash step with 500 µL of cold 70% ethanol.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ supernatant.
 ~Action~ pellet in speed-vac at 45˚C for 5-10 minutes.
 ~Action~ pellet in nuclease free water or TE buffer (10 mM Tris pH 8.0, 1 mM EDTA pH 8.0).

Estimation of viral-induced phytoplankton mortality using the modified dilution method
To create the grazer-free diluent whole seawater is  ~Action~ through acid-washed 0.2–0.45 µm filters (e.g., PALL Acropak™ Supor® membrane capsules) into a clean carboy.
After gravity filtration half of the grazer-free diluent is  ~Action~ a tangential flow filtration system with kilodalton (kDa) pore size to create the virus-free diluent.
The grazer-free and virus-free diluents are  ~Action~ to 10-L polycarbonate bottles in the correct proportions to create the parallel t0 dilution series, e.g., 20%, 40%, 70%, and 100% whole water.
The mesoplankton-free whole water is then gently  ~Action~ by siphoning.
From each of these t0 bottles, triplicate 1-L polycarbonate bottles were  ~Action~ twice and then gently  ~Action~ by siphoning (to minimize physical damage to the grazers, viruses, and phytoplankton populations), ensuring that bottles are  ~Action~ completely to avoid trapping air bubbles inside upon closure.
After filling, triplicate experimental bottles are  ~Action~ randomly into experimental conditions.
For determination of phytoplankton composition and abundance and virus abundance, triplicate subsamples (5 mL) are  ~Action~ from the 10 L t0 dilution bottles and the 0.2–0.45-µm and kDa diluents.
Initial (t0) and final (t24) phytoplankton composition and abundance estimates are typically  ~Action~ by analysis of samples using flow cytometry
Apparent phytoplankton growth rates (µ, d–1) are  ~Action~ from each experimental bottle as the changes in abundance during the incubation using the equation:µ = ln(Pt/Po)/t.
The actual dilution rate is  ~Action~  ~Reagent~  ~Reagent~ is gravity filtered through  ~Modifier~  ~Size~  ~Device~ (e.g., PALL Acropak™ Supor® membrane capsules) into a  ~Modifier~  ~Location~

Methyltransferase Assay.

This step is necessary to remove trace nuclease activity when using endA+ strains such as the JM series, HB101 and its derivatives, or any wild-type strain, which have high levels of nuclease activity or high carbohydrate content.
Host strains such as XL-1 Blue and DH5®α do not require this additional wash step.

Clear Slides: Removes paraffin and hydrates the tissue.
A. Xylene:5 minutes in each of (3) different 250mL containers 
B. 100% alcohol 5 minutes in each of (3) different 250mL containers 
C. 95% alcohol 3 minutes in (1) 250mL container 
D. 70% alcohol 3 minutes in (1) 250mL container 
E. Water 1 minutes in each of (3) different 250mL containers 
F. H2O2 (3%) 15 minutes in (1) 250mL container.
 ~Action~ slides with lab grade water.
Note: Lab grade filtered water such as injection grade, cell culture grade, Reverse Osmosis De-Ionisation (RODI).

Do NOT wash after this step.

XIT™ Genomic DNA Blood Kit Protocol for Purificaton of DNA from Amniotic Fluid
 ~Action~ 1‐3ml Amniotic fluid to a 1.5ml centrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ 14,000xg for 5 seconds then remove supernatant carefully without disturbing the pellet.
 ~Action~ supernatant leaving 10‐20µl residual liquid in the tube.
 ~Action~ the tube to resuspend the cells in the residual liquid.
 ~Action~ 400µl of XIT™ Lysis Buffer to the resuspended cells and vortex vigorously to lyse the cells.
Usually no incubation is required; however, if cell clumps are visible after mixing,  ~Action~ at 37°C for 5‐10 minutes or until the solution is homogenous.
 ~Action~ the tube on ice for 1 minute to rapidly cool to room temperature.
 ~Action~ 90µl XIT™ Protein Precipitation Buffer to the sample and  ~Action~ by inverting the tube 10‐20 times.
 ~Action~ at 16,000g for 5 minutes.
Carefully,  ~Action~ the supernatant to a new tube.
 ~Action~ 400µl isopropanol and 5µl Glycogen Solution to the supernatant and  ~Action~ by gently inverting the sample at least 20‐25 times.
 ~Action~ at 14,000rpm for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ the supernatant and use a pipette to carefully remove remaining liquid without disturbing the DNA pellet.
 ~Action~ 200µl 70% ethanol and invert the tube twice to wash the pellet.
 ~Action~ at 14,000rpm for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ the supernatant and drain the tube on a piece of clean absorbent paper.
Allow to air dry for 15 minutes.
 ~Action~ 50µl TE buffer to dissolve the DNA.
Rehydrate the genomic DNA by  ~Action~  ~Action~ the genomic DNA by incubating at 55‐65°C for one hour.
 ~Action~ overnight at room temperature to ensure complete genomic DNA hydration.
 ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~ supernatant carefully without disturbing the pellet.
Algal culture harvest and RNA extraction for RNA-Seq
Use sterile techniques to harvest 800 ml of culture, and  ~Action~ into 4 250 ml centrifuge bottles with 200 ml each.
 ~Action~ the centrifuge bottles at 5000 g for 10 min.
Carefully  ~Action~ the supernatant.
Use 0.5 ml of RNALater to resuspend the pellet and  ~Action~ it to a microcentrifuge tube.
Use another 0.25 ml of RNALater to wash the bottle and  ~Action~ any remaining cells.
 ~Action~ this 0.25 ml into the same microcentrifuge tube.
Depending on whether you want pseudo-replicates, you can  ~Action~ the 4 harvested pellet separate or mixed.
 ~Action~ the harvested cells at or below -20oC until ready for RNA extraction.
Before RNA extraction, the RNALater needs to be removed.
 ~Action~ samples if they are frozen.
 ~Action~ samples at > 10 k g for 10 min at 4oC.
RNALater sometimes affects the buoyancy of the cells, and make them a bit harder to pellet.
If you find that the cells are not pelleting,  ~Action~ harder for a longer time.
 ~Action~ supernatent with RNALater.

 ~Action~ any DNA from the extracted samples using DNase (Sigma), following manufacturer's instructions.
 ~Action~ the total RNA using a RNA Clean & Concentrator kit (Zymo), following the manufacturer's instructions.
 ~Action~ the RNA using any preferred method, e.g. Qubit fluorometer.
 ~Action~ the RNA at -80oC.

 ~Action~ lymph nodes (superficial cervical, mandibular, axillary, inguinal, and mesenteric) from mice.
 ~Action~ lymph nodes through a sterile 70-μm nylon cell strainer to obtain single-cell suspensions in IMDM containing 10% FCS (complete medium).
 ~Action~ cells in complete medium and use your favorite method to isolate CD4+ cells.
Check out Biocompare.com to find useful kits.

Aseptically  ~Action~ antibody solution from the plate.
 ~Action~ plate 3 times with sterile PBS.

Protein Expression & Isolation & Purification
Through expression, we can explore the function and the mechanism of regulation of gene expression, as well as the protein encoded by cloned gene expression can be used for the study of structure and function.
E. Coli is the most widely used protein expression systems and the expression level of exogenous gene product is much higher than other gene expression systems.
The amount of targeted protein expressed is even more than 80% of the total bacterial proteins.
In this study, a plasmid carrying the gene of the target protein in E. coli BL21, and at 37 C, IPTG induced overexpression of carries six consecutive histidine residues recombinant chloramphenicol acetyltransferase protein that available one kind by covalent conjugation of nitrilotriacetic acid (NTA) nickel ions (Ni2 +) immobilized chromatographic media to be purified, in fact boil metal affinity chromatography (MCAC).
The degree of purification of the protein can be analyzed by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis.
Reagents and Equipment ReagentLB broth: Trytone 10g, yeast extract 5g, NaCl 10g; add up to 1000ml with distilled water;ampicillin: 100mg / mLSampleBuffer: 100 mM NaH2PO4, 10 mMTris, 8M Urea, 10 mM2-ME, pH8.0(4) Washing Buffer：100 mM NaH2PO4, 10 mM Tris, 8 M Urea, pH6.3(5) Elution Buffer:100 mM NaH2PO4, 10 mMTris, 8M Urea, 500 mM Imidazole, pH8.0(6) IPTG EquipmentShaker, centrifuges, chromatography column (1'10 cm). 
Operating method.
Induction of Chloramphenicol acetyltransferase recombinant protein.
 ~Action~ E. coli BL21 strain containing the recombinant protein of chloramphenicol acetyltransferase in 5mL LB liquid medium (containing 100ug/mL ampicillin), 37 C shaking and culture overnight.
 ~Action~ 1mL overnight cultures in 100 mL (containing 100ug/mL ampicillin) LB liquid medium; 37 C  ~Action~ culture until OD600 = 0.6 - 0.8.
 ~Action~ 10ul samples for SDS-PAGE analysis.
 ~Action~ IPTG to a final concentration of 0.5 mmol/l,  ~Action~ 1-3h at 37 C.
12,000rpm centrifugation for 10 min,  ~Action~ the supernatant;  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ containing the  ~Reagent~ of  ~Reagent~ in  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~ (containing 100ug/mL ampicillin),  ~Temperature~  ~Action~ and  ~Action~  ~Time~ 
Transfer  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~ in  ~Amount~ (containing 100ug/mL ampicillin)  ~Reagent~   ~Temperature~ shake  ~Reagent~ until  ~Generic-Measure~  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~  LB liquid medium; 37 C shake culture until OD600 = 0.6 - 0.8.

The average eluate volume is 9 µl from 10 µl elution buffer volume.Elution efficiency is dependent on pH.
The maximum elution efficiency is achieved between pH 7.0 and 8.5.

Cloning shRNA Oligos into pLKO.1
 ~Action~ oligos in ddH2O to a concentration of 20 μM.
 ~Action~ 5ul Forward oligo. 
 ~Action~ 5ul Reverse oligo. 
 ~Action~ 5 μL	10x NEB buffer 2. 
 ~Action~  ~Amount~  ~Amount~  ~Amount~  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~  
Add 5ul  ~Reagent~  
Add 5 μL	 ~Reagent~  
Add 35 μL  ~Reagent~  ~Reagent~ in  ~Reagent~ to a concentration of  ~Concentration~ 
Add 5ul Forward oligo. 
Add 5ul Reverse oligo. 
Add 5 μL	10x NEB buffer 2. 
Add 35 μL ddH2O. 
Incubate for 4 minutes at 95°C in a PCR machine or in a beaker of boiling water.
Incubate the sample at 70°C for 10 minutes in a PCR machine.
Slowly cool to room temperature over the period of several hours.
Mix: 6 μg pLKO.1 TRC-cloning vector (maxiprep or miniprep DNA) with 5 μL	10x NEB buffer 1 with 1 μL	AgeI bring to 50 μL	ddH2O. 
Incubate at 37°C for 2 hours.
Purify with Qiaquick gel extraction kit, eluting in 30 μL of ddH2O.
Digest eluate with EcoRI by mixing: 30 μL pLKO.1 TRC-cloning vector digested with AgeI with 5 μL	10x NEB buffer for EcoRI with 1 μL	EcoRI and 14 μL	ddH2O. 
Incubate at 37°C for 2 hours.
Run digested DNA on 0.8% low melting point agarose gel until you can distinctly see 2 bands, one 7kb and one 1.9kb.
Cut out the 7kb band and place in a sterile microcentrifuge tube.
Purify the DNA using a Qiaquick gel extraction kit.
Elute in 30 μL of ddH2O.
Measure the DNA concentration.

This step will digest hard to handle tissues and significantly improve the yield.

 ~Action~ the tubes 10 times to precipitate the DNA.

Transcriptomics During One-Step Growth Curves for Cellulophaga Phages
Do a plaque assay to determine the PFU/ml of the lysate you plan to use Inoculate a new culture; i.e., pick a colony into a 125 ml flask containing MLB media. 
The next day, transfer 10 ml of this culture to 500 ml of new media in a Fernbach flask (short and fat 2800 ml). 
Inoculate enough 500 ml cultures for your experiment. 
Immediately after the transfer, take a 'time 0' growth reading. 
Continue taking readings in this way periodically.  
Graph the results as you go!
Determine the concentration of your culture at the time you want to start the infection. 
Calculate the total number of cells in each of your 500 ml cultures. 
Calculate how many phages you should add for MOI 3.  
Add phages to the experimental flask and an equal volume of MSM to the control flask and start your timer. 
Immediately, dilute the infection 1:1 in MLB media; i.e., add 500 ml fresh media to each flask and swirl to mix.  
Take a sample immediately after dilution Steps for centrifuged plaque assay:  
Steps for non-centrifuged plaque assay:  
Steps for RNA samples: 
The next day, count the plaques on all plates that have a countable number of them  The next day, count any new plaques that have appeared; add these to your original count.  
Count again on the third day. 
Continue sampling in this way for 8 hours. 
Calculate PFU/ml at each time point for both the centrifuged (free phage only) and not centrifuged (total phage) samples.  
Graph the results. 
 ~Action~  ~Action~ a plaque assay to determine the PFU/ml of the lysate you plan to use Inoculate a new culture; i.e., pick a colony into a 125 ml flask containing MLB media.

 ~Action~ restriction enzymes to digest your plasmid.
 ~Action~ by reading the instructions for your enzyme.
In a 1.5mL tube  ~Action~ the following:  DNA (all amounts are for a typical reaction; your amount may vary depending on the enzymes).
Typical mixture for single digest: Nuclease-free Water, 16 ul; 10X Buffer EcoRI2 ulDNA (0.5/1 ug/ul), 1 ul; EcoRI0. 5-2 ul;
Typical Mixture for Double Digest: Nuclease-free Water, 15 ul; 10X Buffer, 02 ul; DNA (0.5-1 ug/ul), 1 ul; EcoRI, 1 ul; PstI, 1 ul;
 ~Action~ gently by pipetting.
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ to digest your plasmid.
Cleaning of the Nuclear Fraction (FOCUS™ SubCell Kit)
 ~Action~ the nuclear pellet in 300µl SubCell Buffer‐III.
 ~Action~ the tube at 700x g for 5 minutes and  ~Action~ the supernatant.
The pellet containing nuclei is clean enough for most purposes.
If further cleaning required, go to next step.
 ~Action~ 300µl SubCell Buffer‐IV to a 1.5ml centrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ the nuclear pellet in 100µl SubCell Buffer‐III.
Carefully  ~Action~ the nuclear suspension on the surface of SubCell Buffer‐IV.
 ~Action~ the tube at 1,000x g for 10 minutes.
Using a sharp pipette tip,  ~Action~ the sticky lump if any.
The lump is formed from dead cells and some lysed nuclei.

Recovery of DNA from Low Melting Point Agarose
Low melting point agarose gels should be  ~Action~ and allowed to  ~Action~ in the cold room, but  ~Action~ at room temperature.
The gels should be  ~Action~ at 4°C and  ~Action~ until ready to cut out the DNA bands from the gel.
 ~Action~ the DNA bands from the gel with new razor blades.
 ~Action~ a new razor blade for each band.
 ~Action~ the agarose pieces into sterile capped tubes (the size of the tubes depends on the volume of the agarose involved).
 ~Action~ 1X TE buffer to the tubes of agarose (as small a volume as possible, usually about 5X the volume of the gel pieces).
 ~Action~ the tubes to 37°C.
 ~Action~ an equal volume of buffer-saturated phenol.
The phenol should have been  ~Action~ to 37°C.
 ~Action~ the tubes at room temperature to separate the phases.
 ~Action~ at 10,000 rpm, 10 min in the Sorvall or 5 min in the microfuge.
 ~Action~ the upper aqueous layers to clean tubes.
 ~Action~ an equal volume of phenol:CHCl3:Isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1) to the tubes.
 ~Action~ well and  ~Action~ at 10,000 rpm, 10 min in the Sorvall or 5 min in the microfuge.
 ~Action~ the aqueous layer 2X with CHCl3:Isoamyl alcohol (24:1) in the centrifuge as before.
 ~Action~ 3 M Na acetate to a final concentration of 0.3 M and precipitate the DNAs with 2X volumes of 100% EtOH at -20°C overnight.
 ~Action~ the tubes to pellet the DNAs.
 ~Action~ in the Sorvall at 10,000 rpm, 10 min, 4°C or 10-15 min at 4°C in the microfuge. 
 ~Action~ the DNAs 1X with 70% EtOH in the centrifuge as before and  ~Action~ the DNA pellets in the vacuum desiccator briefly (10-15 min) to remove the EtOH.
 ~Action~ the DNAs with a small volume of 1X TE buffer.
 ~Action~ the tubes at 65°C for 10-15 min.
 ~Action~  ~Modifier~  ~Reagent~ should be poured and allowed to set up in the  ~Temperature~  but electrophoresed at  ~Temperature~ 
FLV tracer assays Prepare FLVs for tracer assays.
 ~Action~ seawater samples from the desired location.
After determining the concentration of the FLVs in the concentrate, and the ambient concentration of viruses in the seawater, the proper amount of FLV concentrate should be added at tracer levels (<10% of original ambient virus concentration) into sample volumes of no less than 400 mL.
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ samples from the  ~Location~ 
After determining the concentration of the FLVs in the concentrate, and the ambient concentration of viruses in the seawater, the proper amount of FLV concentrate should be added at tracer levels (<10% of original ambient virus concentration) into sample volumes of no less than 400 mL.
Designate a  ~Method~ 
At each time point, total viral abundance and FLV numbers should be determined in duplicate from small volume subsamples (5–30 mL) taken into sterile, 15- or 50-mL polyethylene tubes.
Subsamples are immediately fixed with 1% to 2% (final concentration) 0.02-µm filtered formalin and stored at 4°C.

MojoSort™ Nanobeads Regular Protocol
 ~Action~ cells from your tissue of interest without lysing erythrocytes.
In the final wash of your sample preparation,  ~Action~ the cells in MojoSort™ Buffer by adding up to 4 mL in a 5 mL (12 x 75 mm) polystyrene tube.
Note:  ~Action~ MojoSort™ Buffer on ice throughout the procedure.
 ~Action~ the cells with a 70 μm cell strainer,  ~Action~ at 300 x g for 5 minutes, and  ~Action~ in an appropriate volume of MojoSort™ Buffer.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the cell concentration to 1 x 108 cells/mL.
 ~Action~ 100 μL of cell suspension (107 cells) into a new tube. 
 ~Action~ the beads by vortexing, maximum speed, 5 touches.
 ~Action~ 10 μL of Nanobeads,  ~Action~ well and  ~Action~ on ice for 15 minutes.
 ~Action~ the volume accordingly if separating more cells.
For example,  ~Action~ 100 μL for 1 x 108 cells.
When working with less than 107 cells, use indicated volumes for 107 cells.
 ~Action~ MojoSort™ Buffer up to 4 mL and  ~Action~ the cells at 300 x g for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ the cells in 3 mL of MojoSort™ Buffer.
Optional:  ~Action~ an aliquot before placing the tube in the magnet to monitor purity and yield. 
 ~Action~ the tube in the magnet for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ the liquid.
 ~Action~ the labeled cells in appropriate amount of buffer.
 ~Action~ steps 7 – 9 on the labeled fraction 2 more times, for a total of 3 magnetic separations.
Optional:  ~Action~ a small aliquot to monitor purity and yield.
If desired,  ~Action~ the unlabeled fractions and  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ from  ~Reagent~  ~Method~

Marine Purity Broth
Autoclave BD Difco AC Broth and NaCl Qs to 1 L with distilled water for 20 min.
After broth has cooled, add 16 ml 2 M MgSO4 and 10 ml 1 M CaCl2.  
Dispense 2.0 or 4.5 ml per sterile tube. 
Inoculate sterile MPB with 1:5 (vol:vol) dilution of culture.

It is dark brown in color with pH 13).
To get rid of sodium, the humus is  ~Action~ in dialysis tubes or parchment paper against running tap water for 24 h.  
It is free of sodium.

Isolation of cyanophages by plaque assays
 ~Action~ base plates Prepare top agar/agarose.
 ~Action~ target indicator cells.
 ~Action~ the sample: Environmental samples should be prefiltered as described earlier.
 ~Action~ 50 to 100 µL sample (as is, and 10-fold serial dilutions, up to ca.
3 levels) to 0.5 mL target cells under the usual culturing conditions (e.g., for Synechococcus sp.
strain DC2, constant 5–25 µmol quanta m–2s–1, at 25°C), agitate occasionally to encourage adsorption of phage to host.
After 1 h,  ~Action~ virus: host mixture to 2.5 mL soft agar.
Quickly and gently  ~Action~ the mixture and  ~Action~ the entire tube contents onto the surface of the agar plate.
Working rapidly, gently  ~Action~ the plate to  ~Action~ the mixture evenly onto the plate surface before the agar starts to gel.
Set aside on a flat surface to harden (about 1 h).
Prepare a control plate containing only cells; this plate will allow you to monitor cell growth.
Seal plate with parafilm, flip plates upside down.
Incubation of plates under constant low light conditions (5 to 25 µmol quanta m–2s–1) will produce darker lawns thus allowing for easier detection of plaques.
Note the number of plaque forming units (PFUs), plaque size, and morphology.
Choose a well-isolated plaque on a plate that contains less than 100 PFUs.
Harvest the plaque using a Pasteur pipette: gently press the tip of the pipette into the plaque to the bottom agar; using gentle suction, remove the plug.
Transfer the plug to 1 mL media and vortex briefly to break it up.
Place the tube at 4°C and allow the phages particle to  ~Action~  ~Action~ plate with parafilm,  ~Action~ plates upside down.
Incubation of plates under constant low light conditions (5 to 25 µmol quanta m–2s–1) will produce darker lawns thus allowing for easier detection of plaques.
Note the number of plaque forming units (PFUs), plaque size, and morphology.
 ~Action~ a well-isolated plaque on a plate that contains less than 100 PFUs.
 ~Action~ the plaque using a Pasteur pipette: gently  ~Action~ the tip of the pipette into the plaque to the bottom agar; using gentle suction,  ~Action~ the plug.
 ~Action~ the plug to 1 mL media and  ~Action~ briefly to break it up.

 ~Action~ the tube periodically each hour.
This step will digest hard to handle tissues and significantly improve the yield.

Roseobacter Screening Of Surface Waters For Viruses
 ~Action~ Roseobacter cultures from freeze and  ~Action~ in 5 ml broth cultures. 
 ~Action~ virus screening in sterile 96 well flat-bottom tissue culture treated microtiter plates. 
 ~Action~ seawater filtrates at 4°C. 
 ~Action~ the viruses to the bacteria. 
 ~Action~ 15 µl of log phase cells and 15 µl of seawater filtrate (containing virus) into wells of a 96 well plate. 
 ~Action~ the viruses  ~Action~ to the bacteria for 1 hour. 
 ~Action~ 200 µl growth media (1/2 or 1/10 YTSS) to the wells. 
 ~Action~ the plate with parafilm and  ~Action~ with shaking. 
Look for infected wells that show lysis with respect to uninoculated controls Enrich for viruses by transferring from initial 96 well plate to another 96-well plate containing fresh liquid media (“frogging” into new wells).  
Once enriched sufficiently,  ~Action~ cells with 0.2um filtration into 1.5ml microfuge tubes  ~Action~ for 5 mins. at max to pellet cells. 
 ~Action~ supernatant to fresh tube for storage.  
 ~Action~ at 4°C.  
Plaque-purify wells containing virus by growing cells plus virus on solid media.   
 ~Action~ solid agar media and 0.5% overlay agar. 
 ~Action~ virus to cells using as a starting point, 25 µl virus from 96 well plate enrichments and 200 µl log-phase host bacteria for 1hr. 
 ~Action~ the virus-absorbed cells in the 5 ml overlay agar. 
 ~Action~ the solid media. 
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ plaque formation. 
 ~Action~ representatives of all plaque types present and  ~Action~ appearance of the plaques. 
 ~Action~ the broth that contains the agar plugs at 4°C and allow the viruses to diffuse out of the agar into the broth. 
Once the viruses are plaque-purified they can be scaled-up in 5 ml broth cultures for DNA purification  ~Action~ 25 µl of the plaque-purified virus (agar plug in ~100 µl broth) and  ~Action~ to 200 µl log-phase bacteria for 1 hr.

One-step growth curves for Cellulophaga phages
 ~Action~ a new culture; ie,  ~Action~ a colony into a new flask containing 10 ml of MLB media. 
Immediately after the transfer, take a ‘time 0’ growth reading (T0).
Continue taking readings as performed in step 2 periodically.
Do a plaque assay to determine the PFU/ml of the lysate you plan to use.
 ~Action~ the volume needed for 107 phages.
 ~Action~ the concentration of your culture at the time you start the infection.
 ~Action~ the volume of host culture needed for 108 cells.
 ~Action~ this amount into a 1.5 ml tube.
 ~Action~ 107 phages to the tube and start your timer for 15 minutes to allow the phages to adsorb to the host cells.
After 15 minutes,  ~Action~ the infection 1:1000 in MLB media in a 250 ml flask.
Take a sample immediately after dilution. 
Continue sampling in this way for 8 hours.  
 ~Action~ the filtered samples at 4°C.
The next day,  ~Action~ the plaques on all plates that have a countable number of them. 
Decide which dilution gives the best count at each time point for the next time you do this same phage-host pair.
The next day,  ~Action~ any new plaques that have appeared and add these to your original count.
Count again on the third day.
 ~Action~ PFU/ml at each time point for both the centrifuged (free phage only) and not centrifuged (total phage) samples.

To adapt this protocol for your preferred system, volumesshould be adjusted accordingly.

This creates a working probe solution of 125 nM.
This solution will be used on steps  12 and 13.

 ~Action~ for 10 minutes at 37⁰C. 
 ~Action~ 30nM substrate DNA  ~Action~ thoroughly.
 ~Action~ at 37°C for 1 hour.
 ~Action~  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~ by diluting the  ~Reagent~ with  ~Modifier~  ~Reagent~ on  ~Location~ 
Construction of shotgun libraries from RNA virus assemblages
Cesium chloride gradient is conducted to purify viruses from viral concentrate of seawater as described in others chapters of this book (Wommack et al. 2010, this volume; Steward and Culley 2010, this volume).
Each density fraction is then extracted with the QIAamp Viral RNA Mini kit (Qiagen) as directed by the manufacturer with the following exception (see annotation).
 ~Action~ contaminating DNA from RNA preparations with the Turbo DNAfree kit (Applied Biosystems) as described in the protocol provided with the kit.
In preparation for cDNA synthesis, 10 µL purified RNA viral template is  ~Action~ with a final dNTP concentration of 0.2 mM and 1 µM and 5 nM final concentrations of FR26RV-N and FR40RV-T primer, respectively.
The reaction is  ~Action~ to 65°C then  ~Action~ on ice to allow the primers to anneal.
While still on ice, DTT (0.5 mM final conc.) is  ~Action~ to the reaction as an enzyme stabilization reagent with 40 U RNase OUT (Invitrogen) to protect the sample form RNAse activity.
The complementary DNA strand is  ~Action~ with 200 U of Superscript III (Invitrogen) reverse transcriptase.
The reaction is  ~Action~  ~Action~ with the QIAamp Viral RNA Mini kit (Qiagen) as directed by the manufacturer with the following exception (see annotation).
Remove contaminating DNA from RNA preparations with the Turbo DNAfree kit (Applied Biosystems) as described in the protocol provided with the kit.
In preparation for cDNA synthesis, 10 µL purified RNA viral template is mixed with a final dNTP concentration of 0.2 mM and 1 µM and 5 nM final concentrations of FR26RV-N and FR40RV-T primer, respectively.
The reaction is heated to 65°C then cooled on ice to allow the primers to anneal.
While still on ice, DTT (0.5 mM final conc.) is added to the reaction as an enzyme stabilization reagent with 40 U RNase OUT (Invitrogen) to protect the sample form RNAse activity.
The complementary DNA strand is synthesized with 200 U of Superscript III (Invitrogen) reverse transcriptase.
The reaction is incubated initially at 25°C for 10 min so that the hexamer 3′ end of primer FR26RV-N and the poly(T)20 3′ end of primer FR40RV-T remain annealed to the template while cDNA synthesis commences.
The temperature is then  ~Action~ to 50°C, the temperature at which Superscript III’s processivity is highest, for 60 min.
After the hour-long incubation at 50°C, the first strand synthesis reaction is  ~Action~ immediately to 94°C for 3 min and then rapidly  ~Action~ on ice.
A complementary second strand is subsequently  ~Action~ at 37°C for 60 min with the addition of 2.5 U of Klenow Fragment, 3′-5′ exo – (New England Biolabs).
The Klenow reaction is  ~Action~ with a final incubation at 75°C for 10 min.
One PCR reaction contains 5 µL of template taken directly from the second strand synthesis reaction, 40 pM of FR20RV primer (see Table 1), a final dNTP concentration of 0.2 mM, 1 × Gold buffer, 2.5 mM MgCl2, and 2.5 U of Ampligold DNA polymerase (Applied Biosystems) in a final volume of 50 µL.
The reaction is  ~Action~ at 94°C for 10 min to fully  ~Action~ the template and  ~Action~ the hot start enzyme.
Followed by 35 cycles of  ~Action~ at 94°C for 1 min.
 ~Action~ at 65°C for 1 min.
 ~Action~ at 72°C for 2 min.
A final extension for 13 min that permits the completion of complementary strand synthesis.
Before gel separation, we  ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the PCR reactions with a MinElute PCR cleanup column (Qiagen) as described by the manufacturer.
Purified PCR products are  ~Action~ onto a 1% agarose gel containing 1 × SYBR safe stain (Invitrogen) and 0.5 × TBE buffer.

 ~Action~ the titer plate to remove the supernatant and  ~Action~ to remove all excess supernatant.

Using 1ml pipette, rapidly  ~Action~ 1ml Reagent II directly into each tube containing Reagent I plus DI Water and immediately mix it by inverting the tubes.

Bead Beating RNA extraction from 25 mm filter
 ~Action~ 4°C centrifuge. 
 ~Action~ internal standards on ice. 
 ~Action~ 2.0 ml tube adaptor on Mo Bio Vortex Genie 2.
For each sample,  ~Action~ a 2.0 ml tube with the following 3-bead mixture: 200 μl 0.1 mm zirconium beads, 100 μl 0.4-0.6 mm glass beads, 100 μl 0.5 mm zirconium beads. 
 ~Action~ Ambion Denaturation Solution to each tube. 
To each bead tube,  ~Action~ internal standards to reach ~0.5% of expected RNA yield. 
 ~Action~ one 25 mm sample filter into each bead tube using RNase-free forceps. 
 ~Action~ sample tubes on vortex adaptor and  ~Action~ for 5 min. 
Switch tube positions and  ~Action~  ~Action~ tube positions and beat another 5 min.
 ~Action~ sample tubes for 1 min at 5000 rpm at 4°C. 
 ~Action~ as much of the RNA lysate as possible to a new 1.5 ml centrifuge tube (Can carryover some beads). 
 ~Action~ RNA tubes for 5 min at 5000 rpm at 4°C. 
 ~Action~ lysate to new 2.0 ml tube (Do not carry over any beads).
 ~Action~ 1 volume of 100% ethanol to the lysate. 
 ~Action~ the RNA lysate up into a 3.0 ml syringe with a 21g1 gauge needle and  ~Action~ it back out 8 times to shear RNA. 
 ~Action~ 700 μL of RNA lysate to RNeasy mini column. 
 ~Action~ tube gently and  ~Action~ 15 sec at 13000 rpm. 
 ~Action~ flow-through.
Repeat steps 16-18 until entire sample has been applied to column.
 ~Action~ 700 μl Buffer RW1 to RNeasy Mini spin column.
 ~Action~ for 15 sec at 13000 rpm.
 ~Action~ the flow-through.
 ~Action~ 500 μl Buffer RPE to RNeasy spin column.
 ~Action~ for 15 sec at 13000 rpm.
 ~Action~ flow-through.
 ~Action~ 500 μl Buffer RPE to RNeasy spin column.
 ~Action~ for 2 min at 13000 rpm. 
 ~Action~ column in new 2.0 ml collection tube.
 ~Action~ for 1 min at 13000 rpm. 
 ~Action~ column in a new 1.5 ml sterile tube. 
 ~Action~ 35 μl RNase-free water directly onto filter and close the lid.
Incubate tube for 1 min at room temperature. 
 ~Action~  ~Action~ tube for 1 min at room temperature. 
Centrifuge for 1 min at 13000 rpm.
 ~Action~ another 35 μl RNase-free water into same column/tube. 
 ~Action~ for 1 min at room temperature. 
 ~Action~ for 1 min at 13000 rpm. 
 ~Action~ column and  ~Action~ tube with RNA on ice. 
 ~Action~ extracted RNA with Nanodrop (2 μl). 
 ~Action~ the following in a 1.5 ml tube:
componentamountextracted sample50 μlRNase-free water40 μlDNase reaction buffer10 μlTurbo DNase3 μl. 
 ~Action~ for 20 min at 37 °C. 
 ~Action~ 3 μl more Turbo DNase to sample. 
 ~Action~ an additional 20 min at 37 °C. 
 ~Action~ 20 μl inactivation solution to sample (make sure solution is well mixed).
 ~Action~ on and off for ~4 min. 
 ~Action~ for 1 min at 13000 rpm. 
Carefully, without disturbing inactivation reagent,  ~Action~ supernatant (~100 μl) into a new 1.5 ml tube and  ~Action~ on ice. 
 ~Action~ DNased RNA with Nanodrop (2 μl) 
Optional:  ~Action~ and  ~Action~ DNased RNA using Zymo RNA Clean & Concentrator-5 according to manufacturer protocol. 
Chlorovirus DNA Miniprep Procedure
 ~Action~ appropriate host with desired Chlorovirus species at moi of ~0.001-0.01.
 ~Action~ the samples at 25°C for 24-72 hours, with continuous light and shaking.
 ~Action~ 30 mL of the lysates in the Sorvall SS34 rotor at 5,000 rpm (3,000 rcf), 5 min, 4°C.
 ~Action~ 10% NP-40 (or Triton X-100) to the lysate supernatants for a final concentration of 1%.
 ~Action~ the material in a Beckman Ti 50.2 rotor at 15,000 rpm (~27,000 rcfmax), 75 min, 4°C.
 ~Action~ the virus pellets with 1.0 mL of 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 10 mM MgCl2.
 ~Action~ 500 µL of the resuspended virus to 1.5 ml screw-cap microfuge tubes.
 ~Action~ 9 µL of DNAse I and  ~Action~ 
 ~Action~ 6.0 µL of 500 mM EDTA, pH 8.0 to the samples and  ~Action~ 
 ~Action~ 300 µL of buffer-saturated phenol and 300 µL of CHCl3:Isoamyl alcohol (24:1) to the tubes.
 ~Action~ in the microfuge at maximum speed for 5 min at 4°C.
 ~Action~ the upper aqueous layers to clean tubes.
 ~Action~ 600 µL of CHCl3:Isoamyl alcohol (24:1) to the tubes.
 ~Action~ the upper aqueous layers to clean tubes and repeat the CHCl3:Isoamyl alcohol extraction 1X.
 ~Action~ 66 µL of 3 M NaOAc to each tube.
 ~Action~ the DNAs with 2X volumes (approximately 1350 µL) of 100% EtOH.
 ~Action~ the tubes in the microfuge for 10-15 min at 4°C to pellet the DNAs.
 ~Action~ the DNA pellets 1X with 1000 µL of 70% EtOH in the microfuge for 5 min at 4°C.
 ~Action~ the DNAs with approximately 60 µL of 1X TE buffer.
 ~Action~ the DNAs at 4°C.
 ~Action~ 57 µL of proteinase K and 29 µL of 10% Na sarcosyl and  ~Action~ 
 ~Action~ the pellets briefly (10-15 min) in the vacuum desiccator to  ~Action~ the EtOH.
 ~Action~ the supernatants.
 ~Action~ the supernatants.
 ~Action~ at room temperature for 60 min.
 ~Action~ the samples at 60-65°C for 60 min.
 ~Action~ by inversion.
 ~Action~ for 5 min at 4°C in the microfuge.
 ~Action~ by inversion.
 ~Action~ the last extraction into 2.0 mL microfuge tubes.
 ~Action~ well and  ~Action~ at -20°C overnight.
 ~Action~ the supernatants.
If the DNA doesn’t go into solution overnight,  ~Action~ in the microfuge for 15 min at 4°C.
 ~Action~ the supernatants to clean tubes.
 ~Action~  ~Modifier~  ~Reagent~ with  ~Modifier~  ~Reagent~ at  ~Generic-Measure~ 
Fixation of Planktonic Samples
Add freshly prepared PFA fixative (see 'Fixing Cells with PFA Protocol') to water sample to a final concentration of 1-2%.
Alternatively, use Formaldehyde, and fix for 12-24 hours at 4°C.
Place a moistened support filter (0.45 μm pore size, cellulose nitrate, 47 mm diameter) and a membrane filter (0.2 μm pore size, white polycarbonate (GTTP), 47 mm diameter) into a filtration tower. 
Filter an appropriate volume of the fixed sample by applying gentle vacuum (~ 5 inch). 
Place a moistened support filter (0.45 μm pore size, cellulose nitrate, 25 mm diameter; Sartorius, Germany) and a membrane filter (0.2 μm pore size, white polycarbonate (GTTP), 25 mm diameter; Millipore, Eschborn, Germany) into a filtration tower. 
Filter 1 ml of the fixed sample by applying gentle vacuum (~5 inch). 
Filter 2 ml of the fixed sample on a second filter.
After complete sample filtration, wash with 10-20 ml of sterile H2O. 
Remove H2O by filtration. 
Put membrane filter on blotting paper for drying and cover, e.g.
with the lid of a cryo box or a Petri dish.
Allow air-drying. 
Store each filter in a separate labelled Petri dish. 
Place membrane filter between separator sheets that the GTTP membrane filters were provided with. 
Seal Petri dish with parafilm. 
Store at  ~Temperature~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~ 2 ml of the fixed sample on a second filter.

Depending on your application, the recommended option for RNA quantification is:Bioanalyzer (Agilent) using the RNA 6000 Pico total RNA kit: quantitative range = 0.05-5.0 ng / µl (dilute samples 1:10 and 1:100 prior to analysis), allows visualization of RNA size distribution, less accurate, ~1 hr processing time.
Order primers (found in guidelines).

Check the worms each day – the worms may start to shed eggs after day 5 so can be collected after day 6 – if not collect eggs on day 7 – if the worms are left longer they may dissolve and the eggs will be difficult to collect cleanly
 ~Action~ the dialysis membrane from the culture tube and cut it open above any visible eggs, flush out onto a petri dish using ddH20.
 ~Action~ the petri dish to about ¼ full of ddH20
Under the stereo microscope with cold light source tilt the plate and the eggs should line up on the surface.
 ~Action~ the egg layer with a glass pipette and transfer to fresh petri dishes – up to 4 depending on the number of eggs.
 ~Action~ all the plates up to about half full with ddH20 including the original petri dish.
 ~Action~ each plate with an identification number/name

Do not mix or shake.
 ~Action~ vial(s) from the 42°C bath and  ~Action~ them on ice.
 ~Action~ 250 μL of pre-warmed S.O.C medium to each vial.
S.O.C is a rich medium; sterile technique must be practiced to avoid contamination.

ELISPOT Protocol
 ~Action~ Low-Endotoxin/Azide-Free sterile unlabeled capture antibody (BioLegend’sLEAF™ format antibodies are specifically designed for this assay) to a final concentration of 0.5–4 μg/ml in sterile Coating Buffer and  ~Action~ 100μl/well to a high affinity binding PVDF membrane ELISPOT plate (e.g., Millipore; Cat. No. MAIPS-4510).
 ~Action~ plates overnight in humidified box at 4°C or at 37°C for ≥ 4 hours inhumidified atmosphere.
 ~Action~ plate 3 times with sterile PBS, 200 μl/well.
 ~Action~ 200 μl/well of sterile Blocking Buffer.
 ~Action~ plate and  ~Action~ at room temperature for ≥ 1 hour.
 ~Action~ plate 3 times with sterile PBS, 200 μl/well.
 ~Action~ appropriate sterile antigen or mitogen solution  ~Action~ in appropriate sterile tissue culture medium (TC) to ELISPOT plate, 100 μl/well.
 ~Action~ cells diluted in sterile TC medium, 100 μl/well.
 ~Action~ 50,000-500,000 cells/well (the minimum number of cells should be determined in preliminary experiments).
 ~Action~ plate and  ~Action~ at 37°C 5% CO2 in humidified atmosphere for theoptimum stimulation period.
BioLegend recommends a 24 hour incubation for IFN-γ, IL-2, and TNF-α, and a 48 hour incubation period for IL-4, IL-5, and IL-10 for most activation conditions.
 ~Action~ plate 3 times with PBS, 200 μl/well.
 ~Action~ plate 3 times with PBS-Tween, 200 μl/well.
 ~Action~ 100 μl/well of diluted biotinylated detection antibody at 0.25-2 μg/ml in PBS-Tween-BSA.
 ~Action~ the plate and  ~Action~ at 4°C overnight, or 2 hr at room temperature.
 ~Action~ plate 4 times with PBS-Tween, 200 μl/well.
 ~Action~ 100 μl per well of the Av-HRP conjugate (Cat. No. 405103) or otherenzyme conjugate diluted to its pre-determined optimal concentration in PBS-Tween-BSA (usually between 1/500 – 1/2000).
 ~Action~ the plate and  ~Action~ at room temperature for 1 – 2 hours.
 ~Action~ plate 3 times with PBS-Tween, 200 μl/well.
 ~Action~ plate 3 times with PBS, 200 μl/well.
 ~Action~ 200 μl/well of fresh Substrate solution.
 ~Action~ spot/color development at room temperature and  ~Action~ reaction by  ~Action~ plate with tap water and vigorously  ~Action~ plate over a waste container or sink, followed by  ~Action~ on paper towels or other absorbent materials.
 ~Action~ plate overnight, until it is completely dry.
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ (BioLegend’sLEAF™ format antibodies are specifically designed for this assay) to a final concentration of  ~Concentration~  ~Measure-Type~ of 0.5–4 μg/ml in  ~Reagent~ and transfer  ~Amount~ to a  ~Location~ (e.g., Millipore; Cat. No. MAIPS-4510).
Cesium Chloride Gradients
 ~Action~ cesium chloride densities of p1.2, p1.4, p1.5 and p1.65 in seawater (sw) that has been 0.02μm (or 0.2μm) filtered and autoclaved.
 ~Action~ tube of prepared cesium on balance.  
Tare balance to 0. 
 ~Action~ 1ml with sterile pipet tip.
 ~Action~ CsCl from the bottom using a gradient fractionator if you have one or by hand. 
Carefully  ~Action~ on sample (~5ml can be layered with SW40 ~15ml with SW28).
 ~Action~ and balance tubes.
 ~Action~ using SW40 or SW28 Beckman rotor @ 24,000rpm for 4hr at 4°C. 
Have sterile 0.5ml tubes (SW40) or 1.5ml tubes (SW28) labeled 1-24  ~Action~  ~Action~ 1-24 Open tubes in a rack.
 ~Action~ tube on ring stand. 
 ~Action~ about 2mm from the bottom side of the tube using a sterile 20 guage needle, bevel up.
 ~Action~ droplets to fill each tube in order.
 ~Action~ tube with sample on 4-place balance in holder.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ balance to 0. 
Remove 1ml with sterile pipet tip.
Layer CsCl from the bottom using a gradient fractionator if you have one or by hand. 
Carefully layer on sample (~5ml can be layered with SW40 ~15ml with SW28).
Weigh and balance tubes.
Centrifuge using SW40 or SW28 Beckman rotor @ 24,000rpm for 4hr at 4°C. 
Have sterile 0.5ml tubes (SW40) or 1.5ml tubes (SW28) labeled 1-24 Open tubes in a rack.
Place tube on ring stand. 
Puncture about 2mm from the bottom side of the tube using a sterile 20 guage needle, bevel up.
Collect droplets to fill each tube in order.
Place tube with sample on 4-place balance in holder.
Wet-mount Method for Enumeration of Aquatic Viruses
 ~Action~ 1 mL of sample into a 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ 1 μL Iron Chloride Solution and  ~Action~ to mix.
 ~Action~ the sample at ~14K RCF for 20 minutes.
 ~Action~ supernatant using a pipette, leaving a small, undisturbed pellet of Fe oxyhydroxides behind (Figure 2).
 ~Action~ the pellet in 10 μL of Ascorbic-EDTA Buffer, creating a 100-fold concentration of the original sample.
 ~Action~ and then pipette up and down to ensure complete dissolution.
 ~Action~ and then pipette up and down to ensure complete dissolution.
 ~Action~ 10 μL sample (concentrated or unconcentrated) and 2 μL SYBR Gold Working Stock,  ~Action~ to mix, and  ~Action~ in dark for 15 minutes.
If sample is unconcentrated,  ~Action~ 1 μL of Ascorbic Acid Antifade Solution.
 ~Action~ 5 μL of glycerol to stained sample and vortex to mix.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ to mix.
Add 2 µL Working Bead Solution to sample.
 ~Action~ glass slides and cover slips with isopropanol and Kimwipes.
Thoroughly  ~Action~ the sample/bead mixture by pipetting up and down, then immediately  ~Action~ 10 μL of it onto a glass microscope slide.
 ~Action~ a coverslip over the mixture and avoid trapping air under the coverslip.
 ~Action~ a coverslip over the mixture and avoid trapping air under the coverslip.
 ~Action~ viruses under ~495 nm excitation at 1000X magnification using an epifluorescence microscope.
 ~Action~ the number of viruses in one defined field of view.
Once complete,  ~Action~ the excitation and  ~Action~ the white light of the microscope to  ~Action~ the beads in the same field of view (Figure 3).

Fingerprinting aquatic virus communities using denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE)
Using lint-free tissues,  ~Action~ glass plates, spacers, and combs thoroughly with 70% ethanol.
 ~Action~ the gel sandwich by placing the small glass plate on top of the large plate, being sure to correctly  ~Action~  ~Action~ the small glass plate on top of the large plate, being sure to correctly place a 1-mm spacer along each edge of the plate assembly.
To prevent current leakage and the resultant “smiles” in the bands near the edges of the gel,  ~Action~ both sides of the spacers with as little as possible silicon grease to cover the full length of the spacer but only a quarter of the spacer width.
 ~Action~ the plate clamps and  ~Action~ the entire assembly into the casting stand.
 ~Action~ the plate assembly to ensure that the two glass plates and the spacers form a flush surface along the sides, and ensure that all gaskets adequately seal the plate assembly.
 ~Action~ the gradient maker and  ~Action~ with sdH2O.
Empty pump tubing and  ~Action~ pipette tip at the outlet tube to the top-middle of the gel chamber.
To optimize the gradient conditions for a new DGGE experiment (new primer sets, new sample type/habitat, etc.), we usually start with a relatively broad gradient (20% to 80% denaturant).
We then  ~Action~ the gradient around the area of interest to include the highest and lowest bands in different samples.
Table 1 (guidelines) can be used to  ~Action~ the appropriate composition of the denaturing gradient gel (16 × 16 cm) that has a total volume of 29 mL.
 ~Action~ two solutions of 14.5 mL each, a low denaturant concentration solution and a high denaturant concentration solution.
 ~Action~ the solutions A and B (guidelines) to the desired percentage.
After  ~Action~ the denaturing gel solutions,  ~Action~ for 15 min and  ~Action~ through a 0.45-mm syringe filter.
Immediately before casting the gel,  ~Action~ 145 µL 10% APS and 7.25 µL TEMED into each solution and  ~Action~ gently to  ~Action~ 
At this point, you will have approximately 10 min to  ~Action~ the gel.
Make sure the pump is off and the gradient maker-channel is closed (handle up).
 ~Action~ solution with the highest denaturant in the right leg of the gradient maker (at the pump side) and the solution with the lowest denaturant in the left leg.
Turn the magnetic stirrer on, while simultaneously  ~Action~ the pump (5 mL/min).
Simultaneously,  ~Action~ the pump (5 mL/min) and  ~Action~ the handle of the gradient maker to horizontal position (channel open).
Use approximately 4–5 min to  ~Action~ the gel.
 ~Action~ the tubing and  ~Action~ thoroughly with sdH2O.
 ~Action~ the comb, flat or straight side down, making sure that there are no bubbles under the comb.
Different combs (16 or 20 wells) are available, depending on the number of samples that you want to run.
 ~Action~ gels with cling film and allow ~2 h for the gel to  ~Action~ 
The gel can be kept at 4°C until the next day.
 ~Action~ approximately 7 L of 1× TAE and  ~Action~ the buffer chamber.
 ~Action~ about 0.5 L aside for later use.
To enhance the circulation of the running buffer,  ~Action~ the tank on a magnet stirrer and  ~Action~ a magnetic stirrer bar in the bottom of the tank.
 ~Action~ the buffer in the DCode apparatus to 60°C; this will take about 2 h.  ~Action~ the gel plates to the core assembly.
 ~Action~ the clamps a quarter-turn counterclockwise to prevent breaking of the sandwich clamps (due to heat expansion).
Then  ~Action~ the core assembly into the heated buffer in the tank.
 ~Action~ the magnetic stirrer (if loading in tank).
 ~Action~ each well with buffer using syringe with needle to  ~Action~ any unpolymerized acrylamide and excess urea.
 ~Action~ each well with buffer again before  ~Action~ approximately 10–50 µL of PCR products mixed with loading dye into each well.
To  ~Action~ PCR products, we recommend gel quantification using a DNA mass standard (e.g., Low DNA Mass ladder; Invitrogen) and commercially available gel quantification software such as Quantity One (Bio-Rad) or free software such as Image J (available for download at http://rsbweb.nih.gov/ij/download.html).
In the DGGE gel,  ~Action~ a marker on each side of the gel adjacent to the samples (markers can be custom made for each DGGE application using known PCR products, or common molecular weight markers can be used)  for  ~Action~ of band positions, or  ~Action~ of different gels.
 ~Action~ of 200 V for 5 min before  ~Action~ the pump to  ~Action~ the buffer, then  ~Action~ the magnetic stirrer.
The length of the run and the running voltage depend on the size of the PCR products and the percentage of acrylamide/bis in the gel.
A good starting point is to  ~Action~ the gel at 60 V (about 20 mA for one gel) for 19 h. 
When the electrophoresis is complete,  ~Action~ the apparatus and  ~Action~ the glass plates from the gel clamps.
Carefully  ~Action~ the plates, leaving the gel exposed on the large plate.
Use the edge of the small plate to  ~Action~ the well walls, but be sure to leave the leftmost wall slightly higher than the others for use as a gel orientation reference.
For easy manipulation, the gel can either be  ~Action~ on the large plate or  ~Action~ to,  ~Action~ on, and  ~Action~ on a plastic sheet.
 ~Action~ the gel for 30 min in 50–500 mL fluorescent gel stain.
 ~Action~ the gel for 30 min in 1 × TAE.
Remember, the fluorescent dye binds to nucleic acids; therefore, it is important to minimize contact with skin, so gloves (powder-free) should be worn.
If staining in a container, use plastic and not glass, as the fluorescent dyes accumulate over time on glass surfaces.

PCR yield can be monitored by running an Agilent BioAnalyzer High Sensitivity DNA assay using a dilution of 1 μL of PCR product and 9 μL of nuclease-free water.
A typical result shows a distinct peak at approximately 140bp (Figure 2 in Guidelines).
 ~Action~ the volume of TBE buffer needed and  ~Action~ 5X TBE Buffer to 1X for use in gel electrophoresis.
 ~Action~ the gel electrophoresis apparatus.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ Mix C300 from -20°C storage.
Allow it to equilibrate to room temperature for a minimum of 30 minutes before use.
Pre-heat the thermal cycler to 70°C and pre-heat another thermal cycler to 25°C if available.
Denature the RNA Sample by assembling the following components in a sterile 200 μL PCR tube on ice: RNA Sample,6μL; Mix A300 2μL;
Vortex mix thoroughly and incubate at 70°C for 1 minute and then place the tube on ice.
Set up the following 3’ Adapter Ligation reaction on ice: Denatured RNA mix from step 4, 8μL; Mix B300, 2μL; Mix C300, 6.5μL;  
Vortex mix thoroughly and pulse spin.
Incubate at 25°C for 1 hour.
Vortex the TailorMag Purification Beads (TPB) until they are evenly suspended.
Prepare 80% ethanol for rinse step.
Add 30 μL of TPB with each 3’-adapter ligated sample from Step 6.
Vortex mix thoroughly and pulse spin.
Incubate at room temperature for 15 minutes the following: 3’-adapter ligated sample from Step 6, 16.5μL; TailorMag Purification Beads (TPB), 30μL;  
Place the sample tube on the magnetic stand at room temperature for 5 minutes.
Carefully remove and discard 40 μL of the supernatant.
Keep sample tube on the magnetic stand.
Gently rinse the TPB pellet with 150 μL of 80% ethanol without disrupting the TPB pellet.
Discard the rinse solution.
Air dry sample tube at room temperature.
Remove sample tube from the magnetic stand.
Add 7 μL of nuclease free water to the dried TPB pellet.
Vortex to resuspend and pulse spin.
Incubate sample resuspension at room temperature for 2 minutes.
Set up the following 5’ Adapter Ligation reaction on ice: 3’ Adapter Ligated RNA from step 18, 7μL; Mix D300, 3μL; Mix E300, 2μL;  
Gently pipette mix thoroughly and incubate at 25°C for 1 hour and then place the tube on ice.
Pre-heat the thermal cycler to 50°C.
Set up the following cDNA Synthesis reaction on ice: 3’ and 5’ Adapter Ligated RNA from Step 16(contains TPB), 12μL; Mix F300, 2μL; Mix G300 1μL;  
Vortex mix thoroughly and pulse spin.

BetaMark™ x-40 ELISA Kit (Colorimetric) Protocol
 ~Action~ (2) 1.5mL microcentrifuge tubes as intermediate #1 & 2.
(use enclosed tubes)  ~Action~ 990uL of standard diluent to intermediate tubes #1 & 2.
Reconstitute one 20ug vial of 1-40 standard with 80uL of Standard Diluent.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ one 20ug vial of 1-40 standard with 80uL of Standard Diluent.
Mix well by inversion, do not vortex.Concentration will be 250ug/mL.
 ~Action~ 30 minutes at room temperature Note: During 30 minute incubation; proceed thru appropriate sections below (e.g. sections 2, 3 and 4).
After 30 minutes incubation,  ~Action~ well by inversion, do not vortex.
Once reconstituted, standard must be used within the same day.
 ~Action~ 10uL from the vial of reconstituted 1-40 standard to 990uL of standard diluent in intermediate tube #1.
 ~Action~ well by inversion, do not vortex.
 ~Action~ 10uL from intermediate #1 tube and  ~Action~ to 990uL of standard diluent in intermediate #2 tube.
 ~Action~ well by inversion, do not vortex The final concentration of standard in intermediate tube #2 will be 25ng/mL.
 ~Action~ a 50mL centrifuge tube as “1X Incubation Buffer”.
 ~Action~ 2X Incubation buffer to 1X by  ~Action~ 10mL of 2X incubation buffer to 10mL of lab grade water* in the 50mL tube labeled “1X Incubation Buffer”.
*Note: Lab grade filtered water such as injection grade, cell culture grade, Reverse Osmosis De-Ionization (RODI).
 ~Action~ well by vortexing.
This will be diluent for the standard curve and samples.
 ~Action~ a 1L container “1X Wash buffer”.
 ~Action~ 5X wash buffer to 1X for use.
 ~Action~ 125mL of 5X Wash buffer with 500mL of lab grade water for a total volume of 625mL.
 ~Action~ (8) 1.5mL microcentrifuge tubes as #1-8 (use enclosed tubes).
 ~Action~ 240uL of the 1X incubation buffer (made previously in step II) to each of the standard curve tubes (#2-8) and 490uL to tube #1 (standard curve top point).
 ~Action~ 10uL from intermediate #2 and add to 490uL 1X incubation buffer in tube #1 (this will be the top point of the standard curve, final concentration will be 250pg/mL.
 ~Action~ well by inversion, do not vortex.
Continue making 1.8 fold serial dilutions by adding 300uL of the previous dilution to 240uL of 1X incubation buffer in tubes #2-7.
 ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~ 1.8 fold serial dilutions by adding 300uL of the previous dilution to 240uL of 1X incubation buffer in tubes #2-7.
Mix well by inversion between each dilution.
 ~Action~ samples in 1X incubation buffer to 2X concentration.
 ~Action~ well by inversion.
For example, if the final sample dilution should be 1:10,  ~Action~ the sample 1:5 in 1X incubation buffer.
The sample will then be diluted 1:2 in step VII for a final dilution factor of 1:10.
 ~Action~ samples in duplicate or triplicate.
Note: All sample matrices will perform differently in the kit.
It is important that you determine the ideal dilution for your particular sample type.
It is good practice to  ~Action~ 2-3 dilutions per sample to ensure at least 1 dilution falls within the range of the standard curve.
For most sample types, a good starting dilution would be 1:5-1:10.Due to the format of the assay, samples are not able to run neat.
 ~Action~ a 15mL tube as "Diluted HRP Detection Antibody".
 ~Action~ 6mL of 1X Incubation buffer to the tube labeled "Diluted HRP Detection Antibody".
 ~Action~ 6uL of HRP Detection Antibody and  ~Action~ well by vortexing  ~Action~ plate from foil pouch.
 ~Action~ extra strip wells if necessary and  ~Action~ in resealable foil pouch at 2-8°C until use.
 ~Action~ 300uL per well of 1X Wash Buffer (Prepared in step III above).
 ~Action~ wash buffer and  ~Action~ on paper towels.
 ~Action~ 50uL of each prepared standard to the plate in duplicate or triplicate.
Follow the plate layout outlined inTable 3 below.
Note: Wells E1-E3 contain the zero or blank sample (Std #8).
 ~Action~ 50uL of each sample to the plate in duplicate or triplicate.
 ~Action~ 50uL per well of diluted HRP detection antibody to all wells.
 ~Action~ plate with plate sealer.
 ~Action~ the plate gently on a plate shaker.
 ~Action~ overnight at 2-8°C.
NOTE: Once diluted with 50uL of diluted HRP detection antibody, the final standard cuve concentrations will be outlined in Table 4.
Please use these concentrations to  ~Action~ your standard curve.
 ~Action~ plate from refrigerator and  ~Action~ contents.
 ~Action~ plate by  ~Action~ 300uL of 1X Wash Buffer per well.
 ~Action~ 1X Wash Buffer and  ~Action~ 
 ~Action~ steps B-C 4 more times for a total of 5 washes.
 ~Action~ 200uL TMB subrate to each well.
Read Plate at 620nm.

Illumina Small RNA cloning protocol using Random Adapters
Section I: Size selection and Gel purification of RNA sample.
 ~Action~ a 12% polyacrylamide/urea gel
(thickness will depend on the amount of total RNA being run.
As a guide, we use 1.0mm for <20µg,1.5mm for >20µg).
 ~Action~ RNA samples with 32P-labeled 19, 24, 28 and/or 33bp oligos (~10,000 counts per oligo, per minute) – depending on the application.
 ~Action~ the sample(s) and  ~Action~ the gel at constant 10W for 1-1.5 hrs (until the first dye front reaches the middle of the gel).
 ~Action~ an equal amount of Gel Loading Buffer II (1X),  ~Action~ samples at 95C for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ on ice for 1 minute.
Carefully  ~Action~ gel slices by hand using a pestle.
 ~Action~ a phosphor-screen over the gel for 10-15 minutes (time will vary depending on radioactivity intensity and imager sensitivity)  ~Action~ 420µL of 0.4M NaCl.
 ~Action~ briefly in a centrifuge at maximum speed.
 ~Action~ samples for 1 minute in a bath of EtOH and dry ice.
 ~Action~ eluant to a fresh microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ 20µg GlycoBlue,  ~Action~  and  ~Action~ 2.5 volumes of 100% EtOH  ~Action~ at 4C for 30 minutes.
 ~Action~ at -20C for 3-6+ hours.
 ~Action~ for <5 min and  ~Action~ pellet in 13µL DEPC-MilliQ H20 Here, one can insert a gel slice into a dialyzer tube (Novagen, D-Tube Dialyzer Midi, MWCO 3.5 kDA – Cat. No. 71506-3) along with 450ul of water.
 ~Action~ the poles and  ~Action~ for 2 minutes to pull the sample off the dialysis tubing wall.
 ~Action~ the dialyzer into a gel box,  ~Action~ in 1xTAE, such that the dialysis tubing has the current running perpendicularly through it.
 ~Action~ all of the water into a fresh microcentrifuge tube,  ~Action~ in 20µg GlycoBlue and  ~Action~ 2.5 volumes of 100% EtOH  ~Action~ with 70% EtOH and then  ~Action~ ALL EtOH.
 ~Action~ at 4C for 30 minutes  ~Action~ with 70% EtOH and then  ~Action~ ALL EtOH  ~Action~ for <5 min and  ~Action~ pellet in 13µL DEPC-MilliQ H20.
 ~Action~ at 100V for 18mins.
 ~Action~ the ligation mix as described in the cited publication.
 ~Action~ at 37C for 4 hours.
 ~Action~ 20µl Gel Loading Buffer II.
Section II: 3’ linker ligation.
Section III: Gel purification of 3’ ligated RNA product.
 ~Action~ a 1.0mm, 12% polyacrylamide/urea gel.
 ~Action~ inactivate at 95C for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ samples at 95C for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ for 1 minute.
 ~Action~ the sample(s) and  ~Action~ the gel at constant 10W for 1.5-2 hrs (until the first dye front reaches the bottom of the gel).
 ~Action~ a phosphorimager screen over the gel for 30-45 minutes (time will vary) (Figure 2).
 ~Action~ the precise band corresponding to the desired size of small RNA (including the ligated radiolabeled oligo(s)) into a microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ briefly in a centrifuge at maximum speed.
Carefully  ~Action~ gel slices using a pestle.
 ~Action~ 5ng of 32P-labeled Decade Marker as a size marker.
 ~Action~ 420µL of 0.4M NaCl.
Quickly  ~Action~ samples for 1 minute in a bath of EtOH and dry ice.
 ~Action~ overnight at room temperature (RT) with agitation (secured on a vortex).
 ~Action~ gel slice homogenate through micropore filter at full speed for 1 minute at RT.
 ~Action~ eluant to a microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ 20µg GlycoBlue, mix, and  ~Action~ 2.5 volumes of 100% EtOH.
 ~Action~ at -20C for 3-6+ hours.
 ~Action~ at 4C for 30 minutes.
 ~Action~ with 70% EtOH and then  ~Action~ ALL EtOH.
 ~Action~ for <5 min and  ~Action~ pellet in 13µL DEPC-MilliQ H20.
Section IV: 5’ linker ligation.
 ~Action~ the linker ligation reaction mix as described in the publication.
 ~Action~ at 37C for 2 hours.
 ~Action~ 20µl Gel Loading Buffer II.
 ~Action~ inactivate at 95C for 5 minutes.
Section V: Gel purification of 5’ and 3’ ligated RNA product.
 ~Action~ a 1.0mm, 12% polyacrylamide/urea gel.
 ~Action~ 2.5ng of 32P-labeled Decade Marker as a size marker.
 ~Action~ samples at 95C for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ for 1 minute.
 ~Action~ a phosphorimager screen over the gel for 1+ hours (time will vary) (Figure 3).
 ~Action~ the sample(s) and  ~Action~ the gel at constant 10W for 2+ hrs (until first dye front passes the bottom of the gel).
 ~Action~ briefly in a centrifuge at maximum speed.
 ~Action~ the precise band corresponding to the desired size of small RNAs (including the ligated radiolabeled oligo(s)) into a microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ briefly in a centrifuge at maximum speed.
 ~Action~ 420µL of 0.4M NaCl.
Quickly  ~Action~ samples for 1 minute in a bath of EtOH and dry ice.
 ~Action~ gel slice homogenate through micropore filter at full speed for 1 minute at RT.
 ~Action~ eluant to a microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ 20µg GlycoBlue, mix, and  ~Action~ 2.5 volumes of 100% EtOH.
 ~Action~ at -20oC for 3-6+ hours.
 ~Action~ at 4C for 30 minutes.
Carefully  ~Action~ gel slices using a pestle.
 ~Action~ for <5 min and  ~Action~ pellet in 6.3µL DEPC-MilliQ H20.
Section VI: Reverse transcription.
 ~Action~ at 72C for 2 minutes.
 ~Action~ overnight at room temperature (RT) with agitation (secured on a vortex).
 ~Action~ at RT for 1 minute.
 ~Action~ on ice for 2 minutes.
 ~Action~ 8.4µL Reverse Transcriptase (RT) Mix (see publication for details).
 ~Action~ into two tubes (9µL each).
 ~Action~ either 1µL Superscript III RT (Invitrogen) (+RT) or 1µL DEPC-MilliQ H20 (-RT control).
 ~Action~ to 70C for 15 minutes.
 ~Action~ at -20C until use.
 ~Action~ at 50C for 1 hour.
