Anti-Neu5Gc Antibody Kit Protocol - ELISA
 ~Action~ the 96-well ELISA plate with the target molecule in 50 mM sodium carbonate-bicarbonate buffer, pH 9.5 (up to 1 μg/well in 100 μl carbonate buffer, in triplicate) for at least 2 hours at ambient temperature or overnight at 4°C.
 ~Action~ the wells 3 to 5 times with PBS.
 ~Action~ wells with PBS-T (200 μl/well) for 1 hour at room temperature.
 ~Action~ the anti-Neu5Gc antibody (or the negative control antibody),  ~Action~ in PBS-T, to the appropriate well(s) and  ~Action~ for 2 hours at room temperature.
 ~Action~ wells as before with PBS-T. 
 ~Action~ enzyme-conjugated secondary antibody (donkey-anti-chicken antibody, 1:10,000 in PBS) to each well and  ~Action~ for 1 hour at room temperature.
 ~Action~ wells again with PBS-T. 
 ~Action~ enzyme substrate, allow the wells to develop;  ~Action~ the reaction if necessary.
 ~Action~  ~Location~ with the target molecule in  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~   ~pH~ (up to 1 μg/well in 100 μl carbonate buffer, in triplicate) for  ~Modifier~  ~Time~ at ambient temperature or  ~Time~ at  ~Temperature~  ~Temperature~ or overnight at 4°C.
Yeast DAPI Staining
 ~Action~ yeast in liquid medium overnight.
 ~Action~ 333 μL (or 1 volume) yeast culture to a 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ 666 μL (or 2 volume) of 100% Ethanol to the 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube.
Let the yeast ethanol mixture  ~Action~ at room temperature for 30-60 minutes.
 ~Action~ yeast cells for 1 minute at 2500 RPM.
 ~Action~ the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 1mL of 1 x PBS, then centrifuge for 1 minute at 2500 RPM.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ the pellet in 1mL of 1 x PBS, then centrifuge for 1 minute at 2500 RPM.
Pour out the supernatant and  ~Action~ the pellet in 200 μL of a 1 x PBS / 1:2000 Dilution DAPI mixture.
Immunoprecipitation
Take cell dishes out of incubator and  ~Action~ on ice.
 ~Action~ cells gently with ice-cold PBS for twice.
 ~Action~ cells and  ~Action~ @ 500 rpm, 10min, 4 °C.
 ~Action~ 500l ul IP lysis buffer to each cell pellets (upto 2E+7 cells).
 ~Action~ for 2h at 4°C.
 ~Action~ 14,000rpm for 30 min.
 ~Action~ supernatant.
(Optional) Roughly  ~Action~ protein concentration with OD280.
 ~Action~ all samples to the same concentration.
Determine amount of beads needed (Rockland True Blot IP beads; 20 ul beads per 500ul sample).
 ~Action~ beads in 1ml lysis buffer for twice.
 ~Action~ @500g, 30s.
 ~Action~ pelleted beads in 1mg/ml BSA , rotate @ RT, 10min.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ @ RT, 10min.
Remove BSA and  ~Action~ beads in lysis buffer for 3 times.
 ~Action~ pelleted beads 1:1 with lysis buffer.
 ~Action~ 40ul of IP lysate per sample as input.
 ~Action~ primary Ab and beads to IP lysate.
 ~Action~ @4 degree for overnight.
 ~Action~ beads @ 500g for 30sec @RT and  ~Action~ the supernatant.
 ~Action~ beads in 1ml ice-cold lysis buffer.
 ~Action~ 3 times.
 ~Action~ beads in 30ul of 2× loading buffer.
 ~Action~ the beads for 5min.
 ~Action~ @ RT for 1min.
Conjugation of Thalassiosira pseudonana
Pick bacterial colonies from your Gent+Kan plates and inoculate 10 mL LB medium.
Grow overnight.
Measure OD600 and start a 150 mL LB subculture (recommended starting OD600 either 0.05 or 0.1).
Grow at 37oC until OD600 reaches 0.3-0.4.
 ~Action~ at  ~Speed~  ~Action~ bacterial colonies from your Gent+Kan plates and inoculate 10 mL LB medium.
Grow overnight.
Measure OD600 and start a 150 mL LB subculture (recommended starting OD600 either 0.05 or 0.1).
Grow at 37oC until OD600 reaches 0.3-0.4.
Centrifuge at 4,000 rpm, 10oC, for  ~Time~ 
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ and  ~Action~ in  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~ 
Tp was cultured in L1 medium as described in the 'Before start' section.
Spin down 2 x 108 cells at 4000 rpm, 10oC, for 10 min.
Decant supernatant and resuspend pellet in 1 mL L1 medium.
Mix 200 µL T. pseudonana cells and 200 µL E. coli cells in a 1.5 mL tube.
 ~Action~ up and down a few times.
 ~Action~ on 1/2xL1 1% agar plates w/ 5% LB.
 ~Action~ in dark at 30oC for 90 minutes.
Move plates to your standard Tp growth conditions - in my case 18oC and constant light - for 4 hours.
Add 1 mL L1 medium and scrape with a cell scraper or L spreader.
Expect to recover ~500 µL co-culture suspension after scraping.
Plate 200 µL of the resulting suspension on pre-dried 1/2xL1 1% agar plates w/ 100 µg/mL nourseothricin.
Leave at 18oC and constant light until colonies appear - ~2 weeks.
Here are a few ways to confirm the presence and expression of your heterologous gene in resulting colonies:
Growth under selection pressure.
Make sure colonies are able to grow in liquid L1 medium with 100 µg/mL nourseothricin (Nou100).
Pick colonies with a small tip or better a toothpick and inoculate ~0.5 mL L1 medium.
Once you observe growth subculture in larger volume.
PCR- Use 1 µL of diatom culture as a template to amplify your expression cassette.
- Confirm the absence of donor DNA by amplifying E. coli-specific genes.
NOTE:I used primers to amplify the corC gene.
Make sure you always run E. coli EPI300 posititve control.
- Confirm the absence of live donor cells by plating some diatom culture on LB plates w/o antibiotics.
NOTE: Any remaining donors cells and donor DNA are gone after a few liquid subcultures.
You can also patch colonies on fresh 1/2xL1 Nou100 plates.
RT-PCR- Purify total RNA from Nou100 diatom culture, convert it to cDNA and use it to run a PCR with heterologous gene-specific primers.
- An example of my result with controls can be found here.
Episome recovery- Perform a diatom miniprep as described by Karas et al.
(2015).
- Transform E. coli with diatom-derived DNA.
-  ~Action~ on  ~Location~ with  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~  ~Action~ E. coli with diatom-derived DNA.
- Select on LB agar plates with 50 µg/mL kanamycin.
PhosphoSerine Western Blotting
 ~Action~ 40% of IP eluate on 10% gel.
 ~Action~ protein to PVDF membrane for 1hr at RT with ice pack (100V).
 ~Action~ membrane just below 180kD (top MW marker on benchmark prestained ladder).
 ~Action~ Membrane at ~82kD (the blue band above the pink band using benchmark prestained ladder).
**Note, the GST-tagged protein is ~115 kD.
Cutting the membrane in the places will help reduce non-specific binding.
Also, running a ladder in the middle of the gel will help you cut straight across the membrane in the event that the gel is transferred at an angle relative to the membrane.
Block membrane with 5% BSA (IgG and Protease-Free)/TBST for 2hrs at RT Probe membrane with rabbit-anti-phosphoserine antibody from millipore in IgG-Free/Protease-Free BSA/TBST (1:2000, you can try 1:1000 if signal is not great at 1:2000).
Probe overnight at 4C in cold room on tilting tray.
 ~Action~ membrane 8x over the course of 2hrs with 1x TBST Block membrane in 5% milk/TBST for 1hr Probe with mouse-anti-rabbit light-chain specific secondary antibody at 1:2000 for 2hrs at RT.
 ~Action~ 6x with TBST over 1hr at RT.
 ~Action~ membrane with pico ECL.
 ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~ membrane with 5% BSA (IgG and Protease-Free)/TBST for 2hrs at RT  ~Action~ membrane with rabbit-anti-phosphoserine antibody from millipore in IgG-Free/Protease-Free BSA/TBST (1:2000, you can try 1:1000 if signal is not great at 1:2000).
DNEasy DNA Extraction - Vibrio Gram Negative Broth Bacteria
 ~Action~ Buffer ATL and AL at 56 C for 5 minutes before using.
 ~Action~ 250ul of broth culture to 2ml deep well (autoclaved). 
 ~Action~ cells (maximum 2 x 109 cells) by centrifuging plate for 15 min at 4063 x g. 
 ~Action~ supernatant.
 ~Action~ pellet in 200 µl Buffer ATL by pipetting up and down 15 times.
 ~Action~ with foil and  ~Action~ in oven at 56 C for one hour.
 ~Action~ extra plate on seal so foil doesn’t come off.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ up and down 15 times.
Seal with foil and place in oven at 56 C for one hour.
Place extra plate on seal so foil doesn’t come off.
Pipette up and down 15 times and spin down.
(May  ~Action~ in -80 C and  ~Action~  later at this point.)
If placed in -80 C,  ~Action~ and  ~Action~ @ 1000g for 1 min. 
 ~Action~ 205 uL Buffer AL and 205 uL molecular grade EtOH.
 ~Action~ up and down 15 times and spin down.
 ~Action~ DNeasy 96 plates on top of 2ml deep well plate .
 ~Action~ the DNeasy 96 plates for later sample identification.
Carefully  ~Action~ the lysate (approximately 600ul) of each sample from step 7 to each well of the DNeasy 96 plates.
Do not  ~Action~ more than 900 µl per well.
 ~Action~ each DNeasy 96 plate with a porous film.
 ~Action~ for 15 min at 4063g.
If lysate remains in any of the wells,  ~Action~ for a further 10 min.
 ~Action~ 500 µl Buffer AW1 to each sample.
 ~Action~ each DNeasy 96 plate with a new AirPore Tape Sheet (provided).
 ~Action~ for 5 min at 4063g.
 ~Action~ the tape.
Carefully  ~Action~ 500 µl Buffer AW2 to each sample.
 ~Action~ for 15 min at 4063g.
Do not seal the plate with AirPore Tape.
The heat generated during centrifugation ensures evaporation of residual ethanol in the sample (from Buffer AW2) that might otherwise inhibit downstream reactions.
 ~Action~ in new collection rack (2ml deep well plate) and spin again 15 minutes at 4063g.
 ~Action~ each DNeasy 96 plate in the correct orientation on a new rack of VWR 500ul plate.
To  ~Action~ the DNA,  ~Action~ 200 µl Buffer TE to each sample, seal and incubate for 1 minute at room temp.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ and  ~Action~ for 1 minute at room temp.
Centrifuge for 4 min at 4063g.
200 µl Buffer TE is sufficient to elute up to 75% of the DNA from each well of the DNeasy 96 plate.
Nuclear Factor Fixation and Permeabilization Staining Protocol

 ~Action~ once with 1 ml Biolegend's Nuclear Factor Permeabilization Buffer (1x).

 ~Action~ appropriate amount of flurochrome-conjugated antibodies for nuclear target of interest, and  ~Action~ at room temperature in the dark for 30 minutes.

MPN (Most Probable Number) assay for infectivity of algal viruses
Virus Dilution Series.
 ~Action~ a series of 5 mL round bottom tubes from 10-1 to 10-10.
 ~Action~ 1.8 mL culture media to each tube.
 ~Action~ 200 µL virus sample into the “10-1” tube and  ~Action~ to mix.
Use a clean pipette tip to transfer 200 µL from the “10-1” tube to the “10-2” tube and  ~Action~ to mix.
 ~Action~ serial dilution to 10-10.
 ~Action~ 500 µL virus sample to a sterile 1.2 mL cryovial (to preserve for FCM counts).
In the chemical hood,  ~Action~ 5 µL 25% glutaraldehyde (0.25% final concentration) and gently  ~Action~ to mix.
 ~Action~ 250 µL to a duplicate cryovial and  ~Action~ cryovials into cryocanes.
 ~Action~ at 4°C for 30 minutes in the dark.
 ~Action~ in liquid nitrogen and  ~Action~ at -80°C until analysis.
Plate Setup.
 ~Action~ remaining culture medium into a sterile sample reservoir.
Use a multichannel pipette to  ~Action~ 50 µL medium to all wells in Column 9 (“Control”) on all plates.
 ~Action~ unused medium and  ~Action~ sample reservoir with host culture.
 ~Action~ 150 µL host cells to all wells in Columns 1-9 on all plates.
 ~Action~ remaining culture.
 ~Action~ “10-10” viral dilution into new sterile sample reservoir.
 ~Action~ a multichannel pipette to  ~Action~ 50 µL 10-10-diluted virus sample to all wells in Column 8 on all replicate plates.
 ~Action~ remaining 10-10-diluted virus sample and  ~Action~ “10-9” viral dilution into the same sample reservoir.
 ~Action~ the same pipette tips to  ~Action~ 50 µL 10-9-diluted virus sample to all wells in Column 7 on all plates.
 ~Action~ additions of diluted virus samples from most dilute to most concentrated (moving from right to left across the microplates).
After final 10-3-diluted virus sample is added to plates,  ~Action~ optical density for T0 in plate reader (as described below) and  ~Action~ (unstacked to prevent shading) at standard growth conditions for ~2 weeks, measuring growth every few days.
Data Collection.
 ~Action~  ~Amount~  ~Location~ from  ~Method~

Extraction of DNA from Virus

 ~Action~ them by hands for 5mins.
 ~Action~ the liquid to the centrifuge tubes, balance them &  ~Action~  ~Action~ them & centrifuge for 15 mins at 14000 rpm at 4ºC.
 ~Action~ the aqueous (upper) part with pipette to the clean centrifuge tubes.
Don’t worry getting protein in it.
 ~Action~ the bottom layer into the waste container.
 ~Action~ tubes again at 14,000 rpm for 15 min.
Now it easy to get pure liquid without protein debris.
Aqueous layer may be  ~Action~ overnight at 4 ºC.
Estimate the volume of the aqueous layer and  ~Action~ 0.1 volume of 3M (or 5M) Sodium Acetate (pH 6.0).

Let it  ~Action~ on the glass rod.
 ~Action~ alcohol into the waste container.

 ~Action~ for 10-20 min.
 ~Action~ the glass rod with DNA against the wall of beaker to get rid of the ethanol.
 ~Action~ the stirring rod in the test tube rack and  ~Action~ for 5 min.
Use 15ml plastic tubes.

a. Optional step is to run this lysate through a Qiashredder for additional lysis.

Optiprep gradient preparation for virus separation
Optiprep preparation UV and sterilize class II cabinet with reagent alcohol.
Work with gloves and sleeve guards to prevent contaminating the hood.
 ~Action~ 5 15ml falcon tubes with 25%, 30%, 35%, 40% and 45% labels.
 ~Action~ a 50 ml falcon tube "Optiprep".
 ~Action~ OptiPrep solution from the fridge and  ~Action~ sides, cap and septum with alcohol.
 ~Action~ septum with needle (20 gauge 1/2 inch needles work best) attached to appropriately-sized syringe and aseptically  ~Action~ 15-16 ml of OptiPrep for every 2 gradients you intend to make.
Place Optiprep in the sterile 50 ml falcon tube.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ Optiprep in the sterile 50 ml falcon tube.
Make 25%, 30%, 35%, 40% and 45% Optiprep solutions in the labeled falcon tubes.
You will need 2.5 ml of each solution for every gradient you plan to make.
 ~Action~ well.
For example, if you are making 2 gradients, you will prepare 5 ml of each solution as follows: 25% = 3 ml media + 2 ml Optiprep30% = 2.5 ml media + 2.5 ml OptiPrep35% = 2.1 ml media + 2.9 ml OptiPrep40% = 1.7 ml media + 3.3 ml OptiPrep45% = 1.25 ml media + 3.75 ml OptiPrep. 
 ~Action~ a loading system for the centrifuge tubes by attaching the thin end of a pasteur pipet to a 5 ml syringe with parafilm or a rubber tube.
 ~Action~ the syringe with a ring clamp so that the end of the Pasteur pipet tip hovers just above the bottom of the tube.
 ~Action~ 2.4 ml of 25% solution into the syringe.
It will begin to  ~Action~ into the centrifuge tube via gravity.
When nearly all the solution has left the syringe,  ~Action~ 2.4 ml of the 30%.
 ~Action~ for all solutions.
NOTE: Try not to let the syringe run dry as it will  ~Action~ air bubbles into the tube and disrupting the reagent.
If this happens, you can  ~Action~ the flow by placing your thumb on the top of the syringe to generate and  ~Action~ and then  ~Action~ your thumb up and down to increase the pressure in the syringe.
Once all tube has been poured (all percent solutions have been added),  ~Action~ the top with parafilm and place the tubes in the fridge.
Allow the tubes to sit overnight to form a continuous gradient.
NOTE:  Tubes may  ~Action~  ~Action~ overnight to form a continuous gradient.
NOTE:  Tubes may sit in the fridge for several weeks and will still be good as long as they are sealed.
Separating viruses on the Optiprep gradient.
The next morning,  ~Action~ 0.5 - 4 ml of your viral concentrate onto each gradient.
 ~Action~ the tubes using sterile growth medium if necessary (or whatever solution the virus sample is suspended in).
 ~Action~ the tubes in a swinging bucket rotor in the Beckman Advanti J30-I (use rotor JS-25.15) at max speed (40,000 rpm) for at least 4 hours at 8˚C.
NOTE: Occasionally you will need to  ~Action~ for longer than 4 hours to achieve separation.
In these cases an overnight or 24 hour spin may be required.
 ~Action~ the tubes carefully out of the rotor and place them on a standing clamp to visualize the bands.
NOTE:  Sometimes the bands are not visible until you  ~Action~ the tubes in a beaker of water, remove and back light them.
Extracting bands.
 ~Action~ the bands separately using sterile needles and a 3 ml syringe.
NOTE: You must use 20 gauge half-inch needles at this stage to avoid puncturing both walls of the tube!
Do not use any needles longer than ½”.
 ~Action~ the sides of the tube wall with ethanol.
 ~Action~ the syringe just below the band and puncture the wall.
 ~Action~ and remove the band with the syringe until the band disappears.
It usually results in about 400 ul – 1 ml volume removed.
 ~Action~ a piece of scotch tape over the hole in the tube to prevent the gradient from leaking out.
 ~Action~ the sample into a 1.5 ml centrifuge tube and  ~Action~  ~Action~ the tubes in the fridge.

Ligation of Sticky Ends with T4

Isotopic labeling of freshwater mixotrophic algae using isotopic labeled heat-killed bacteria
 ~Action~ modified DY-V media.   
Media used for Ochromonas growth was a modified version of DY-V media.
Modifications were:No MES was used, as it can be used as a source of carbon (bicarbonate and heat-killed bacteria are the only sources of carbon used in this media).
No Na2SiO3 was used (Ochromonas does not need silica).
No NaNO3 (ammonium and heat-killed bacteria were the only sources of nitrogen used in this media).
Sodium bicarbonate added at a final concentration of 95 µM.
Bicarbonate addition is done before algal inoculum by 0.2 µm filtration of a stock solution (do not autoclave).
Media inoculation with labeled HKB. 
 ~Action~ 15N 13C labeled heat-killed bacteria (HKB) to the media (isolation and labeling of HKB was done following this protocol).
 ~Action~ an inoculum of the mixotrophic algae (volume of inoculum should be low as to avoid dilution of the isotopic label and carry over of nutrients).
NOTE: as an example, values commonly used were ~5x103 Ochromonas mL-1 and ~5x107 HKB mL-1 as starting concentrations for the cultures.
Mixotrophic growth of the algae. 
Let the algae  ~Action~ o it incorporates the isotopic signature in its biomass.
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~  ~Modifier~ DY-V media.   
Media used for Ochromonas growth was a modified version of DY-V media.
Modifications were:No MES was used, as it can be used as a source of carbon (bicarbonate and heat-killed bacteria are the only sources of carbon used in this media).
No Na2SiO3 was used (Ochromonas does not need silica).
No NaNO3 (ammonium and heat-killed bacteria were the only sources of nitrogen used in this media).
Sodium bicarbonate added at a final concentration of 95 µM.
Bicarbonate addition is done before algal inoculum by 0.2 µm filtration of a stock solution (do not autoclave).
Media inoculation with labeled HKB.

Enumerating algal viruses by flow cytometry
FCM Sample Collection.
 ~Action~ samples of virus and TE buffer (i.e., for background noise) as described below.
 ~Action~ 600 µL of culture sample to a sterile 1.2 mL cryovial tube.
 ~Action~ 6 µL 25% glutaraldehyde (0.25% final concentration) and gently  ~Action~ to  ~Action~ 
 ~Action~ 200 µL to two additional cryovials (i.e., triplicate samples).
 ~Action~ 3 x 1 mL of 0.02-µm-filtered TE buffer to  ~Action~ sterile 1.2 mL cryovials.
 ~Action~ 10 µL 25% glut to each tube and gently  ~Action~ to  ~Action~ 
 ~Action~ cryovials into cryocanes and  ~Action~ at 4°C for 30 minutes in the dark.
 ~Action~ in liquid nitrogen.
 ~Action~ at -80°C until analysis.
Virus Dilution and CountingDilute and  ~Action~ a sample aliquot for viruses immediately after  ~Action~ 
 ~Action~ thawed sample on ice.
An aliquot can be run for host cell counts while the diluted virus sample is  ~Action~  ~Action~ for host cell counts while the diluted virus sample is incubating.
 ~Action~ sample in 0.02-µm-filtered 1X TE buffer according to the Dilution Table.
NOTE: For a new sample, prepare multiple dilutions to test and determine the most appropriate dilution factor.
Stagger these dilutions/staining by ~5 minutes to allow for sample loading and back-flushing between dilution tests.
Prepare a 1.7 mL microcentrifuge tube for staining by adding 2.5 µL of 100X SYBR Green I nucleic acid stain (this can be pre-aliquoted and kept in the dark at room temperature).
Add 497.5 µL of the diluted sample to the staining tube (0.5X SYBR Green I final conc) and mix by pipetting and gentle vortexing.
Incubate the diluted/stained sample for 15 minutes in the dark at room temperature.
After incubation, transfer 480 µL of the stained sample to a 5 mL round bottom tube.
Add 10 µL 3° Grn and 10 µL 4° YG beads to the 5 mL tube.
Run immediately on HIGH voltage settings: Trigger = 520, TFSC = 40, PFSC = 27, SSC = 40, 520 = 40, 572 = 40, 692 = 40.
Load sample for 2 min, run for 2-4 min (depending on concentration), and back-flush for 2 min.
Host Cell Counts.
Run an unstained aliquot of sample for host cell counts while the diluted virus sample is incubating.
Prepare a 5 mL round bottom tube with 10 µL 3° Grn and 10 µL 4° YG beads.
Depending on the host cell concentration, add 50 or 100 µL sample to the 5 mL tube.
Bring volume up to 500 µL by adding 430 or 380 µL 1X PBS to the 5 mL tube.
Run immediately on LOW voltage settings: Trigger = TFSC, TFSC = 27, PFSC = 19, SSC = 40, 520 = 40, 572 = 40, 692 = 40.
 ~Action~ sample for 2 min, run for 2-4 min (depending on concentration), and  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~ and  ~Action~ between dilution tests.

Quick Protocol for Monarch® PCR & DNA Cleanup Kit (5 μg) (NEB #T1030)
Dilute sample with DNA Cleanup Binding Buffer according to the table below.
Mix well by pipetting up and down or flicking the tube.
Do not vortex.
A sample volume of 20–100 μl is recommended.
For smaller samples, TE can be used to adjust the volume.
For diluted samples larger than 800 μl, load a portion of the sample, proceed with step 2, and then repeat as necessary.

Discarding flow-through is optional).

Use care to ensure that the tip of the column does not come into contact with the flow-through.
If in doubt, re-spin for 1 minute.
Add ≥ 6 μl of DNA Elution Buffer to the center of the matrix.

T-maze (light vs dark)
24h before the experiment, anesthetize 3-6 d old flies under CO2, and clip 2/3 from both wings to half of them.
In the same vial,  ~Action~  ~Action~ 3-6 d old flies under CO2, and  ~Action~ 2/3 from both wings to half of them.
In the same vial, place around 30 flies with clipped wings and another 30 intact flies.
Let them recover from anaesthesia until experiment begins.
 ~Action~ the flies in the entrance tube (see figure) and let them adapt for 10 min.
 ~Action~ the light source.
 ~Action~ the flies to the elevator by gently  ~Action~ the apparatus, and  ~Action~ the movable part down in order to close it.
Flies are  ~Action~ in the elevator for 30 sec.
 ~Action~ the movable part, so that the elevator is placed between the transparent and the opaque tubes.
Allow the flies to choose between dark and light for 30 sec.
 ~Action~ all tubes by pulling up the movable part, in order to lock the flies in the tube they have selected.
 ~Action~  ~Modifier~  ~Reagent~ under  ~Reagent~  and clip  ~Amount~ from  ~Reagent~ to half of them.

MojoSort™ Mouse CX3CR1 Selection Kit Protocol
 ~Action~ cells from your tissue of interest.
Enzymatic digestion, followed by myelin removal, is strongly recommended.
In the final wash of your sample preparation,  ~Action~ the cells in MojoSort™ Buffer by adding up to 4mL in a 5 mL (12 x 75 mm) polystyrene tube.
Note:  ~Action~ MojoSort™ Buffer on ice throughout the procedure.
 ~Action~ the cells with a 40 μm cell strainer,  ~Action~ at 300 x g for 5 minutes, and  ~Action~ in anappropriate volume of MojoSort™ Buffer.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the cell concentration to 1 x 107cells/mL.
 ~Action~ 100 μL of cell suspension (106 cells) into a new tube.
 ~Action~ 10 μL of the Biotin‐CX3CR1 antibody,  ~Action~ well and  ~Action~ on ice for 15 minutes.
 ~Action~ the volume accordingly if separating more cells.
For example,  ~Action~ 100 μL for 1 x 107 cells.
When working with less than 106 cells,  ~Action~ indicated volumes for 106 cells.
Optional:  ~Action~ unused cells, or  ~Action~ an aliquot before adding the cocktail to monitor purity and yield.
 ~Action~ the cells by adding MojoSort™ Buffer up to 4 mL;  ~Action~ the cells at 300 x g for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ supernatant and  ~Action~ in 100 μL of MojoSort™ Buffer.
 ~Action~ the beads by vortexing, maximum speed, 5 touches.
 ~Action~ 10 μL of Streptavidin Nanobeads.
 ~Action~ well and  ~Action~ on ice for 15 minutes.
 ~Action~ the volume accordingly if separating more cells.
For example,  ~Action~ 100 μL for 1 x 107 cells.
When working with less than 106 cells,  ~Action~ indicated volumes for 106 cells.
 ~Action~ the cells by adding 3 mL of MojoSort™ Buffer;  ~Action~ at 300 x g for 5 minutes,  ~Action~ supernatant.
Optional:  ~Action~ an aliquot before placing the tube in the magnet to monitor purity and yield.
 ~Action~ the cells in 3 mL of MojoSort™ Buffer.
Note: If you observe aggregates,  ~Action~ the suspension.
To maximize yield, you can  ~Action~ the aggregates by pipetting the solution up and down.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the liquid.
These are the cells of interest; DO NOT DISCARD.
If needed,  ~Action~ 3 mL of MojoSort™ Buffer and  ~Action~ steps 10 and 11 with the magnetically labeled fraction up to two times, and then  ~Action~ the unlabeled fractions.
Notes: Repeating the magnetic separation increases the yield, without a strong impact on the purity.
The yield will typically increase about 8 – 10% with a second separation, and about 2 – 5% with a third separation.
The purity may decrease 1 – 2% with each separation.
Optional: Take a small aliquot beforeplacing the tube in the magnet to monitor purity and yield.

Transformation Protocol for BL21(DE3) Competent Cells (C2527H)
 ~Action~ a tube of BL21(DE3) Competent E. coli cells on ice for 10 minutes.
 ~Action~ 1–5 µl containing 1 pg–100 ng of plasmid DNA to the cell mixture.
Carefully  ~Action~ the tube 4–5 times to mix cells and DNA.
 ~Action~ 
 ~Action~ the mixture on ice for 30 minutes.
Do not mix.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ 
Heat shock at exactly 42°C for exactly 10 seconds.
Do not mix.
 ~Action~ on ice for 5 minutes.
Do not mix.
 ~Action~ 950 µl of room temperature SOC into the mixture.
 ~Action~ at 37°C for 60 minutes.
 ~Action~ vigorously (250 rpm) or rotate.
 ~Action~ selection plates to 37°C.
 ~Action~ the cells thoroughly by flicking the tube and inverting.
 ~Action~ several 10-fold serial dilutions in SOC.
Transformation Protocol
 ~Action~ competent cells on ice. 
 ~Action~ approximately 5 ng (2 μl) of the ligation mixture in a 1.5 ml microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ 50 µl of competent cells to the DNA.
 ~Action~ gently by pipetting up and down or flicking the tube 4–5 times to mix the cells and DNA.
Do not vortex.
 ~Action~ the mixture on ice for 30 minutes.
Do not mix.
 ~Action~ at 42°C for 30 seconds.
Do not mix.
 ~Action~ 950 µl of room temperature media to the tube.
 ~Action~ tube at 37°C for 60 minutes.
 ~Action~ vigorously (250 rpm) or rotate.
 ~Action~ selection plates to 37°C.
 ~Action~ 50–100 µl of the cells and ligation mixture onto the plates.
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ on  ~Location~  
Phenol/chloroform extraction. 
 ~Action~ your nucleic acid sample to 100–700 µL or divide your samples into tubes such that you have no more than 700 µL per tube.
 ~Action~ an equal volume of phenol to the tube,  ~Action~ vigorously to mix the phases.
 ~Action~ in a microfuge at top speed for 1–2 min to separate the phases.
 ~Action~ the aqueous phase to a new tube, being careful not to transfer any of the protein at the phase interface.
 ~Action~ the phenol extraction from step 4.
 ~Action~ the phenol extraction from step 4.
 ~Action~ the sample with an equal volume of chloroform:isoamyl alcohol to remove any trace phenol.
 ~Action~ the sample again with an equal volume of chloroform:isoamyl alcohol to remove any trace phenol.
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ to 100–700 µL or divide your samples into tubes such that you have no more than 700 µL per tube.

Preparation of deionized glyoxal
 ~Action~ 25 ml of 40% glyoxal to be deionized with 2.5 g of mixed bed resin.
 ~Action~ the solution by magnetic stirrer for 30 minutes at room temperature.
The resin color will change from blue to amber, when its capacity is reached.
 ~Action~ the deionized material from the resin by decanting or (sterile) filtration.
 ~Action~ the deionization process (steps 2. and 3.)
until the color of the resin does not change anymore.
Approximately half of the resin particles remain blue and half become amber after a 30-minute incubation.
 ~Action~ the pH of the glyoxal solution by  ~Action~ 200 μl of glyoxal with 2 μl of a 10 mg/ml aqueous solution of bromocresol green and observing the color change.
Bromocresol green is yellow at pH <4.8 and blue-green at pH >5.2.
Alternatively, use pH indicator strips instead of a bromocresol green solution.
 ~Action~ the deionization process (steps 2. and 3.)
until the pH of the glyoxal is >5.5.
Final resin removal should be done through a small pore-size filter (e.g. 0.22-0.45 µm, gamma sterilized) to avoid carry-over of the resin.
Deionized glyoxal can be stored indefinitely at -20 °C (or -80 °C) under nitrogen in tightly sealed small aliquots (e.g. microcentrifuge tubes). ~Action~ each aliquot only once, then  ~Action~  ~Amount~ of 40% glyoxal to be deionized with 2.5 g of mixed bed resin.
Splenocyte Preperation
Harvest mouse spleen and prepare a single cell suspension.
Use slides or a syrings to push the spleen through a cell strainer.
Pellet the cells by centrifugation (350 x g); aspirate the supernatant.
Dilute the 10X Red Blood Cell Lysis Buffer to 1X working concentration with deionized water and resuspend the pellet in 5 ml of 1X Lysis Buffer.
Incubate on ice for 4-5 minutes with occasional shaking.
Stop the reaction by diluting the Lysis Buffer with 20-30 ml of 1X PBS.
Spin the cells (350 x g) and discard the supernatant.
 ~Action~ the pellet in the appropriate buffer Count cells,  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~ on ice for 4-5 minutes with occasional  ~Action~  ~Action~ the 10X Red Blood Cell Lysis Buffer to 1X working concentration with deionized water and  ~Action~  ~Action~ the cells by  ~Action~ (350 x g);  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~ mouse spleen and  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ and prepare a  ~Numerical~  ~Reagent~ 
Basic Illumina Sequence Quality Control
Assess raw FASTQ sequences using the program FastQCGoal.
 ~Action~ low quality sequences to increase average quality score of reads above 28 For current sequencing centers, the 5' end of has had Illumina adapters and primers  ~Action~ 
But there can be inclusion of the 3' end Illumina adapter in DNA fragments with length less than the number of the cycles for the sequencer.
 ~Action~ Illumina adaptor sequences from 3' end of sequences - be sure to  ~Action~ eads of 0 length.
 ~Action~ step for all raw read files.
Assess Cutadapt results with FastQC.
 ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Measure-Type~ of  ~Reagent~ above  ~Numerical~ For current sequencing centers, the  ~Reagent~ of has had  ~Reagent~ and  ~Reagent~  ~Reagent~  the 5' end of has had Illumina adapters and primers removed.
But there can be inclusion of the 3' end Illumina adapter in DNA fragments with length less than the number of the cycles for the sequencer.
Remove  ~Reagent~ from  ~Reagent~ - be sure to preserve  ~Reagent~ of  ~Generic-Measure~ 
Repeat  ~Method~ for all raw read files.
Protocol for Pulsed Field Gel Electrophoresis
A 15-20 liter natural seawater sample is passed through a glass fiber pre-filter (Gelman A/E) and a 0.22 μm pore size membrane (Durapore, Millipore).
 ~Action~ to ca. 150-200 ml using 30 kD MWC Spiral Cartridge Concentrator (SCC).
 ~Action~ the SCC retentate to Centriprep 30’s.
 ~Action~ balance of concentrate in refrigerator.
 ~Action~ in IEC-HN SE II at full speed for 15 minutes (in refrigerator if possible).
 ~Action~ central reservoir without refilling and repeat centrifugation step.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ keeping volumes equal in order to maximize filtration area of Centripreps and balance rotor.
Continue to spin and empty until no more water enters central chamber.
 ~Action~ central insert from 2 of units,  ~Action~ caps, and  ~Action~ retentate chamber briefly to recover droplets from sides.
Combine retentate into 2, and finally one Centriprep unit, by gentle pipetting.
When all have been combined and spun, the final volume is ca. 500 μl.
 ~Action~ a 1% agarose gel by combining 1 g Bio-Rad Molecular Grade Agarose with 99ml 0.5x TBE, and heating until completely clear of unmelted material.
 ~Action~ mold with backing plate in place and  ~Action~ in liquid.
Let set.
Meanwhile,  ~Action~ electrophoresis chamber with 2 liters 0.5x TBE.
 ~Action~ pump and chiller, and  ~Action~ temperature to 14°C.
When gel is set,  ~Action~ comb and sides of mold, and  ~Action~ backing plate, with gel attached, out of mold.
 ~Action~ gel with backing plate into receiver in electrophoresis chamber, taking care not to dislodge gel from plate, with wells in rear and let chill.
 ~Action~ aliquots into Microcons (30 or 100 kD MWC).
 ~Action~ each aliquot in a separate Microcon and spin at 1000 x g for 20 minutes (about 4000 RPM in Eppendorf Microfuge) to near dryness (most of the Microcon membrane is dry, and only a small ring of liquid remains around edge).
As they reach the proper volume, smaller volume aliquots can be removed and stored in the refrigerator until the larger have been reduced to the proper volume.
When all samples have been reduced,  ~Action~ 50 μl 1:10 TE to each tube, taking care not to touch membrane with pipette tip, and  ~Action~ again to reduce volume as described above.
 ~Action~ step 22.
 ~Action~ step 22 again.
Now  ~Action~ 20 μl 0.5x TBE to membrane to elute viruses, again taking care not to touch membrane.
 ~Action~ cartridge, place in fresh tube, and  ~Action~  ~Action~ fresh tube, and spin for 5 minutes at 1000 x g to recover.
 ~Action~ tubes containing recovered viruses in 60°C water bath for 10 minutes.
 ~Action~ tubes and  ~Action~ immediately on ice for 2 minutes.
 ~Action~ to microfuge and  ~Action~ briefly to recover condensation from walls of tubes.
 ~Action~ molecular weight markers by combining 100-200 ng of marker stock to 0.5x TBE to a final volume of 20 μl.
 ~Action~ 10 μl PFGE loading buffer to each tube.
 ~Action~ by simultaneously inverting several times slowly, while rolling between index finger and thumb.
 ~Action~ chiller and pump off.
 ~Action~ samples.
 ~Action~ pump on, then turn chiller on.
 ~Action~ lid and check connections to make sure all is in order.
 ~Action~ voltage to 6V.
 ~Action~ initial switch time to 1s.
 ~Action~ final switch time to 10s.
 ~Action~ run time to 18h.
Push start.
After 10 minutes,  ~Action~  ~Action~ centrifugation step.
NC64A virus purification
 ~Action~ flasks with Chlorella and  ~Action~ at 25°C with continuous light and shaking until the cells are in the actively growing phase.
 ~Action~ flasks with Chlorella NC64A in MBBM (or Micractinium Pbi in FES) and  ~Action~ at 250C with continuous light and shaking until the cells are in the actively growing phase (about 1-2 X 107 cells/ml).
 ~Action~ the flasks of chlorella with virus at an moi of 0.01 to 0.001.
 ~Action~ the flasks for 48-72 hours at 25°C with continuous light and shaking.
This material is now termed “lysate”.
 ~Action~ the lysate in the Sorvall GSA rotor in 250 ml bottles at 5,000 rpm (4,000 rcf), 5 min, 4°C.
 ~Action~ the pellets.
 ~Action~ Triton X-100 to the lysate supernatants for a final concentration of 1% (from a 10 or 20% stock).
 ~Action~ the lysate in the Beckman Type 19 225 mL ultracentrifuge rotor at 17,000 rpm (43,000 rcf), 50 min, at 4°C.
 ~Action~ the supernatants.
 ~Action~ the virus pellets with a small volume of 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.8 (approximately 1.0 mL per 100 mL of original lysate).
 ~Action~ the virus suspension onto 100-400 mg/mL (10-40%) linear sucrose density gradients equilibrated with 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.8, made up in Beckman SW28 rotor tubes (layer approximately 3-4 mL per gradient).
 ~Action~ the gradients in a Beckman SW28 rotor at 20,000 rpm (72,000 rcfmax), 20 min, 4°C.
 ~Action~ the virus bands from the gradients with sterile bent needles and transfer to oak ridge 30 mL polypropylene centrifuge tubes.
 ~Action~ the virus from 3 gradients between 2 tubes.
Slowly  ~Action~ the virus to the tube volume with 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.8.
 ~Action~ the tubes in Beckman Ti 50.2 rotor at 27,000 rpm (~44,000 rcfmax), 3 hours, 4°C.
Alternatively,  ~Action~ the virus from the gradients ~10-fold with Tris buffer and  ~Action~ in the Type 19 rotor for 1 hour, 17,000 rpm, 4 C. 
A GSA type high speed rotor can be used for at 2 hours, 12,000 rpm.
 ~Action~ the supernatants.
 ~Action~ the virus pellets with a small volume of 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.8.
 ~Action~ the virus at 4°C.
Do not freeze.
Filter sterilizition using a 0.45 µm cellulose acetate or other low protein binding filter is recommended.
Gently  ~Action~ the pellet and  ~Action~ with some 50 mM Tris, pH 7.8 buffer to  ~Action~ residual sucrose  ~Action~  ~Location~ with  ~Reagent~ and incubate at  ~Temperature~  ~Modifier~ until the cells are in the actively growing phase.

Phenol-chloroform extraction with ethanol precipitation
To the viral suspension (≤0.6 mL per 2-mL microcentrifuge tube, scale up for larger volumes)  ~Action~ an equal volume of PCI and  ~Action~ to emulsify.
 ~Action~ at 10,000g for 5 min to facilitate separation of the organic and aqueous phases.
 ~Action~ the DNA-containing aqueous phase (upper) to a new tube by aspiration with a pipette, being careful to avoid material at the interface.
 ~Action~ steps 1–3 as needed until the interface appears to be free of extracted material (one extraction may suffice for relatively pure viral preparations).
 ~Action~ an equal volume of CI to the aqueous phase and  ~Action~ to emulsify.
 ~Action~ as in step 2 to separate phases.
 ~Action~ the aqueous phase (upper) to a new tube.
 ~Action~ 1 µL polyacryl carrier.
 ~Action~ 1/10 of a volume of sodium acetate and  ~Action~ tube or  ~Action~ to mix.

 ~Action~ or  ~Action~ the supernatant, being careful not to disturb the pellet.
 ~Action~ 500 µL ice-cold 70% ethanol.
 ~Action~ at 10,000g for 10 min.
 ~Action~ or  ~Action~ supernatant as completely as possible, being careful not to disturb the pellet.

Extracting DNA from bananas
 ~Action~ the  ~Reagent~ in the  ~Location~ for about  ~Time~ until it has a pudding-like consistency and all lumps are gone.
 ~Action~  ~Location~ with the  ~Reagent~ and  ~Reagent~ 
 ~Action~ the  ~Reagent~ into the  ~Location~  and  ~Action~ the  ~Location~ 
Gently  ~Action~ the  ~Reagent~ and  ~Reagent~ together for  ~Time~ 
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ into the  ~Location~ and gently  ~Action~ the  ~Reagent~ 
You do not want the mixture to become too foamy.
 ~Action~ the  ~Device~ in a  ~Location~  securing the top of the filter around the lip of the cup.
 ~Action~ the  ~Reagent~ of the  ~Location~ into the  ~Device~ and let it sit until all of the liquid has dripped down into the cup.
 ~Action~ the  ~Device~ 
 ~Action~ the  ~Location~ and slowly  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ down the  ~Location~ of the  ~Location~ until there is a layer that is 2.5-5cm (1-2in) thick.
Keep the alcohol and liquefied banana as separate as possible.
Let this two-layered mixture  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ sit for  ~Time~ 
The longer you wait, the more defined this layer becomes.
This is the DNA pieces clumping together.

ASP12A Recipe for culturing Aureococcus anophagefferens
 ~Action~ Trace Metal Solutions I - III, Fe-EDTA Sodium Salt Solution, and Vitamin Solution.
 ~Action~ constituents to 750 mL MilliQ water, shake to dissolve.
 ~Action~ MilliQ water to 1.0 L.
 ~Action~ 
Trace Metal Solutions and Fe-EDTA Sodium Salt Solution are  ~Action~ at 4ºC in 15 - 50 mL aliquots, while the Vitamin solution is  ~Action~ at -20ºC in 5 - 10 mL aliquots.

Do not mix.

Do not mix.

Pierce Silver Stain Kit
 ~Action~ gel in ultra pure water for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ the water and  ~Action~ for another 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ gel in 30% ethanol:10% acetic acid solution (i.e., 6:3:1 water:ethanol:acetic acid) for 15 minutes.
 ~Action~ the solution and  ~Action~ for another 15 minutes.
Note: Gel may be kept in fixing solution overnight without affecting stain performance.
 ~Action~ gel in 10% ethanol solution for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ solution and wash for another 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ gel in ultrapure water for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ water and  ~Action~ for another 5 minutes.
Prepare Sensitizer Working Solution by  ~Action~ 1 part Silver Stain Sensitizer with 500 parts ultrapure water (e.g., mix 50µL Sensitizer with 25mL water).
 ~Action~ gel in Sensitizer Working Solution for exactly 1 minute, then  ~Action~ with two changes of ultrapure water for 1 minute each.
Prepare Stain Working Solution by  ~Action~ 1 part Silver Stain Enhancer with 50 parts Silver Stain (e.g., 0.5mL of Enhancer with 25mL Stain).
 ~Action~ gel in Stain Working Solution for 30 minutes.
Note: Gel may be incubated in Stain Working Solution for as short as 5 minutes or as long as overnight without affecting stain performance.
 ~Action~ Developer Working Solution by  ~Action~ 1 part Silver Stain Enhancer with 50 parts Silver Stain Developer (e.g., mix 0.5mL of Enhancer with 25mL Developer).
 ~Action~ 5% acetic acid solution as a Stop Solution.
Quickly  ~Action~ gel with two changes of ultrapure water for 20 seconds each.
Immediately  ~Action~ Developer Working Solution and  ~Action~ until protein bands appear (2-3 minutes).
Note: Protein bands will begin to appear within 30 seconds and then continue to develop.
Between 2 and 3 minutes, protein detection vs. background is optimal.
After 3 minutes, lane background signal may increase to undesirable levels.
When the desired band intensity is reached,  ~Action~ Developer Working Solution with prepared Stop Solution (5% acetic acid).
 ~Action~ gel briefly, then  ~Action~ Stop Solution and  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ in  ~Reagent~ for  ~Time~

Building an HPC blast pipeline
 ~Action~ to the hpc (at the University of Arizona) with your user name  ~Action~ a directory for the pipeline  ~Action~ to the hpc-blast directory and  ~Action~ sub directories to hold std-err, std-out, data, blastdb, blast-results and scripts.
 ~Action~ to the blastdb directory and  ~Action~ the blast database.
 ~Action~ the input files over from iPlant.
We will be using the day/night transcriptomes we discussed last week.
You will use two of the Perl scripts from the homework in the hpc pipeline.
 ~Action~ these into the scripts directory.
config.sh: Now we need to  ~Action~ the config.sh script.
This script will contain all of the environmental variables that the user will be able to modify for running blast.
The idea of this script is to give the user one place to make any changes they need to run their particular blast job.
The user should not have to go in and change any of the scripts in the 'scripts' directory.
Instead, we will capture all of these variable here.
* note the the config.sh script is in the hpc-blast directory (in the first part of the pipeline), where it is easy for the user to modify it.
blast-pipeline.sh:Now we will  ~Action~ the "driver script", the script that is used to run each part of the pipeline.
run-fasta-splitter.sh.
 ~Action~ a shell script that runs the fasta splitter perl code.
run-blast.sh:  ~Action~ a shell script that runs blast on a compute node.
run-parse-blast.sh:Create a shell script to parse the blast output that runs on a compute node on the cluster.
04-blast-search.pl:  ~Action~ the blast search script. ~Action~ the e-value to be less stringent.Modify the Perl script 04-blast-search.pl to include additional information about the hit.
 ~Action~ all of the scripts  ~Action~ and then  ~Action~ the pipeline.If you don't get any errors, the pipeline will take <1 day to run.
Check to see if the pipeline is running Once the pipeline is finished running (and you don't see the jobs listed under qstat), check for std-errors and std-out.Note you can check while the pipeline is running too.
Now you try.See if you can update the pipeline to  ~Action~ one final step that  ~Action~ all of the parsed blast output into a single file for each of the original fasta files.Note that you can comment out the parts of the blast-pipeline.sh that you have already run in the steps above, to test your code.
Otherwise, these will run again.Also, before you run this final step, make sure the blast parsing is complete.Can this run on the head node, or should we run this on a compute node?The complete pipeline can be found in github here.
 ~Action~  ~Location~ (at the University of Arizona) with your  ~Reagent~ Create a  ~Reagent~ for the pipeline Go to the  ~Location~ and create  ~Reagent~ to hold std-err, std-out, data, blastdb, blast-results and scripts.
MegaLong™ Protocol for Isolation of >100kb Genomic DNA (Tissue Sample)
For optimal yield, rapidly  ~Action~ tissue and proceed with  ~Action~ immediately,  ~Action~ samples on ice or promptly  ~Action~ in liquid nitrogen and  ~Action~ at -70°C until required.
On ice,  ~Action~ 1-25mg ground frozen tissue or fresh diced tissue to a microcentrifuge tube containing 500µl Nuclei Isolation Buffer.
 ~Action~ the sample with a microfuge pestle until a homogenous suspension is acquired.
 ~Action~ the sample at 4°C for >1 minute to  ~Action~ large tissue fragments without sedimenting the nuclei.
During the incubation  ~Action~ the Tube-ODIALYZER™.
 ~Action~ the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ cap in a beaker of TE buffer and  ~Action~ at 4°C until required.
 ~Action~ the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ tube with TE buffer.
With a pipette  ~Action~ the supernatant to the Tube-O-DIALYZER™, ensuring the settled cellular debris is left behind.
 ~Action~ a supplied cap on the tube and  ~Action~ at 16,000xg for 5 minutes to  ~Action~ the nuclei.
 ~Action~ the LongLife™ Proteinase K and  ~Action~ 10µl to the nuclei.
 ~Action~ 70µl Digestion Buffer and  ~Action~ with gentle rocking.
 ~Action~ at 55°C for 2-4 hours with periodic rocking.
 ~Action~ 
After digestion is complete,  ~Action~ the tube for 20 seconds at 1,000g.
 ~Action~ the cap with the dialysis cap.
 ~Action~ the storage cap as this will be required for storage of DNA.
 ~Action~ the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ upside down in a 50ml centrifuge tube and  ~Action~ at 1000xg for 30 seconds to bring the sample onto the dialysis membrane.
 ~Action~ the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ from the 50ml tube with forceps and keeping it inverted slide into the provided float and  ~Action~ in 500ml 1X TE buffer at room temperature for 18-24 hours with 2-3 buffer changes.
Gently  ~Action~ tube to  ~Action~ contents at each buffer change.
Following dialysis the genomic DNA may be  ~Action~ in the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ using either Tube-O-DIALYZER™ Concentrator (Cat. # 786-144) or Concentrator Solution (Cat. # 786-143).
Simply  ~Action~ the Concentrator as per the instructions and  ~Action~ the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ containing your DNA in the solution.
If concentration is not required or following concentration,  ~Action~ the tube at 1000xg for 1 minute.
 ~Action~ the dialysis cap with the normal cap.
The genomic DNA is now ready for use.
 ~Action~ 70µl Suspension Buffer to the nuclei and gently  ~Action~ or  ~Action~ the tube to  ~Action~ the nuclei.
Carefully  ~Action~ the supernatant and  ~Action~ the tube on a paper towel to  ~Action~  ~Modifier~ dissect  ~Reagent~ and proceed with DNA extraction  ~Modifier~  keeping  ~Reagent~ on  ~Location~ or  ~Modifier~ freeze in  ~Reagent~ and store at  ~Temperature~ until required.

Peroxide Value Method
Weigh 0.01 mg oil into test tube and record exact weight.
Solid fat should be melted first.
Samples with high PV may need to be serially diluted in working solvent.
Make sure to record dilution factor if so.
Up to 0.10 g can be used for samples with very low PV.
Immediately add 3 mL working solvent and vortex to dissolve-make sure it is fully dissolved.
Prepare a blank tube (solvent in place of sample).
Add 15 μl ammonium thiocyanate to all tubes, and vortex 2-4 sec.
Add  ~Amount~  ~Amount~  ~Action~ 15 μl ammonium thiocyanate to all tubes, and vortex 2-4 sec.
 ~Action~ 15 μl ferrous chloride to all tubes, and vortex 2-4 sec.
Let sit at room temperature  ~Time~  ~Time~  ~Time~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Modifier~ add 3 mL working solvent and vortex to dissolve-make sure it is fully dissolved.
Prepare a blank tube (solvent in place of sample).
Add 15 μl  ~Reagent~ to all tubes, and vortex 2-4 sec.
Add 15 μl  ~Reagent~ to all  ~Location~  ~Modifier~  ~Action~ 2-4 sec.

MojoSort™ Human CD45 Nanobeads Protocol A
 ~Action~ cells from your tissue of interest without lysing erythrocytes.
In the final wash of your sample preparation,  ~Action~ the cells in MojoSort™ Buffer by  ~Action~ up to 4 mL in a 5 mL (12 x 75 mm) polystyrene tube.
Note: Keep MojoSort™ Buffer on ice throughout the procedure.
 ~Action~ the cells with a 70 μm cell strainer,  ~Action~ at 300 x g for 5 minutes, and  ~Action~ in an appropriate volume of MojoSort™ Buffer.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the cell concentration to 1 x 108 cells/mL.
 ~Action~ 100 μL of cell suspension (107 cells) into a new tube.
 ~Action~ the beads by  ~Action~ maximum speed, 5 touches.
 ~Action~ 10 μL of Nanobeads,  ~Action~ well and  ~Action~ on ice for 15 minutes.
Scale up the volume accordingly if separating more cells.
For example, add 100 μL for 1 x 108 cells.
When working with less than 107 cells, use indicated volumes for 107 cells.
 ~Action~ MojoSort™ Buffer up to 4 mL and  ~Action~ the cells at 300 x g for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ the cells in 3 mL of MojoSort™ Buffer.
Optional:  ~Action~ an aliquot before placing the tube in the magnet to monitor purity and yield.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ the tube in the magnet to monitor purity and yield.
Place the tube in the magnet for 5 minutes.
Pour out the liquid.
 ~Action~ the labeled cells in appropriate amount of buffer.
Repeat steps 7 – 9 on the labeled fraction 2 more times, for a total of 3 magnetic separations.
Optional:  ~Action~ a small aliquot to monitor purity and yield.
Saltwater BG-11 recipe
 ~Action~ 1L.
 ~Action~ of the final media to 8.2.
* Be sure to  ~Action~ K2HPO4 first, then NaSiO3, then  ~Action~ the others stock solutions to prevent precipitation.
0.2 um  ~Action~ into clean, autoclaved containers in a biosafety hood.
Do not autoclave the media as the silica will form precipitate and be cloudy!
To Prepare Conjugation Plates (1/2 BG-11, 5% LB, 1% agar): Dilute Saltwater BG-11 1:1 with ddH2O.
 ~Action~ 50mL of 1x LB for each litre of Conjugation Plate media being made.
 ~Action~ 5g of Bacto Agar to a 1L Earlenmeyer flask for each 500mL of Conjugation Plate media being made.
 ~Action~ 500 mL of Conjugation Plate media to each 1L Earlenmeyer flask.
 ~Action~ with flask opening with aluminum foil and  ~Action~ at 121C for 30 minutes.
 ~Action~ media  ~Action~ while stirring on magnetic stir plate.
Make sure the stirring is not too vigorous as to cause bubbles.
It should cool enough to be able to touch, but not have the agar solidified.
 ~Action~ plates and  ~Action~ overnight.
To Prepare Selection Plates (1/2 BG-11, 1% agar, + antibiotics):  ~Action~  ~Action~ Saltwater BG-11 1:1 with ddH2O.
Add 50mL of 1x LB for each litre of Conjugation Plate media being made.
Add 5g of Bacto Agar to a 1L Earlenmeyer flask for each 500mL of Conjugation Plate media being made.
Distribute 500 mL of Conjugation Plate media to each 1L Earlenmeyer flask.
Cover with flask opening with aluminum foil and autoclave at 121C for 30 minutes.
Allow media to cool while stirring on magnetic stir plate.
Make sure the stirring is not too vigorous as to cause bubbles.
It should cool enough to be able to touch, but not have the agar solidified.
Pour plates and allow to cool overnight.
To Prepare Selection Plates (1/2 BG-11, 1% agar, + antibiotics): Dilute Saltwater BG-11 1:1 with ddH2O.
 ~Action~ 5g of Bacto Agar to to a 1L Earlenmeyer flask for each 500mL of Selection Plate media being made.
Preparation of PBCV-1 Lysin
Centrifuge the NC64A chlorella (use actively growing cells approximately 1.0-2.0 X 107 cells/mL) in the Sorvall GSA rotor at 7,000 rpm, 5 min, 4°C.
Use sterile bottles to harvest the cells.
Discard the supernatants.
Resuspend the cells with sterile BBM.
Adjust the final volume to 500 mL with sterile BBM.
Add filter-sterilized tetracycline (12.5 mg/Ml stock, add 0.1 mL per 50 mL of BBM solution) and PBCV-1 at an moi (multiplicity of infection) of 0.01.
 ~Action~ overnight at 25°C with continuous light and shaking.
This material is now termed “lysate”.
 ~Action~ the lysate in the Sorvall GSA rotor at 3,500 rpm, 10 min, 5°C.
 ~Action~ the supernatants to clean bottles.
 ~Action~ the supernatant on the Sorvall GSA rotor at 10,000 rpm, 60 min, 5°C.
 ~Action~ the supernatant to clean flasks.
 ~Action~ d-H2O to a final volume of 1000 mL.
 ~Action~ at 4°C.
 ~Action~  at 4°C: 2-ME to 2 mM EDTA to 5 mM NaN3 to 200 mg/liter (NH4)2SO4 to 40% saturation  ~Action~ the pH to 7.0 with NaOH.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ at 4°C overnight.
 ~Action~ the material in the Sorvall GSA rotor at 10,000 rpm, 60 min, 5°C.
 ~Action~ the supernatant to clean flasks.
 ~Action~ the pellets.
 ~Action~  at 4°C, (NH4)2SO4 to 65% saturation.
 ~Action~ the pH to 7.0 with NaOH.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ at 4°C overnight.
 ~Action~ the material in the Sorvall GSA rotor at 10,000 rpm, 10 min, 5°C.
 ~Action~ the supernatant.
 ~Action~ the pellet.
 ~Action~ the pellet with 10.0 mL of 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 1 mM EDTA, 2 mM 2-ME + 2 mg NaN3.
 ~Action~ the material in the Sorvall SS34 rotor at 15,000 rpm, 60 min, 5°C.
 ~Action~ the supernatant.
 ~Action~ the supernatant for 48-72 hours at 4°C against 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 1 mM EDTA, 2 mM 2-ME, 200 mg/liter NaN3.
 ~Action~ the buffer once every 24 hours.
 ~Action~ the material from the dialysis.
 ~Action~ the material in the Sorvall SS34 rotor at 13,000 rpm, 60 min, 5°C.
 ~Action~ the supernatant into microfuge tubes and  ~Action~ at -20°C.
Assay the supernatant fraction for lysin activity.

You have now made SC +FUdR agar.
Design primers with overhangs that target the cassette to your desired locus.
(See the guidelines for details.)
 ~Action~ the HERP cassette of choice using your targeting primers and a high‐fidelity polymerase such as New England Biolab's Phusion system.
If your reaction makes use of DMSO or other harsh chemicals,  ~Action~ your PCR product with a column before proceeding.
 ~Action~ your strain of choice by inoculating 50 mL of YPD media with enough overnight culture of your strain to bring the OD600 to 0.2‐0.25.
 ~Action~ at the optimal temperature for your strain or species until the culture's OD600 reaches 0.85‐1.0.
 ~Action~ at the optimal temperature for your strain or species until the culture's OD600 reaches 0.85‐1.0.
 ~Action~ the cells by centrifugation in a 50‐mL conical vial at 3000 RPM for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ supernatant, wash with 25 mL water, and spin at 3000 RPM for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ supernatant and suspend cells in 1 mL of water.
 ~Action~ 100 μL cell suspension to microcentrifuge tubes,  ~Action~ for 30 seconds at max speed in a microcentrifuge, and  ~Action~ supernatant.

Once heat‐shocking has been completed,  ~Action~ the reactions for 30 seconds at max speed,  ~Action~ the supernatant, and  ~Action~ the cells in 600 μL of YPD.
 ~Action~ to glass culture tubes and  ~Action~ in a culture wheel for 3 hours at the strain's or species' optimal temperature.
 ~Action~ 200 μL of recovered cells to each of three YPGly +AF plates.
Only one 200 μL volume of control reaction, however, needs to be plated.
Once all the liquid has been absorbed,  ~Action~ agar up at the optimal temperature.
Colonies will appear in 3‐10 days.
 ~Action~ colonies out to fresh YPGly +AF plates.
 ~Action~ by amplifying target locus via PCR and/or sequencing across the insertion junction.
Once you have molecularly confirmed the insertion of the HERP cassette, phenotypically  ~Action~ its sensitivity to FUdR by spotting ~1,000 cells onto SC +FUdR plates multiple times.
Sensitive strains should exhibit no growth, while insensitive strains will rapidly grow.
Once your HERP insertion is confirmed and you have established FUdR sensitivity,  ~Action~ by inoculating the strain in 50 mL of 2X YPA100 +4% galactose (see main text) to an OD600 of 0.2‐0.25 and culture at the optimal temperature.
Once an OD600 of 0.85‐1.0 is reached,  ~Action~ steps C4 to C6, except  ~Action~ the HERP cassette PCR product in C6 with your desired replacement PCR product.
Once the heat shock is completed,  ~Action~ the supernatant and  ~Action~ in 600 μL water.
 ~Action~ 200 μL onto each of three SC plates.
 ~Action~ at optimal temperature for 24 hours.
After 24 hours,  ~Action~ plates at 4° for one hour.
Lightly  ~Action~ plates to SC +FUdR plates.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ 
You have now made SC +FUdR agar.
Purifying Viruses Using Sucrose Cushion
 ~Action~ sucrose (Molecular Biology Grade or higher) as 38% (weight to volume) in SM buffer (100mM NaCl, 8mM MgSO4, 50mM TrisJHCl, pH 7.5) that has been 0.2μm filtered.
 ~Action~ SW40 tubes with SM buffer or sterile water.
 ~Action~ the 9.5ml DNase I-treated sample into the rinsed ultracentrifuge tube.
Using a 3cc syringe and cannula,  slowly  ~Action~ the 2.5 ml of 38% sucrose under the sample trying not to cause any mixing of sample and sucrose.
 ~Action~ at ~175,000g for 3.25 hr at 18°C.
Using a sterile transfer or serological pipet, pull off the 9.5 ml sample layer.
Pull off the interface and 2.5 ml sucrose, being careful not to disturb or suction off the pelleted sample at the bottom.
Keep this  sucrose layer until virus counts from the pellets are completed.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ the 9.5 ml sample layer.
 ~Action~ the interface and 2.5 ml sucrose, being careful not to disturb or suction off the pelleted sample at the bottom.
Keep this  sucrose layer until virus counts from the pellets are completed.
Anti-BrdU Staining Protocols Using DNAse with Surface and Fluorescent Proteins
 ~Action~ actively dividing cells with BrdU (in vitro, cell culture media can be pulsed by adding 10-40 μM of BrdU for 1-2 hours).
 ~Action~ cells and  ~Action~ for 5 minutes at 1200-1500 rpm (200-300 x g)  ~Action~ cells in Cell Staining Buffer (Cat. No. 420201) and  ~Action~ for 5 minutes at 1200-1500 rpm (200-300 x g).
 ~Action~ supernatant. 
 ~Action~ 5 x 105- 1 x 106 cells per 12 x 75 mm tube. 
Optional:  ~Action~ cells for surface antigens if required, utilizing the Cell Surface Immunofluorescence Staining Protocol (see link). 
Wash cells by adding 1 ml of Cell Staining Buffer to each tube and  ~Action~ for 5 minutes at 1200-1500 rpm (200-300 x g).
 ~Action~ supernatant. 
Fix cells by  ~Action~  ~Action~ 1 ml of Cell Staining Buffer to each tube and centrifuging for 5 minutes at 1200-1500 rpm (200-300 x g).
Discard supernatant. 
Fix cells by adding 100 μl of 4% paraformaldehyde at room temperature for 20-30 minutes. 
 ~Action~ cells by repeating step 6 twice.
(Optional: Cells can be stored in FACS buffer at 4⁰C for up to 72 hrs).
Permeabilize cells by  ~Action~ 500 μl of 0.5% Triton-X 100 in PBS for 15 minutes at room temperature. 
 ~Action~ cells by repeating step 6 twice. 
 ~Action~ cells with 20 μg of DNAse (Cat. No. D4513, Sigma-Aldrich) diluted in DPBS with calcium and magnesium to each tube and  ~Action~ at 37⁰C for 1 hour.
 ~Action~ cells by repeating step 6 twice. 
 ~Action~ 50 μl of Cell Staining Buffer to each tube then  ~Action~ the recommended concentration of anti-BrdU antibody to each tube.
 ~Action~ for 20 minutes at room temperature in the dark Repeat step 6.

Hold at -80°C for 60 min.
Centrifuge the bottles in the Sorvall GSA rotor at 10,000 rpm, 10 min, 4°C.
Discard the supernatants.
Resuspend the pellets with 10 mL each of 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 100 mM NaOAc.
Transfer the material to 30 mL corex tubes.
Add an equal volume of buffer-saturated phenol to each tube.
Mix well and centrifuge in the Sorvall SS34 rotor at 10,000 rpm, 10 min, room temperature.
Remove the upper aqueous layers to clean 30 mL corex tubes.
Precipitate the DNAs with 2X volumes of 100% EtOH.
Hold at -80°C for 45 min.
Centrifuge the tubes in the Sorvall HB-4 rotor at 10,000 rpm, 10 min, 4°C.
Discard the supernatants.
Dry the pellets briefly (10-15 min) in the vacuum  desiccator to remove the EtOH.
Resuspend each plasmid DNA with a total of 10 mL of 1X TE buffer.
Weigh out exactly 6.8 gm of CsCl into each of 2-30 mL corex tubes for each plasmid DNA.
Divide each plasmid DNA solution between the 2 tubes of CsCl, measuring the volume.
Add 1X TE buffer to the tubes of CsCl to a final volume of 6.4 mL added to each  tube.
 ~Action~  ~Modifier~  until all the CsCl is in solution.

High quality DNA extraction from Fungi_small scale
 ~Action~ tissue/spores (10-20mg) in a 2ml eppendorf tube with one metal bead.
 ~Action~ tissue/spores with liquid nitrogen in a precooled tissuelycer.
 ~Action~ 50Hz for 1min.

 ~Action~ 500ul lysis buffer into the powder, briefly vortex, incubate at 64oC for 30 mins Cool on ice for 5 mins.
 ~Action~  ~Action~   ~Action~ at 64oC for 30 mins  ~Action~ on ice for 5 mins.
Add 100 ul (0.2 vol) of KAc 5M,  ~Action~ by inversion,  ~Action~ on ice for max 5 mins.
 ~Action~ at 4oC at max speed for 10 mins.
 ~Action~ supernatant to fresh eppendorf tube containing 500ul (1vol) (P/C/I) and  ~Action~ by inversion for 2 mins.
 ~Action~ at 4 °C and max speed for 10 mins.
 ~Action~ supernatant (~400ul) to fresh eppendorf tube containing 500ul RT isopropanol.
 ~Action~ at RT for 5-10mins.
 ~Action~ at 4 °C and max speed for 30 mins.
Carefully  ~Action~ supernatant with pipette and  ~Action~ with 1mL fresh 70% Ethanol,  ~Action~ several times to  ~Action~ pellet.
 ~Action~ in table top centrifuge for 5mins at 13000g.
 ~Action~ supernatant with pipette and  ~Action~ with 1mL fresh 70% Ethanol,  ~Action~ several times to  ~Action~ pellet.
 ~Action~ in table top centrifuge for 5mins at 13000g.
 ~Action~ supernatant with pipette.
 ~Action~ in table top centrifuge for 1min at 13000g.
 ~Action~ the remaining ethanol with pipette.
 ~Action~ pellet for 7mins.
 ~Action~ 50ul of TE buffer and  ~Action~ the tube slightly for mixing.

BetaMark™ x-42 ELISA Kit (Colorimetric) Protocol
 ~Action~ (2) 1.5mL microcentrifuge tubes as intermediate #1 & 2. (use enclosed tubes). 
 ~Action~ 990uL of standard diluent to intermediate tubes #1 & 2.
 ~Action~ one 20ug vial of 1-42 standard with 80uL of Standard Diluent.
 ~Action~ well by inversion.
 ~Action~ Concentration will be 250ug/mL.
 ~Action~ 30 minutes at room temperature.
Note: During 30 minute incubation; proceed thru the next 3 sections. 
After 30 minutes incubation,  ~Action~ well by inversion,  ~Action~ 
Once reconstituted, standard must be used within the same day.
 ~Action~ 10uL from the vial of reconstituted 1-42 standard to 990uL of standard diluent in intermediate tube #1.
 ~Action~ ell by inversion,  ~Action~ 
 ~Action~ 10ml from intermediate #1 tube and  ~Action~ to 990mL of standard diluent in intermediate #2 tube.
 ~Action~ well by inversion,  ~Action~ 
The final concentration of standard in intermediate tube #2 will be 25ng/mL.
 ~Action~ a 50mL centrifuge tube as “1X Incubation Buffer”. 
Dilute 2X Incubation buffer to 1X by adding 10mL of 2X incubation buffer to 10mL of lab grade water* in the 50mL tube labeled “1X Incubation Buffer”.
*Note: Lab grade filtered water such as injection grade, cell culture grade, Reverse Osmosis De-Ionization (RODI).
 ~Action~ well by  ~Action~ 
This will be diluent for the standard curve and samples.
 ~Action~ a 1L container “1X Wash buffer”.
 ~Action~ 5X wash buffer to 1X for use.
 ~Action~ 125mL of 5X Wash buffer with 500mL of lab grade water for a total volume of 625mL.
 ~Action~ (8) 1.5mL microcentrifuge tubes as #1-8 (use enclosed tubes).
 ~Action~ 240uL of the 1X incubation buffer (made previously in step II) to each of the standard curve tubes (#2-8) and 490mL to tube #1 (standard curve top point).
 ~Action~ 10uL from intermediate #2 and  ~Action~ to 490uL 1X incubation buffer in tube #1 (this will be the top point of the standard curve, final concentration will be 250pg/mL).
 ~Action~ well by inversion,  ~Action~ 
Continue making 1.8 fold serial dilutions by  ~Action~ 300uL of the previous dilution to 240uL of 1X incubationbuffer in tubes #2-7.
 ~Action~ well by inversion between each dilution.
 ~Action~ samples in 1X incubation buffer to 2X concentration.
 ~Action~ well by inversion.
For example, if the final sample dilution should be 1:10,  ~Action~ the sample 1:5 in 1X incubation buffer.
The sample will then be diluted 1:2 in step VII for a final dilution factor of 1:10.
 ~Action~ samples in duplicate or triplicate.
Note: All sample matrices will  ~Action~ differently in the kit.
It is important that you determine the ideal dilutionfor your particular sample type.
It is good practice to run 2-3 dilutions per sample to ensure at least 1 dilution falls within the range of the standard curve.
For most sample types, a good starting dilution would be 1:5-1:10.
Due tothe format of the assay, samples are not able to run neat.

Also  ~Action~ to show the size of the plasmid without insert DNA.

 ~Action~ the gel on a UV light box and photograph the gel.

For further analysis, plasmid DNA may be isolated from those samples that indicate that they have inserts of the appropriate size.

Quick Protocol for Monarch® DNA Gel Extraction Kit (NEB #T1020) Excise the DNA fragment from the agarose gel, taking care to trim excess agarose.
 ~Action~ to a 1.5 ml microfuge tube and weigh the gel slice.
Minimize exposure to UV light.
 ~Action~ 4 volumes of Gel Dissolving Buffer to the gel slice (e.g., 400 μl buffer per 100 μl or 100 mg agarose).
 ~Action~ the sample between 37–55°C (typically 50°C), until the gel slice is completely dissolved (generally 5–10 minutes).
The time that takes a gel slice to melt depends on the size of the slice, the temperature used in the incubation as well as the percent agarose used in the gel.
The time recommended above should be used just as a guideline.
 ~Action~ column into collection tube and load sample onto the column.
 ~Action~ for 1 minute at 16,000 x g, then discard flow-through.
Re-insert column into collection tube.

Discarding flow-through is optional.
Repeat Step 5 (Step 5: Re-insert column into collection tube.

Discarding flow-through is optional).

Use care to ensure that the tip of the column does not come into contact with the flow-through.

We have investigated transformation efficiency throughout the growth curve and found this to be the sweetspot.

After a minimum of 8-12 days, untransformed Phaeodactylum tricornutum cells die off, and colonies of transformed cells begin to appear – in some cases, this can take 3-4 weeks.
Alternatively  ~Action~ can be done in  ~Reagent~ using  ~Reagent~ as a reporter and  ~Action~ using  ~Reagent~  ~Temperature~  ~Temperature~  ~Time~  in LB+antibiotics, for each planned transformation.

Gently  ~Action~ cells using residual volume to  ~Action~ cell pellet.

Stellaris® RNA FISH Protocol for Frozen Tissue
Frozen tissue must be  ~Action~ at a thickness of 4-10 μm using a cryostat and  ~Action~ onto a microscope slide.
 ~Action~ the slide-mounted tissue section to room temperature.
 ~Action~ the slide in fixation buffer for 10 minutes at room temperature.
 ~Action~ with 1 mL of 1X PBS for 2-5 minutes.
 ~Action~ again with 1 mL of 1X PBS for 2-5 minutes.
To permeabilize the tissue section,  ~Action~ the slide in 70% ethanol for at least 1 hour at room temperature.
If frozen before using,  ~Action~ the reconstituted probe solution to room temperature.
 ~Action~ well by  ~Action~  then  ~Action~ briefly.
To prepare the Hybridization Buffer containing probe,  ~Action~  ~Action~ the Hybridization Buffer containing probe, add 1 µL of probe stock solution to 100 µL of Hybridization Buffer, and then  ~Action~ and  ~Action~  which is enough for one coverslip.
This creates a working probe solution of 125 nM.
This solution will be used in the steps below.
 ~Action~ the slide-mounted tissue section in 1X Wash Buffer 1 (see recipe on website) for 2-5 minutes.
 ~Action~ humidified chamber: 150 mm tissue culture plate; a single water-saturated paper towel placed alongside the inner chamber edge.
 ~Action~ the slide from wash buffer, and carefully  ~Action~ away excess buffer surrounding the tissue section.
 ~Action~ 100 µL of Hybridization Buffer containing probe onto the tissue section of the slide.
Carefully  ~Action~ a clean 18 mm square coverglass over the Hybridization Buffer containing probe to completely  ~Action~ the tissue section, and  ~Action~ for even distribution of the solution.
 ~Action~ the slide in the humidified chamber,  ~Action~ with the tissue culture lid, and  ~Action~ with Parafilm.
 ~Action~ in the dark at 37 °C for at least 4 hours.
 ~Action~ the slide in Wash Buffer 1, and  ~Action~ the submerged coverglass to slide off the tissue section.
 ~Action~ in the dark at 37 °C for 30 minutes.
 ~Action~ Wash Buffer 1, and then  ~Action~ DAPI nuclear stain (1X Wash Buffer 1 consisting of 5 ng/mL DAPI) to  ~Action~ the nuclei.
Incubate in the dark at 37 °C for 30 minutes.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ in the dark at 37 °C for 30 minutes.
Decant the DAPI staining buffer, and then  ~Action~ slide in Wash Buffer 2 for 2-5 minutes.
 ~Action~ the slide from Wash Buffer 2, and carefully  ~Action~ excess buffer surrounding the tissue section.
 ~Action~ a small drop (approximately 15 µL) of Vectashield Mounting Medium onto the tissue section, and  ~Action~ with a clean 18 mm square #1 coverglass.
Gently  ~Action~ out excess anti-fade from underneath the coverglass.
 ~Action~ the coverglass perimeter with clear nailpolish, and allow to dry.
Transformation of competent E.coli cells with plasmid DNA
Thaw the appropriate amount of competent cells on ice.
Pre-chill the required number of empty 1.5 ml microcentrifuge tubes.
Pipet 100 µl aliquots of cells into the pre-chilled tubes.
Add 5-10 µl of a ligation reaction mix or 5 ng of pure plasmid DNA to each tube.
 ~Action~ gently!
Incubate the tubes of ice for 30 min. 
 ~Action~  ~Action~ the required number of empty 1.5 ml microcentrifuge tubes.
 ~Action~ 100 µl aliquots of cells into the pre-chilled tubes.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ the appropriate amount of competent cells on ice.
Pre-chill the required number of empty 1.5 ml microcentrifuge tubes.
Pipet 100 µl aliquots of cells into the pre-chilled tubes.
Add 5-10 µl of a ligation reaction mix or 5 ng of pure plasmid DNA to each tube.
Mix gently!

Agrobacterium mediated transformation of Marchantia spores
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the spore heads: 
Get ready: At the flow hood.
 ~Action~ eppendorf tubes, and 3 x 50mL falcon tubes: 1) for sterile water, 2) for Milton solution (1 Milton tablet in 25ml sterile water), and 3) for the washed spores heads.
Use two sporangia per transformation.
Check number of sporangia in the spore head (this is variable, ex there may be only 1 sporangia in one spore head, and 5 sporangia in another spore head).
 ~Action~ the spores heads to an eppendorf tube.
Depending on final number of spore heads needed, you may need to divide them into several eppendorfs tubes.
 ~Action~ 0.5ml Milton solution to each eppendorf tube.
Use a plastic pestle to crush the sporangia and vortex them until completely re-suspended.
 ~Action~ crushed spore heads:
 ~Action~ the 70 μm cell strainer on a 50 ml falcon tube.
 ~Action~ onto the filter the solution with ground sporangia from all eppendfors,  ~Action~ the 0.5 ml from each eppendorf.
The solution with spores will flush through the cell strainer.
 ~Action~ the Eppendorf(s) and strainer with 0.5 ml of Milton solution for each two sporangia used (ex. 3 ml for 12 sporangia).
 ~Action~ the solution with spores in eppendorf tubes (0.5 or 1ml per tube), let them sit for 5 minutes and  ~Action~ for 6-7 minutes at 13000rpm.
 ~Action~ the supernatant and  ~Action~ the spores in each tube with 150 μl of sterile water.  
Plate spores:  ~Action~ the 150 μl of re-suspended spores on a 1/2 GB plate (no antibiotics).
 ~Action~ an L-shaped spreader.
If 0.5 ml aliquots made (equivalent to 2 sporangia), use one plate per transformation.
If 1 ml aliquots made (equivalent to 4 sporangia), use half a plate per transformation.
 ~Action~ upside down (rhizoids will grow away from the media) for 5-6 days at 21 ºC CL 150μE Sporelings (germinated spores) have red fluoresence from chlorophyll autofluorescence after ~ 3 days. 
Agro transformation: 
 ~Action~ DNA and Agro: For each agro transformation,  ~Action~ 20-50ng of plasmid to 50 μL of thawed electrocompetent Agrobacterium cells (kept on ice).
 ~Action~ in a chilled 2 mm cuvette with a 2.5 kV pulse.
Recover Agro: Immediately  ~Action~ 1mL of SOC (or LB) and incubate 1-2h at 28 ºC 150 rpm.
Plate Agro:  ~Action~ 20-50μL on LB plates + antibiotics (Kan 50, Tet 5, for GV2260 with a pGreen plasmid).
Each Agro transformation in a different plate.
 ~Action~ for 3 days at 28 ºC or 30 ºC, incubator. 
Optional Agro colony PCR: all agrobacterium colonies on LB + antibiotics plates should be positive, however if there are some issues with the transformations it may be useful to do a quick screen to check if there are any false positives on the plate.
In that case, do a colony PCR of Agro colonies.
Grow Agro culture:   (~ 15'' – set up sometime in the afternoon) For each Agro transformation  ~Action~ a single colony from plate,  ~Action~ 5 ml LB media + antibiotics (Kan 50, Tet 5 for GV2260 with a pGreen plasmid) in a 15 ml falcon tube (unskirted tube).
 ~Action~ at 28 ºC - 150 rpm (wrap the tubes in foil) and let grow for 1.5 days.

For each agrobacterium culture,  ~Action~ the supernatant and  ~Action~ in 3 ml of 1/2 GB media sup containing 100 μM Acetosyringone.
 ~Action~ acetosyringone to a final concentration of 100 μM (for 3ml media add 3 μl 100 mM stock solution).
 ~Action~ for 6 h at 28 ºC at 150 rpm in the dark (wrap the tubes in foil).
Agro co-Cultivation with sporelings.
 ~Action~ the 6 days old sporelings from the plate using an L shaped spreader,  ~Action~ the sporelings and move them into a 100-250 ml autoclaved flask.
 ~Action~ one plate per flask (transformation) if you plated 2 sporangia per plate, or half a plate if you plated 4 sporangia per plate.
 ~Action~ to each flask 25 ml of 1/2 GB media sup and 25 ul of 100mM Acetosyringone, for a final concentration of 100μM.
To each flask,  ~Action~ 1ml of the appropiate Agrobacterium culture (induced 6 h prior).
Co-cultivate for 2 days (at least 36 h or 1.5 days) on a shaker in the tissue culture room (21 ºC, CL 150-200 uE) Sporelings Collection.

For each co-cultivation flask (transformation),  ~Action~ the sporelings  by pouring the flask contents in a 70 μm cell strainer placed on a 1L bottle.

Quick Protocol for Monarch® DNA Gel Extraction Kit (NEB #T1020)
 ~Action~ the DNA fragment from the agarose gel, taking care to  ~Action~ excess agarose.
 ~Action~ to a 1.5 ml microfuge tube and  ~Action~ the gel slice.
Minimize exposure to UV light.
 ~Action~ 4 volumes of Gel Dissolving Buffer to the gel slice (e.g., 400 μl buffer per 100 μl or 100 mg agarose).
 ~Action~ the sample between 37–55°C (typically 50°C), until the gel slice is completely dissolved (generally 5–10 minutes).
The time that takes a gel slice to melt depends on the size of the slice, the temperature used in the incubation as well as the percent agarose used in the gel.
The time recommended above should be used just as a guideline.
 ~Action~ column into collection tube and  ~Action~ sample onto the column.
 ~Action~ for 1 minute at 16,000 x g, then  ~Action~ flow-through.
 ~Action~ column into collection tube.
 ~Action~ 200 μl DNA Wash Buffer (with ethanol added) and  ~Action~ for 1 minute at 16,000 x g. 
Discarding flow-through is optional.
Repeat Step 5 (Step 5: Re-insert column into collection tube.
 ~Action~ 200 μl DNA Wash Buffer and  ~Action~ for 1 minute at 16,000 x g. 
Discarding flow-through is optional).
 ~Action~ column to a clean 1.5 ml microfuge tube.
Use care to ensure that the tip of the column does not come into contact with the flow-through.
If in doubt,  ~Action~ for 1 minute.
 ~Action~ ≥ 6 μl of DNA Elution Buffer to the center of the matrix.
 ~Action~ for 1 minute, and  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ from the  ~Reagent~  taking care to trim excess  ~Reagent~ 
One-step growth curves for Cellulophaga phages
 ~Action~ a new culture; ie, pick a colony into a new flask containing 10 ml of MLB media.  
Immediately after the transfer, take a ‘time 0’ growth reading. 
Continue taking readings as performed in step 2 periodically. 
Do a plaque assay to determine the PFU/ml of the lysate you plan to use. 
 ~Action~ needed for 107 phages. 
 ~Action~ of your culture at the time you want to start the infection.  
Calculate the volume of host culture needed for 108 cells. 
 ~Action~ this amount into a 1.5 ml tube. 
 ~Action~ 107 phages to the tube and start your timer for 15 minutes to allow the phages to adsorb to the host cells. 
After 15 minutes,  ~Action~ the infection 1:1000 in MLB media in a 250 ml flask. 
Take a sample immediately after dilution – this is ‘time 0’. 
Steps for centrifuged sample: 
Steps for samples that are not centrifuged:  
Continue sampling in this way for 8 hours.   
 ~Action~ the filtered samples at 4°C. 
The next day, count the plaques on all plates that have a countable number of them.  
Decide which dilution gives the best count at each time point for the next time you do this same phage-host pair. 
The next day, count any new plaques that have appeared and add these to your original count. 
 ~Action~ again on the third day. 
Calculate PFU/ml at each time point for both the centrifuged (free phage only) and not centrifuged (total phage) samples Graph the results.

Phenol/chloroform extraction
 ~Action~ your nucleic acid sample to 100–700 µL or  ~Action~ your samples into tubes such that you have no more than 700 µL per tube.
 ~Action~ an equal volume of phenol to the tube,  ~Action~ vigorously to mix the phases.
 ~Action~ in a microfuge at top speed for 1–2 min to separate the phases.
 ~Action~ the aqueous phase to a new tube, being careful not to transfer any of the protein at the phase interface.
Repeat the phenol extraction from step 4.
Repeat the phenol extraction from step 4.
 ~Action~ the sample with an equal volume of chloroform:isoamyl alcohol to remove any trace phenol.
 ~Action~ the sample again with an equal volume of chloroform:isoamyl alcohol to remove any trace phenol.
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ to  ~Amount~ or divide your  ~Reagent~ into  ~Location~ such that you have no more than 700 µL per tube.

Trypsin Digestion
 ~Action~ 6M Urea solution by adding 108.11 mg of Urea to 300 µL of 50mM ammonium bicarbonate (NH4HCO3) containing protein.
 ~Action~ 20 µL of 1.5 M Tris pH 8.8.

 ~Action~ 60 µL of 200mM iodoacetamide and vortex.
 ~Action~ for one hour at room temperature in a dark area.
 ~Action~ 60 µL of 200mM DTT and  ~Action~  ~Action~ 
Incubate for one hour at room temperature in a dark area.
Add 60 µL of 200mM DTT and vortex.
 ~Action~ for one hour at room temperature.
 ~Action~ 150 µL each into three 1.5 mL centrifuge tubes.
 ~Action~ 800 µL of 25mM ammonium bicarbonate to each tube to dilute the urea.
 ~Action~ 200 µL of MeOH to each tube.
 ~Action~ Trypsin to protein at a ratio of 50 protein to 1 trypsin and  ~Action~ overnight at room temperature.
 ~Action~ until dry.
