Roseobacter Screening Of Surface Waters For Viruses
 ~Action~ Roseobacter cultures from freeze and grow in 5 ml broth cultures. 
 ~Action~ virus screening in sterile 96 well flat-bottom tissue culture treated microtiter plates. 
 ~Action~ seawater filtrates at 4°C. 
 ~Action~  ~Action~ in 5 ml broth cultures. 
Perform virus screening in sterile 96 well flat-bottom tissue culture treated microtiter plates. 
Store seawater filtrates at 4°C. 
Absorb the viruses to the bacteria. 
 ~Action~ 15 µl of log phase cells and 15 µl of seawater filtrate (containing virus) into wells of a 96 well plate. 
 ~Action~ the viruses to  ~Action~ to the bacteria for 1 hour. 
 ~Action~ 200 µl growth media (1/2 or 1/10 YTSS) to the wells. 
 ~Action~ the plate with parafilm and  ~Action~ with shaking. 
Look for infected wells that show lysis with respect to uninoculated controls. 
Enrich for viruses by  ~Action~ from initial 96 well plate to another 96-well plate containing fresh liquid media (“frogging” into new wells). 
Once enriched sufficiently,  ~Action~ cells with 0.2um filtration into 1.5ml microfuge tubes  ~Action~ for 5 mins. at max to pellet cells. 
 ~Action~ supernatant to fresh tube for storage.  
 ~Action~ at 4°C.  
Plaque-purify wells containing virus by  ~Action~ cells plus virus on solid media.   
 ~Action~ solid agar media and 0.5% overlay agar. 
 ~Action~ virus to cells using as a starting point, 25 µl virus from 96 well plate enrichments and 200 µl log-phase host bacteria for 1hr. 
 ~Action~ the virus-absorbed cells in the 5 ml overlay agar. 
Pour over the solid media. 
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ for plaque formation. 
 ~Action~ representatives of all plaque types present and  ~Action~ appearance of the plaques. 
 ~Action~ the broth that contains the agar plugs at 4°C and allow the viruses to  ~Action~ of the agar into the broth. 
Once the viruses are plaque-purified they can be scaled-up in 5 ml broth cultures for DNA purification. 
 ~Action~ 25 µl of the plaque-purified virus (agar plug in ~100 µl broth) and  ~Action~ to 200 µl log-phase bacteria for 1 hr. 
Isolation Of Total DNA From NC64A Chlorella
 ~Action~ 500 mL flasks with NC64A chlorella, each flask to contain 360 mL of cells at 1.2 X 106 cells/mL in MBBM.
 ~Action~ the flasks at 25°C for 72 hours, with continuous light and shaking.
 ~Action~ the cells.
 ~Action~ aliquots of NC64A chlorella, each aliquot to contain 6.0 X 109 cells.
If the cells are to be infected with virus, infection should be at an moi (multiplicity of infection) of 3-5.
 ~Action~ the samples in the Sorvall GSA rotor at 5,000 rpm, 5 min, 4°C to harvest the cells.
 ~Action~ the cells 1X with sterile d-H2O in the Sorvall HB-4 rotor at 5,000 rpm, 5 min, 4°C.
 ~Action~ the cells pellets with liquid N2 and  ~Action~ the frozen pellets at -80°C until ready for processing.
 ~Action~ each frozen sample with 5.0 mL of 50 mM NaHPO4, pH 7.4, 2.0 M NaCl.
 ~Action~ the samples at 65°C for 30 min (leave in the MSK flasks during the heating).
 ~Action~ the samples a second time in the MSK for 30 sec with CO2 cooling.
 ~Action~ the homogenates to clean tubes (SS34 plastic tubes).
 ~Action~ a 0.3 mL aliquot from each sample to microfuge tubes for determination of the 			original DNA concentration for each sample (use the fluorometric procedure).
 ~Action~ each sample with 500 µL of proteinase K for 60 min at 37°C (add 200 µL/sample).
 ~Action~ the samples at 65°C for 5 min.
 ~Action~ 20% SDS to each sample to a final concentration of 1% (add 500 µL/sample).
 ~Action~ 2.7 mL of 5 M KOAc to each sample,  ~Action~ well (a final concentration of 1 M).
 ~Action~ the samples in the cold room for 30 min.
 ~Action~ the samples with RNAse at 200 µg/mL for 2 hours at 37°C (add 200 µL/sample).
Precipitate the DNAs in the samples by  ~Action~ 2X volumes of 100% EtOH (approximately 30 mL/sample).
 ~Action~ the tubes in the Sorvall HB-4 rotor at 10,000 rpm, 15 min, 4°C.
 ~Action~ each DNA sample with 3.5 mL of 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 10 mM EDTA.
 ~Action~ the samples overnight at 4°C against several changes of 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 10 mM EDTA.
 ~Action~ 375 µL of 3 M NaOAc to each sample.
 ~Action~ the samples in the Sorvall SS34 rotor at 10,000 rpm, 20 min, 4°C.
 ~Action~ the DNA pellets 1X with 10 mL of 70% EtOH in the Sorvall SS34 rotor at 10,000 rpm, 5 min, 4°C.
 ~Action~ the pellets briefly (10-15 min) in the vacuum desiccator to remove the EtOH.
 ~Action~ the DNA concentration of the samples using the fluorometric procedure.
 ~Action~ CsCl gradients.
 ~Action~ the required volume of cells for each aliquot in the Sorvall GSA rotor at 5,000 rpm, 5 min, 4°C.
 ~Action~ each aliquot with 160 mL of fresh MBBM.
 ~Action~ the flasks for 45-60 min at 25°C for the cells to acclimate to the new media.
 ~Action~ the flasks for the desired length of time at 25°C with continuous light and shaking.
 ~Action~ the supernatants.
 ~Action~ the cells in the MSK mechanical homogenizer with 5.0 gm of 0.3 mm glass beads for 60 sec, with CO2 cooling.
 ~Action~ the glass beads with 50 mM NaHPO4, pH 7.4, 2.0 M NaCl.
 ~Action~ the washes to the homogenates.
 ~Action~ the sample in the Sorvall SS34 rotor at 14,000 rpm, 20 min, 4°C.
 ~Action~ the supernatants to clean tubes.
 ~Action~ at -20°C for 2-3 hours.
 ~Action~ the supernatants.
Precipitate the DNAs by adding an equal volume of isopropanol to each tube.
 ~Action~ well and  ~Action~ at room temperature for 30 min.
 ~Action~ the supernatants.
 ~Action~  ~Size~  ~Location~ with  ~Reagent~  each flask to contain  ~Amount~ of cells at  ~Concentration~ in  ~Reagent~ 
Bottle cleaning procedure for dissolved cobalt analyses
 ~Action~ 60 mL narrow-mouth low density polyethylene bottles (LDPE) for this procedure.
Bottles are  ~Action~ for 10 days in the acidic detergent, Citranox, and  ~Action~ after approximately 5 days to make sure all sides of the bottles have been coated with soap.
The bottles are then  ~Action~ thoroughly with Milli-Q water (usually 5 times, or until all soap is gone), and then  ~Action~ with 10% HCl (new HCl) to  ~Action~ for 10 days (also being rotated after 5 days).
Each bottle is then  ~Action~ thoroughly with pH 2 Milli-Q, and  ~Action~ and  ~Action~  ~Size~  ~Location~ (LDPE) for this procedure.
Plant cell protoplast isolation
 ~Action~ plants of Arabidopsis thaliana (ecotype Col0) on a 3:1 (v/v) compost to vermiculite mixture at 20oC, under short day conditions (12h light:12h dark) and low light intensities (50-100µE m-2 s-1).
 ~Action~ fresh enzyme solution and transfer to glass petridish.
 ~Action~ 20-40 leaves from 4 week old Arabidopsis thaliana rosettes.
 ~Action~ up 5-10 leaves at a time,  ~Action~ into thin (~2mm) strips across the leaf using a sharp scapel blade dipped into ethanol.
 ~Action~ strips into enzyme solution.
 ~Action~ until all leaves have been cut.
 ~Action~ the enzyme solution.
 ~Action~ cells in the petri dish at 20oC without shaking.
Twice filter cells and enzyme solution through a 125μm nylon mesh to remove residual debris into a pointed bottom, glass test tube.
Leave cells to settle to the bottom of the tube.
Carefully aspirate out the liquid solution leaving the cell pellet intact.
Add Incubation Buffer.
Gently resuspend protoplast in incubation solution by light swirling of the test tube.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ protoplast in incubation solution by light  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~ to glass petridish.

Bulk gDNA extraction from coral samples
 ~Action~ sample material.
Small amounts of coral tissue, with or without skeleton, may be obtained by clipping off branch tips, scraping with a razor blade, etc.
 ~Action~ sample to 500 µL 1% SDS in DNAB in a microcentrifuge tube.
Be sure that sample is fully immersed in the buffer.
 ~Action~ sample for 60-90 minutes at 65°C.
Sample is now stabilized for storage at room temperature, and can be treated as an "archive" for future use.
These archives can be used for multiple attempts at DNA extraction.
 ~Action~ 25 µL Proteinase K (10 mg/mL) to sample archive and  ~Action~ well.
 ~Action~ overnight at 37°C, for 6-7 hours at 45°C, or for 2-3 hours at 55°C.
 ~Action~ a new set of 1.5 mL tubes for the samples you intend to process, and  ~Action~ 100 µL of each sample archive (in 1% SDS in DNAB) to the new set of tubes.
 ~Action~ the remainder of the sample archive to storage.
 ~Action~ CTAB mix (stored at -20°C) and  ~Action~ twice volume (200 µL) to each sample.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ at 65°C for 30-60 minutes.
Allow samples to cool.
In fume hood,  ~Action~ equal volume (300 µL) of chloroform.
Be sure to ‘ ~Action~  (i.e.,  ~Action~ and  ~Action~ pipette tip with chloroform 2 to 3 times) the pipette tip before first use, or your tip will leak chloroform.
 ~Action~ sample and  ~Action~ several times, but be careful that caps are tight – leaking chloroform will erase your sample labels!
 ~Action~ in rack on rotating platform for 2-3 hours.
 ~Action~ at 10,000g (RCF) for 10 minutes.
 ~Action~ tubes in centrifuge so that hinges are on the outside.
While spinning,  ~Action~ a new set of labeled 1.5 mL tubes.
 ~Action~ samples from centrifuge and very carefully  ~Action~ top ~250 µL into new tube.
 ~Action~ the rest of the contents into appropriate waste container.
 ~Action~ twice volume (500 µL) of 100% (200-proof) ethanol (EtOH).
Ensure caps are shut tightly and  ~Action~ samples in their rack several times, together with a few brief  ~Action~ to make sure samples are well mixed.
 ~Action~ samples in freezer for at least 2 hours to  ~Action~ DNA precipitation.
If the EtOH is pre-chilled, you can  ~Action~ it in the -20°C freezer for only a 1/2 hour.
 ~Action~ samples in centrifuge ( ~Action~ that the hinges of the tubes are on the outside) and  ~Action~ for 10 minutes at 10,000g (RCF).
 ~Action~ samples from centrifuge and carefully  ~Action~ ethanol from all the tubes into a waste container.
The DNA pellet should  ~Action~ to the inside of the tube.
 ~Action~ tubes, with their caps open, in the Vacufuge/Speedvac.
Be careful when putting the tubes in and  ~Action~ the inside of the caps.
 ~Action~ at 45°C for 30-60 minutes.
 ~Action~ samples from vacufuge and  ~Action~ 100 µL of 0.3 M NaOAc (do not use the stock 3 M solution!).
 ~Action~ sample well to dissolve pellet.
When the pellet is dissolved the sample will appear “syrupy” and will not  ~Action~ around as droplets inside the tube.
Once the pellet is dissolved,  ~Action~ 200uL of 100% Ethanol,  ~Action~ and  ~Action~ several times and  ~Action~ in freezer for at least 2hrs.
 ~Action~ samples from freezer, and  ~Action~ for 10 minutes at 10,000g (RCF).
 ~Action~ supernatant into appropriate waste container.
 ~Action~ 100 µL of 70% Ethanol, and  ~Action~ thoroughly (this is the “Ethanol Wash” step).
 ~Action~ for 10 minutes at 10,000g (RCF), and again  ~Action~ supernatant into appropriate waste container.

Note: Repeating the magnetic separation increases the yield, without a strong impact on the purity.
The yield will typically increase about 8 – 10% with a second separation, and about 2 – 5% with a third separation.
The purity may decrease 1 – 2% with each separation.

Quick Protocol for Monarch® DNA Gel Extraction Kit (NEB #T1020)
 ~Action~ the DNA fragment from the agarose gel, taking care to trim excess agarose.
 ~Action~ to a 1.5 ml microfuge tube and  ~Action~  ~Action~ excess agarose.
Transfer to a 1.5 ml microfuge tube and weigh the gel slice.
Minimize exposure to UV light.
 ~Action~ 4 volumes of Gel Dissolving Buffer to the gel slice (e.g., 400 μl buffer per 100 μl or 100 mg agarose).
 ~Action~ the sample between 37–55°C (typically 50°C), until the gel slice is completely dissolved (generally 5–10 minutes).
The time that takes a gel slice to melt depends on the size of the slice, the temperature used in the incubation as well as the percent agarose used in the gel.
The time recommended above should be used just as a guideline.
 ~Action~ column into collection tube and  ~Action~ sample onto the column.
 ~Action~ for 1 minute at 16,000 x g, then  ~Action~ flow-through.
 ~Action~ column into collection tube.
 ~Action~ 200 μl DNA Wash Buffer (with ethanol added) and  ~Action~ for 1 minute at 16,000 x g. 
Discarding flow-through is optional.
Repeat Step 5 (Step 5: Re-insert column into collection tube.
 ~Action~ 200 μl DNA Wash Buffer and  ~Action~ for 1 minute at 16,000 x g. 
Discarding flow-through is optional).
 ~Action~ column to a clean 1.5 ml microfuge tube.
Use care to ensure that the tip of the column does not come into contact with the flow-through.
If in doubt, re-spin for 1 minute.
 ~Action~ ≥ 6 μl of DNA Elution Buffer to the center of the matrix.
From siRNA to shRNA
 ~Action~ the siRNA sequence (19nt) on your target gene.
 ~Action~ 2nt of upstream +19nt siRNA + 1nt of downstream, which is totally 22nt of nucleotides.
Antisense shRNA:  ~Action~ the reverse complement of the 22nt into shRNA backbone.
Sense shRNA:  ~Action~ the 22nt (from step 2) into shRNA backbone.
 ~Action~ the 1st nt with other nucleotide (replace A with G and vice versa; replace C with T and vice versa).
Now your shRNA designing job is done.
You see, how easy it is!
 ~Action~ the shRNA nucleotides and  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ (19nt) on your  ~Reagent~ 
Extract  ~Amount~ of upstream +19nt siRNA + 1nt of downstream, which is totally 22nt of nucleotides.
Immunoprecipitation Protocol
 ~Action~ cells and  ~Action~ at 1200 rpm for 5 minutes at 4°C.
 ~Action~ protein G agarose beads with cell lysis buffer by  ~Action~ in a microcentrifuge tube (two minutes at 5,000 rpm).
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ supernatant.
 ~Action~ the beads with celllysis buffer (1/3).
 ~Action~ the beads with celllysis buffer (2/3).
 ~Action~ the beads with celllysis buffer (3/3).
Adjust antibody concentration to 5-10 µg/ml in PBS and transfer 500 µl of diluted antibody to 5-10 µl of agarose beads for each sample.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ antibody concentration to 5-10 µg/ml in PBS and transfer 500 µl of diluted antibody to 5-10 µl of agarose beads for each sample.
Place the antibody-protein G agarose mix on a shaker and rotate at 4°C for one hour.
 ~Action~ the protein G beads for two minutes at 5,000 rpm and  ~Action~  ~Action~ at 4°C for one hour.
Spin down the protein G beads for two minutes at 5,000 rpm and wash the antibody-beads three times with cell lysis buffer.
 ~Action~ the supernatant and immediately  ~Action~ 800 µl of ice-cold lysis buffer to the cells and  ~Action~  then  ~Action~ for 30 minutes on ice.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the samples with dry ice for two more cycles or sonicate for 15 seconds to ensure the full  ~Action~ of the proteins from the cells.
 ~Action~ lysates at 14,000 rpm in a pre-cooled centrifuge for 10 minutes and  ~Action~ the supernatant.
 ~Action~ the protein concentration of the supernatant to 1-2 mg/ml with lysis buffer.
 ~Action~ 100-500 µl of cell extract with antibody-protein G agarose and  ~Action~ the samples at 4°C for about two hours.
 ~Action~ the agarose beads by  ~Action~ in a microcentrifuge tube (two minutes at 5,000 rpm, 4°C).
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the supernatant.
 ~Action~ the beads with ice-cold cell lysis buffer (1/3).
 ~Action~ the beads with ice-cold cell lysis buffer (2/3).
 ~Action~  ~Action~ 500 µl of diluted antibody to 5-10 µl of agarose beads for each sample.
Place the antibody-protein G agarose mix on a shaker and rotate at 4°C for one hour.
Spin down the protein G beads for two minutes at 5,000 rpm and wash the antibody-beads three times with cell lysis buffer.
Discard the supernatant and immediately add 800 µl of ice-cold lysis buffer to the cells and vortex, then incubate for 30 minutes on ice.
Freeze and thaw the samples with dry ice for two more cycles or sonicate for 15 seconds to ensure the full release of the proteins from the cells.

Protocol for  transfection of H4, (ATCC®: HTB-148) Cells by FuGENE HD in 96 well plates.
Cell plating H4 (neuroglioma) cells were seeded from 90-100% confluent culture the day before transfection with the density 7,000 cells/well in 100μl complete growth medium (DMEM + 10% Fetal Bovine Serum).
For transfection in 100% Fetal Bovine Serum the complete growth medium was replaced with Fetal Bovine Serum two hours before transfection.

Tissue culture 96-round bottom well plates were used for complex preparation: Prepare 0.02μg/μl pCMVβ DNA solution in OptiMEM® or sterile deionized water.

Nutrient deplete/replete algal culture for elemental analysis
Culture Preparation/GrowthComparative measurements depend on having well-characterized culture growth.
 ~Action~ an experimental culture to allow for at least 7 generations of characterized exponential growth (10 generations is the gold standard) prior to centrifugation and resuspension.
 ~Action~ growth daily, including  ~Action~ to pre-determined mid-exponential density (i.e., semi-continuous culture) until target biomass is reached.
A safe estimate for the target biomass is to assume ~10% recovery of cells after centrifugation and washing (this is strain dependent).
Ensure cell density remains within the exponential range by  ~Action~ culture volume (not cell density) when  ~Action~ to target biomass.
Example Ostreococcus lucimarinus (CCMP2972A) culture preparation:
Growth conditions: 18°C, 14:10 hour light:dark cycle, light irradiance of ~100 µE m-2 s-1.
Growth media: L1 with natural seawater base.
Exponential range: 7x105 – 2x107 cells/mL Day12345678910.

NOTE: Extra-large volumes used for omics experiment Concentration and Resuspension.
When target culture biomass has been reached, split volume evenly among 2 or 4 acid-cleaned and autoclaved centrifuge bottles.
Weigh and balance bottles by removing volume until bottle pairs are within 0.01 g of each other.
Only open bottles in hood to maintain axenicity!
Carry bottles over to Sorvall RC 26 Plus centrifuge.
 ~Action~ centrifuge with large rotor (accomodates 4 centrifuge bottles).
Make sure pins are offset when rotor is placed into the centrifuge.
 ~Action~ paired bottles opposite of each other in the rotor and  ~Action~ the lid.
Spin at the following settings: Rotor = GS-3 (choose option code “03”), Speed = 7300 RPM (equivalent to 10,000 rcf with this large rotor), Time = 0:32 minutes (includes 2 minute ramp up), *strain specificTemp = +20/+25°C, (will try to maintain lower temp, and shut down at max temp).
After the spin, carefully  ~Action~ the bottles back to hood, taking care not to  ~Action~ the cell pellets/smears.
Gently  ~Action~ the supernatant into a waste container, trying to disturb the cell smear as little as possible.
 ~Action~ cells with a volume of nutrient deplete medium equivalent to the initial culture volume in each bottle.
Repeat 2-8.Resuspend cells with a volume of nutrient deplete medium that is ~5% of the initial culture volume in each bottle.
 ~Action~ a sample of the cell concentrate in the Accuri to determine density.
 ~Action~ cells at normal growth conditions during Accuri run and calculations.
Experimental Culture Initiation.
 ~Action~ appropriate volume based on Accuri measurement to  ~Action~ experimental nutrient replete and deplete culture flasks from the cell concentrate at a starting density corresponding to early-exponential growth.
NOTE: It helps to have some amount of media pre-aliquoted to experimental flasks.
 ~Action~ as needed to  ~Action~ target density and volume.
Once all experimental cultures have been inoculated,  ~Action~ and sample for FCM and Accuri measurements to  ~Action~ growth daily.
When the average daily growth rate of the nutrient deplete cultures (GRDEP), is reduced to half or less of the growth rate of the replete cultures (GRDEP/GRREP < 0.5), collect samples for FCM (i.e., cell counts) and elemental analyses (i.e., particulate carbon/nitrogen and phosphorus, as well as dissolved nutrients).

Sorted viral-tagged cells can be subjected to DNA extraction and separation of 15N-labeled “heavy” host DNA from non-labeled “light” viral DNA by CsCl density ultracentrifugation (See "Cesium Chloride Virus Purification and Dialysis"). 
Light DNA can be linker amplified8 for sequencing by 454 Roche Titanium and Illumina HiSeq 2000

MegaLong™ Protocol for Isolation of >100kb Genomic DNA (Blood)
On ice,  ~Action~ 5-400µl blood to a Tube-O-DIALYZER™ and centrifuge at 5,000xg for 5 minutes to  ~Action~  ~Action~ at 5,000xg for 5 minutes to pellet cells.
 ~Action~ the supernatant.
 ~Action~ 500µl Nuclei Isolation Buffer.
 ~Action~ the tube 2-3 times to  ~Action~ the cells,  ~Action~ for 10 minutes on ice.
 ~Action~ the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ cap in a beaker of TE buffer and  ~Action~ at 4°C until required.
 ~Action~ the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ tube with TE buffer.
With a pipette  ~Action~ the supernatant to the Tube-O-DIALYZER™, ensuring the settled cellular debris is left behind.
 ~Action~ a supplied cap on the tube and  ~Action~ at 16,000xg for 5 minutes to  ~Action~ the nuclei.
Carefully  ~Action~ the supernatant and  ~Action~ the tube on a paper towel to  ~Action~ excess supernatant.
 ~Action~ 70µl Suspension Buffer to the nuclei and gently  ~Action~ or  ~Action~ the tube to dislodge the nuclei.
 ~Action~ the LongLife™ Proteinase K and  ~Action~ 10µl to the nuclei.
 ~Action~ 70µl Digestion Buffer and  ~Action~ with gentle  ~Action~ 
Incubate at 55°C for 2-4 hours with periodic  ~Action~  ~Action~ at 55°C for 2-4 hours with periodic rocking.
Do not vortex.
After digestion is complete,  ~Action~ the tube for 20 seconds at 1,000g.
 ~Action~ the cap with the dialysis cap.
Do not discard the storage cap as this will be required for storage of DNA.
 ~Action~ the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ upside down in a 50ml centrifuge tube and  ~Action~ at 1000xg for 30 seconds to bring the sample onto the dialysis membrane.
 ~Action~ the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ from the 50ml tube with forceps and keeping it inverted slide into the provided float and  ~Action~ in 500ml 1X TE buffer at room temperature for 18-24 hours with 2-3 buffer changes.
Gently  ~Action~ tube to  ~Action~ contents at each buffer change.
Following dialysis the genomic DNA may be  ~Action~ in the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ using either Tube-O-DIALYZER™ Concentrator (Cat. # 786-144) or Concentrator Solution (Cat. # 786-143).
Simply  ~Action~ the Concentrator as per the instructions and  ~Action~ the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ containing your DNA in the solution.
If concentration is not required or following concentration,  ~Action~ the tube at 1000xg for 1 minute.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ 
After digestion is complete, centrifuge the tube for 20 seconds at 1,000g.

YES Rich Medium
 ~Action~ 5.0 g Yeast Extract to a 1 Liter Erlenmeyer Flask.
 ~Action~ 30 g Glucose or Dextrose to the flask.
 ~Action~ 0.25 g Adenine to the flask.
 ~Action~ 0.25 g Uracil to the flask.
 ~Action~ 0.25 g Histidine to the flask.
 ~Action~ 0.25 Leucine to the flask.
 ~Action~ 0.25 g Lysine to the flask.
 ~Action~ 1 g Arginine to the flask.
Optional: For solid medium  ~Action~ 20 g Difco Bacto Agar to the flask.
 ~Action~ the flask with water up to the 1 Liter mark on the flask.
 ~Action~ a magnetic stir bar into the flask and place the flask on a magnetic stirrer to dissolve the powder into the water.
 ~Action~ the stir bar with a magnetic rod.
 ~Action~ aluminum foil over the top of the flask and then autoclave on a liquid cycle for 20 minutes.
If solid medium,  ~Action~ while still hot into plates and let them sit out to cool overnight on the lab bench.
If liquid medium,  ~Action~  ~Action~ them  ~Action~  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~ to a  ~Size~  ~Location~

Filtering for Cell Collection
Pump → Steel filter tank → A/E filter → Durapore → DI rinsed cubie container (the one the sample was in).  
 ~Action~ all tubes to manifolds and filter tanks.  
Make sure bleeder valves are on top. 
Turn on pump and then bleed A/E then Durapore and the A/E again.  
 ~Action~ cubie container on ice- water will be used for viral concentration.   
 ~Action~ “out” tube from Durapore onto a filter flask that is attached to the vacuum side of the pump.  
Wait until water stops moving towards the vacuum and only bubbles are coming through.   
 ~Action~ steel filter tank lid and slowly  ~Action~ tank bleeder valve to depressurize (SLOWLY). 
When pressure has dropped significantly push in steel tank lid, allow a few more minutes for water to drain through.  
 ~Action~ clamp from bottom side of A/E filter,  ~Action~ tube from “out” side of A/E.  
 ~Action~ Durapore on knees and swirl gently so all water goes into the filter flask. 
Once water is out, open manifold slowly, fold up filter and place in whirlpack. 
 ~Action~ Durapore “out” tube from filter flask, place A/E “out” tube onto filter flask.   
 ~Action~ A/E on knees, let water drain out into the filter flask as before. 
 ~Action~  ~Location~ to manifolds and filter tanks.  
Make sure bleeder valves are on top.

Usually no incubation is required; however, if cell clumps are visible after mixing,  ~Action~ at 37°C for 5‐10 minutes or until the solution is homogenous.

Extraction of surface-community DNA from Ulva sp.
This method performs a direct lysis of the microbial community on the algal surface followed by an organic extraction and precipitation of the microbial DNA.
Ulva plants do get damaged during the treatment, however eukaryotic microbes might be lysed.
Therefore microscopic check of the algal surface before treatment and removal of basal parts (old and most likely covered by secondary colonisers) is necessary.
 ~Action~ several Ulva sp. plants by hand from intertidal pool and  ~Action~ into a plastic bag container with sea water (from the same site).
 ~Action~ into the laboratory asap.
 ~Action~ plants into sterile washing bowl container with a bit of CMFSW and  ~Action~ the buttom part (2-3 cm) of the plant with a sterile knife and forceps.
 ~Action~ the plant into piece of roughly 2-4 cm length width.
 ~Action~ plant pieces 3 times for 1-2 min with CMFSW; make sure smaller bits and non-plant material get wash away.
Take a couple of random pieces and  ~Action~ a microscopic observation on it: ~Action~ Ulva piece onto glass slidecover Ulva piece with approx. 10 µl of live stain.
 ~Action~ on cover slip and  ~Action~ excessive liquid with a tissue.
 ~Action~ under fluorescent microscope.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ surface coverage of cells.
Using a balance  ~Action~ out 12 g of plant wet-weight (drip dry) into a petri dish.
 ~Action~ 12 g of plant into a sterile 50 ml Falcon tube with 30 ml of CMFSW and 300 µl of 3M Multi Enzyme Cleaner;  ~Action~ gently to make sure the plant surface is covered with the CMFSW cleaner mix.
 ~Action~ at room temperature.
 ~Action~ microscopy after 30 min (see point 6).
If surface shows little cells left or is cleared, then go to point 12.
Otherwise continue incubation (total 1 hour or 2 hours), until most cells on the plant surface are remove.
 ~Action~ liquid into 1 or 2 new 50ml Falcon tubes (file tubes not more than 20 ml); make sure no plant material is being transferred, optional the liquid can be filtered through a sterile 125 µm sieve of a 0.8 µm filter.
 ~Action~ an equal volume of phenol chloroform isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1) to the supernatant and  ~Action~ gently but thoroughly.
 ~Action~ for 5 min at 2000 x g.
 ~Action~ aqueous phase into a SS34 tubes.
 ~Action~ 1/10 volume of 3M sodium acetate and 3 volumes of 95% ethanol.
 ~Action~ gently but thoroughly; note: a white precipitate will become visible.
 ~Action~ at –20oC for at least 2 hours.
 ~Action~ for 30 min at 20 000 x g.
 ~Action~ supernatant.
 ~Action~ 10 ml of 70% ethanol to pellet.
 ~Action~ for 5 min at 20 000 x g.
 ~Action~ supernatant and air-dry pellet.
 ~Action~ pellet in 0.5 ml sterile water and  ~Action~ into 2 ml microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ 1/10 volume of 3M sodium acetate and 3 volumes of 95% ethanol.
 ~Action~ gently but thoroughly; note: a white precipitate will become visible.
 ~Action~ at –20oC for at least 2 hours.
 ~Action~ for 30 min at 20 000 x g.
 ~Action~ supernatant.
 ~Action~ 1 ml of 70% ethanol to pellet.
 ~Action~ for 5 min at 20 000 x g.
 ~Action~ supernatant and air-dry pellet.
 ~Action~ pellet into 50-100µl TE-buffer.
 ~Action~  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~  ~Method~ from  ~Location~ and transfer into a  ~Location~  ~Modifier~ (from the same site).
Basic electron microscopy of aquatic viruses
For high-resolution images, samples should be sterile and free from bacteria and other large particles.
 ~Action~ through membrane filters of 0.22–0.45 µm pore size.
 ~Action~ in a buffer, e.g., 0.1 M ammonium acetate (pH 7), in an ultracentrifuge with a fixed-angle rotor (25,000g or 25,000 rpm for 1 h).
 ~Action~ a drop of virus suspension on a grid  ~Action~ for 30s for adsorption of viruses. 
 ~Action~ a drop of stain. 
 ~Action~ liquid using filter paper. 
 ~Action~ transmission electron microscopes (TEMs) at 60–80 kV. 
 ~Action~  ~Device~ of  ~Size~ pore size.
Cas9 RNP nucleofection for cell lines using Lonza 4D Nucleofector
 ~Action~ 100 pmol of Cas9 to a final volume of 5 µL using Cas9 buffer (20 mM HEPES-KOH pH 7.5, 150 mM KCl, 10% glycerol, 1 mM TCEP).
For 40 µM stock: 2.5 µL.
 ~Action~ 120 pmol sgRNA to a final volume of 5 µL using Cas9 buffer.
This means you will need a minimum sgRNA concentration of 24uM.
 ~Action~ Cas9 to sgRNA slowly while swirling pipette tip, should take 30s to 1 minute.
Allow RNP to  ~Action~ for 10-20 minutes.
 ~Action~ cells.
(Trypsinize as needed.)
For each nucleofection,  ~Action~ 200k cells into a 15 mL conical.
 ~Action~ 100 x g for 10 minutes to pellet cells softly.
While the cells are spinning,  ~Action~ plate and cuvette.
 ~Action~ a 12-well-plate with 1mL media per well, and  ~Action~ in the incubator.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ wells on 20uL nucleofection strips.
 ~Action~ Lonza 4d using recommended cell-type program.
 ~Action~ media from cells, gently but completely, using a P200.
The pellet is very soft so be careful.
 ~Action~ cells in 20 µL of nucleofector solution (usually SF media) using a P200.
 ~Action~ the entire 10 µL RNP mix to the 20 µL resuspension and  ~Action~ 
 ~Action~ 1uL of 100uM donor DNA (100 pmoles) and  ~Action~ well.
 ~Action~ nucleofection mixes to the multiwell cuvette, and  ~Action~ 
Pay attention to the orientation of the cap and cuvette in the nucleofector, which is noted in the manufacturer’s instructions.
 ~Action~ cuvette into nucleofector and  ~Action~ 
Allow cells to sit in nucleofection strips for 10 minutes post-nucleofection.
This is supposed to increase efficiency.
 ~Action~ 80uL of pre-warmed media to each well.
 ~Action~ mixture out with a P200 into your pre-warmed 12-well plate.
This should get the vast majority of cells, but if you wish, you may wash out the rest with media from the same well, chemistry-style.
Allow cells 24 hours to  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Amount~ of  ~Reagent~ to a final volume of  ~Amount~ using  ~Reagent~ ( ~Amount~  ~Reagent~  ~pH~   ~Amount~  ~Reagent~   ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~   ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~  ~Measure-Type~ of 5 µL using Cas9 buffer (20 mM HEPES-KOH pH 7.5, 150 mM KCl, 10% glycerol, 1 mM TCEP).
For 40 µM stock: 2.5 µL.
Swift™ Membrane Stain
Following protein transfer to a membrane,  ~Action~ the membrane in a suitable tray.
a. For PVDF Membranes: 
 ~Action~ 20ml 100% methanol and  ~Action~ for 10‐30 seconds.
 ~Action~ the methanol and immediately  ~Action~ 12ml Swift™ Membrane Stain.
b. For Nitrocellulose Membranes: 
 ~Action~ 20ml deionized water and  ~Action~ for 30 seconds.
 ~Action~ the wash and  ~Action~ 12ml Swift™ Membrane Stain.
 ~Action~ the trays on a rocking shaker.
Protein bands appear in ~30 seconds.
 ~Action~ the membrane in DI water to remove the staining solution for improved image capture by scanning or photography.
For rapid de‐staining of the membranes,  ~Action~ the membrane in DI water to remove staining solution.
 ~Action~ the membranes for 30‐60 seconds in 50ml 1X Swift™ Destain, or until the stain has been removed.
Once de‐stained,  ~Action~ in DI water and  ~Action~  ~Device~ in a suitable  ~Location~ 
MojoSort™ Isolation Kits Regular Protocol
 ~Action~ cells from your tissue of interest without  ~Action~ erythrocytes.
In the final wash of your sample preparation,  ~Action~ the cells in MojoSort™ Buffer by  ~Action~ up to 4 mL in a 5 mL (12 x 75 mm) polystyrene tube.
Note: Keep MojoSort™ Buffer on ice throughout the procedure.
 ~Action~ the cells with a 70 μm cell strainer,  ~Action~ at 300 x g for 5 minutes, and  ~Action~ in an appropriate volume of MojoSort™ Buffer.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the cell concentration to 1 x 108 cells/mL.
 ~Action~ 100 μL of cell suspension (107 cells) into a new tube.
 ~Action~ 10 μL of the Biotin-Antibody Cocktail,  ~Action~ well and  ~Action~ on ice for 15 minutes.
 ~Action~ up the volume accordingly if separating more cells.
For example,  ~Action~ 100 μL for 1 x 108 cells.
When working with less than 107 cells, use indicated volumes for 107 cells.

Fingerprinting aquatic virus communities using pulsed field gel electrophoresis (PFGE)
 ~Action~ the 1.5% agarose and the lysis buffer.
 ~Action~ the agarose at 80°C until further use.
 ~Action~ 5 mL of the freshly made lysis buffer into 50-mL Falcon tubes, one for each sample.
 ~Action~ equal volumes (200 µL) of virus concentrate and molten 1.5% agarose.
 ~Action~ briefly.
 ~Action~ the mixture into plug molds with a pipette.
 ~Action~ the plug molds in the freezer (–20°C) for at least 2 min to set.
 ~Action~ the tape from the bottom of the plug molds and  ~Action~ the plugs out from the molds into 5 mL lysis buffer.
 ~Action~ the plugs in lysis buffer overnight in the dark at 30°C.
The next day,  ~Action~ the lysis buffer using a plastic sieve (screened cap) that can be attached at the top of the Falcon tube.
 ~Action~ the plugs three times, 30 min each, in TE buffer 10:1 at room temperature.
The plugs can be stored at 4°C in TE 20:50 for several month before further processing; nevertheless, we recommend running the samples as soon as possible, because degradation of the viral DNA will occur and result in less discrete bands.
 ~Action~ the gel rig.
 ~Action~ a 1% agarose gel in 1× TBE buffer.
 ~Action~ until the agarose is completely dissolved.
 ~Action~ the warm agarose at 60°C for 10 min before pouring into the gel rig and allowing it to cool.
 ~Action~ ~5 mL agarose at 60°C for later use to seal the wells.
When the agarose is set,  ~Action~ 50 mL of 1× TBE running buffer on the top of the gel and  ~Action~ it in the refrigerator for at least 20 min or overnight.
 ~Action~ molecular weight standards (slices of ~5 mm) on either side of the gel.
 ~Action~ the samples between the markers using a sterile loop.
 ~Action~ the wells with leftover molten 1% agarose.
 ~Action~ the gel from the pouring rig and  ~Action~ any extraneous agarose from the bottom and edges.
 ~Action~ the 1× TBE (running buffer) and  ~Action~ at 14°C until further use.
 ~Action~ the gel into the electrophoresis chamber and carefully  ~Action~ the cooled 1× TBE running buffer into the chamber.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ at 4°C in TE 20:50 for several month before further processing; nevertheless, we recommend running the samples as soon as possible, because degradation of the viral DNA will occur and result in less discrete bands.
Set up the gel rig.
One-step Phage Infection of Cyanobacteria (large-scale)
Before T0, use flow cytometry to  ~Action~ cell concentrations of cyanobacterial cultures from Step 2.
Use SYBR staining (e.g. SYBR counts of viruses) to  ~Action~ concentration of your concentrated viral lysate from Step 1.
 ~Action~ volumes of cells, phage and media to  ~Action~ to each experimental bottle/tube.
We have an Excel template to do this calculation, based on the desired MOI, cell concentration, and final experimental culture volume.
For gene expression experiments, we use an MOI of 3, final cell density of 5e7/ml, and volume of 200ml for each replicate -- this scale allows us to sample for RNA, protein, and phage & cell concentration, over a 12-14 hour time course.
Working quickly, and with sterile technique, initialize experiment by  ~Action~ volumes (calculated in Step 3) of media, cells, and phage.
First  ~Action~ appropriate volume of sterile medium to your experimental culture vessel (e.g. sterile 250ml polycarbonate bottles for 200ml cultures).
Then  ~Action~ cells (prepared in Step 2).
Then, to uninfected control bottles,  ~Action~ lysate that has been filtered to  ~Action~ phage particles (e.g. the filtrate that goes through an Amicon centrifugal device).
[This is important to control for small molecules that may be added with the phage particles in infected treatments; however keep in mind that other large molecules will get retained, along with phage particles, in the Amicon reservoir.]
Finally, just before T0,  ~Action~ phage to their respective bottles.
This begins the one-step infection.
 ~Action~ bottles by gentle  ~Action~ 
Sample immediately for time 0.
Suggested sampling: FCM for cell counts, Fluorescence, extracellular phage, RNA-protein.
 ~Action~ bottles in incubator until next time point.
 ~Action~ sampling in Step 5 at each time point (e.g. every 1-2 hours) until lysis is complete.
 ~Action~ cells for infection:  ~Action~ sufficiently large volumes of cells to be infected.
Plan carefully so that cells are in mid-log phase on the day of the experiment.
If you are growing volumes of 1L or more,  ~Action~ your culture with an aquarium pump (ambient air) connected to a diffuser stone, to prevent CO2 limitation.
 ~Action~ phage stockGrow: On day minus-8,  ~Action~ phage stock to 4L of mid-log cells to  ~Action~ the infection (a low MOI is sufficient, e.g. 0.01-0.05), and  ~Action~ for about a week until the culture clears.
Harvest: When the culture has cleared (i.e. most cells have lysed), centrifuge the cleared culture (max speed, 10 min) to  ~Action~  ~Action~ the cleared culture (max speed, 10 min) to remove large cell debris and unlysed cells.
 ~Action~ supernatant (containing phage) into disposable sterile vacuum filtration units containing a 0.2µm PES filter;  ~Action~ the pellet containing cell debris.
 ~Action~ to vacuum source and  ~Action~ the lysate; save filtrate containing your phage particles.
Concentrate:  ~Action~ this clarified phage lysate using VivaFlow Concentration of Phage Lysate.
Further  ~Action~ the phage stock, and  ~Action~  ~Device~ to measure  ~Measure-Type~ of  ~Reagent~ from  ~Method~

Luminex Bead Coupling
 ~Action~ the bead stock suspension to yield a homogeneous bead suspension.

 ~Action~ the 100 μl bead suspension at 10,000 x g.

 ~Action~ the beads in 80 μl activation buffer.
 ~Action~ 10 μl of S-NHS solution and 10 μl of EDC solution to the bead suspension.
 ~Action~ with agitation at room temperature in the dark at roughly 900 rpm.
 ~Action~ your protein stock solution with coupling buffer to a concentration of 0.1 mg/ml in a volume of 100 μl.
Optimal coupling may occur at a concentration within 25-250 μg/ml.
Note the protein stock cannot have any other amine groups present.

Carefully  ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the supernatant.

Subcellular Fractionation from Liver or Brain Soft Tissues (FOCUS™ SubCell Kit)
OPTIONAL: Delipidated BSA can be added to 1X SubCell Buffer‐II to the concentration of 2mg/ml for removing free fatty acids prior to processing.
An appropriate amount of protease inhibitor cocktail can be added to the 1X SubCell Buffer‐II just before use.
Use a fresh tissue sample (obtained within one hour of sacrifice) kept on ice.
 ~Action~ 
 ~Action~ approximately 50‐100mg tissue.

 ~Action~ steps 4-7 on ice.
 ~Action~ the minced tissue to an ice‐cold Dounce tissue homogenizer.
 ~Action~ on ice for 2 minutes.
 ~Action~ the homogenate to a centrifuge tube and  ~Action~ large chunks of tissue fragments in the homogenizer to be discarded.
 ~Action~ the sample at 700x g for 5 minutes to pellet the nuclei.
Carefully  ~Action~ the supernatant into a new tube.
 ~Action~ supernatant at 12,000xg for 10 minutes.
 ~Action~ the supernatant (post mitochondria) to a new tube and  ~Action~ the pellet in 10 volumes of 1X SubCell Buffer II without BSA.
 ~Action~ the sample at 700x g for 5 minutes to pellet the nuclei.
Carefully  ~Action~ the supernatant into a new tube.
 ~Action~ supernatant at 12,000xg for 10 minutes and  ~Action~ the supernatant.
The pellet contains mitochondria.
 ~Action~ the mitochondrial pellet in Working Mitochondria Storage Buffer (approximately 50μl for pellet from ~100mg tissue) and keep the suspension on ice before downstream processing.
The suspension may be stored on ice for up to 48 hours.
Enrichment of other cell organelles: The post mitochondria supernatant from step 12 can be further fractionated using a variety of gradient and differential centrifugations.
 ~Action~ 10 volumes of 1X SubCell Buffer‐II and using a loose‐fitting pestle,  ~Action~ the tissue with 5‐10 strokes or until the tissue sample is completely homogenized.
Using a tight‐fitting pestle,  ~Action~ the nuclei with 8‐10 strokes.

How to make a 20 mg/mL X-Gluc Stock Solution

Ki-67 Staining Protocol
Prepare 70% ethanol and chill at -20°C.
Prepare target cells of interest and wash 2X with PBS by centrifuge at 350xg for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ and  ~Action~ the cell pellet by  ~Method~  ~Reagent~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Generic-Measure~ ethanol and chill at -20°C.
Prepare target cells of interest and wash 2X with PBS by centrifuge at 350xg for 5 minutes.
Discard supernatant and loosen the cell pellet by vortexing.
Add 3 ml cold 70% ethanol drop by drop to the cell pellet while vortexing.
Continue vortexing for 30 seconds and then incubate at -20°C for 1 hour.
Wash 3X with BioLegend’s Cell Staining Buffer (Cat. No. 420201) and then resuspend the cells at the concentration of 0.5-10 x 106/ml.
MojoSort™ Mouse NK Cell Isolation Kit Protocol
 ~Action~ cells from your tissue of interest without lysing erythrocytes.
In the final wash of your sample preparation,  ~Action~ the cells in MojoSort™ Buffer by  ~Action~ up to 4mL in a 5 mL (12 x 75 mm) polystyrene tube.
Note: Keep MojoSort™ Buffer on ice throughout the procedure.
 ~Action~ the cells with a 70 μm cell strainer,  ~Action~ at 300 x g for 5 minutes, and  ~Action~ in anappropriate volume of MojoSort™ Buffer.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the cell concentration to 1 x 108 cells/mL.
 ~Action~ 100 μL of cell suspension (107 cells) into a new tube.
 ~Action~ 10 μL of the Biotin-Antibody Cocktail,  ~Action~ well and  ~Action~ on ice for 15 minutes.
 ~Action~ up the volume accordingly if separating more cells.
For example,  ~Action~ 100 μL for 1 x 108 cells.
When working with less than 107 cells, use indicated volumes for 107 cells.
Optional: Keep unused cells, or take an aliquot before adding the cocktail to monitor purity and yield.
 ~Action~ the beads by  ~Action~  maximum speed, 5 touches.
 ~Action~ 10 μL of Streptavidin Nanobeads.
 ~Action~ well and  ~Action~ on ice for 15 minutes.
 ~Action~ up the volume accordingly if separating more cells.
For example, add 100 μL for 1 x 108 cells.
When working with less than 107 cells, use indicated volumesfor 107 cells.
 ~Action~ the cells by  ~Action~ 3 mL of MojoSort™ Buffer;  ~Action~ at 300 x g for 5 minutes,  ~Action~ supernatant.
Optional: Take an aliquot before placing the tube in the magnet to monitor purity and yield.
 ~Action~ the cells in 3 mL of MojoSort™ Buffer.
Note: If you observe aggregates, filter the suspension.
To maximize yield, you can disrupt the aggregates by  ~Action~  ~Action~ the aggregates by pipetting the solution up and down.
 ~Action~ the tube in the magnet for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ from your tissue of interest without lysing erythrocytes.
In the final wash of your sample preparation, resuspend the cells in MojoSort™ Buffer by adding up to 4mL in a 5 mL (12 x 75 mm) polystyrene tube.
Note: Keep MojoSort™ Buffer on ice throughout the procedure.
Filter the cells with a 70 μm cell strainer, centrifuge at 300 x g for 5 minutes, and resuspend in anappropriate volume of MojoSort™ Buffer.
Count and adjust the cell concentration to 1 x 108 cells/mL.
Aliquot 100 μL of cell suspension (107 cells) into a new tube.
Add 10 μL of the Biotin-Antibody Cocktail, mix well and incubate on ice for 15 minutes.
Stellaris® RNA FISH 96 Well Glass Bottom Plate Protocol
 ~Action~ cells in a 96-well glass bottom cell culture plate.
 ~Action~ growth medium, and  ~Action~ with 200 μL of 1X PBS.
To fix cells,  ~Action~ 200 μL of 3.7% Formaldehyde fixation solution.
 ~Action~ at room temperature for 10 minutes.
 ~Action~ with 200 μL of 1X PBS.
 ~Action~ with 200 μL of 1X PBS.
The Alternative Fixation steps are an alternative to the standard fixation and are not meant to be sequential.
 ~Action~ cells in a 96-well glass bottom cell culture plate. 
 ~Action~ growth media, and  ~Action~ with 200 μL of 1X PBS To fix and permeabilize cells,  ~Action~ 200 μL of methanol-acetic acid (MeOH-AcOH) fixation solution.
 ~Action~ at room temperature for 10 minutes.
Cells can be stored at +2 to +8 °C in MeOH-AcOH up to 48 hours before hybridization.
Do not use a well if the MeOH-AcOH has completely evaporated.
If frozen before using, warm the reconstituted probe stock to room temperature.
 ~Action~ well by  ~Action~  then  ~Action~ briefly.
To prepare the Hybridization Buffer containing probe,  ~Action~ 1.5 μL of probe stock solution to 75 μL of Hybridization Buffer, and then vortexand centrifuge (enough for one well).
This creates a working probe solution of 250 nM.
This solution will be used on step 17.
 ~Action~ MeOH-AcOH or 70% ethanol from wells containing adherent cells.
 ~Action~ 200 μL of Wash Buffer A (see recipe above), and  ~Action~ at room temperature for 2-5 minutes.
 ~Action~ Wash Buffer A Add 75 μL of Hybridization Buffer containing Probe into each well.
 ~Action~ in the dark at 37 °C for 4 to 16 hoursa).
Incubation is recommended for 16 hours using the Standard Fixation Methodb).
Incubation is recommended for 2 hours using the Alternative Fixation Method.
 ~Action~ the Hybridization Buffer containing Probe, and  ~Action~ 200 μL of Wash Buffer A.
 ~Action~ in the dark at 37 °C for 30 minutes.
 ~Action~ Wash Buffer A, and then  ~Action~ 200 μL of DAPI nuclear stain (Wash Buffer A consisting of 5 ng/mL DAPI) to counterstain the nuclei.
 ~Action~ in the dark at 37 °C for 30 minutes.
 ~Action~ DAPI staining buffer, and then  ~Action~ 200 μL of Wash Buffer B.
 ~Action~ at room temperature for 2-5 minutes.
 ~Action~ 30 μL of VectaShield Mounting Medium to the well and  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ in a  ~Modifier~  ~Modifier~  ~Location~

Extracting nucleic acids from viruses on a filter
 ~Action~ 1 mL T + C lysis buffer containing 100 µg/ml proteinase K to a low-volume (1–3 cc) syringe that has been fitted with a female–female Luer-Lok adapter (the injection syringe).
 ~Action~ that there is minimal air in the injection syringe-adapter assembly, then  ~Action~ it to the outlet of the filter.
 ~Action~ a second low-volume syringe to the filter inlet (the aspiration syringe).
 ~Action~ the filter-syringe assembly vertically with the injector syringe pushing upward from below.
 ~Action~ the filter securely to the injection syringe and gently, but firmly,  ~Action~ extraction buffer into the filter housing until liquid just begins to appear in the aspiration syringe.
 ~Action~ the assembly (filter with two syringes attached) for 15 min at 65°C in a hybridization oven.
Allow the syringe-filter assembly to  ~Action~ briefly.
 ~Action~ the extract by  ~Action~ the syringe assembly vertically with the aspiration syringe underneath (and the filter upside down) and gently pulling on the plunger to pull the extract into the aspiration syringe.
 ~Action~ the aspiration syringe.
 ~Action~ the extract to a microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ on ice for 2–3 minutes.
 ~Action~ one-half volume of MPC protein precipitation reagent (supplied in the kit) and  ~Action~ for 10 s.
 ~Action~ the debris by centrifugation at 10,000g for 10 min.
 ~Action~ the supernatant (containing the nucleic acids) to a sterile microcentrifuge tube; be very careful to avoid the pellet (containing the SDS-protein complex).
 ~Action~ up to 800 µl of the sample to a fresh tube;  ~Action~ 1 µl polyacryl carrier, and  ~Action~ briefly.
 ~Action~ 1 µl polyacryl carrier, and  ~Action~ briefly.
 ~Action~ an equal volume of 100% isopropanol.
 ~Action~ by  ~Action~ the tube several times.
 ~Action~ the sample at ≥10,000g for 15–45 min.
 ~Action~ or  ~Action~ the supernatant.
 ~Action~ the pellet twice, each time  ~Action~ 70% ethanol,  ~Action~ for 1 min, and  ~Action~ (or aspirating) the ethanol.
 ~Action~ the pellet, then  ~Action~  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~ containing  ~Concentration~ proteinase K to a low-volume (1–3 cc) syringe that has been fitted with a female–female Luer-Lok adapter (the injection syringe).
Ensure that there is minimal  ~Reagent~  ~Modifier~ air in the  ~Location~  then connect it to the  ~Device~ of the filter.
Gambierdiscus Whole Cell Hybridization
 ~Action~ Prehybridization/ Hybridization Buffer.
The Promega filtration manifold has a 14-sample capacity.
The following recipe prepares buffer for 15 samples.
In a 50 mL centrifuge tube labeled “prehybridization” buffer  ~Action~  20.4 mL Milli-Q water 6.0 mL 25X SET 300 μL 10% IGEPAL CA-630 300 μL Poly A 10 mg/mL (3-10 freezer in Styrofoam box) 3.0 mL Formamide* (in flammable refrigerator/freezer in 3-30). 
 ~Action~ hybridization buffer: Probe working stock concentration = 200 ng/μL.
For each sample,  ~Action~ 1 mL buffer + 10 μL working stock probe.

 ~Action~ this for each of the virus samples. 
Using a 12x300 µL multi-channel pipettor set at 30 µL with 12 tips attached,  ~Action~ row H up and down to  ~Action~ the dilution. 
 ~Action~ the tips and pipette 30 µL from row H into row A (the 10-2 row). 
 ~Action~ several times to mix. 
 ~Action~ the tips and transfer 30 µL into row B (10-3 row). 
 ~Action~ this mixing, replacing tips and transferring 4 more times until you are at row F (10-7 row).   
Using a 12x300 µL multi-channel pipettor set to 30 µL with 8 tips attached,  ~Action~ 30 µL host cells into all appropriate wells of the sample plate.  
 ~Action~ the pipettor to dispense 20 µL,  ~Action~ 8 fresh tips and  ~Action~ 20 µL from the virus dilution plate to the same corresponding column in the sample test plate.

Make sure the EPPS is fully dissolved, and then  ~Action~ the  ~Reagent~  ~Amount~  ~Amount~  ~Action~ 22 g of  ~Reagent~ directly into a  ~Amount~ trace metal clean  ~Location~  ~Modifier~  ~Modifier~  ~Modifier~ metal clean bottle.
General protocol for the concentration of virioplankton from a large volume (>20 L) water sample
 ~Action~ ambient water sample with a 25-µm wound polypropylene sediment filter before any concentration using a peristaltic or diaphragm pump.
 ~Action~ the concentration container three times with prefiltered water before filling with prefiltered sample water.
Once the concentration container is full of 25 µm prefiltered ambient water,  ~Action~ the tubing for tangential flow filtration (TFF).
 ~Action~ the 0.22-µm tangential flow filtration (TFF) filter feed and  ~Action~ tubing to the TFF filter housing inlet and outlet ports, respectively.
 ~Action~ the permeate tubing to the permeate port of the TFF filter housing and  ~Action~ into a separate container to catch virus-containing water.
 ~Action~ the feed tubing through a large peristaltic pump head.
If the peristaltic pump head has an occlusion setting,  ~Action~ it to maximal occlusion to help  ~Action~ the 0.22-µm TFF filter and  ~Action~ all air.
 ~Action~ the peristatic pump on and  ~Action~ the peristaltic pump speed to 20% to prime the tubing and  ~Action~  ~Action~ the tubing and remove excess air.
Once the tubing and filter are completely filled with water,  ~Action~ the occlusion knob to a looser setting to  ~Action~ 
Slowly  ~Action~ the pump speed to 45%.
Once the system is running smoothly, partially  ~Action~ the permeate valve on the 0.22-µm TFF filter to the second tick mark (~20° open).
 ~Action~ the <0.22 µm permeate into an appropriately sized carboy.
When the permeate carboy is more than half full with <0.22 µm permeate,  ~Action~ the 30-kD TFF filter for viral concentration.
 ~Action~ the large peristaltic pump speed to 10%.
 ~Action~ the feed and retentate tubing to the appropriate ports on the 30-kD TFF.
 ~Action~ the permeate tubing from the 30-kD TFF filter into a clean carboy to  ~Action~ ultrafiltrate (UF; virus-free water).
Carefully  ~Action~ the feed tubing into the second pump head of the large peristaltic pump.
 ~Action~ the large peristaltic pump speed to 20%.
Again,  ~Action~ the occlusion knob on the pump head to prime the 30-kD TFF filter and  ~Action~ all air.
Once the filter and lines are fully primed  ~Action~ the pump head occlusion knob.
Slowly  ~Action~ the pump speed to 45%.
Slowly  ~Action~ the backpressure knob on the 30-kD TFF filter until permeate begins to flow.
Monitor the level of <0.22 µm water in the <0.22 µm permeate carboy.
The level should be maintained at half full until the pre filtered ambient water is nearly gone.
 ~Action~ 1 L of ultra filtrate (30 kD TFF permeate) in a 2-L bottle for rinsing of the 30-kD TFF filter.
When ~5 L of 25 µm filtered ambient water remains in the large carboy,  ~Action~ the pump head and  ~Action~ the 0.22-µm TFF filter feed tubing from the large peristaltic pump.
Continue to  ~Action~ the 30-kD TFF filter until ~1 L of <0.22 µm water remains in the carboy.
When 1L or less of <0.22 µm water remains,  ~Action~ the large peristaltic pump and  ~Action~ the 30-kD TFF filter into the <0.22 µm water carboy.
Slowly  ~Action~ the 30-kD TFF filter from the 1 L of collected UF from step 22 and then  ~Action~ ( ~Action~   ~Action~ and  ~Action~ lines of the 30-kD filter in the 1L of UF) the UF at 30% pump speed for 5 min.
 ~Action~ the pump,  ~Action~ the pump head, and  ~Action~ all tubing into the 2-L UF bottle.
 ~Action~ the recirculated UF with the ~1 L of retentate from the primary viral concentration through the 30-kD TFF filter.
The volume of the ~2 L viral concentrate can be further  ~Action~ by using a small-scale TFF ultrafilter.
To avoid excessive degradation of viruses, it is advisable to  ~Action~ the first stage VC at 4°C and perform a second stage small-scale concentration a soon as possible (i.e., within no more than 1 d).
Insure that the permeate port is closed, then begin  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ with a  ~Size~  ~Modifier~  ~Device~ before any concentration using a  ~Modifier~ or  ~Modifier~  ~Location~ 
Iron Chloride Precipitation of Viruses from Seawater
 ~Action~ two 142mm filtering towers and  ~Action~ the filter apparatus to a peristaltic pump with a pressure gauge (maximum pressure = 15 psi).
 ~Action~ 20L of seawater using a 150mm Whatman GF/A filter.
 ~Action~ again to  ~Action~ bacteria using a 0.22um, 142mm Millipore Express Plus filter.
 ~Action~ the virus fraction (0.22μm filtrate) with FeCl3 to  ~Action~ the viruses by  ~Action~ 1ml of 10g/L Fe Stock Solution to each 20L of filtrate.
 ~Action~ vigorously for 1 minute.
 ~Action~ an additional 1ml of 10g/L Fe stock solution to each 20L of filtrate (for a total of 2ml Fe Stock Solution per 20L filtrate).
 ~Action~ vigorously for 1 minute.
Let the FeCl3 treated filtrate  ~Action~ for 1 hour at room temperature.
 ~Action~ the FeCl3 treated filtrate using a 1.0μm, 142mm, polycarbonate (PC) membrane filter on top of a 0.8μm, 142mm, support filter and  ~Action~ the filter apparatus to a peristaltic pump with a pressure gauge (maximum pressure = 15 psi).
 ~Action~ all of the polycarbonate filters from the 20L into a 50ml centrifuge tube being careful not to scrape off any of the FeCl3 on the edge of the tube (having precipitate facing out aids in dissolving the precipitate).
 ~Action~ the Supor support filter.
 ~Action~ fresh 0.1M EDTA; 0.2M MgCl2; 0.2M Ascorbate Buffer, pH6.5.
 ~Action~ 1ml buffer for each 1mg Fe, which is 20ml of 1x buffer for the 20L seawater precipitate (10ml of a 2X concentrated buffer).
 ~Action~ the tube vigorously.
Place tubes on a rotator and  ~Action~  ~Action~ tubes on a rotator and rotate at 4°C overnight.
 ~Action~ stored at 4°C until ready to  ~Action~ or further  ~Action~ the viral fraction.
To collect the resuspended precipitate,  ~Action~ the tube and collect liquid into a fresh tube.
Using a sterile pipet, applicator stick, or bleached and rinsed forceps  ~Action~ an edge of the filter onto the tube edge so it is caught in the lid when secured.
 ~Action~ at low speed (less than 1000 rpm) for 3-5 minutes to  ~Action~ more buffer.
If the filter has precipitate on it,  ~Action~ more buffer,  ~Action~ again for a couple hours, and  ~Action~  ~Numerical~  ~Device~ and attach the  ~Device~ to a  ~Location~ with a  ~Device~ (maximum pressure = 15 psi).
Isolation of Mitochondria from Soft Tissues (Liver or Brain) using the FOCUS™ Mitochondria Kit
OPTIONAL: Delipidated BSA can be added to 1X SubCell Buffer-II to the concentration of 2mg/ml for removing free fatty acids prior processing.
An appropriate amount of protease inhibitor cocktail also can be added to the 1X SubCell Buffer-II just before use.
Use a fresh tissue sample (obtained within one hour of sacrifice) kept on ice.
Do not freeze.
Weigh approximately 50-100mg tissue.
On a cooled glass plate, with the aid of a scalpel, mince the tissue into very small pieces.
Perform this step on ice.
Transfer the minced tissue to an ice-cold Dounce tissue homogenizer.
Stand on ice for 2 minutes.
Transfer the homogenate to a centrifuge tube and leave large chunks of tissue fragments in the homogenizer to be discarded.
Centrifuge the lysate at 700x g for 5 minutes to pellet the nuclei.
Carefully transfer the supernatant into a new tube.
Centrifuge supernatant at 12,000x g for 10 minutes.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 10 volumes of 1X SubCell Buffer-II without BSA.
(Centrifuge as in steps 9-10.)
Transfer the homogenate to a centrifuge tube and leave large chunks of tissue fragments in the homogenizer to be discarded.
Suspend the mitochondrial pellet in Working Mitochondria Storage Buffer (approximately 50μl for pellet from ~100mg tissue) and keep the suspension on ice before downstream processing.
The suspension may be stored on ice for up to 48 hours.
Add 10 volumes of 1X SubCell Buffer-II and using a loose-fitting pestle disaggregate the tissue with 5-10 strokes or until the tissue sample is completely homogenized.
Using a tight-fitting pestle, release the nuclei with 8-10 strokes.
Do not twist the pestle as nuclei shearing may occur.
(Centrifuge as in steps 9-10.)
Centrifuge the lysate at 700x g for 5 minutes to pellet the nuclei.
Carefully transfer the supernatant into a new tube.
Centrifuge supernatant at 12,000x g for 10 minutes.
 ~Action~ the  ~Reagent~  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ at  ~Speed~ for  ~Time~  ~Action~  ~Modifier~ transfer the  ~Reagent~ into a  ~Modifier~  ~Location~  ~Action~ the  ~Reagent~ at  ~Speed~ for  ~Time~  ~Action~  ~Generic-Measure~ of  ~Reagent~  ~Action~ the  ~Reagent~ in  ~Location~ (approximately 50μl for pellet from ~100mg tissue) and  ~Action~ the  ~Reagent~ on  ~Location~ before downstream processing.
The suspension may be stored on ice for up to 48 hours.

Metatranscriptomics sample preparation protocol w/ScriptSeq
 ~Action~ 2-ml screw-cap tube on ice (should take a while).
If using sterivex filters, follow notes in annotations.
 ~Action~ the cells on the filters: Remove the 300 µl RNAlater carefully and discard.
 ~Action~ 750 µl (1.5mL)* Lysis/Binding buffer, vortex vigorously to completely lyse the cells.

 ~Action~ to mix.
Leave the mixture on ice for 10 min.
 ~Action~ the 825 µl lysate to a new Non-stick RNase-free tube or a 2 mL tube with o-ring (might need to spin the tubes to get as much lysate out as possible).
 ~Action~ 750 µl Acid-Phenol:Chloroform, vortex for 30-60 sec to mix.
 ~Action~ for 5 min at maximum 10,000 X g at RT.
Carefully remove the top aqueous phase w/o disturbing the lower phase, transfer it to a fresh tube.
 ~Action~ Elution Solution (or Nuclease-free water) to 95ºC.
 ~Action~ 1.25 volumes of RT 100% ethanol to the aqueous phase, mix well, load to a Filter Cartridge in the collection tube (provided).
 ~Action~ for 15 sec at 10,000 X g, discard the flow-through.
 ~Action~ 700 µl miRNA Wash Solution 1 to the Filter Cartridge and centrifuge for 10 sec at 10,000 X g, discard the flow-through.
 ~Action~ 500 µl Wash Solution 2/3, spin 15 sec at 10,000 X g, and discard the flow-through.
Repeat step 14.
 ~Action~ the Filter Cartridge back in the tube, centrifuge for 1.5 min at 10,000 X g to remove residual fluid from the filter.
 ~Action~ the Filter Cartridge into a fresh collection tube, apply 50 µl pre-heated (95 ºC) Elution Solution (0.1 mM EDTA) to the center of the filter.
Wait ~1 minute.
 ~Action~ for 30 sec at 10,000 X g.  
Repeat steps 17-19 with another 50 µl pre-heated (95ºC) Elution Solution.
 ~Action~ 1/10th volume of DNase I buffer (~10 µl) and 2 µl DNase I (2U/µl), gently mix and incubate at 37 ºC for 30 min.
If RNeasy MinElute is to be used immediately after this, there is no need to use the DNase inactivation reagent – go directly to the RNeasy MinElute Procedure.

 ~Action~ for 1.5 min at 10,000 X g, transfer RNA to a fresh new 0.5 ml non-stick Rnase-free tube, store in –70 ºC.

 ~Action~ 500 µl 100% ethanol, mix thoroughly by pipetting.

Bead washing (do this before or during the hybridization step).
For each sample,  ~Action~ 400 µl of beads* to a 1.5 ml tube.
Wash 1: bind beads to magnetic separation rack (takes ~2 min),  ~Action~ and  ~Action~ supernatant,  ~Action~ beads in equal volume of 0.1N NaOH (deactivates bead-associated RNases), and quick  ~Action~ to  ~Action~  spin down,  ~Action~ to magnet and  ~Action~  ~Action~ beads to magnetic separation rack (takes ~2 min), pipet off and discard supernatant, re-suspend beads in equal volume of 0.1N NaOH (deactivates bead-associated RNases), and quick vortex to re-suspend, spin down, re-bind to magnet and pipet off supernatant.
Do this step quickly.
Wash #2: Repeat wash in step57 using 1X SSC buffer.
On the 3rd wash,  ~Action~ beads in buffer on ice until hybridization is complete.
Wash #3: Repeat wash in step57 using 1X SSC buffer and leave beads in buffer on ice until hybridization is complete.
Hybridization.
In a thermal cycler,  ~Action~ under the following conditions:  5 min at 70ºC,  ~Action~ to 25°C, using 5°C increments for 1 min each.
 ~Action~ the reaction and let  ~Action~ at RT for 2-5 min.
Bead binding.

 ~Action~ the hybridization reaction in PCR tubes to 100 µl using 20% formamide in 1X SSC.
 ~Action~ the hybridization reaction (now 100 µl) to the dried beads.
 ~Action~ at RT for 10 min, with occasional  ~Action~ to  ~Action~ 
Bead removal.
Quick  ~Action~ the tubes.
 ~Action~ the beads on the magnetic rack (2-3 min).
 ~Action~ the non-rRNA-containing supernatant to a 1.5 ml tube using a P200 pipettor.
 ~Action~ remaining beads with 100 µl 1X SSC, capture beads as above,  ~Action~ supernatant to the same 1.5 ml tube (200 µl total volume).

 ~Action~ RNA at -80°C for downstream applications.
If needed,  ~Action~ the subtracted RNA to maximum volume of 9 µl.
Use all of the template material remaining after the rRNA-subtraction step.

Protocol for washing and modifying QCM-D sensors
 ~Action~ solutions of 2% SDS, 0.1% SDS and 0.1 M HCl.
 ~Action~ the gold-coated QCM-D sensors by hand with 2% SDS to mechanically  ~Action~ contaminants.
Be sure that the glove is wet all the time so it doesn't scratch the sensor!
 ~Action~ the sensors in a stand and put them in a 0.1% SDS solution.
 ~Action~ for 10 min at 80°C, then rinse the sensors with water.
 ~Action~ the sensors in a 0.1 M HCl solution.
 ~Action~ for 10 min at 80°C, then  ~Action~ the sensors with water several times to  ~Action~ all HCl solution.
Then blow the sensors  ~Action~ under a flow of nitrogen.
 ~Action~ an ethanolic solution with total concentration 10 mM of mixed PEG thiols (PEG and biotin-PEG thiols in a molar ratio of 99:1).
(MW, dS-PEG = 386.5 Da and MW, dS-PEG-biotin = 788.0 Da)  ~Action~ the QCM-D sensors in the ethanolic PEG thiol solution for at least 16 hours at 4°C in darkness.
 ~Action~ the sensors a couple of times with ethanol, then a couple of times with milli-Q water and lastly blow them  ~Action~ with nitrogen.
They may now be used or  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ of  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~   ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~ and  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~ 
Can Crusher-Culley Protocol

 ~Action~ the Anotop to the end of the syringe.

 ~Action~ the Anotop from the syringe.
 ~Action~ on the Anotop itself using a waterproof Sharpie. 
 ~Action~ the Anotop in clean parafilm, covering both the inlet and outlet.

MegaLong™ Protocol for Isolation of >100kb Genomic DNA (Cell Culture)
On ice,  ~Action~ up to 2.5x106 cells to a Tube-O-DIALYZER™ and  ~Action~ at 5,000xg for 5 minutes to pellet cells.
 ~Action~ the supernatant.
 ~Action~ 500µl Nuclei Isolation Buffer.
 ~Action~ the tube 2-3 times to suspend the cells,  ~Action~ for 10 minutes on ice.
 ~Action~ the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ cap in a beaker of TE buffer and  ~Action~ at 4°C until required.
 ~Action~ the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ tube with TE buffer.
With a pipette  ~Action~ the supernatant to the Tube-O-DIALYZER™, ensuring the settled cellular debris is left behind.
 ~Action~ a supplied cap on the tube and  ~Action~ at 16,000xg for 5 minutes to pellet the nuclei.
Carefully  ~Action~ the supernatant and  ~Action~ the tube on a paper towel to  ~Action~ excess supernatant.
 ~Action~ 70µl Suspension Buffer to the nuclei and gently  ~Action~ or  ~Action~ the tube to dislodge the nuclei.
 ~Action~ the LongLife™ Proteinase K and  ~Action~ 10µl to the nuclei.
 ~Action~ 70µl Digestion Buffer and  ~Action~ with gentle rocking.
 ~Action~ at 55°C for 2-4 hours with periodic rocking.
 ~Action~ 
After digestion is complete,  ~Action~ the tube for 20 seconds at 1,000g.
 ~Action~ the cap with the dialysis cap.
 ~Action~ the storage cap as this will be required for storage of DNA.
 ~Action~ the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ upside down in a 50ml centrifuge tube and  ~Action~ at 1000xg for 30 seconds to bring the sample onto the dialysis membrane.
 ~Action~ the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ from the 50ml tube with forceps and keeping it inverted slide into the provided float and dialyze in 500ml 1X TE buffer at room temperature for 18-24 hours with 2-3 buffer changes.
Gently  ~Action~  ~Action~ in 500ml 1X TE buffer at room temperature for 18-24 hours with 2-3 buffer changes.
Gently swirl tube to mix contents at each buffer change.
Following dialysis the genomic DNA may be concentrated in the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ using either Tube-O-DIALYZER™ Concentrator (Cat. # 786-144) or Concentrator Solution (Cat. # 786-143).
Simply  ~Action~ the Concentrator as per the instructions and  ~Action~ the Tube-O-DIALYZER™ containing your DNA in the solution.
If concentration is not required or following concentration,  ~Action~ the tube at 1000xg for 1 minute.
 ~Action~  ~Location~  add up to  ~Generic-Measure~  ~Reagent~ to a  ~Device~ and centrifuge at  ~Speed~ for  ~Time~ to  ~Action~  ~Reagent~

As a negative control 5–10 µL phage buffer (e.g., SM buffer: 450 mM NaCl, 50 mM MgSO4, 50 mM Tris, 0.01 % Gelatin, pH = 8) or 0.02 µm filtered sample water is spotted in triplicate on the  ~Reagent~  ~Location~  ~Action~  ~Amount~  ~Modifier~  ~Reagent~  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~  ~Modifier~ 5–10 µL phage buffer (e.g., SM buffer: 450 mM  ~Reagent~  50 mM  ~Reagent~  50 mM  ~Reagent~  0.01 %  ~Reagent~  ~Concentration~ MgSO4,  ~Concentration~ Tris,  ~Concentration~  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~  450 mM NaCl, 50 mM MgSO4, 50 mM Tris, 0.01 % Gelatin, pH = 8) or 0.02 µm filtered sample water is spotted in triplicate on the soft agar.
The  ~Location~ are  ~Action~ for  ~Time~ depending on the growth rate of the bacteria, and the presence of lytic phages in the sample is detected as a clearing zone (plaque) in the spotted area of the lawn of bacteria that develops over time on the plate.
If clearing zones appear in the spotted area, this indicates the presence of lytic phages, which can be isolated and purified.
Once detected as clearings in the spotting zone, phages are further  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ are further isolated and  ~Action~ from the  ~Location~  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~ in  ~Reagent~  ~Modifier~  is melted in a water bath or a microwave oven.
Gel DNA Recovery
 ~Action~ up to 200 mg gel slice containing the DNA fragment using a clean scalpel or razor blade.
 ~Action~ as close to the DNA as possible to  ~Action~ the gel volume.
 ~Action~ the gel slice into a 1.5 mL tube.
 ~Action~ 200 µL of Extraction Buffer.
 ~Action~ thoroughly by  ~Action~ 
 ~Action~ the gel mixture at 50-58°C for 10 minutes or until the gel slice is completely dissolved.
 ~Action~ the tube by inversion every few minutes to facilitate the melting process.
Ensure that the gel is completely dissolved. 
 ~Action~ 200 µL of ethanol (96-100%) and  ~Action~ by pipetting.
 ~Action~ the mixture to the DNA Purification Micro Column preassembled with a collection tube.
 ~Action~ the column for 1 minute at 14,000 × g. 
 ~Action~ the flow-through.
 ~Action~ the DNA Purification Micro Column back into the collection tube.
 ~Action~ 200 µL of Prewash Buffer (supplemented with ethanol, see p. 3) to the DNA Purification Micro Column and  ~Action~ for 1 minute at 14,000 × g. 
 ~Action~ the flow-through and place the purification column back into the collection tube.
 ~Action~ 700 µL of Wash Buffer (supplemented with ethanol, see p. 3) to the DNA Purification Micro Column and  ~Action~ for 1 minute at 14,000 × g.
 ~Action~ the flow-through and  ~Action~ the purification column back into the collection tube.
Repeat step 7  ~Action~ the empty DNA Purification Micro Column for an additional 1 minute at 14,000 × g to completely  ~Action~ residual Wash Buffer.
 ~Action~ the DNA Purification Micro Column into a clean 1.8 mL microcentrifugetube  ~Action~ 10 µL of Elution Buffer to the DNA Purification Micro Column.

Filtering for Cell Collection Pump → Steel filter tank → A/E filter → Durapore → DI rinsed cubie container (the one the sample was in).  
 ~Action~ all tubes to manifolds and filter tanks.  
Make sure bleeder valves are on top. 
Turn on pump and then bleed A/E then Durapore and the A/E again.  
Keep cubie container on ice- water will be used for viral concentration.   
 ~Action~ “out” tube from Durapore onto a filter flask that is attached to the vacuum side of the pump.  
 ~Action~ until water stops moving towards the vacuum and only bubbles are coming through.   
 ~Action~ steel filter tank lid and slowly open tank bleeder valve to depressurize (SLOWLY). 
When pressure has dropped significantly push in steel tank lid, allow a few more minutes for water to drain through.  
 ~Action~ clamp from bottom side of A/E filter,  ~Action~ tube from “out” side of A/E.  
 ~Action~ Durapore on knees and  ~Action~ gently so all water goes into the filter flask. 
Once water is out,  ~Action~ manifold slowly,  ~Action~ filter and  ~Action~ in whirlpack. 
 ~Action~ Durapore “out” tube from filter flask,  ~Action~ A/E “out” tube onto filter flask.   
Place A/E on knees, let water drain out into the filter flask as before. 
 ~Action~ manifold slowly,  ~Action~ ring of filter,  ~Action~  fold filter and  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Location~ to  ~Location~ and  ~Location~  ~Modifier~ tubes to manifolds and filter tanks.  
Make sure bleeder valves are on top.

Concentration of Phage Lysate using Vivaflow Tangential/Crossflow Filtration Cassette
To filter 4-8 L of phage lysate,  ~Action~ one Vivaflow50 cassette per 4 L of sample (this was the capacity successfully tested by our lab).
If two cassettes are needed for a phage sample,  ~Action~ in parallel with separate tubing lines, using the double tubing pump head.
Refer to the Sartorius user manual and online videos for tubing  ~Action~ ent and flow  ~Action~ 
For all tubing, keep the ends to be  ~Action~ in the sample and  ~Action~ as clean as possible once  ~Action~ from the packaging.
To adapt the smaller cassette tubing to our lab’s pump head size, make sure to  ~Action~ the size 25 Masterflex tubing first.
Keep clean/sterile the end to be placed in the phage sample.
If running more than one phage sample simultaneously, make sure to  ~Action~ all input and output tubing, cassettes and bottles or flasks with sample ID’s, and keep separate to prevent any phage cross contamination.
Per the Sartorius manual,  ~Action~ the cassette (aka: module) before use by pre-rinsing the system at full pressure to  ~Action~ trace amounts of glycerine and sodium azide and  ~Action~ at the tubing connections.
 ~Action~ the input tubing into the 1 L bottle of 0.2 um filtered, sterile nanopure water.
 ~Action~ the output return tubing in the same bottle and  ~Action~ liquid through the system to  ~Action~ any air pockets.
You will need ~500 ml of water per cassette, and you can  ~Action~ two parallel cassettes to use the same bottle.
The recirculation rate should be in the range of 200-400 ml/min and suitable flow should exit the filtrate line.
If used, the pressure indicator should read approximately 2.5 bar.
This corresponds to a pump setting of around 60.
Allow 400 ml per cassette to  ~Action~ into the filtrate collection.
 ~Action~ at connections.
Finally,  ~Action~ the system and empty the filtrate flask.
To  ~Action~ the phage sample,  ~Action~ the input and output lines into the initial lysate container (usually a 1L bottle).
If the container lid is off,  ~Action~ a piece of parafilm over the opening to minimize contamination and  ~Action~ the tubing in place.
 ~Action~ the liquid through the system at the same rate and pressure as specified for the rinsing step above.
For two cassettes filtering one sample, a pump setting of around 60 corresponds to a filtrate production of about 250 ml per 14 min initially, but which may slow some as more concentrated sample is added to the recirculation.
Monitor the sample level and  ~Action~ when volume reaches 100-200 ml to refill the bottle with more sample.
Also monitor the filtrate flask to prevent overflowing and  ~Action~ (or keep, if desired) the filtrate down the sink (this should be free of phage!).
 ~Action~ phage sample after you have concentrated 4 L to between 175 and 200 ml.
Note that about 15-20 ml are left in the system.
When the desired volume has been reached,  ~Action~ the recirculation rate to 20-40 ml/min (pump setting around 10) and  ~Action~ the concentrated sample for 1-2 minutes to maximize recovery.
 ~Action~ phage sample after you have concentrated 4 L to between 175 and 200 ml.
Note that about 15-20 ml are left in the system.
When the desired volume has been reached,  ~Action~ the recirculation rate to 20-40 ml/min (pump setting around 10) and  ~Action~ the concentrated sample for 1-2 minutes to maximize recovery.
If there are > 4 L of sample to concentrate, begin the next fraction:  ~Action~ the input and return tubes into the next lysate sample bottle, parafilm cover, and  ~Action~ the concentration process (steps 5-8).
Then  ~Action~ the concentrated sample into a second 250 ml bottle and  ~Action~ the remaining sample completely from the system.
To  ~Action~ a final rinse from the filters for a more complete sample recovery,  ~Action~ 100 ml ASW salts into a clean 250 ml bottle.
 ~Action~ the input and return tubing into the bottle,  ~Action~ the top with parafilm and  ~Action~ on lower speed until the volume is reduced to about 20 ml.
Then  ~Action~ the system as before and  ~Action~ the remaining rinse fraction into the bottle.
Even though the Vivaflow 50 cassettes are not reusable, they were kept until the concentration of phage sample was determined.
To  ~Action~ the cassettes,  ~Action~ them with ASW salts and keep at 4 °C.
 ~Action~ 50 ml ASW salts into a sterile 50 ml tube and  ~Action~ this through the filter and tubing to  ~Action~ air bubbles.
Then either  ~Action~ the open tubing ends in the media tube and  ~Action~ with parafilm, or  ~Action~ the tubing ends with tape.

Prophage Induction in Natural Populations of Heterotrophic Bacteria
