FLVP assays
Perform preparation of FLVPs as described in Viral and bacterial isolates, propagation and preparation of stocks.
 ~Action~ a 10-fold dilution series of the culture or natural sample to be enumerated so that ~105 cells mL–1 of the target (FLVP-specific species) will be obtained.
 ~Action~ all subsequent steps under subdued light, since the stain will fade if exposed.
 ~Action~ 0.1 mL FLVP working stock to 0.9 mL sample in a microcentrifuge tube for each slide to be prepared and vortex to mix.
Allow up to 30 min for adsorption of FLVPs to target cells.
 ~Action~ each 1 mL sample onto a 0.2-µm Anodisc filter using a 0.45-µm HA filter for backing.
 ~Action~ 10 µL mounting medium onto the surface of a slide.
 ~Action~ the filter over the drop.
 ~Action~ 10 µL mounting medium onto the surface of the filter.
 ~Action~ a 25 × 25 mm coverslip over the filter.
 ~Action~ the slides under blue-light excitation and  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Amount~ FLVP working stock to  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~  ~Reagent~ to 0.9 mL sample in a  ~Location~ for each slide to be prepared and vortex to  ~Action~  ~Action~ and vortex to mix.
Methyltransferase Assay
 ~Action~ the assays, to contain 50.0 µL total per assay with 3 µg of DNA and 2 µCi of Adenosyl-L-Methionine, S-Methyl (3H), and the enzyme to be tested.
 ~Action~ the assays at 37°C for 2 hours.
 ~Action~ 30 µL (60 µg) of proteinase K to each assay.
 ~Action~ at 65°C for 20 min.
 ~Action~ 4 µL (20 µg) of ss salmon sperm DNA as a carrier.
 ~Action~ an equal volume (84 µL) of 20% TCA and  ~Action~ at 4°C for 10 min to precipitate the samples.
 ~Action~ the assays in the microfuge for 5 min at 4°C.
 ~Action~ the supernatants.
 ~Action~ the pellets 2X with 200 µL of 5% TCA in the microfuge for 5 min at 4°C.
 ~Action~ the pellets with 500 µL each of 500 mM NaOH.
 ~Action~ the assays at 65°C for 20 min.
 ~Action~ the samples with 500 µL of 20% TCA for 10 min at 4°C.
 ~Action~ the samples in the microfuge for 5 min at 4°C.
 ~Action~ the pellets 2X with 200 µL of 5% TCA in the microfuge for 5 min at 4°C.
 ~Action~ the pellet with 500 µL of 5% TCA.
 ~Action~ in boiling water for 30 min ( ~Action~ the caps or  ~Action~ the caps of the tubes).
 ~Action~ the samples in the microfuge for 5 min at 4°C to remove the insoluble material.
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~  to contain 50.0 µL total per assay with  ~Amount~ of  ~Reagent~ and  ~Amount~ of  ~Reagent~   ~Reagent~  and the  ~Reagent~ to be tested.
Hybridized Chain Reaction Fluorescent in situ Hybridization (HCR-FISH)
[1.1]  ~Action~ juvenile squid from hatching table (refer to colonization protocol as needed) and  ~Action~ into collection cups.
 ~Action~ with desired V. fischeri strain.
[1.2]  ~Action~ squid for 2 min by placing into 2% ethanol in filtered seawater.
[1.3] Under dissecting scope,  ~Action~ and peel back mantle on anterior side.
Then carefully  ~Action~ the funnel to expose the light organ.
[1.4]  ~Action~ dissected squid into 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) and  ~Action~ overnight at 4 °C on shaker to fix.
The best vessels to use are 1.5mL screw-cap vials, to prevent leaking at later wash steps.
Permeabilization by Proteinase KUse RNase-free equipment and solutions throughout the remainder of the protocol.
 ~Action~ all treatments, hybridizations, and washes in a 500-μL volume, on a rotator/shaker, unless otherwise noted.
[2.1]  ~Action~ each sample five times (5 min per wash) with Permeabilization Buffer at room temperature (RT).
[2.2]  ~Action~ with 0.01 mg/mL Proteinase K Permeabilization Buffer at RT for 15-20 minutes.
 ~Action~ on shaker or rotator.
[2.3]  ~Action~ the proteinase K digestion with two washes of 2 mg/mL glycine in Permeabilization Buffer.
[2.4]  ~Action~ in Permeabilization Buffer with 4% PFA for 1 h at RT on the shaker.
[2.5]  ~Action~ with Permeabilization Buffer five times (5 min per wash).
Note: Permeabilized juveniles can be used immediately, or stored for no longer than 1 week at 4 °C in Permeabilization Buffer.
Pre-hybridization for Probes.
[3.1]  ~Action~ as much of the Permeabilization Buffer as possible from the sample.
 ~Action~ sample in 500 μL of 50% Hyb Buffer at 65 °C for 30 min.
[3.2]  ~Action~ sample into 500 μL of fresh 50% Hyb Buffer, and  ~Action~ at 65 °C for 2.5 h.
Note:  ~Action~ drying during prolonged incubations.
When using petri plates,  ~Action~ them in a humidified chamber or  ~Action~ the cover of the plate with a strip of parafilm.
Probe Hybridization.
To identify possible artifacts and confounding effects, the following alternate sample preparations should be performed:
Autofluorescence (AF) – Follow protocol but do not add probes (step 4) or hairpins (step 7).
Non-Specific Amplification of hairpins (NSA) – Sample incubated without probes (step 4) but with hairpins included.
Non-Specific Detection of targets (NSD) – This control is applicable only for (i) transgenic (non-endogenous) targets, where a wild-type sample missing the target transcript is treated using the same protocol, and with the test probes and hairpins; or (ii) non-ubiquitous endogenous target transcript, where the locus of expression is known beforehand, and for which surrounding tissue can give an estimate of NSD in the same sample after treatment.
[4.1]  ~Action~ 1 pmol of each probe in 500 μL of 50% Hyb buffer at 45 °C for 30 min (this step should be coordinated with step [3.2] so that they are completed at the same time).
[4.2]  ~Action~ the 50% Hyb buffer from [3.2], and  ~Action~ this probe solution to samples for overnight (16 h) incubation at 45 °C.
Probe Washes.
All solutions used here must be pre-warmed to 45 °C.
Probe solution is not reused, and hence discarded at the start of the washes.
[5.1]  ~Action~ samples in 500 μL Probe Wash Buffer for 15 min at 45 °C.
[5.2]  ~Action~ samples in 500 μL (75% of Probe Wash Buffer + 25% of 5X SSC) for 15 min at 45 °C.
[5.3]  ~Action~ samples in 500 μL (50% of Probe Wash Buffer + 50% of 5X SSC) for 15 min at 45 °C.
[5.4]  ~Action~ samples in 500 μL (25% of Probe Wash Buffer + 75% of 5X SSC) for 15 min at 45 °C.
[5.5]  ~Action~ samples 2 times, in 500 μL of 5X SSC for 15 min at 45 °C.
[5.6]  ~Action~ samples 2 times, in 500 μL of 5X SSC for 30 min at 45 °C.
Pre-hybridization for Hairpins [6.1] Incubate samples in 500 μL of DNA Amplification Buffer at RT for 30 min.
[6.2]  ~Action~ samples in fresh 500 μL of DNA Amplification Buffer at RT for 30 min.
[6.3]  ~Action~ 6 pmol (for every 100 μL of DNA Amplification Buffer) of each hairpin in a separate PCR tube.
[6.4]  ~Action~ the hairpins to 95 °C for 90 sec (e.g., using a PCR machine/thermal cycler).
[6.5]  ~Action~ the heated hairpins in the dark for 30 min at RT (keep hairpins unmixed).
[6.6]  ~Action~ 100 μL of fresh DNA Amplification Buffer equilibrated at RT.
Note: (Steps [6.2] through [6.6] should be coordinated so that they are completed at the same time for all samples).
Hairpin Amplification.
[7.1]  ~Action~ all hairpins in 100 μL of pre-equilibrated DNA Amplification Buffer at RT.
(Final concentration of each hairpin is 60 nM.)
Note: The volume of this incubation can be scaled up if needed (i.e., for high-abundance squid transcripts); however, the hairpin concentration must be kept constant.
[7.2]  ~Action~ final wash solution from [6.2] and add the hairpin solution to the samples for an overnight (16 h) incubation at RT.
[7.3]  ~Action~ the sample tubes (or incubation oven) in aluminum foil to keep light out.
Hairpin Washes.
Note: All solutions used here must be pre-equilibrated to RT.
[8.1]  ~Action~ samples 4 times, in 500 μL of 5X SSCTw for 5 min each at RT.
[8.2]  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Location~  ~Reagent~ from  ~Location~ (refer to colonization protocol as needed) and isolate into collection cups.

Total digestion of marine particles
 ~Action~ filter into PFA vial, ideally with sample side facing downwards or folded inwards.
 ~Action~ 1.5 mL of sulfuric acid to all samples and blanks. 
 ~Action~ lid atop loosely and leave filter to  ~Action~ for 20 min at room temperature. 
 ~Action~ lid slightly to  ~Action~ 0.5mL of hydrogen peroxide.
Gently,  ~Action~ vial to mix.
 ~Action~ for 60 min in a hot plate at 110˚C with lid placed on loosely. 
 ~Action~ another 0.5 mL peroxide,  ~Action~ caps loosely and  ~Action~ hotplate temperature to 200˚C. 
If undissolved filter pieces or semi-digested viscous material persist,  ~Action~ it  ~Action~ down and  ~Action~ d 100-200µL aliquots of peroxide to digest this material. 
 ~Action~ vial contents at 235-250˚C. 
Note: If a small droplet of sulfuric acid remains at this point, let vial cool and suspend contents in a small aliquot of Milli-Q water or 8N nitric acid and re-dry at 235˚C until the droplet is removed.
 ~Action~ dried samples in 2 mL of a freshly prepared mixture of HNO3, HCl, and HF acids (4M each) in milli-Q water.
 ~Action~ for 4 hours at 100-110˚C.
 ~Action~ vials  ~Action~ to room temperature,  ~Action~ and  ~Action~ at 100-110˚C (overnight).
 ~Action~ 2mL of freshly prepared 50% HNO3/15% H2O2 (v/v). 
Take vials to dryness on a hotplate at 100-110˚C. 
 ~Action~ sample in 200-500 µL of 50% HNO3/15% H2O2 (v/v).
 ~Action~ loosely and  ~Action~ at 110˚C.
After vigorous bubbling cease,  ~Action~ vials and  ~Action~ at 135˚C.

 ~Action~ sample to 5% of original concentration with 0.1 M HNO3 for analysis. 
After concentration analysis,  ~Action~  ~Device~ into  ~Location~  ideally with sample side facing downwards or folded inwards.

Preparation of Custom Synthesized RNA Transcript Standard
Briefly  ~Action~ the tube to ensure the contents are on the bottom.  
 ~Action~ the sample in a volume of TE Buffer resulting in a stock concentration of 0.1 ug/uL.  
To prepare a working solution  ~Action~ 1 uL of the stock solution to 99 uL of water to reach a concentration of 1.0 ng/uL.  
 ~Action~ resuspended DNA at -20 °C. 
 ~Action~ frozen competent cells and pre-labeled tubes on ice. 
 ~Action~ a hot water bath to 42 °C. 
In a tube on ice  ~Action~ 2 uL (~2 ng) of plasmid working solution to 100 uL of thawed competent cells,  ~Action~ the tubes to gently mix.  
 ~Action~ the mixture on ice for 30 minutes.  
 ~Action~ the tubes for 45 seconds in the 42 °C bath. 
Immediately  ~Action~ the tubes on ice for 2 minutes.  
 ~Action~ 500 uL of SOC or LB to each tube and  ~Action~ the tubes at 37°C for 1 hour with shaking (~225 rpm).  
 ~Action~ agar plates to 37°C in incubator.  
 ~Action~ 10 uL, 100 uL, and 200 uL and  ~Action~ on LB-Amp agar plates.  
 ~Action~ the plates upside down in 37°C incubator for 12-24 hours.  
 ~Action~ a 5 uL liquid LB-Amp culture by picking a single well-isolated colony from the LB-Amp plate grown overnight.  
 ~Action~ liquid culture at 37°C for ~8 hours with vigorous shaking (~300 rpm).   ~Action~ 850 uL of starter culture and  ~Action~ into a 2 mL freezer vial with 150 uL of sterilized 100% glycerol,  ~Action~ thoroughly, and  ~Action~ at -80 °C.  
 ~Action~ the starter culture 1/500 to 1/1000 into a larger volume of LB-Amp.  
 ~Action~ the culture at 37°C with vigorous shaking (~300 rpm) for 12-16 hours.  
 ~Action~ the culture by centrifugation at 6000 x g for 15 min at 4°C.  
 ~Action~ supernatant.  
 ~Action~ plasmid DNA using a commercial plasmid mini-prep and the corresponding protocol. 
In a PCR tube combine in the order listed:
12.8 uL Nuclease-free water
2.00 uL NEBuffer 4 
(10X)0.20 uL BSA 
(100X)4.00 uL Plasmid DNA (0.5 ug/uL). 
In a thermocycler  ~Action~ the mixture for 1 hour at 37 °C. 
 ~Action~ the enzyme by incubating at 65 °C for 20 minutes. 
 ~Action~ the reaction to 100 uL by adding TE buffer.  
 ~Action~ 100 uL of Phenol:Chloroform:Isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1).  
 ~Action~ for 5 minutes at 11,000 rpm.  
 ~Action~ the aqueous phase to a new tube.  
 ~Action~ 0.1 volumes (10 uL) of 3M Sodium Acetate and 0.7 volumes (70 uL) of Isopropanol to the aqueous phase.  
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ for 10 minutes at room temperature. 
 ~Action~ for 30 minutes at 11,000 rpm at 4 degrees Celsius.  
 ~Action~ the supernatant.  
 ~Action~ the pellet with 200 uL of ice cold 70% ethanol.  
 ~Action~ for 5 minutes.  
 ~Action~ the pellet.

 ~Action~ remaining 3 uL of diluted plasmid prep on a 1% agarose gel to check for complete digestion.

OmniPrep™ For High Quality Genomic DNA Extraction From Fungal Tissue
 ~Action~ fungal tissue from liquid culture and wash 2-3 times in sterile water.
Fungal mycelia are best prepared by grinding samples using Molecular Grinding Resin™ in Genomic Lysis Buffer.
For fungal teliospores, grinding samples in liquid nitrogen to a fine powder and quickly add to an appropriate volume of Genomic Lysis Buffer is recommended.
 ~Action~ 10-20mg fungal mycelia to a microcentrifuge tube containing 500µl Genomic Lysis Buffer.
 ~Action~ 30µl Molecular Grinding Resin™ using a wide bore pipette tips and  ~Action~ with a microcentrifuge pestle.
For teliospoes,  ~Action~ ground powder to 500µl Genomic Lysis Buffer and  ~Action~ to wet sample.
Allow the sample to cool to room temperature.
 ~Action~ 200µl chloroform and  ~Action~ by inverting the tube several times.
 ~Action~ for 10 minutes at 14,000xg and carefully  ~Action~ the upper phase to a clean microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ 50µl DNA Stripping Solution to the sample and  ~Action~ several times to mix.
 ~Action~ the sample for 5-10 minutes at 60°C.
 ~Action~ 100µl Precipitation Solution and  ~Action~ by inverting the tube several times.
 ~Action~ the sample at 14,000xg for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ the supernatant to a clean tube and  ~Action~ the genomic DNA with 500µl isopropanol.
 ~Action~ the tubes 10 times to precipitate the DNA.
OPTIONAL: For increased DNA recovery,  ~Action~ 2µl Mussel Glycogen as a DNA carrier.
 ~Action~ at 14,000xg for 5 minutes to pellet genomic DNA.
 ~Action~ the supernatant.
 ~Action~ 700µl 70% ethanol to the tube and invert several times to wash the DNA pellet.
 ~Action~ for 1 minute at 14,000xg.
 ~Action~ or pipette off the ethanol wash.  
 ~Action~ the tube on a clean absorbent surface for several minutes to allow any excess ethanol to drain away.
 ~Action~ 50µl TE Buffer to the pellet.
 ~Action~ at room temperature for at least 15 minutes to rehydrate.
OPTIONAL: 1µl LongLife™ RNase for every 100µl TE Buffer can be added at this stage.
 ~Action~ DNA at 4°C, for long term storage store at -20°C or -80°C.
 ~Action~ 1µl Proteinase K solution for every 100µl Lysis Buffer and  ~Action~ at 60°C for 1-2 hours.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ samples in liquid nitrogen to a fine powder and quickly add to an appropriate volume of Genomic Lysis Buffer is recommended.

Stellaris® RNA FISH Protocol for Brain
 ~Action~ the slide-mounted tissue section to room temperature.
 ~Action~ the slide in cold 4% E.M. grade paraformaldehyde in 1X PBS for 15 minutes.
 ~Action~ with 1X PBS for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ twice with 1X PBS for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ the slide in nuclease-free water.
 ~Action~ the slide in 1X TEA buffer.
 ~Action~ the slide in 1X TEA + Acetic Anhydride for 10 minutes (Stirring!)

 ~Action~ the slide in 70% ethanol for 3 minutes.
 ~Action~ the slide in 95% ethanol for 3 minutes.
 ~Action~ the slide in 100% ethanol for 3 minutes.
 ~Action~ the slide in Chloroform for 5 minutes.
3 ~Action~ the slide in 100% ethanol for 3 minutes.
 ~Action~ the slide in 95% ethanol for 3 minutes.
Let  ~Action~ for 90+ minutes (but no longer than 4 hours).
If frozen before using,  ~Action~ the reconstituted probe solution to room temperature.
 ~Action~ well by vortexing, then  ~Action~ briefly.
To prepare the hybridization solution,  ~Action~ 4.0 μL of probe stock solution to 200 μL of hybridization buffer, and then  ~Action~ and cen ~Action~ ifuge.
This creates a working probe solution of 250 nM.
This solution will be used on step 18.
 ~Action~ a humidified chamber: 150 mm tissue culture plate; a single water-saturated paper towel placed alongside the inner chamber edge.
This chamber will help prevent evaporation of the probe solution from the tissue section.
After slide has dried for 90+ minutes,  ~Action~ 200 μL of hybridization buffer containing probe onto the tissue sections of the slide.
Carefully  ~Action~ a clean 24 x 60 mm rectangular coverglass over the hybridization solution to completely cover the tissue sections and allow for even distribution of the hybridization solution.
 ~Action~ the slide in the humidified chamber,  ~Action~ with the tissue culture lid, and  ~Action~ chamber with parafilm.
 ~Action~ in the dark at 37 °C for at least 4 hours (incubation can be continued up to 16 hours).
 ~Action~ the slide in wash buffer A, and allow the submerged coverglass to slide off the tissue section.
Gentle agitation maybe required to remove the coverglass.
 ~Action~ in the dark at 37 °C for 30 minutes.
 ~Action~ wash buffer A, and then  ~Action~ DAPI nuclear stain (wash buffer consisting of 5 ng/mL DAPI) to counterstain the nuclei.
 ~Action~ in the dark at 37 °C for 30 minutes.
 ~Action~ DAPI staining buffer, and then  ~Action~ slide in Wash Buffer B for 3 minutes.
 ~Action~ slide in 50% ethanol for 3 minutes.
 ~Action~ slide in 85% ethanol for 3 minutes.
 ~Action~ slide in 100% ethanol for 3 minutes.
Let  ~Action~ for 5-10 minutes.
 ~Action~ a drop or two (approximately 50-100 μL) of Prolong Gold Antifade Mountant onto the tissue sections.
 ~Action~ with a clean 24 x 60 mm coverglass, allowing the antifade to spread evenly across the tissue sections.
Allow Prolong Gold to  ~Action~ overnight, in the dark, at room temperature.
 ~Action~ the coverglass perimeter with clear nail polish, and allow to  ~Action~  ~Action~ the tissue section.
Gentle agitation maybe required to remove the coverglass.

MojoSort™ Human CD45 Nanobeads Protocol B
 ~Action~ cells from your tissue of interest without lysing erythrocytes.
In the final wash of your sample preparation,  ~Action~ the cells in MojoSort™ Buffer by  ~Action~ up to 4 mL in a 5 mL (12 x 75 mm) polystyrene tube.
Note: Keep MojoSort™ Buffer on ice throughout the procedure.
 ~Action~ the cells with a 70 μm cell strainer,  ~Action~ at 300 x g for 5 minutes, and  ~Action~ in an appropriate volume of MojoSort™ Buffer.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the cell concentration to 1 x 108 cells/mL.
 ~Action~ 100 μL of cell suspension (107 cells) into a new tube.
 ~Action~ the beads by  ~Action~  maximum speed, 5 touches.
 ~Action~ 10 μL of Nanobeads,  ~Action~ well and  ~Action~ on ice for 15 minutes. ~Action~ up the volume accordingly if separating more cells.
For example, add 100 μL for 1 x 108 cells.
When working with less than 107 cells, use indicated volumes for 107 cells.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ 100 μL for 1 x 108 cells.
When working with less than 107 cells, use indicated volumes for 107 cells.
Add MojoSort™ Buffer up to 4 mL and  ~Action~ the cells at 300 x g for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ the cells in 3 mL of MojoSort™ Buffer.
Optional:  ~Action~ an aliquot before placing the tube in the magnet to monitor purity and yield.
 ~Action~ the tube in the magnet for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ the liquid containing the unlabeled fraction.
 ~Action~ the tube from the magnet and  ~Action~ the first labeled fraction in appropriate amount of buffer.
 ~Action~ the tube containing the unlabeled fraction back in the magnet for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ the liquid containing the unlabeled fraction from the second magnetic incubation.
These are the CD45- cells, ready to use as needed.
 ~Action~ the tube from the magnet and  ~Action~ the fraction obtained in step 10 to  ~Action~ this second labeled fraction and  ~Action~  ~Amount~ of cell suspension (107 cells) into a new tube.
Resuspend the beads by vortexing, maximum speed, 5 touches.

RNA Isolation from Viral-infected Chlorella NC64A
 ~Action~ NC64A to mid-log phase.
 ~Action~ to 1 x 108 cells/ml.
 ~Action~ 30 ml concentrated cells per time point (3 x 109 cells~91 mg cells wet weight).
 ~Action~ with virus at m.o.i.=5 for appropriate time.
 ~Action~ infected cells by centrifugation at 5000 rpm, 5 min., 4°C.
 ~Action~ supernatant and  ~Action~ pellet in liquid nitrogen.
 ~Action~ at -80°C until ready to proceed to step #8.
 ~Action~ 1 to 2 samples from the freezer at a time (keep on ice),  ~Action~ pellets loose with spatula, and  ~Action~ 1 ml TRIZOL reagent to each tube.
Work as quickly as possible to prevent RNA degradation.
 ~Action~ pellets up with spatula and vortexing.
 ~Action~ into 2 ml microcentrifuge tube(s) containing 250 mg of 0.25-0.30 mm baked glass beads.
Immediately vortex at highest speed 5 min., 4°C.
 ~Action~ at -80°C overnight.
Repeat steps #8-12 for the remaining samples.
 ~Action~ samples and vortex another 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ 250 µl chloroform to samples, then vortex briefly.
Let stand at room temp. 3 min.
 ~Action~ samples at 12,000 x g, 15 min., 4°C.
Withdraw the RNA-containing aqueous upper phase and deliver to fresh microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ 500 µl isopropanol.
Let stand 10 min. at room temp.
 ~Action~ at 12,000 x g, 10 min., 4°C.
 ~Action~ supernatant.
 ~Action~ pellet with 75% EtOH with vortexing.
 ~Action~ 12,000 x g, 5 min., 4°C.
 ~Action~ pellets in vacuum dessicator 5-10 min.
DO NOT DRY COMPLETELY.
DNAse each sample by resuspending each pellet in 250 µl dd-H20.
 ~Action~ 250 µl of 2X MOPS, 20mM MgCl2 (2X), and 100-200 U RNAse-free DNAse I. 
 ~Action~ 1-2 h on ice.
 ~Action~ with equal volume of phenol:chloroform (500 µl).
 ~Action~ at 12,000 x g, 5 min., 4°C.
Withdraw aqueous phase, add NaOAc to 0.3 M.   
 ~Action~ 1 ml isopropanol.
Let stand 10 min., room temp.
 ~Action~ up to 12,000 x g, 10 min., 4°C.
 ~Action~ supernatant.
 ~Action~ pellet with 75 % EtOH with vortexing.
 ~Action~ 12,000 x g, 5 min., 4°C.
 ~Action~ pellets in vacuum dessicator 5-10 min.
Do not dry completely.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ at 5000 rpm, 5 min., 4°C.

Stellaris® RNA FISH Cells in Suspension Protocol

 ~Action~ supernatant, leaving cells in a pellet at base of tube.

 ~Action~ well by gently pipetting up and down to  ~Action~ pellet.
To permeabilize cells,  ~Action~ cells in 1 mL of 70% ethanol for at least 1 hour at +2 to +8 °C.
Cells can be stored at +2 to +8 °C in 70% ethanol up to a week before hybridization.
If frozen before using, warm the reconstituted probe solution to room temperature.
 ~Action~ well by vortexing, then  ~Action~ briefly.

While applying pressure, be careful not to move the coverglass horizontally as this could result in sheared cells.
The Kimwipe will wick up excess mounting medium.

ethanol for at least 1 hour at +2 to +8 °C.
If frozen before using,  ~Action~ the reconstituted probe solution to room temperature.
 ~Action~ well by vortexing, then centrifuge briefly.
To prepare the hybridization buffer containing probe,  ~Action~ 1 µL of probe stock solution to 100 µL of hybridization buffer, and then  ~Action~ and  ~Action~  ~Action~ the hybridization buffer containing probe, add 1 µL of probe stock solution to 100 µL of hybridization buffer, and then vortex and centrifuge, which is enough for one coverslip.
This creates a working probe solution of 125 nM.
This solution will be used in the steps below.

 ~Action~ in the dark at 37 °C for at least 4 hours.

 ~Action~ at room temperature for 2-5 minutes.

Charcoal treatment of seawater to remove organics (esp. vitamins).
 ~Action~ seawater for medium, filter through a 0.22 μm filter to remove cells and particles.
 ~Action~ or  ~Action~ the filtered water to sterilze.
Allow water to  ~Action~ before treating with charcoal.
 ~Action~ the sterilzed water into a designated flask with stir bar that can contain at least 1L of liquid.
 ~Action~ activated charcoal.
 ~Action~ 2.5g NaCl to 500mL of Milli Q water into a designated clean flask for charcoal washing.
The charcoal sticks so it is best to dedicate a flask for washing (and other treatment steps).
 ~Action~ 10g of activated charcoal to the NaCl2 solution.
 ~Action~ stir bar.
 ~Action~ for at least 10min.
 ~Action~ the charcoal by filtration upon a glass fiber (GF/F) filter using a designated filter rig.
Use a scoopula to add washed charcoal to the sterilized seawater made in Step1.
Take care not to rip the GF/F filter.
Obtain the remaining charcoal in the rig by  ~Action~ sterilzed water in the filtration rig and  ~Action~ that out into your flask with the sterilzed seawater (and now washed charcoal).
 ~Action~ the washed charcoal plus sterilzed seawater for at least 30min, using a stir plate.
 ~Action~ charcoal from the seawater by  ~Action~ the mixture using a disposable filtration rig with a 0.2 μm filter.

Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
Salt lake samples are  ~Action~ from hypersaline waters, which typically range from 15% w/v total salt, up to saturation (ca 35%).
Samples are  ~Action~ in sterile 5–10 mL vessels and may be  ~Action~ for several weeks at room temperature.
In the laboratory, cells and cellular debris are  ~Action~ by centrifugation (5,000g, 10 min, room temperature).
The supernatant is then  ~Action~ directly  ~Action~ by plaque assay.
The choice of host strains depends on the experimental objectives, and includes well-characterized members of the Halobacteriaceae, such as Hbt.
salinarum (host for ΦH and several others) or Har.
hispanica (host for SH1, His1, His2, and others), or natural isolates from the same source, such as Hrr.
coriense (host for HF2).
Base and overlay plates (90 mm) are  ~Action~ with MGM (see guidelines),  ~Action~ using 15% w/v agar.
A range of salt water concentrations should be  ~Action~  because salt concentration seems to greatly affect the size and clarity of plaques.
Plates can be  ~Action~ indefinitely at 4°C (wrapped in plastic to prevent dessication), but should be  ~Action~ to room temperature or warmer for use.
For virus isolation, 100–500 µl of the cleared water sample is  ~Action~ with 150 µl of exponentially growing host cells.
Then, 3–4 mL of molten (50°C) top-layer MGM (with 0.7% w/v agar) is  ~Action~  and the solution  ~Action~ gently and  ~Action~ evenly over the plate.
After setting on a level surface for 5–10 min, plates are  ~Action~ aerobically,  ~Action~ in airtight containers at 30°C and 37°C for 1–4 d, and che ~Action~ ed every day  ~Action~ 
Any visible plaques are  ~Action~ using sterile glass Pasteur pipettes, or sterile plastic micropipette tips.
These agar plugs are then  ~Action~ to tubes containing 500 µl of halovirus diluent: 2.47 M, NaCl; 90 mM, MgCl2; 90 mM, MgSO4; 60 mM, KCl; 3 mM, CaCl2; 10 mM, Tris-HCl, pH 7.5;
They are then  ~Action~ to homogenize the sample.
These suspensions are then  ~Action~ on overlay plates to  ~Action~ the isolates and to  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ are collected from  ~Reagent~  which typically range from 15% w/v total salt, up to saturation (ca 35%).

FLV tracer assays
Prepare FLVs for tracer assays.
 ~Action~ seawater samples from the desired location.
After determining the concentration of the FLVs in the concentrate, and the ambient concentration of viruses in the seawater, the proper amount of FLV concentrate should be added at tracer levels (<10% of original ambient virus concentration) into sample volumes of no less than 400 mL.
Designate a control treatment.
At each time point, total viral abundance and FLV numbers should be determined in duplicate from small volume subsamples (5–30 mL) taken into sterile, 15- or 50-mL polyethylene tubes.
Subsamples are immediately fixed with 1% to 2% (final concentration) 0.02-µm filtered formalin and  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Location~  ~Reagent~ from the desired location.

4% / 10% Stacking and Separating Protein Gel

 ~Action~ 5 uL TEMED, then invert tube several times to properly  ~Action~ all components and initiate the polymerization process.
 ~Action~ 1 mL at a time of the 10% separating gel mixture between the two pieces of glass until you are about 75% of the way full.
 ~Action~ a miniature amount of isopropyl alcohol on top of your separating gel so that it levels off (less than 50 uL), then wait for the gel to polymerize.
You will know it has polymerized as you should have some left in your centrifuge tube.
If you invert your centrifuge tube and the solution stays stuck on the bottom, then the gel has successfully polyermized.

 ~Action~ 1.6 mL H2O  ~Action~ 20 uL 10% Ammonium Persulfate. 
 ~Action~ 4 uL TEMED and invert tube to properly  ~Action~ and  ~Action~ polymerization.

Crude Membrane protein extraction from tissues
Thaw 20–50 mg of tissue or 15CM dish cells in 1 mL of high salt buffer.
Homogenize tissues using an IKA Ultra Turbax blender at maximum speed ( ∼25,000rpm) for 30 s. 
Ultracentrifuge the suspension in Beckman MLA 130 at 100,000 g for 10 min.
The tubes should be balanced to a difference less than 50 mg.
Discard the supernatant and homogenize pellets in 1 mL of carbonate buffer as in step 2 .
Incubate for 30 min with gentle mixing.
Collect the non-soluble material by centrifugation as in step 3 (If the content of integral membrane proteins in the purified membranes is not at least 30–40% of total identified proteins, steps 4–6 can be repeated two to three times).
Discard supernatant and resuspend pellets in wash buffer as in step 2 .

OmniPrep™ For High Quality Genomic DNA Extraction From Plant Tissue (Fresh or Frozen)
Most plant tissues are best prepared by freezing in liquid nitrogen.
 ~Action~ samples in liquid nitrogen to a fine powder and quickly  ~Action~ to an appropriate volume of Lysis Buffer.
 ~Action~ 50-100mg finely ground dried tissue, frozen tissue or fresh leave tissue to a microcentrifuge tube containing 500µl Genomic Lysis Buffer.
If ground, vortex for 5 seconds; if unground,  ~Action~ the sample with a microfuge pestle until a homogenous suspension is acquired, approximately 30-60 strokes.
 ~Action~ the sample at 65°C for 60 minutes with periodic inversions.
Allow the sample to  ~Action~ to room temperature.
 ~Action~ 200µl chloroform and mix by inverting the tube several times.
 ~Action~ for 10 minutes at 14,000xg and carefully  ~Action~ the upper phase to a clean microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ 50µl DNA Stripping Solution to the sample and  ~Action~ several times to mix.
 ~Action~ the sample for 5-10 minutes at 60°C.
 ~Action~ 100µl Precipitation Solution and mix by inverting the tube several times.
 ~Action~ the sample at 14,000xg for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ the supernatant to a clean tube and  ~Action~ the genomic DNA with 500µl isopropanol.
 ~Action~ the tubes 10 times to precipitate the DNA.
OPTIONAL: For increased DNA recovery, add 2µl Mussel Glycogen as a DNA carrier.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ 2µl Mussel Glycogen as a DNA carrier.
Centrifuge at 14,000xg for 5 minutes to pellet genomic DNA.
 ~Action~ the supernatant.
 ~Action~ 700µl 70% ethanol to the tube and  ~Action~ several times to wash the DNA pellet.
 ~Action~ for 1 minute at 14,000xg.
 ~Action~ or  ~Action~ the ethanol wash.  
 ~Action~ the tube on a clean absorbent surface for several minutes to allow any excess ethanol to drain away.
 ~Action~ 50µl TE Buffer to the pellet.
 ~Action~ at room temperature for at least 15 minutes to rehydrate.
OPTIONAL: 1µl LongLife™ RNase for every 100µl TE Buffer can be added at this stage.

Gel Electrophoresis
 ~Action~ 50 mL of 1X TAE Buffer into an Erlenmeyer Flask.
 ~Action~ 0.5 g Agarose and add it to the Erlenmeyer Flask.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ it to the Erlenmeyer Flask.
Place Erlenmeyer Flask in a microwave on high power for two minutes or until solution is clear and agarose is completely dissolved.
 ~Action~ Erlenmeyer Flask from microwave and let it sit on the lab bench to cool just until you can comfortably pick it up.
 ~Action~ 5 uL Ethidium into the flask and  ~Action~ to  ~Action~  taking care not to introduce bubbles.
 ~Action~ gel tray on clamp and clamp securely.
 ~Action~ well plates where you want wells and use a level to ensure it is balanced.
 ~Action~ contents of the Erlemeyer Flask into the gel tray and let it sit for 30 minutes, or until a blue tint appears.
 ~Action~ the well plates carefully as to not tear the gel and remove the tray from the clamp, but ensure the gel remains in the tray.
 ~Action~ gel tray into gel electrophoresis apparatus with the wells closer to the negative/black end.
 ~Action~ additional TAE Buffer to fill each side of the apparatus and to create a thin layer of buffer covering the top of the gel.
 ~Action~ 10 uL of the 1kb DNA Ladder with Loading Dye into a well.
Typically this is placed into one of the wells near an edge.
 ~Action~ your DNA with Loading Dye mixture into another well.
Repeat for each sample.
 ~Action~ lid on apparatus and  ~Action~ cables into amplifier.
Set amplifier to stay at a constant voltage of 100 V. Let run for 30 minutes or until the loading dye has sufficiently moved.
 ~Action~ gel from gel tray after draining excess TAE Buffer and  ~Action~ on plastic wrap.

Transformation Protocol.  
 ~Action~ competent cells on ice Chill approximately 5 ng (2 μl) of the ligation mixture in a 1.5 ml microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ 50 µl of competent cells to the DNA.
 ~Action~ gently by pipetting up and down or flicking the tube 4–5 times to mix the cells and DNA.
Do not vortex.
 ~Action~ the mixture on ice for 30 minutes.
Do not mix.
 ~Action~ at 42°C for 30 seconds.
Do not mix.
 ~Action~ 950 µl of room temperature media to the tube.
 ~Action~ tube at 37°C for 60 minutes.
 ~Action~ vigorously (250 rpm) or rotate.
 ~Action~ selection plates to 37°C.
 ~Action~ 50–100 µl of the cells and ligation mixture onto the plates.
 ~Action~  ~Amount~ of competent cells to the  ~Reagent~  ~Reagent~ on  ~Location~  ~Action~  ~Modifier~ 5 ng (2 μl) of the ligation mixture in a 1.5 ml microcentrifuge tube.
DNase I Treatment
DNase I made up to 40,000 U/ml in storage buffer (-20°C freezer door) = stock solution.
 ~Action~ stock solution 1:40 in 10x reaction buffer = 1,000 U/ml = 1 U/ul = working dilution.
Use at a 1:10 dilution: 1μl per 9 μl solution to be treated.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ at a 1:10 dilution: 1μl per 9 μl solution to be treated.
Incubate at room temperature for 2hr.
 ~Action~ 1M EDTA disodium salt dihydrate.
 ~Action~ 1M EGTA tetrasodium salt.
Sea stars bacterial sampling
Collected sea stars by hand. 
 ~Action~ the location for sampling of the star with sterile seawater to  ~Action~ any transient microbes.
This is important since the stars are in constant contact with environmental microbes and our sequencing technique is very sensitive; therefore, rinsing reduces noise.
For healthy individuals the sampling site (where the swabbing will occur) should be approximately 15 by 10 cm.
 ~Action~ a clean sterile swab from its wrapping and the cotton tip should be  ~Action~ to the previously rinsed sample location.
The swab should be  ~Action~ the sample location with moderate pressure.
One ‘swab’ consists of pulling the swab back and forth one; this should be  ~Action~ 10 times.
The swab should be  ~Action~ into a labeled sterile screw cap tube and then  ~Action~  ~Location~ for sampling of the star with sterile  ~Reagent~ to remove any  ~Reagent~ 
This is important since the stars are in constant contact with environmental microbes and our sequencing technique is very sensitive; therefore, rinsing reduces noise.
Phenol-chloroform extraction with ethanol precipitation

 ~Action~ the  ~Reagent~ (upper) to a new  ~Location~ by  ~Action~ with a  ~Device~  being careful to avoid material at the interface.
Repeat steps 1–3 as needed until the interface appears to be free of extracted material (one extraction may suffice for relatively pure viral preparations).

High Efficiency Transformation Protocol using NEB 10-beta Competent E. coli (C3019I)
 ~Action~ a tube of NEB 10-beta Competent E. coli cells on ice until the last ice crystals disappear.

Carefully  ~Action~ the tube 4-5 times to  ~Action~ cells and DNA.
Do not vortex.

Do not mix.
 ~Action~ at exactly 42°C for exactly 30 seconds.
Do not mix.

Do not mix.

Modified KAPA Express Extract
Incubate in a thermocycler for 10 minutes at 75ºC.
During this step, cells are lysed, nucleases and proteins degraded and DNA released.
Incubate for 5 minutes at 95ºC to inactivate the thermostable KAPA Express Extract protease.
Vortex reaction product for 2-3 sec.
Centrifuge at high speed for 1 minute to pellet debris.Transfer DNA-containing supernatant to a fresh tube.
Use 1 μl of DNA extract directly in a 25 μl PCR, without quantification.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ in a thermocycler for 10 minutes at 75ºC.

FlowCam Standard Operating Procedure
 ~Action~ FlowCamPush silver button on the left of machine face to turn on computer and machine.
 ~Action~ flow cell into the flow cell holder ~Action~ desired flow cell tubing based on application.
(In general we use the 100 um x 1 mm flow cell).Use a kimwipe or lens paper to gently  ~Action~ the glass portion of the flow cell. ~Action~ glass portion of the flow cell into the flow cell holder.Secure flow cell by gently  ~Action~ the male threaded holder until the flow cell is stationary.
Be careful not to screw too tightly at the risk of breaking the fragile flow cell.
Note:  Since there are multiple projects using the FlowCam be sure to select the flow cell labeled for each specific project.
 ~Action~ the flow cell holder into the FLowCamMake sure that the objective lens and collimator are compatible with each other.
For example, when using the 10X lens, use the corresponding 10X collimator.Use a kimwipe or lens paper to gently  ~Action~ the objective lens and collimnator. ~Action~ flow cell holder (screw pointing up) into the flow cell holder mount located in the middle of the camera apparatus.
 ~Action~ screw on top of holder to secure it to the mount. ~Action~ tubing on top of flow cell into the bottom of sample funnel.
 ~Action~ bottom tubing into tip of syringe.
 ~Action~ syringe-out tubing into small beaker for collecting waste.

Click Start Load Sample1.
Use pipet to  ~Action~ sample from your container.
Usually about 0.2-0.5 mL of homogenized sample is sufficient.
For dense cultures, a dilution may be appropiate (Be sure to note this in your files).
Sieving is great for raw samples that might have detritus or zooplankton.
2.
 ~Action~ tip of pipet into bottom of P1000 sample funnel.
Forcibly  ~Action~ pipet to ensure that sample ends up as one liquid mass and doesn't stick to the walls of the funnel.
3.
On the top menu bar,  ~Action~ Setup -> Pump -> Prime -> Aspirate 0.500mL from Flow Cell   4.
 ~Action~ Stop Pump when the sample volume has reached the flow cell Run Context  ~Action~ on Context.
A window with several tabs will pop up.
Notes Tab - any relevant metadata.
There is a file on the Desktop that can be pasted and modified as needed.
This file includes lines for date, experiment, strain, species, magnification, flow cell, syringe, dilution, etc.Fluidics tab - Adjust here the sample volume (usually 1 mL), relative to the stop rule (see below).
Also, make sure the efficiency is near 25%.Flow cell tab - Adjust the tube length below the flow cell.
By default it is at 0 cm.
Our flow cells are cut to have 10 cm tubing above and 20 cm tubing below.
Stop tab - Stop rule for terminating the run.
Usually after 100 uL (0.1 mL) of sample has been imaged.
This works well with 1 mL of sample and a short priming step (see Setup and Focus below).Reports tab -  ~Action~ the export data and  ~Action~ summary data checkboxes.
This saves the measurements of all captured particles.
The list file with collages of images are saved by default upon starting a run.You can save these settings and load them as needed.
Setup and Focus1.
Click Setup/Focus.
A window will pop up with a live camera view of the flow cell.2.
Use the X-axis and Y-axis adjustment knobs to center the flow cell.3.
Use the Coarse and Fine adjustment knobs to  ~Action~ the sample  ~Action~ 
 ~Action~ Sample1.
 ~Action~ Autoimage.2.
A pop-up with your Notes and Stop rule (Context) will show up.
You can either  ~Action~ a value to automatically stop the run (e.g.
# of events, volume or time) or  ~Action~ the 'Stop when user terminates...' button  ~Action~ and manually stop.3.
A window to create a folder for the run will pop up next.
 ~Action~ an informative folder name with sample info in the title (date, strain info, magnification, flow cell size, dilution, etc.)
and  ~Action~ save.
Once folder has been named, the sample run will begin.4.
The sample will run until the criteria of the set Stop Conditions are reached or the user terminates the run by pressing the Autoimage button which will now display a red stop symbol.
Data The data will be displayed for each filter on the Visual Spreadsheet page. ~Action~ your data (either by  ~Action~ the desired filter or  ~Action~ portions of the graphs and  ~Action~ Open View to evaluate the images. ~Action~ for any dilution used in Context -> Fluidics and checking the Sample Dilution box.
 ~Action~ the ratio of the dilution used (volume of sample / total volume)  Particles / mL is the cell count Make sure the Efficiency is within the range of the flow cell being used.

 ~Action~ the funnel with ddH2O.2.

Internal Genomic DNA Standard for Quantitative Metagenome Analysis
 ~Action~ genomic DNA in a volume of nuclease-free water to produce a stock concentration of 0.1 μg/μL.
 ~Action~ rehydrated DNA overnight at 4°C while rocking, and then  ~Action~ for 1 h at 65°C.
 ~Action~ working solution by adding 1 μL of the stock solution to 99 μL of nuclease-free water to produce a final concentration of 1 ng/μL.
 ~Action~ of stocks fluorometrically using Quant-iT™ PicoGreen® dsDNA Assay Kit Genomic DNA can be stored at −20 °C.
Just prior to sample DNA extraction,  ~Action~ enough standard DNA to each sample to reach ~0.1-1.0% of expected total reads.
Following sequencing,  ~Action~ (steps 8 and 9).
Using a bit score cutoff of 50,  ~Action~ by BLASTn homology search aganst the internal standard genome.
Using the results from step 8 and a bit score cutoff of 40,  ~Action~ against the RefSeq Protein database to identify all protein encoding reads derived from the internal standard genome.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ from dataset.
 ~Action~ of internal standard recovered from sequencing: Sr=SS/SPSr = number of molecules of internal standard genome recovered from sequencingSS = number of protein encoding internal standard reads in the sequence librarySP = number of protein encoding genes in the internal standard reference genome. 
 ~Action~  Pg=Ps*(Sa/Sr)Pg = total number of protein encoding genes in the samplePs = number of protein encoding sequences in the metagenome librarySa = number of molecules of internal standard genome added to the sampleSr = number of molecules of internal standard genome recovered from sequencing.

Anti-Neu5Gc Antibody Kit Protocol - Flow Cytometry
 ~Action~  ~Generic-Measure~  ~Reagent~ in  ~Location~ (diluent buffer).
The following tubes should be set up for flow cytometry analysis: 
* Three (3) tubes containing cells to be examined.
If choosing to use different dilutions of primary antibody, as noted in step 3, more tubes may be needed.
* Three (3) tubes containing positive control cells.
* Three (3) tubes containing negative control cells. 
Each set of tubes to be analyzed should receive an antibody treatment as follows:
* Tube 1 will contain cells that will receive no antibody, to be used as unstained control (optional but highly recommended).
* Tube 2 will contain cells that receive Control Antibody.
* Tube 3 will contain cells that receive Primary Antibody.
- Note: if this is the first time running this experiment, optimize by using different dilutions of primary antibody.
More tubes containing sample will be needed.
 ~Action~ cells by adding 1 ml cold PBS, then gently centrifuge at 4°C.
Carefully  ~Action~ supernatant and  ~Action~  ~Reagent~  ~Modifier~ remove supernatant and discard.
 ~Modifier~  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ in  ~Amount~ of the  ~Modifier~  ~Modifier~  ~Reagent~ as outlined above.
 ~Action~ cells on ice for at least 1 hour. 
 ~Action~ cells as above. 
Gently  ~Action~  ~Modifier~ resuspend  ~Reagent~ in  ~Amount~ Secondary Antibody in diluent buffer, and incubate for 1 hour on ice.
Wash cells as before.
Resuspend cell pellet in  ~Amount~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ as before.
Resuspend cell pellet in 400 μl of diluent buffer. 
Roseobacter Screening Of Surface Waters. 
For Viruses Pull Roseobacter cultures from freeze and  ~Action~ in 5 ml broth cultures. 
 ~Action~ virus screening in sterile 96 well flat-bottom tissue culture treated microtiter plates. 
 ~Action~ seawater filtrates at 4°C. 
 ~Action~ the viruses to the bacteria. 
 ~Action~ 15 µl of log phase cells and 15 µl of seawater filtrate (containing virus) into wells of a 96 well plate. 
Allow the viruses to absorb to the bacteria for 1 hour. 
 ~Action~ 200 µl growth media (1/2 or 1/10 YTSS) to the wells. 
 ~Action~ the plate with parafilm and incubate with shaking. 
Look for infected wells that show lysis with respect to uninoculated controls. 
Enrich for viruses by transferring from initial 96 well plate to another 96-well plate containing fresh liquid media (“frogging” into new wells). 
Once enriched sufficiently,  ~Action~ cells with 0.2um filtration into 1.5ml microfuge tubes Spin for 5 mins. at max to pellet cells. 
 ~Action~ supernatant to fresh tube for storage.  
 ~Action~ at 4°C.  
 ~Action~ wells containing virus by growing cells plus virus on solid media.   
 ~Action~ solid agar media and 0.5% overlay agar. 
 ~Action~ virus to cells using as a starting point, 25 µl virus from 96 well plate enrichments and 200 µl log-phase host bacteria for 1hr. 
 ~Action~ the virus-absorbed cells in the 5 ml overlay agar. 
 ~Action~ over the solid media. 
 ~Action~ and look for plaque formation. 
Pick representatives of all plaque types present and record appearance of the plaques. 
 ~Action~ the broth that contains the agar plugs at 4°C and allow the viruses to diffuse out of the agar into the broth. 
Once the viruses are plaque-purified they can be scaled-up in 5 ml broth cultures for DNA purification. 
 ~Action~ 25 µl of the plaque-purified virus (agar plug in ~100 µl broth) and absorb to 200 µl log-phase bacteria for 1 hr. 
 ~Action~ to 5 ml broth and grow with shaking. 
 ~Action~ cells and filter culture through 0.2 µm filter SYBR stain a portion of the filtrate to determine how much virus is present.  
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ from freeze and grow in  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~  
Staining protocol for unicellular protists: Lysotracker and Dapi
2% PFA Fixation: Add PFA drop by drop and mixing carefully into 1mL cells for a final concentration of 2%PFA. 
 ~Action~  ~Action~ PFA drop by drop and  ~Action~ carefully into 1mL cells for a final concentration of 2%PFA. 
Incubate cells for 4 min at room temperature. 
 ~Action~ at 1000g for 5 minutes. 
 ~Action~ cells with 1XPBS (1/2).

Isotopic labeling of freshwater mixotrophic algae using isotopic labeled heat-killed bacteria
 ~Action~ modified DY-V media.   
Media used for Ochromonas growth was a modified version of DY-V media.
Modifications were:No MES was used, as it can be used as a source of carbon (bicarbonate and heat-killed bacteria are the only sources of carbon used in this media).
No Na2SiO3 was used (Ochromonas does not need silica).
No NaNO3 (ammonium and heat-killed bacteria were the only sources of nitrogen used in this media).
Sodium bicarbonate added at a final concentration of 95 µM.
Bicarbonate addition is done before algal inoculum by 0.2 µm filtration of a stock solution (do not autoclave).
Media inoculation with labeled HKB. 
 ~Action~ 15N 13C labeled heat-killed bacteria (HKB) to the media (isolation and labeling of HKB was done following this protocol).
 ~Action~ an inoculum of the mixotrophic algae (volume of inoculum should be low as to avoid dilution of the isotopic label and carry over of nutrients).
NOTE: as an example, values commonly used were ~5x103 Ochromonas mL-1 and ~5x107 HKB mL-1 as starting concentrations for the cultures.
Mixotrophic growth of the algae Let the algae  ~Action~ o it incorporates the isotopic signature in its biomass.
 ~Action~ the algae growth through microscopy (live samples and/or fixed samples) and the decline of heat-killed bacteria (fixed samples and staining with DAPI to assess HKB concentrations through epifluorescence microscopy.
Sampling for assessment of algal isotopic signature Ochromonas was allowed to grow for 2-3 generations before sampling for isotopic signature.
Two kind of samples can be collected: 
Bulk measurements:  ~Action~ 30-50 mL of the cultures onto pre-combusted glass fiber filters and  ~Action~ at 60 ºC over night to stop all biological activity.
Afterwards, filters can be stored in glass vials at room temperature.
Further processing of the sample included an acidification step with HCl to remove inorganic carbon and the C- and N- isotopic composition of the sample was determined by an isotope rato mas spectrometer (IRMS).
Cell-specific measurements:  ~Action~ 2 mL of sample and  ~Action~  ~Modifier~  ~Reagent~    
Media used for Ochromonas growth was a modified version of DY-V media.
Modifications were:No MES was used, as it can be used as a source of carbon (bicarbonate and heat-killed bacteria are the only sources of carbon used in this media).
No Na2SiO3 was used (Ochromonas does not need silica).

Construction of U6-based sgRNA expression vectors
Order a pair of U6 vector-specific, 23nt targeting primers for each target For each target (GN19), order a forward primer TTCGN19 for the U6 promoter vectors; order a reverse primer AAACN19. 
Note that the N19 in the reverse primers is reverse complementary to that in the forward primer. 
To order primers compatible with both the pU6x-sgRNA vectors and pT7-gRNA (Add gene plasmid #4675; (JAO et al 2013)), order degenerate primers WTMGGN18 (forward) and AMMCN18C (reverse), where M=A or C, W=A or T. 
Again, the N18 in the reverse primers is reverse complementary to that in the forward primer. 
 ~Action~ 1µl 100µM stock each in a 20µl 1x NEB buffer 2. 
 ~Action~ the mixture as follows: 95 °C for 5 min, ramp down to 50 °C at 0.1 °C/sec, 50 °C for 10 min chill to 4 °C at normal ramp speed. 
 ~Action~ the following components to ligate the annealed oligos to the U6 vector of choice (pU6x-sgRNA #1-#5, see diagrams and plasmid list in the Guidelines). 
 ~Action~ at 37 °C for 20 min. 
 ~Action~ at 16 °C for 15 min. 
 ~Action~ at 37 °C for 10 min. 
 ~Action~ at 55 °C for 15 min. 
 ~Action~ at 80 °C for 15 min (optional).  
The reaction is ready for transformation (use 2 µl of the ligation and plate 10% ofthe transformants).
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~  ~Amount~  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~ each in a  ~Amount~  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~

MojoSort™ Human CD4 Memory T Cells Isolation Kit Protocol. 
 ~Action~ the tube in the magnet for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ the cells in 3 mL of MojoSort™ Buffer.
Note: If you observe aggregates, filter the suspension.
To maximize yield, you can disrupt the aggregates by pipetting the solution up and down.
 ~Action~ cells from your tissue of interest without lysing erythrocytes.
In the final wash of your sample preparation,  ~Action~ the cells in MojoSort™ Buffer by adding up to 4mL in a 5 mL (12 x 75 mm) polystyrene tube.
Note: Keep MojoSort™ Buffer on ice throughout the procedure.
 ~Action~ the cells with a 70 μm cell strainer, centrifuge at 300 x g for 5 minutes, and resuspend in anappropriate volume of MojoSort™ Buffer.
 ~Action~ and adjust the cell concentration to 1 x 108 cells/mL.
 ~Action~ 100 μL of cell suspension (107 cells) into a new tube.
 ~Action~ 10 μL of the Biotin-Antibody Cocktail, mix well and incubate on ice for 15 minutes.
Scale up the volume accordingly if separating more cells.
For example, add 100 μL for 1 x 108 cells.
When working with less than 107 cells, use indicated volumesfor 107 cells.
Optional: Keep unused cells, or take an aliquot before adding the cocktail to monitor purity and yield.
 ~Action~ the beads by vortexing, maximum speed, 5 touches.
 ~Action~ 10 μL of Streptavidin Nanobeads.
 ~Action~ well and  ~Action~ on ice for 15 minutes.
Scale up the volume accordingly if separating more cells.
For example, add 100 μL for 1 x 108 cells.
When working with less than 107 cells, use indicated volumes for 107 cells.
 ~Action~ the cells by adding 3 mL of MojoSort™ Buffer;  ~Action~ at 300 x g for 5 minutes,  ~Action~ supernatant.
Optional: Take an aliquot before placing the tube in the magnet to monitor purity and yield Pour out and collect the liquid.
These are your cells of interest; DO NOT DISCARD.
If needed,  ~Action~ 3 mL of MojoSort™ Buffer and  ~Action~ steps 8 and 9 with the magnetically labeled fraction up to two times, and then  ~Action~  ~Device~ in the  ~Location~ for  ~Time~ 
Resuspend the  ~Reagent~ in  ~Amount~ of  ~Reagent~ 
Note: If you observe aggregates, filter the suspension.

 ~Action~ LB-antibiotic plates at 37°C.

Frying Chips for Frying Oil Studies (Food Science)
 ~Action~ Fry Daddy with 900 g liquid soybean (or other edible) oil.
 ~Action~ Fry Daddy and  ~Action~ to frying temperature (180 C).
 ~Action~ a temperature controller if necessary.
 ~Action~ temperature data using a computer if desired.
 ~Action~ chips initially (approximately 40 g, or 20-25 chips).
 ~Action~ chips in the basket provided for 2 minutes.
 ~Action~ the basket, drain the chips well, and  ~Action~ onto a paper towel to  ~Action~ and cool.
 ~Action~ chips out so that they all have contact with the paper towel.
Wait for them to dry a bit.
 ~Action~ chips on the paper towels if necessary to get rid of any pooled oil.
 ~Action~ chips back into weigh boats and record a final weight.
 ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Device~ with  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~ (or other edible)  ~Reagent~  ~Modifier~  oil.
One-Step Transformation of Yeast

 ~Action~ 10 uL of 0.2 N Lithium Acetate to the microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ yeast from 1 mL liquid culture or take a toothpick full of freshly grown yeast on a plate and resuspend in the solution.
 ~Action~ 1 ug of DNA and briefly  ~Action~ 
 ~Action~ at 45°C for 30 minutes to 1 hour,  ~Action~ briefly every 10 minutes.
 ~Action~ 1 mL water to the tube and  ~Action~ to mix, then  ~Action~ at 14,000 RPM for 15 seconds.
 ~Action~ the supernatant and  ~Action~ the pellet in 200 uL water, then  ~Action~ on selective plates and  ~Action~  ~Amount~ of 50% Polyethylene Glycol 3350 to a 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube.
RNA (and optional DNA) extraction from environmental samples (filters)
Take frozen tubes out of the -80C freezer, keep on ice.
While filtere are thawing, add RNase/DNase-free 0.5mm Silica beads to each sample tubea.
If RLT+ buffer (with beta mercaptoethanol) was not added previously, add it here.
 ~Action~ for 5 minutes to ensure beads disrupt filter
a. Ensure filter remains in RLT+ buffer the whole time
b. Options to increase yield:
i.  ~Action~ pre-heated RLT+ buffer (heat for 2-3 minutes at 65C)
ii.  ~Action~ tube on Tissue lyser for bead beating
iii.  ~Action~ for additional minutes Once thoroughly lysed (note foam/bubbles may have appeared),  ~Action~ liquid lysate to new tube (avoid transferring filter).
Using sterile forceps,  ~Action~ the filter carefully into a 5mL sterile syringe.
 ~Action~ out excess lysate from filter through the syringe into the new tube of lysate.
New tube for each sample should only contain lysate.
a. Optional step is to run this lysate through a Qiashredder for additional lysis.
**Start with Qiagen extraction steps here (following Qiagen DNA/RNA All prep kit): 
 ~Action~ the lysate to the AllPrep DNA spin column.
 ~Action~ for 30 seconds at > 10,000 rpm.
 ~Action~ flow-through (filtrate) into a new tube for RNA purification.
This DNA column can now be stored in the fridge until DNA extraction (4C).
a. If multiple spins of the lysate are required, continue this until all lysate has been passed through the DNA column and all flow-through has been obtained in a new tube.
 ~Action~ 1 volume of 70% EtOH to the RNA flow-through product, mix by pipetting.
Do not centrifuge.
 ~Action~ 1 volume of 70% EtOH to the RNA flow-through product, mix by pipetting.
Do not centrifuge.
 ~Action~ up to 700µl of sample (including any precipitate) to an RNeasy spin column.
 ~Action~ for 30 seconds at > 10,000 rpm.
 ~Action~ the flow-through.
 ~Action~ 350µl of Buffer RW1 to RNeasy spin column.
 ~Action~ for 15 seconds at > 10,000 rpm.
 ~Action~ the flow-through.
Make up DNase I and Buffer RDD stock mix for DNase digestion.
For each sample  ~Action~ 10µl of DNaseI stock to 70µl of Buffer RDD,  ~Action~ solution and  ~Action~ briefly.
 ~Action~ DNaseI mix (80µl) directly to RNase spin column.
 ~Action~ at room temperature for 15 minutes.
Again,  ~Action~ 350µl of Buffer RW1 to RNeasy spin column.
 ~Action~ for 15 seconds at > 10,000 rpm.
 ~Action~ the flow-through.
 ~Action~ 500µl of Buffer RPE to RNeasy spin column.
 ~Action~ for 15 seconds at > 10,000 rpm.
 ~Action~ the flow-through.
Again, add 500µl of Buffer RPE to RNeasy spin column.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ 500µl of Buffer RPE to RNeasy spin column.
Centrifuge for 2 minutes at > 10,000 rpm.
 ~Action~ the flow-through.
Option to place RNeasy spin column into a new 2mL collection tube and centrifuge at full speed for 1 minute – this will eliminate any possible carry over of Buffer RPE.
 ~Action~ RNeasy spin column into a new 1.5ml collection tube, add 30-50µl RNase-free water.
 ~Action~ for 1 minute at > 10,000 rpm to elute the RNA.
Options to increase yield:
i.  ~Action~ RNase-free water ahead of addition to RNeasy column
ii. Let RNase free water sit on RNeasy column for 1-2 minutes before centrifugation
iii.  ~Action~ eluted RNA back into the RNeasy column and re-centrifuge to increase concentration.
Genomic DNA purification Grab the DNA spin columns out of the fridge.
 ~Action~ 500µl Buffer AW1 to All Prep DNA spin column.
 ~Action~ for 15 seconds at > 10,000 rpm.
 ~Action~ the flow-through.
Again  ~Action~ 500µl of Buffer AW2 to the DNA column.
 ~Action~ for 2 minutes at full speed.
 ~Action~ the flow-through.
Place DNA column into a new 1.5ml collection tube,  ~Action~ 50-100µl of Buffer EB to the column.
Let sit at room temperature on the column for 1 minute.
 ~Action~  ~Time~ to ensure beads disrupt filter

NUCLEIC dotMETRIC™
For double stranded DNA, use undiluted Nucleic Acid Dilution Buffer.
For RNA or oligos,  ~Action~ the Nucleic Acid Dilution Buffer 100 fold.
i.e. Use 1µl Nucleic Acid Dilution Buffer in 99µl ultrapure water.
 ~Action~ samples at least 1:1 with the appropriate Dilution Buffer.
 ~Action~ the NUCLEIC Test Strip box,  ~Action~ a strip, and  ~Action~ the protective sheets using the forceps provided.
 ~Action~ the white NUCLEIC Strip to the application board with the side magnets.
 ~Action~ 1‐5µl of the diluted samples to the Test Strip using one of these two methods (or see the Guidelines for using G‐Biosciences’ Spot Application Device): 
Free‐Drop Method Of Application  ~Action~ the pipette plunger until a drop is formed at the tip of the pipette tip.
 ~Action~ the drop until it touches the Test Strip.
The nucleic acid solution drop will immediately spread on the Test Strip.
dotMETRIC™ Application Method. 
 ~Action~ sample by point of contact capillary action.
Use pipette tips with an outside bore diameterof 0.6‐0.7 mm (Cat. # 786‐64).
 ~Action~ the pipette tip straight up and allow the capillary action of the strip to draw the sample from the pipette tip (see figure below).
Do not use the plunger to force the solution out.
NOTE: Accurately pipetting 1µl requires skill and caution.
A deviation of up to ± 20% could be due simply to pipetting errors.
In addition, applying more than >1 µl or multiple spots are sometimes slow & tedious.
Samples do not need to dry before adding NUCLEIC Dye.
 ~Action~ the NUCLEIC strip in a developing tray (Cat. # 786‐024) or other small dish.
 ~Action~ 0.5ml NUCLEIC Dye directly to the strip.
 ~Action~ at room temperature for 1 minute without shaking or rocking.
 ~Action~ the NUCLEIC Dye and  ~Action~ the strip for 10 seconds in 50ml ultra pure water.
 ~Action~ the rinse and  ~Action~ with 50ml ultra pure water for 30‐60 seconds or until the blue background disappears.
 ~Action~ the strip from the second wash as soon as the blue background disappears.
For Free‐Drop Method: Compare the color of the test sample spot with the dotMETRIC™ Standard provided.
For dotMETRIC Application: Use the NUCLEIC dotMETRIC™ scale to  ~Action~  ~Reagent~  ~Generic-Measure~ 
i.e. Use  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~ in  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~ Dilute  ~Reagent~  ~Modifier~  ~Generic-Measure~ with the  ~Modifier~  ~Reagent~

Alpha-Synuclein ELISA Kit Protocol

 ~Action~ a 1L bottle as “1X Wash Buffer”.
 ~Action~ 5X Wash Buffer 1:5 using lab grade water* and  ~Action~ well.

 ~Action~ an appropriate sized bottle as “1X Reagent Diluent”.
 ~Action~ 2X Reagent Diluent to 1X by  ~Action~ 30mL of 2X Reagent Diluent to 30mL of lab grade waterin the bottle labeled “1X Reagent Diluent”.
 ~Action~ well by vortex.
Reconstitute lyophilized standard with 50μL of lab grade water and  ~Action~  ~Action~ lyophilized standard with 50μL of lab grade water and mix well by vortex.
Theconcentration after reconstitution will be 500μg/mL.
 ~Action~ (2) 1.5mL microcentrifuge tubes as intermediate #1 & intermediate #2.
 ~Action~ 990μL of 1X Reagent Diluent into intermediate #1 & intermediate #2 tubes.
 ~Action~ 10μL from the vial of reconstituted standard and  ~Action~ to 990μL of 1X Reagent Diluent inintermediate tube #1.
 ~Action~ well by vortex.
 ~Action~ 10μL from intermediate #1 and  ~Action~ to 990μL of 1X Reagent Diluent in intermediate #2tube.
 ~Action~ well by vortex.
The final concentration of intermediate tube #2 will be 50ng/mL.
 ~Action~ (8) 1.5mL microcentrifuge tubes as #1-8.
 ~Action~ 1280μL of 1X Reagent Diluent to tube #1 and 825μL of 1X Reagent Diluent to tubes #2-8.
 ~Action~ 40μL from intermediate #2 and  ~Action~ to 1280μL of 1X Reagent Diluent in tube #1.
 ~Action~ well by vortex (this will be the top point of the standard curve, 1500pg/mL).
 ~Action~ 550μL from tube #1 and  ~Action~ to 825μL of 1X Reagent Diluent in tube #2.
 ~Action~ well by vortex.
Continue making 2.5 fold serial dilutions by adding 550μL of the previous dilution to 825μL of 1XReagent Diluent in tubes #3-7.
 ~Action~ well by vortex between each dilution.
Note: Tube #8 will be the zero or blank sample and should only contain 1X Reagent Diluent Dilute samples in 1X Reagent Diluent.
 ~Action~ each dilution by vortexing 3 X 2 seconds.
 ~Action~ samples in duplicate or triplicate.
Note: It is good practice to run at least 2 dilutions for each sample to ensure one of the dilutions fallswithin the linear range of the standard curve.
We recommend a minimum dilution of 1:10.
Note: Dilution factors will vary based on the sample matrix of your experiments.
We recommendrunning a subset of your samples in the kit to determine optimal dilutions and evaluate any matrixeffects.
Failure to do this type of optimization could result in inconclusive data, for which Biolegend isnot responsible.

 ~Action~ wash buffer and pat dry.
 ~Action~ 3 more times for a total of 4 washes.
 ~Action~ 200μL of each standard to the plate in duplicate or triplicate.
Follow the plate layout below.
Note: The volumes in Table 2 are sufficient for running the standard curve in triplicate.

Sea stars bacterial sampling
 ~Action~ d  ~Reagent~  ~Method~ 
 ~Action~ the location for sampling of the  ~Reagent~ with  ~Modifier~  ~Reagent~ to remove any transient microbes.
This is important since the stars are in constant contact with environmental microbes and our sequencing technique is very sensitive; therefore, rinsing reduces noise.
For healthy individuals the sampling site (where the swabbing will occur) should be approximately 15 by 10 cm.
 ~Action~ a  ~Modifier~  ~Reagent~ from its  ~Location~ and the  ~Reagent~ should be  ~Action~ to the previously rinsed  ~Location~ 
The  ~Reagent~ should be  ~Action~ the  ~Location~ with  ~Method~ 
One ‘swab’ consists of pulling the swab back and forth one; this should be done 10 times.
The  ~Reagent~ should be  ~Action~ into a  ~Modifier~  ~Modifier~  ~Location~ and then  ~Action~ on ice until it can be  ~Action~ at  ~Temperature~ 
 ~Reagent~ are then ready for  ~Method~  ~Location~ for  ~Action~ of the star with sterile seawater to  ~Action~  ~Modifier~  ~Reagent~ 
This is important since the stars are in constant contact with environmental microbes and our sequencing technique is very sensitive; therefore, rinsing reduces noise.
Dimethylglyoxime reagent for cobalt analyses
 ~Action~ 0.2232 g of EDTA into 600 mL of Milli-Q for a final concentration of 10-3 mol L-1 EDTA.
Weigh out approximately 1.2 g of DMG (dimethylglyoxime) onto a weigh boat, and  ~Action~ it into the EDTA solution.
Weigh what is left on the weigh boat (DMG is very sticky so not all of it will pour into the EDTA solution) and record the final weight that was placed into the EDTA solution.
 ~Action~ this solution in a microwave at 50% power until the DMG is fully dissolved,  ~Action~ it carefully in between microwaving, and trying to prevent it from boiling.
This takes up to 30 minutes, so be patient and  ~Action~ it slowly and carefully.
 ~Action~ the solution on ice and let it  ~Action~ overnight in a refrigerator.
After it has recrystallized,  ~Action~ (or slowly  ~Action~  the supernatant until there is as little liquid as possible.
Then  ~Action~ the remaining crystals into a clean, dry weigh boat (that you have weighed and noted the weight for later use) and let the remaining liquid  ~Action~ overnight inside a laminar flow hood.
After all the liquid has evaporated,  ~Action~ the weight boat again to get an approximate measurement of the amount of DMG you have recrystallized.
 ~Action~ how much methanol is needed to  ~Action~ to the DMG in order to get a final concentration of 0.1 mol L-1 DMG, and obtain a trace metal clean bottle of the appropriate size.
 ~Action~ the clean bottle, and then carefully  ~Action~ the recrystallized DMG into this clean bottle and re-weigh (not all the DMG is easily transferred into the clean bottle, so the re-weigh is necessary).
Now  ~Action~ the amount of optima methanol needed to get the desired concentration of 0.1 mol L-1, and  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Amount~ of  ~Reagent~ into  ~Amount~ of  ~Reagent~ for a final concentration of  ~Generic-Measure~  ~Reagent~ 
Weigh out  ~Modifier~  ~Amount~ of  ~Reagent~ (dimethylglyoxime) onto a  ~Device~  and combine  ~Mention~ into the  ~Reagent~ 
Generating viral metagenomes from the coral holobiont
At Trunk Reef, approximately 45 g of coral tissue was sampled from three healthy, freshly collected coral colonies of Pocillopora damicornis.
Approximately 20 g of Acropora tenuis tissue was sampled from three healthy, freshly collected coral colonies collected in Pioneer Bay.
Fragments were  ~Action~ in autoclaved, 0.02 μm filtered virus-free seawater.
Subsequently, tissue was  ~Action~ from the coral skeleton, using an air-gun, into 15 mL 0.02 μm filtered (Anotop, Whatman) SM buffer (100 mM NaCl, 8 mM MgSO4, 50 mM Tris pH 7.5) in a zip-lock bag.
Briefly, 5 mL of chloroform per 40 mL of coral blastate was  ~Action~ and samples were  ~Action~ gently for 1 h at room temperature.
Coral blastates were  ~Action~ at 5000 rpm for 1 min (Heidolph SilentCrusher™).
Samples were immediately  ~Action~ at 1000 g for 15 min.
The supernatant was  ~Action~ to sterile glass corex tubes and  ~Action~ at 12,000 g for 15 min to  ~Action~ the majority of microbial cells (Beckman Coulter JA 25.50 rotor).
A cesium chloride (CsCl) density gradient was then formed by  ~Action~ 1 mL of 1.7, 1.5, and 1.35 g mL−1 CsCl into 13.2 mL UltraClear™ ultracentrifuge tubes (Beckman Coulter) with 9 mL sample layered on the top of the gradient.
Gradients were then  ~Action~ for 2 h at 60,000 g at 4°C in a swinging bucket rotor.
In the MECH method, the coral tissue blastate was  ~Action~ at 10,000 rpm for 1 min.
The coral tissue blastate was then  ~Action~ at 400 g for 5 min.
The supernatant was then  ~Action~ into 1.5 mL aliquots in 2 mL eppendorf tubes containing 0.3 mL acid-washed glass beads (425–600 μm diameter) (Sigma-Aldrich).
The tubes were placed in a bead beater and cells were  ~Action~ at 5000 rpm for 5 min.
Tubes were  ~Action~ at top speed in a bench-top Eppendorf centrifuge for 1 min.
The supernatant was collected for viral fractionation using step CsCl density gradients.
To confirm that the MECH method was not disrupting virus particles, two dsDNA viruses, OtV-2 (Weynberg et al., 2011) and EhV-86 (Wilson et al., 2005b), were subjected to the same mechanical disruption protocol.
Flow cytometry was used to  ~Action~  ~Action~ to the same mechanical disruption protocol.
Flow cytometry was used to enumerate viruses before and after disruption.
All samples were  ~Action~ with DNase and RNase (Ambion) prior to nucleic acid extraction.
DNA was  ~Action~ and RNase  ~Action~ using a MasterPure kit (Epicentre, Illumina) following manufacturer's instructions.
RNA was  ~Action~ using a Qiagen QIAamp viral RNA kit (Qiagen) following manufacturer's instructions, including the final DNase step (Ambion).
Two different amplification methods were used.
In order to  ~Action~ some of the inherent biases in multi-displacement amplification (MDA), such as a preference for ssDNA viral genomes, DNA extractions were converted to dsDNA prior to amplification.
Triplicate 10 μ L aliquots of the DNA extractions, containing ds and ssDNA viral genomes,  ~Action~ a single round of Klenow reaction (3′–5′ exo-, 5U/μ L) by  ~Action~ 1.5 μ L of 10× reaction buffer (New England Biolabs Buffer 2), 1.5 μ L of dNTPs (2.5 mM stock), 1 μ L of random hexamer primers (50 ng/μ L, Invitrogen).
The reaction was  ~Action~ at 94°C for 3 min.
The reaction was then  ~Action~ on ice for 3 min to allow for primer annealing.
1 μ L of Klenow (3′–5′ exo-) was added and incubated at 25°C for 10 min.
It was then  ~Action~ at 37°C for 60 min.
It was then  ~Action~ with a termination step of 75°C for 20 min.
After termination, reactions were  ~Action~ and  ~Action~ using a Qiagen QIAamp DNA mini kit and  ~Action~ in 50 μL of Buffer AE.
Replicate MDA reactions (n = 3 for each sample) were  ~Action~ using 2.5 μ L dsDNA template and the Qiagen RepliG® kit using the standard protocol.
All reactions were  ~Action~ on a 0.8% agarose gel in 1× TAE at 100 V for 30 min to confirm amplification,  ~Action~ and  ~Action~ with QIAampl DNA minikit and  ~Action~ in 200 μ L of Buffer AE.
Negative controls were treated the same and also sent for  ~Action~ to confirm that no viral contamination was present.
As with the RepliG® protocol, Klenow Fragment (3′–5′ exo-) was used to  ~Action~ all DNA genomes to dsDNA using RP-SISPA primers with a 3′ random hexamer sequence that is used for downstream PCR amplification.
To label the first strand with the RP-SISPA primer, 5 μL of nucleic acid was  ~Action~ to 9 μL reaction mix containing: The reaction was  ~Action~ at 94°C for 3 min.
The reaction was then  ~Action~ on ice for 3 min to allow for primer annealing.
1 μL of Klenow Fragment (3′–5′ exo-, 5U/μL, NEB #) was  ~Action~ and  ~Action~ at 37°C for 60 min.
A second round of Klenow Fragment reaction (3′–5′ exo) labeled the second strand with the SISPA primer, by  ~Action~ an additional 1 μL of primer and 1 μL dNTP.
The reaction then  ~Action~ a 94°C for 3 min heating step.
The reaction was then  ~Action~ on ice for 3 min.
The reaction then underwent a final addition of 1 μL of Klenow Fragment (3′–5′ exo-).
The reaction was  ~Action~ at 37°C for 60 min.
The reaction was then  ~Action~ at 75°C for 20 min.
Briefly, in preparation for cDNA synthesis, 10 μ L purified RNA viral template was mixed with 1 μ L of 2.5 mM dNTPs and 1.3 μ L of FR26RV-N (GCCGGAGCTCTGCAGATATCNNNNNN, 10 μ M stock) and FR40RV-T primer (GCCGGAGCTCTGCAGATATC(T)20, 50 nM stock).
The reaction was  ~Action~ to 65°C for 5 min.
The reaction was then  ~Action~ on ice for 3 min to allow the primers to anneal.
While still on ice, 1 μL DTT (Invitrogen) was  ~Action~ to the reaction as an enzyme stabilization reagent with 1 μL RNase OUT (Invitrogen) to protect the sample from RNAse activity.
The complementary DNA strand was  ~Action~ with 200 U of Superscript III reverse transcriptase.
The reaction was  ~Action~ initially at 25°C for 10 min to allow annealing of the hexamer 3′ end of primer FR26RV-N and the poly(T)20 3′ end of primer FR40RV-T to the template while cDNA synthesis commenced.
The temperature was then  ~Action~ to 50°C for 60 min.
The first strand synthesis reaction was  ~Action~ immediately to 94°C for 3 min and then rapidly  ~Action~ on ice.
A complementary second strand was subsequently  ~Action~ at 37°C for 60 min with the addition of 1 μL Klenow Fragment (3′–5′ exo-, 5U/μL).
The Klenow reaction was  ~Action~ with a final incubation at 75°C for 20 min.
PCR amplification of the SISPA primer labeled template (DNA and RNA) was done in triplicate 25 μL reactions containing: The reaction was  ~Action~ at 95°C for 10 min.
The reaction then  ~Action~ 30 cycles of denaturation at: The PCR reactions were  ~Action~ on to a 0.8% agarose gel in 1×TAE at 100 V for 30 min.
If amplification resulted in visible PCR products (typically a smear; products should be longer than 250 bp), a reconditioning PCR was performed on pooled reactions as follows.
One reconditioning PCR contained 10 μL of pooled SISPA reaction template, 10 μL 10× buffer, 16 μL dNTP (2.5 mM stock), 8 μL FR20RV primer (10 μ M stock) and 0.75 μL TaKaRa LA HS Taq.
The reaction was  ~Action~ at 95°C for 10 min.
The reaction then  ~Action~ 5 cycles of denaturation at: Reactions were  ~Action~ and QC was  ~Action~ 
After amplification, samples were  ~Action~ with a QIAamp® DNA Mini kit (RepliG® amplification) or a MinElute® PCR purification kit (RP-SISPA).
Samples were  ~Action~ for quantification using a Quant-iT PicoGreen® kit on a NanoDrop 3300 fluorospecrometer, for quality (260:280 ratios) on a NanoDrop 2000, and were  ~Action~ on a 0.8% agarose gel in 1× TAE at 100 V for 30 min to confirm a size range appropriate for sequencing (~250–500 bp) was present without contamination of smaller fragments.
All metagenomes were sequenced using Nextera XT MiSeq 250 bp paired-end sequencing (Illumina) at the Ramaciotti Centre, University of New South Wales, Sydney, Australia.
Raw sequence reads were  ~Action~ in CLC Genomics Workbench 5.5.
Sequences were  ~Action~ as Illumina paired-end reads, adaptor sequences were  ~Action~  and reads were  ~Action~ for quality using a PHRED score of 20 and a minimum length of 100 bp.
Paired reads were  ~Action~ and a final data set containing merged reads and ORFans was checked again for QC with a minimum length of 200 bp.

Isolation and isotopic labeling of bacteria

The recipe for 1L of minimal growth medium (M9) is as follows:

Bacterial plating.   
Use a small volume (i.e. 0.1 mL) of the sample you want to  ~Action~ your bacteria to  ~Action~ M9 agar plates.

Picking and transfer of colonies.

Recommended to do a first transfer into a small volume (~ 25 - 50 mL).

Production of labeled bacterial biomass.  
In order to produce a large ammount of biomass,  ~Action~ some of the bacteria from the M9 cultures tubes to a larger volume (i.e. 1L).
Let bacteria  ~Action~ until media is completely cloudy and a maximum yield is achieved of biomass (can be 3-4 days until C and N is consummed).
NOTE: for isotopic labeling, M9 media used in this step will contain 15NH4Cl and 13C D-glucose.

Detecting Fungal Infections in Almonds
Manually  ~Action~ almond kernel samples that are pasteurized and shelled.
As mentioned in the 'Before Start Instructions', the almond kernels should be  ~Action~ from multiple harvest cycles.
These particular samples were obtained from the 2012 and 2013 almond seasons.
The samples should be shelled and should not have any type of physical damage or any marks.
 ~Action~ weight and size of almond kernels Separate the samples into two groups.
Out of the 550 almond kernels collected 460 of those will be infected with two types of fungi that commonly affect almond crops.
230 will be infected with A. flavus and another 230 will be infected with A. parasiticus.
The remaining 90 kernels will remain uninfected and will serve as a control group.
 ~Action~ A. flavus and A. parasiticus isolates to infect almonds.
These two types of fungi were chosen due to their well known colonization on the surface of almond kernels.
Prior to inoculation,  ~Action~ the fungi isolates and  ~Action~ them in culture.
Use 5% reconstituted tomato juice agar, in this case it will be V8 juice agar, and  ~Action~ each isolate for 6 days at a temperature of 31 °C in a dark environment.
Once fungal isolates have been grown, conidia is  ~Action~ using a sterilized cotton swab and is  ~Action~ in sterile deionized water.
A haemocytometer will be used to quantify the water solution with conidia and it will then be  ~Action~ to a concentration of 105 spores per ml-1.
 ~Action~ incision on the bottom right of almond kernels using a B-D® 16G1 Precision Glide® Needle.
This incision serves as the point of infection where the conidia in water would be placed.
After making the incision on the surface of the almond, the kernels will be sterilized by  ~Action~ them in 10% bleach solution for a period of 7 minutes.
The kernels will then be  ~Action~ three times with sterile deionized water and will be  ~Action~ a second time into a Dichloran solution for 2 seconds.
 ~Action~ moisture from surface of almonds by blotting them and  ~Action~ them to a biological safety cabinet for a period of 10 to 15 minutes.
 ~Action~ each almond with 5 μl of the fungi solution.
As mentioned earlier, almonds will be in two separate groups: infected and control.
The infected almonds will be inoculated with either A. flavus or A. parasiticus.
Once the almonds have been inoculated,  ~Action~ deionized water to the container where they are located and  ~Action~ them for a period of 7 days at a temperature of 31° in a dark place.
Once the incubation period is over,  ~Action~ almonds with deionized water to remove any traces of fungi spores from the surface.
 ~Action~ almond kernels in a fume hood for a period of 12 hours.
Once the 12 hours are up  ~Action~ kernels at a constant temperature of 2.6°C.
 ~Action~ almond and  ~Action~ it under the spectrophotometer, then  ~Action~ black optic mask in the space between these two.
Scan the surface of the almond kernel using the spectrophotometer, for each individual almond kernel take 32 scans of the face across a wavelength range of 400 nm to 2500 nm, in 2-nm increments.
Use statistical analysis software to  ~Action~  ~Modifier~ select  ~Reagent~ that are  ~Modifier~ and  ~Modifier~

Generation of DNA fragments by DNase digestion
In a 50 µL reaction volume, resuspend 8 µg DNA in 50 mM Tris·HCl (pH 7.6), 10 mM MnCl2, 100 µg mL–1 bovine serum albumin, and 0.01 SU mL–1 DNase I.
 ~Action~ 5 µL aliquots (adding to 45 µL TE buffer, pH 7.6) 0, 0.5, 1, 2, 5, 10, 15, and 30 min after  ~Action~ of the digestion mixture.
Immediately  ~Action~ to a tube containing 25 µL Tris-buffered (pH 7.0) phenol.
 ~Action~ a phenol:chloroform (1:1) extraction.
 ~Action~ a chloroform extraction.
 ~Action~ a chloroform extraction once more.
 ~Action~ the fragmented DNA.
 ~Action~ with 70% ethanol.
 ~Action~ 
 ~Action~ fragmented DNA in 23 µL of Blunt-ending Mix (100 µM dNTPs, 1 × T4 DNA Pol Buffer).
 ~Action~ at 65°C for 30 min to  ~Action~ DNA and inactivate any DNase I that was carried over.
 ~Action~ to room temperature.
 ~Action~ 2.5 U Klenow fragment and 5 U T4 DNA polymerase.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ any DNase I that was carried over.
Cool to room temperature.

 ~Action~ 1 µl of the T7 Endonuclease I to the annealed PCR products.

 ~Action~ the reaction by adding 1.5 µl of 0.25 M EDTA.
