Coral TRIZOL RNA Extraction
 ~Action~ 200 μL chloroform per 1 mL TRIzol® Reagent used.
 ~Action~ 15s and  ~Action~ at room temperature for 2–3 minutes.
Note: If you are not doing a DNAse step below, then instead of vortexing shake the tube vigorously by hand for 15 seconds.
Vortexing may increase DNA contamination of your RNA sample.
Avoid vortexing if your downstream application is sensitive to the presence of DNA or perform a DNase-digestion step during RNA purification (as below) or after purification.
 ~Action~ the sample at 12,000 x g for 15 minutes at 4°C.
Note: After centrifugation, the mixture separates into a lower, red phenol–chloroform phase, an interphase, and a colorless upper aqueous phase which contains the RNA.
The volume of the aqueous upper phase is ~600 μL.
 ~Action~ ~600 μL of the colorless, upper phase containing the RNA to a fresh RNase-free tube.
 ~Action~ an equal volume of 70% ethanol to obtain a final ethanol concentration of 35%.
 ~Action~ well by vortexing.
 ~Action~ the tube to disperse any visible precipitate that may form after adding ethanol.
BINDING:  ~Action~ up to 700 μL of sample (prepared as described above) to a Spin Cartridge (with a Collection Tube).
 ~Action~ at 12,000 × g for 15 seconds at room temperature.
 ~Action~ the flow–through and  ~Action~ the Spin Cartridge into the same Collection Tube.
Repeat until the entire sample has been  ~Action~ (in other words until all sample has passed through the spin column and RNA bound to the silica frit).
 ~Action~ 350* μL Wash Buffer I to the Spin Cartridge.
 ~Action~ at 12,000 × g for 15 seconds at room temperature.
 ~Action~ the flow-through and the Collection Tube.
 ~Action~ the Spin Cartridge into a new Collection Tube.
*Without DNAse treatment in the subsequent step there would be only one step with  ~Action~ of 700 μL Wash Buffer I.
 ~Action~ 500 μL Wash Buffer II with ethanol to the Spin Cartridge.
 ~Action~ at 12,000 × g for 15 seconds at room temperature.
 ~Action~ the flow-through, and  ~Action~ the Spin Cartridge into the same Collection Tube.
Repeat with a second 500 μL Wash Buffer II with ethanol to the Spin Cartridge.
 ~Action~ at 12,000 × g for 15 seconds at room temperature.
 ~Action~ the flow-through, and  ~Action~ the Spin Cartridge into the same Collection Tube.
 ~Action~ the Spin Cartridge and Collection Tube at 12,000 × g for 1 minute at room temperature to dry the membrane with attached RNA.
 ~Action~ the Collection Tube and  ~Action~ the Spin Cartridge into a Recovery Tube.
 ~Action~ 30 μL–3 × 100 μL (3 sequential elutions with 100 μL each) RNase-Free Water to the center of the Spin Cartridge and  ~Action~ at room temperature for 1 minute.
 ~Action~ the Spin Cartridge with the Recovery Tube for 2 minutes at ≥12,000 × g at room temperature.
 ~Action~ the Spin Cartridge.
The recovery tube contains the purified total RNA.
 ~Action~ the purified RNA on ice if used within a few hours.
For long-term storage,  ~Action~ the purified RNA at –80°C.
Note: If you are performing sequential elutions,  ~Action~ all eluates into the same tube.

Chlorovirus Purification
 ~Action~ the virus pellets with a small volume of 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.8.
 ~Action~ flasks with NC64A chlorella in MBBM (or Pbi in FES, SAG 241-80 in MBBM) and  ~Action~ for several days at 25oC with continuous light and shaking.
 ~Action~ the flasks of chlorella with virus at an moi of 0.01 to 0.001.
 ~Action~ Triton X-100 to the lysate supernatants to a final concentration of 1%.
This solubilizes the green pigment in the supernatant.
 ~Action~ this solution at room temperature for at least one hour.
 ~Action~ the lysate in the Sorvall GSA rotor at 5,000 rpm (4,000 rcf), 5 min, 4°C.
 ~Action~ the lysate in the Beckman Type 19 ultracentrifuge rotor at 17,000 rpm (43,000 rcf), 50 min, at 4°C.
 ~Action~ the virus pellets with a small volume of 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.8.
For NC64A and Pbi virus lysates: 
 ~Action~ the virus suspension onto 100-400 mg/mL (10-40%, w/v) linear sucrose density gradients equilibrated with 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.8, made up in Beckman SW28 rotor tubes.
 ~Action~ the gradients in a Beckman SW28 or SW32 rotor at 20,000 rpm (72,000 rcfmax), 20 min, 4°C.
 ~Action~ the virus bands from the gradients with sterile bent needles via top (or via side puncture with sterile needle and syringe) to oak ridge 30 mL polypropylene tubes.
 ~Action~ the flasks for 48-72 hours at 25°C with continuous light and shaking.
 ~Action~ the pellets.
 ~Action~ the supernatants.

Use Organizase 2.8 for second-strand cDbNA  ~Action~  ~Reagent~  ~Method~ for second-strand cDbNA synthesis and for  ~Action~ of  ~Reagent~ 
Subject each  ~Reagent~  ~Action~ each sample to 30 cycles of PCR amplification with  ~Reagent~ (5′-GTTTCCCBGTCBCGBTC-3′) using  ~Reagent~  ~Action~ with Primer Z (5′-GTTTCCCBGTCBCGBTC-3′) using SuuprPerdi Gold.
 ~Action~  ~Generic-Measure~  ~Modifier~ 100 mM Tris — 50 mM glycine buffer at a pH of 9.5 and  ~Modifier~ mix for 20 min at room temperature.
Recover the wash solution immediately and adjust the  ~Measure-Type~ to neutral  ~pH~ 
Use polyethylene glycol (PEG) precipitation to concentrate and purify the viral particles contained in the wash solution.
Mix samples with 10% (weight/volume) PEG 8000 and .3 M NaCl (weight/volume), then incubate at 4 °C for 18 hours before centrifuging the samples at 10,800 × g (8000 rpm) for 30 min at 4 °C.
Pour off the supernatant and dissolve the pellet in 20 mL of  ~Modifier~ phosphate buffered saline, letting soak for 1 hour at room temperature.
Add an equal volume of chloroform to each PEG precipitate to remove the PEG and purify the sample.
Vortex the solutions for 30 seconds and centrifuge at 3000 × g (4300 rpm) for 15 min at 4 °C to collect the supernatant containing virus particles.
Pass the  ~Modifier~ supertanant through 0.45 and 0.22 μm filters and further concentrate to  ~Modifier~ 1 mL by Amicon centrifugal ultrafiltration ( ~Generic-Measure~ .
Treat the final 1 mL concentrates with 100 units of DNase-I for 1 hour at 37 °C before nucleic acid extraction to remove free nucleic acids from the concentrated virus samples.
Extract viral DbNA and bRNA using the AbsJoint viral bRNA/DbNA mini kit following the  ~Method~ 
For each viral concentrate, prepare four individual nucleic acid extracts to minimize nucleic acid extraction bias.
Following extraction, screen the samples with 16S ribosomal DbNA (rDbNA) PCR with 27F/1492R universal primers to ensure no residual microbe toxins are affecting the samples.
Reverse transcribe bRNA with Primer B (5′-GTTTCCCBGTCBCGBTCNNNNNNNNN-3′) using Lackevdencscript future transcriptase.

Sampling for RNA / Protein/ dissolved nutrients from phage infection experiments
At each time point,  ~Action~ 10ml from each experimental bottle/tube into a 15ml conical tube, using a serological pipet.
 ~Action~ one 10ml sample for RNA and one 10ml sample for protein.
 ~Action~ tubes for 15 minutes at 4700 rpm (4816 x g) in a swinging bucket rotor.
If you wish to collect the cell-free fraction (e.g.
for analyzing dissolved inorganic or organic nutrients or phage particles):  ~Action~ supernatants into labeled sterile 50 ml conical tubes.
We  ~Action~ the RNA and protein supernatants together resulting in a 20ml combined supernatant.
If you do not wish to collect the cell-free fraction:  ~Action~ supernatant into waste container.
 ~Action~ cell pellets in 15 ml tubes using liquid nitrogen;  ~Action~ pellets in -80°C freezer until later analysis.
If you are not collecting the cell-free fraction, stop here.
If you are collecting the cell-free fraction, go to Step 5.
 ~Action~ the plunger from a 20ml clean syringe.
 ~Action~ a new 0.2µm syringe filter to the syringe.
 ~Action~ your 20ml combined supernatant into the barrel of the syringe.
 ~Action~ plunger on the syringe and  ~Action~ your 20ml supernatant into appropriate tubes for your downstream nutrient/phage analysis (we use a 15ml conical tube plus a 5ml snap-cap Eppendorf tube).
 ~Action~ step 5 for each sample.
You can reuse the same syringe for replicates of the same condition/treatment.

Protocol for SYBR Counts of Cyanophages and Bacteria
 ~Action~ dilutions of the sample(s).
 ~Action~ volume of samples used.
Custom has been to use 20 µl of phage stocks or 200 µl of cells diluted to 2 ml with autoclaved seawater.
If the final slides appear too sparse or dense then the volume of sample used can be adjusted accordingly.
 ~Action~ the 10% SYBR and phenylenediamine from the freezer.
Keep the stocks away from light (such as in a drawer) while they are thawing.
 ~Action~ the glass flask to the vacuum pump.
 ~Action~ the filter holder so that the grout is flat and level with the table.
 ~Action~ a 0.8 µm filter on top of the grout.
Make sure it is completely flat and centered, with no air bubbles underneath (pre-wetting the grout helps).
This filter can be used many times so long as it stays intact and flat.
 ~Action~ the 0.02 µm filter on top of the 0.8 µm filter. 
Again, make sure it is flat and centered with no air bubbles underneath.
Turning on the vacuum for a brief while can help achieve this.
 ~Action~ the funnel on top of the filters.
 ~Action~ the sample and turn on the pump (pressure should be ~20 kPa or 7 mmHg).
After the last liquid passes through the funnel and clamp should be removed with the vacuum still on.
Turn off the vacuum;  ~Action~ 0.02 µm filter.
Keep track of which side of the filter is the top.
Blot out any seawater on the bottom or the top plastic rim with a kimwipe.
It is very important to make sure the filters are completely dry before continuing.
It is a good idea to rub the back of the filter with a kimwipe and then stick it in a dessicator (we used a makeshift box with some drying rocks) for a few minutes.
 ~Action~ a 100 µL drop of SYBR, made fresh from 2.5 µL 10% stock + 97.5 µL 0.02 µm filtered deionized water, on the bottom of a plastic Petri dish.
 ~Action~ the 0.02 Anodisc filters sample side up on the drops of the SYBR staining solution for 15 minutes in a dark drawer or box.
While waiting it may be a good time to prepare the antifade solution.
 ~Action~ completely as in steps 7-8.
Do not touch the top of the filter.
 ~Action~ the filter sample-side up on a glass slide.
 ~Action~ 30 µL of antifade on a cover slip; then invert slip and place on top of the filter.
Appy pressure to ensure that the antifade fills the space underneath the square.
 ~Action~ with blue excitation.
 ~Action~ at least ten fields in the microscope (We usually examine 20).
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ of the sample(s).
Record  ~Measure-Type~ of samples used.
Custom has been to use 20 µl of phage stocks or 200 µl of cells diluted to 2 ml with autoclaved seawater.
If the final slides appear too sparse or dense then the volume of sample used can be adjusted accordingly.
Remove the  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~ and  ~Reagent~ from the  ~Device~ 
One-step growth curves for Cellulophaga phages. 
 ~Action~ a new culture; ie, pick a colony into a new flask containing 10 ml of MLB media.  
Immediately after the transfer, take a ‘time 0’ growth reading. 
Continue taking readings as performed in step 2 periodically. 
Do a plaque assay to determine the PFU/ml of the lysate you plan to use. 
Calculate the volume needed for 107 phages. 
 ~Action~ the concentration of your culture at the time you want to start the infection.  
 ~Action~ the volume of host culture needed for 108 cells. 
 ~Action~ this amount into a 1.5 ml tube. 
 ~Action~ 107 phages to the tube and start your timer for 15 minutes to allow the phages to adsorb to the host cells. 
After 15 minutes,  ~Action~ the infection 1:1000 in MLB media in a 250 ml flask. 
Take a sample immediately after dilution – this is ‘time 0’ Steps for centrifuged sample: 
Steps for samples that are not centrifuged:  
 ~Action~ sampling in this way for 8 hours.   
 ~Action~ the filtered samples at 4°C. 
The next day,  ~Action~ the plaques on all plates that have a countable number of them.  
Decide which dilution gives the best count at each time point for the next time you do this same phage-host pair. 
The next day, count any new plaques that have appeared and add these to your original count. 
 ~Action~ again on the third day. 
 ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~ a  ~Reagent~ into a  ~Modifier~  ~Location~ containing  ~Amount~ of  ~Reagent~  ~Reagent~  ie, pick a colony into a new flask containing 10 ml of MLB media.  
Immediately after the transfer, take a ‘time 0’ growth reading.

Field size may be full (counting all particles in all 100 small squares) or smaller (e.g. 5 small squares), depending on the virus/bacteria concentration.

 ~Action~ this by a scaling factor of 1.26 x 105 to get the total number of particles on the filter.

Tube-O-Dialyzer (No Loss Dialyzer for Small Samples)
Tube‐O‐DIALYZER™ are supplied in a preservative to maintain quality.
Prior to use  ~Action~ the preservative from the tube and  ~Action~ the dialysis cap upside down in a beaker or other suitable container.
 ~Action~ your sample directly into the Tube‐O‐DIALYZER™ tube.
For Tube‐O‐DIALYZER™ Micro use 20‐250µl and for Tube‐O‐DIALYZER™ Medi use 0.2‐2.5ml.
 ~Action~ the Tube‐O‐DIALYZER™ dialysis cap from the rinse water/buffer and carefully  ~Action~ excess liquid with a pipette tip.
 ~Action~ the dialysis cap on to the Tube‐O‐DIALYZER™ tube until finger tight.
 ~Action~ the Tube‐O‐DIALYZER™, ensuring the entire sample rests upon the membrane.
Keeping the Tube‐O‐DIALYZER™ in an inverted position,  ~Action~ the supplied float onto the Tube‐O‐DIALYZER™ tube.
 ~Action~ the Tube‐O‐DIALYZER™ in the dialysis buffer.
Ensure that the dialysis membrane contacts the dialysis buffer.
If there are large air bubbles trapped underneath the dialysis membrane surface,  ~Action~ the tube or  ~Action~ buffer to remove the air bubbles.
Dialysis Time:  Dialysis time will depend on the nature of sample, MWCO of the Tube‐O‐DIALYZER™, sample and dialysis buffer volume and concentration.
Higher MWCO will allow faster dialysis.
As a guide, the sample should be dialyzed for 2‐12h.
Dialysis buffer should also be replaced at least once during dialysis.
After dialysis,  ~Action~ the Tube‐O‐DIALYZER™ from the float and immediately  ~Action~ the Tube‐O‐DIALYZER™ (in up‐right position) for 5‐6 seconds at 500‐1,000xg.
 ~Action~ the dialysis cap and  ~Action~ with the supplied Storage Cap.
 ~Action~ 1‐2ml DI water or dialysis buffer to rinse.
 ~Action~ the Tube‐O‐DIALYZER™ membrane wet until required.
Gently,  ~Action~  ~Action~ for 2‐12h.
Dialysis buffer should also be replaced at least once during dialysis.

 ~Action~ the cap with the dialysis cap.
 ~Action~ the storage cap as this will be required for storage of DNA.

Making your own electrocompetent cells
 ~Action~ 1 colony from a fresh plate of the strain to be made electrocompetent into 10 ml of SOB in a 125 ml flask. 
 ~Action~ for 16-18 hours at 37°C and 250 rpm. 
 ~Action~ 2, 1 L flasks containing 250 ml each of SOB. 
 ~Action~ two drops of the overnight culture to each of the pre-warmed 250 ml flasks. 
 ~Action~ at 37°C and 250 rpm  ~Action~ the cultures reach an OD600 of 0.5-0.7. 
 ~Action~ centrifuge and  ~Action~ rotor to 4°C well in advance of harvesting cells. 
 ~Action~ 1 L of 10% glycerol on ice well in advance of harvesting cells. 
 ~Action~ cultures on ice for 15 minutes.
From this point on the cultures must be kept ice cold. 
 ~Action~ each 250 ml culture into chilled 500 ml (or 1000 ml) centrifuge bottles. 
 ~Action~ at 5000 rpm for 10 min.  
 ~Action~ the supernatant and  ~Action~ any residual broth. 
 ~Action~ 250 ml of glycerol to each of the centrifuge bottles and completely  ~Action~ the cells by pipetting up and down. 
 ~Action~ at 5000 rpm for 10 min.  
 ~Action~ the supernatant, it is not necessary to aspirate. 
 ~Action~ 250 ml of glycerol to each of the centrifuge bottles and completely  ~Action~ the cells by pipetting up and down. 
 ~Action~ the supernatant and  ~Action~ the cells in the residual glycerol by pipetting up and down. 
To freeze,  ~Action~ 100 µl of the culture to microcentrifuge tubes on ice. 
Once you have used all of the culture,  ~Action~ the tubes to dry ice for 10 minutes.

Activation and Intracellular Staining of Whole Blood: For the Detection of Intracellular Cytokines and Other Intracellular Targets
If staining intracellular antigens (e.g. IFN-γ or IL-4), first perform cell surface antigen staining as described in  ~Method~  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ staining as described in BioLegend’s Cell Surface Immunofluorescence Staining Protocol, then  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ in  ~Amount~  ~Location~  ~Reagent~ (BioLegend Cat. No. 420801) in the  ~Location~ for  ~Time~ at  ~Temperature~ 
 ~Action~ at  ~Speed~ for  ~Time~   ~Action~  ~Reagent~ 
To put the experiment “on hold” at this point for future staining and analysis,  ~Action~  ~Reagent~  ~Concentration~ with  ~Reagent~ (BioLegend Cat. No. 420201).
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ in  ~Reagent~ and  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ at  ~Temperature~ (short term) or in  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~ for  ~Reagent~ at  ~Temperature~ (long term, for fixed cells without surface antigen staining).

Nile Red Staining of Drosophila Larval Tissues
 ~Action~ tissues in ice cold PBS,  ~Action~ samples on ice until required sample size is obtained.
 ~Action~ tissues in 4% PFA for 20 minutes.
 ~Action~ tissues 3x in PBS.
 ~Action~ samples in Nile Red at 0.5 ug/mL diluted in PBS for 1 hour.
 ~Action~ tissues 3x in PBS.
Carefully  ~Action~ the PBS with mounting medium before  ~Action~ samples to slides and  ~Action~ 
 ~Action~ immediately, or temporarily  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ in  ~Location~ keeping  ~Reagent~ on  ~Location~  ~Time~ 
Obtaining pure phage stock
 ~Action~ phages from the clearing zone on the plate to 1 mL phage buffer or sterile sea water in a sterile tube by  ~Action~ the surface layer of the soft agar containing the phages using a sterile loop.
Allow the phages to  ~Action~ into the medium overnight at 4°C.
 ~Action~ the tube and  ~Action~ the sample (10,000 x g, 10 min) to  ~Action~ bacteria and agar.
 ~Action~ the supernatant to a new tube.
This sample will typically contain 106–108 phages mL–1.
To  ~Action~ single phages,  ~Action~ of this concentrate should be done, followed by  ~Action~  and subsequent  ~Action~ of phages from single plaques.
Usually, this procedure is repeated 3 times to  ~Action~ any contaminant phage associated with the phage of interest and increase the probability that only one specific phage is present in the final phage stock.
In the end, the phage concentrate is 0.2 µm  ~Action~ and  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ from the  ~Location~ on the  ~Location~ to  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~ or  ~Modifier~  ~Reagent~ in a  ~Modifier~  ~Location~ by scraping off the  ~Reagent~ of the  ~Reagent~ containing the  ~Reagent~ using a  ~Modifier~  ~Device~ 
Propagation of marine eukaryotic viruses (Prasinoviruses)
Cleaning and Concentration of Lysate.
Once the primary infection culture has cleared,  ~Action~ entire volume of lysate through a 0.45-µm-pore-size PES membrane sterile disposable filter unit to remove large cell debris.
 ~Action~ 20 mL filtered lysate to the upper reservoir of a 100,000 Dalton MWCO PES membrane Vivaspin20 ultrafiltration unit.
NOTE: Appropriate MWCO will depend on virus capsid size.
For maximum recovery select a MWCO at least 50% smaller than the molecular size of the particle of interest.
200 kDa is the equivalent of ~10 nm.
 ~Action~ unit with counter-balance in swinging bucket rotor in pre-cooled (4°C) benchtop centrifuge so that the printed side faces upwards/outwards.
 ~Action~ at 1,000 x g (do not exceed!) for 5-10 minutes.
Centrifuge time will depend on the amount of material in the sample.
Do not let the filter go dry.
 ~Action~ the volume retained in the upper reservoir.
 ~Action~ the filtrate by separating the upper reservoir from the bottom of the Vivaspin20 unit.
Repeat 2-6 (adding filtered lysate to the retentate in the upper reservoir up to 20 mL before re-centrifuging) until the entire volume of filtered lysate has been processed.
NOTE: Several Vivaspin20 units can be used in parallel for large lysate volumes, and pooled after concentration.
 ~Action~ the concentrated virus sample (retentate) from the upper reservoir to a sterile 15 or 50 mL conical tube.
 ~Action~ the upper reservoir from the Vivaspin20 unit and  ~Action~ the bottom with a double-layer of Parafilm.
 ~Action~ 2 mL of 0.02-µm-filtered 1X TE buffer (pH 8.0) to the upper reservoir.
 ~Action~ the upper reservoir (Parafilm side down) for ~20 sec on 60% power to wash the Vivaspin20 filter.
 ~Action~ the washed sample to the recovered viral concentrate.
Repeat 10-12 twice more for a total of 3 washes with TE buffer.
 ~Action~ concentrated virus sample at 4°C protected from light.
Primary Infection.
Ethanol-clean culture hood as usual, then UV pipettes, tips, and tube rack for 10 min.
 ~Action~ with one virus at a time, transferring the master stock from 4°C to the culture hood.
Initiate the primary infection by  ~Action~ the master virus stock at 1% of the total culture volume (e.g., 5 mL virus to 500 mL exponentially-growing host culture).
 ~Action~ the infected flask and  ~Action~ at standard growth conditions until culture is mostly lysed (e.g., ~5 days for O. lucimarinus viruses).
Thoroughly  ~Action~ pipette and gloves with ethanol before repeating for additional viruses.

Phototaxis suppression
To ensure that you only use photopositive/photonegative flies for this experiment, do a  ~Action~ by  ~Action~ a regular, single-trial photoxasis experiment without aversive stimulus and collect only the flies in either the bright or the dark tube.
After placing the filter paper in the appropriate tube and with the elevator down,  ~Action~ the selected flies (around 50) into the entrance tube and give them 10 minutes for dark adaption.
 ~Action~ the elevator all the way up,  ~Action~ the flies into the elevator and  ~Action~ it to the middle position (between the entrance tube and the dark tube).
 ~Action~ the T-maze back into the vertical position and  ~Action~ the elevator with the flies all the way down.
Now let the flies choose between the bright tube and the dark tube for 30 seconds.
 ~Action~ all the flies into the tube which doesn’t contain the aversive stimulus (The elevator is still down).
Take this tube and  ~Action~ all the flies in the entrance tube again (with a funnel).
Let them  ~Action~ for 15 seconds.
 ~Action~ the "Bright/dark tube choice" section (steps 3 through 8).
 ~Action~ the tube which contains the aversive stimulus with a tube without any filter paper and  ~Action~ the "Bright/dark tube choice" section (steps 3 through 8).
 ~Action~ the elevator up and  ~Action~ the flies in the entrance tube, the transparent tube and the opaque tube after  ~Action~  ~Modifier~   ~Modifier~  ~Method~ without  ~Modifier~  ~Reagent~ and  ~Action~ only the  ~Reagent~ in either the  ~Modifier~ or the  ~Modifier~  ~Location~  ~Modifier~ aversive stimulus and collect only the flies in either the bright or the dark tube.

 ~Action~ 10 ml of sterile H2O.
 ~Action~ completely.
 ~Action~ a 0.2 µm syringe filter by  ~Action~ through 5-10 ml of sterile H2O and  ~Action~ water.
 ~Action~ Kanamycin Stock through the prepared 0.2 µm syringe filter.
Stock may be  ~Action~  ~Amount~ of  ~Reagent~  
Isolation and Purification of DNA from Chlorella Viruses
For each gradient, in 100 x 13 mm tubes,  ~Action~ together 500 µL of virus, 60 µL of 10X TEN, pH 7.4, and 60 µL of 1% Na sarcosyl.
 ~Action~ 600 µL of 60% (w/w) CsCl to each tube.
 ~Action~ the tubes at 75°C for 15 min.
 ~Action~ the samples onto pre-formed 40-60% (w/w) CsCl gradients in SW60 rotor tubes (to make a final 30-60% gradient).
 ~Action~ 1200 µL of the heated virus to each gradient.
 ~Action~ the gradients in SW60 rotors at 35,000 rpm, 18 hours, 25°C.
 ~Action~ the DNA bands from the gradients with a wide bent needle to silicon-coated 30 mL corex tubes.
Extract the Hoechst dye from the DNA by  ~Action~ an equal volume of CsCl/TE-saturated isopropanol to the DNA solution,  ~Action~ gently by inversion,  ~Action~ for 1 min at 3,000 rpm in the Sorvall to separate the phases, and  ~Action~ the upper isopropanol layer.
Repeat last step.
 ~Action~ 1.0 mL of 3 M NaOAc to each tube and  ~Action~ the volume of each tube to 10.0 mL with 1X TE buffer.
 ~Action~ the DNAs with 2X volumes of 100% EtOH.
 ~Action~ well and  ~Action~ at -20°C overnight.
 ~Action~ the DNA samples in the Sorvall HB-4 rotor at 10,000 rpm, 20 min, 4°C.
 ~Action~ the supernatants.
 ~Action~ the pellets briefly (10-15 min) in the vacuum desiccator to remove the EtOH.
 ~Action~ the DNA samples with approximately 500 µL of 1X TE buffer.
 ~Action~ the DNA concentrations and  ~Action~  ~Size~  ~Location~  mix together  ~Amount~ of  ~Reagent~   ~Amount~ of  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~   ~Measure-Type~  ~Numerical~  and  ~Amount~ of  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~ 
Adsorption of phage to cyanobacteria
Have everything ready to perform plaque assay:
a. Plating cells, aliquoted, and set aside.
b. Bottom plates labeled (24 + plates).
c. Top agar aliquoted and temperature equilibrated.
d. Dilution tubes—these contain 1.5 mL media, labeled and kept on ice.
e. Cyanophage stock diluted into 1–5 mL media Set up a table to record times such as Table 1 (guidelines).
 ~Action~ adsorption cultures (e.g., 250 mL polycarbonate Erlenmeyer flasks with screw cap).
 ~Action~ flask with 100 mL host cells.
 ~Action~ cyanophage stock of known titer to host at an MOI of ca. 0.01 and quickly  ~Action~ to disperse the virus.
Immediately  ~Action~ a subsample and dilute 100× for time zero:  ~Action~ 15 µL to a tube containing 1.5 mL of ice cold media.
 ~Action~ to mix.
 ~Action~ host for 5 min at ca.
16,000g and 4°C; note the time.
Carefully  ~Action~ a small aliquot (50 µL) of the supernatant to a new tube and  ~Action~ for plaque assay; note time.
 ~Action~ adsorption cultures under usual conditions (e.g., light and temp).

MojoSort™ Streptavidin Nanobeads Protocol
 ~Action~ cells from your tissue of interest without lysing erythrocytes. 
In the final wash of your sample preparation,  ~Action~ the cells in MojoSort™ Buffer by  ~Action~ up to 4 mL in a 5 mL (12 x 75 mm) polystyrene tube. 
Note:  ~Action~ MojoSort™ Buffer on ice throughout the procedure. 
 ~Action~ the cells with a 70 μm cell strainer,  ~Action~ at 300 x g for 5 minutes, and  ~Action~ in an appropriate volume of MojoSort™ Buffer. 
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the cell concentration to 1 x 108 cells/mL.
 ~Action~ 100 μL of cell suspension (107 cells) into a new tube. 
 ~Action~ appropriate amount of antibody or antibody cocktail to the cell suspension,  ~Action~ well and  ~Action~ on ice for 15 minutes.
Note: The antibody volume to add should not exceed more than 20% of the 100 μL cell suspension volume.
Thus, for 100 μL of cell suspension  ~Action~ more than 20 μL of antibody.
If you need to  ~Action~ more than 20 μL of antibody,  ~Action~ the cells in step 3 at a higher concentration.
For example, to  ~Action~ 50 μL of antibody,  ~Action~ the cells to a final concentration of 2 x 108 cells/mL.
You can then  ~Action~ 50 μL of cells and  ~Action~ 50 μL of antibody,  ~Action~ well and  ~Action~ on ice for 15 minutes.
Always keep the total volume around 100 μL.
 ~Action~ MojoSort™ Buffer up to 4 mL,  ~Action~ the cells at 300 x g for 5 minutes. 
 ~Action~ the cells in 100 μL of of MojoSort™ Buffer. 
 ~Action~ the beads by  ~Action~  maximum speed, 5 touches.
 ~Action~ appropriate amount of pre-titrated Streptavidin Nanobeads,  ~Action~ well and  ~Action~ on ice for 15 minutes.
Note: The Streptavidin Nanobeads volume to add should not exceed more than 20% of the 100 μL cell suspension volume.
Thus, for 100 μL of cell suspension do not add more than 20 μL of Nanobeads.
If you need to  ~Action~ more than 20 μL of Nanobeads,  ~Action~ the cells in step 6 at a higher concentration.
For example, to  ~Action~ 50 μL of Nanobeads,  ~Action~ the cells in 50 μL of MojoSort™ Buffer.
Always keep the total volume around 100 μL.
 ~Action~ MojoSort™ Buffer up to 4 mL and  ~Action~ the cells at 300 x g for 5 minutes. 
 ~Action~ the cells in 3 mL of MojoSort™ Buffer. 
Optional:  ~Action~ an aliquot before placing the tube in the magnet to monitor purity and yield. 
 ~Action~ the tube in the magnet for 5 minutes. 
Negative Selection: If you are interested in the untouched cells,  ~Action~ the liquid in a new tube.
These are your cells of interest; do not discard.
If needed, repeat the magnetic separation on this cell fraction to increase the yield.
Positive Selection: If you are interested in the cells that are bound to the Nanobeads,  ~Action~ the liquid while the tube is in the magnet (negative fraction).
Then,  ~Action~ the tube from the magnet and  ~Action~ your cells.
Repeat steps 9 – 11 on the labeled fraction 2 more times, for a total of 3 magnetic separations to increase yield, if needed.
Optional:  ~Action~ a small aliquot to monitor purity and yield.
 ~Action~ the unlabeled fractions and  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ from  ~Reagent~  ~Action~  ~Reagent~

Megabase DNA Extraction from Animal Blood
 ~Action~ 3mL animal's blood in 5 mL EDTA anticoagulative tube, and  ~Action~ at 4 °C. 
Mix blood by gently rocking for 10min at room temperature to ensure a homogenous WBC distribution.
 ~Action~ 3ml blood to 15ml screw cap tube containing 9ml RBC lysis solution (3 volumes), and mix by gently inverting 10x.
 ~Action~ 5 min at room temperature.
Gently mix by inverting at least once during incubation.
 ~Action~ 5 min at 2000xg at 4⁰C and carefully  ~Action~ supernatant while not disturbing the pellet.
 ~Action~ cell pellet in 3ml PBS (1 blood volume): 
 ~Action~ 9ml rbc lysis sol (3 volumes),  ~Action~ to mix and  ~Action~ 5 min at room temperature.
 ~Action~ cell suspension for 5 min at 2000xg at 4⁰C and carefully  ~Action~ supernatant while not disturbing the pellet.
Remove the last drop of liquid by tilting the tube and removing liquid with pipet tip.
 ~Action~ cell pellet in 580ul cell suspension buffer (Bio Rad plug lysis kit) until homogenous suspension.
 ~Action~ 375ul to a new microfuge tube and  ~Action~ (400).
 ~Action~ 187.5ul to another tube labeled (200);  ~Action~ 187.5ul cell suspension buffer, and pipet  ~Action~ gently 5x.
 ~Action~ both tubes on ice until ready to embed in agarose (section II).
Melt 2% agarose (Bio Rad kit) by immersing in microwave-boiled water for 10-15min until agarose is completely melted.
 ~Action~ both tubes from step 11 section I in 43°C water bath/heat block for at least 5 min before use.
After 5 min, prepare 5 plugs from one tube by performing the next steps rapidly to avoid solidification of the cell-agarose mixture before pipeting into plug mold: 
 ~Action~ plug cast on ice for at least 45min or until agarose has solidified.
Alternatively, can place plug cast on inverted metal microfuge ice block on ice for 45min, to avoid potential contact of agarose with ice. 
 ~Action~  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~ in  ~Size~  ~Location~  and store at  ~Temperature~  
Subcellular Fractionation from Animal Cells (FOCUS™ SubCell Kit)
OPTIONAL: Add appropriate protease inhibitor cocktail (e.g.
G‐Biosciences’ ProteaseArrest, Cat. # 786‐108) to SubCell Buffer‐I immediately prior to use.
 ~Action~ fresh cells only.
 ~Action~ the harvested cells by centrifugation at ~800 x g for 1 minute.
Carefully  ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the supernatant.
Gently  ~Action~ to suspend the cells and  ~Action~ on ice for 10 minutes.
 ~Action~ 500µl of ice cold SubCell Buffer‐I.
 ~Action~ this lysis step on ice.
Using a narrow opening (20 gauge) syringe needle, gently  ~Action~ the suspension up and down 10‐30 times.
 ~Action~ 250µl 3X SubCell Buffer‐II (350µl if Dounce homogenizer is used) and  ~Action~ by inverting.
 ~Action~ the tube at 700x g for 10 minutes to pellet the nuclei.
 ~Action~ the supernatant to a new tube.
 ~Action~ supernatant at 12,000x g for 15 minutes.
 ~Action~ the supernatant (post mitochondria) to a new tube for further processing.
The pellet contains mitochondria.
 ~Action~ 500µl 1X SubCell Buffer‐II to the pellet, and  ~Action~ again at 12,000 x g for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ the supernatant.

Isotopic Labeling of Cyanobacteria and DNA Analysis
 ~Action~ Pro99, SN, SNAX or Amp1 medium according to directions, but use 15N ammonium chloride which will provide the heavy isotope.
15 NH4Cl is available from Cambridge Isotope Laboratories, Inc. (#NLM-467-1).
 ~Action~ cyanobacteria in the medium with heavy nitrogen and  ~Action~ at least 3 times before use.
 ~Action~ the bacteria grown in heavy nitrogen.
 ~Action~ bacterial DNA using standard methods.
 ~Action~ the DNA using Quant-iT Pico Green.
Use at least 10 µg of DNA for density gradient centrifugation.
For density gradient centrifugation, a Beckman VTi 65 vertical rotor was used with 13x48 mm OptiSeal polyallomer tubes (4.9 ml capacity).
 ~Action~ the DNA with TE buffer (10mM Tris, 1mM EDTA, pH7.6) to a final volume of 0.9 ml.
 ~Action~ the DNA with 4ml of CsCl prepared in TE to a density of p1.8 (measure the density of the final solutions, they should be p1.7).
 ~Action~ 4.9 ml of the DNA sample in CsCl into the OptiSeal tube and  ~Action~ with the black caps.
 ~Action~ the tubes into the rotor and  ~Action~ caps on all carriers.
 ~Action~ at 44,000 rpm (=184,678.5 g) in a Beckman L70 or L80 ultracentrifuge for 48 hr at 18°C.
 ~Action~ 0.2-0.25 ml fractions.
 ~Action~ amount of DNA in each fraction using Quant-iT Pico Green (perform in duplicate) and  ~Action~ the density of each fraction.
 ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Reagent~   ~Reagent~   ~Reagent~ or  ~Reagent~  ~Method~  but use  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~ which will provide the heavy isotope.
Gibson Assembly® Protocol (E5510)
 ~Action~ samples in a thermocycler at 50°C for 15 minutes when 2 or 3 fragments are being  ~Action~ or 60 minutes when 4-6 fragments are being  ~Action~ 
 ~Action~ samples on ice or at –20°C for subsequent transformation.
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ in a  ~Device~ at  ~Temperature~ for  ~Time~ when 2 or 3 fragments are being assembled or  ~Time~  ~Reagent~  ~Numerical~ or  ~Numerical~ fragments are being assembled or 60 minutes when  ~Numerical~  ~Reagent~ are being assembled.
General Autoclaving
 ~Action~ reservoirs in autoclave bags.
 ~Action~ plates in foil and  ~Action~ a piece of autoclave tape on top.
 ~Action~ autoclave tape on pipet tip boxes. 
 ~Action~ all items in beige autoclave tray.
 ~Action~ to autoclave.
 ~Action~ table hanging from autoclave: Name/Lab, Process, Time Open autoclave door by pressing button.
For dry autoclave place tray with items in the middle of the autoclave.

T-maze phototaxis with LEDs
Clip wings of half of the flies.
 ~Action~ flies recover for  ~Time~  ~Reagent~  ~Action~ wings of  ~Generic-Measure~ of the  ~Reagent~ 
Let  ~Reagent~  ~Action~ for 1 day (at 25°C, faster recovery).
 ~Action~ the  ~Reagent~ in the  ~Location~ (entrance tube) and  ~Action~  ~Mention~  ~Action~ themselves to the machine and the darkness for  ~Time~ 
 ~Action~ the flies into the elevator (the mobile part of the T-maze), and let them stay there for around 1 minute.
 ~Action~ the flies to the bottom of T-maze (taking down the elevator).
Now they will have to make a decision between two different tubes: one is completely dark, and the other one has a LED in the bottom/is entirely transparent.
We are going to use different LEDs: White LEDs, Yellow LEDs, Green LEDs. 
 ~Action~ for 30 seconds for the flies to make their decision, and lock them in the tubes that they have chosen (taking up the elevator).

Quick Protocol for Monarch® Plasmid Miniprep Kit (NEB #T1010)
Pellet 1–5 ml bacterial culture by centrifugation at 16,000 x g for 30 seconds.
Discard supernatant.
Resuspend pellet in 200 μl Plasmid Resuspension Buffer (B1).
Vortex or pipet to ensure cells are completely resuspended.
There should be no visible clumps.
Add 200 μl Plasmid Lysis Buffer (B2), gently invert tube 5–6 times, and incubate at room temperature for 1 minute.
Color should change to dark pink, and solution will become transparent and viscous.
Do not vortex.
Add 400 μl of Plasmid Neutralization Buffer (B3), gently invert tube until neutralized, and incubate at room temperature for 2 minutes.
Sample is neutralized when color is uniformly yellow and precipitate forms.
Do not vortex.
 ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Amount~ bacterial culture by  ~Method~ at  ~Speed~ for  ~Time~ 
Discard supernatant.
Resuspend pellet in 200 μl Plasmid Resuspension Buffer (B1).
Vortex or pipet to ensure cells are completely resuspended.
There should be no visible clumps.
Add 200 μl Plasmid Lysis Buffer (B2), gently invert tube 5–6 times, and incubate at room temperature for 1 minute.
Color should change to dark pink, and solution will become transparent and viscous.
Do not vortex.
Add 400 μl of Plasmid Neutralization Buffer (B3), gently invert tube until neutralized, and incubate at room temperature for 2 minutes.
Sample is neutralized when color is uniformly yellow and precipitate forms.
Do not vortex.
Centrifuge lysate at 16,000 x g for 2–5 minutes.
For culture volumes >1 ml, we recommend a 5 minute spin to ensure efficient RNA removal by RNase A.
Pellet should be compact; spin longer if needed.
Carefully transfer supernatant to the spin column and centrifuge at 16,000 x g for 1 minute.

 ~Action~ 5ul of the digested reaction to 50ul of kit‐provided competent cells. 
 ~Action~ at 42°C for 30s. 
 ~Action~ 950ul of SOC medium and  ~Action~ for 1h at 37°C.
 ~Action~ 25ul on Carb plate.
 ~Action~ the remaining 975ul for 3min at 5K and also  ~Action~ the pellet.
One half (or more) of the colonies will have the correct insertion.
Pick 6 colonies to  ~Action~ each in 2ml of bacterial culture.
Miniprep (Qiagen kit, include the PB wash, elute in 50ul of H2O) and send to  ~Action~  ~Action~ (Qiagen kit, include the PB wash, elute in 50ul of H2O) and send to sequencing using the forward sequencing primer in the guidelines.

 ~Action~ the GFP plasmid pCM1.53 (available at Addgene) with primers containing the desired flanking regions (~30‐60 bp), mutations in the sgRNA site(s) and GFP sequence.
 ~Action~ are performed using Phusion taq 2X Master Mix (NEB), 45s elongation step, 30 cycles, 50ul reaction.
 ~Action~ step is done using a gradient from 60°C to 72°C.
 ~Action~ PCR reactions on agarose gel to confirm the amplification.

The DNA concentration should be >500ng/ul (at this concentration, the amount of PCR oligo remaining in the mixture will be low enough to avoid any toxicity).
We use pRF4 roller plasmid at 120ng/ul, but you can use any marker that you find convenient.

Do not let cultures grow for more than 16 hours.

 ~Action~ a large plate of worms

 ~Action~ embryos (less than 2000) on NA22 large plate.

 ~Action~ 30‐40 worms.
AddingM9 #1:  ~Action~ 5ul of M9 (Start adding M9 every 5-10 minutes, about 1h after the worms have been put in recovery buffer).

With a pick,  ~Action~ 5 to 10 injected worms from the recovery buffer to the M9 drop and  ~Action~ them away from the M9 drop towards the food.
 ~Action~ until all the worms are transferred.
Even if the worms look inert at this or the next step, they are worth transferring as they may yield edited progeny.
Leave the injected worms on OP50 plates at room temperature for 5h and then  ~Action~  ~Action~ the injected worms on OP50 plates at room temperature for 5h and then transfer each worm (P0) to a new OP50 plate (1 P0 per plate).
Allow the P0s to lay eggs at 20°C for 1 or 2 days.
 ~Action~ the P0s to fresh OP50 plates between the first and second day.
Let the F1s  ~Action~ at 20°C.
When all the F1s have reached the young adult stage (4 days at 20°C), check for rollers.
GFP fusions: if you know what you are looking for, it is possible to  ~Action~ directly for GFP expression in the F1 (or F2) animals.
PCR screening:  ~Action~ the F1 rollers and their non‐roller F1 siblings to new plates (2 to 8 F1s per plate).
PCR Screening: Let the F1 lay eggs for 24h at 20°C.
 ~Action~ the F1s for PCR: In each 10 uL tube of lysis buffer, put 2 to 8 F1s.
We recommend testing each gene‐specific PCR assay before starting the injections.
See the guidelines for PCR Screening details.
 ~Action~ the F2/3s from positive F1 plates.
It is useful to let the worms crawl on a no‐bacteria plate before picking to avoid accidental transfer of siblings.
If 2 F1s were pooled per plate,  ~Action~ 16 F2s.
If 8 F1s were pooled per plate,  ~Action~ the starved plate if necessary and  ~Action~ 24 to 32 F2/F3s.
 ~Action~ and PCR F2/3s using the same methods as for the F1s.
EXCEPT: When looking for homozygous GFP worms, use primers that flank the GFP fusion.

Use 7ul for this elution as a template and use a primer inside the PCR product for sequencing.
Once a homozygous F2/3 plate is identified, it is recommended to  ~Action~ 4 worms again to new plates and to verify their genotype to ensure that the line is truly homozygous.

BetaMark™ x-40 ELISA Kit (Chemiluminescent) Protocol
 ~Action~ a 1L bottle as “1X Wash Buffer”.
 ~Action~ 5X Wash Buffer 1:5 using lab grade water* and mix well.
*Note: Lab grade filtered water such as injection grade, cell culture grade, Reverse Osmosis De-Ionization(RODI).
 ~Action~ an appropriate sized bottle as “1X Reagent Diluent”.
 ~Action~ (2) 1.5mL microcentrifuge tubes as intermediate #1 & 2 (use enclosed tubes).
 ~Action~ 990uL of standard diluent to intermediate tubes #1 & 2.
 ~Action~ 20ug vial of 1-40 standard with 80uL of Standard Diluent.
 ~Action~ well by inversion, donot vortex.
Concentration will be 250ug/mL.
*Once reconstituted, standard must be used within the same day.
 ~Action~ 10uL from the vial of reconstituted 1-40 standard to 990uL of standard diluent in intermediatetube #1.
 ~Action~ well by inversion, do not vortex.
 ~Action~ 10uL from intermediate #1 tube and add to 990uL standard diluent in intermediate #2 tube.
 ~Action~ well by inversion, do not vortex.
The final concentration of intermediate tube #2 will be 25ng/mL.
 ~Action~ a 50mL centrifuge tube as “1X Incubation Buffer”.
 ~Action~ 2X incubation buffer to 1X by adding 10mL of 2X incubation buffer to 10mL of lab grade water* in the 50mL tube labeled “1X Incubation Buffer”.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ well.
*Note: Lab grade filtered water such as injection grade, cell culture grade, Reverse Osmosis De-Ionization(RODI).
Time Efficient Method for Washing 15 mL Vials
 ~Action~ vials so that they all sit upright in a large plastic cage.
I’ve found you can usually fit about 60 vials (a bit more than one bag) into a single cage.
 ~Action~ caps into a small cage.
 ~Action~ cages upright into a soap bath overnight.
 ~Action~ a large piece of PTFE over the cages to keep them submerged.
 ~Action~ cages from soap, and  ~Action~ thoroughly 7 times to remove soap.
It’s important to make sure that water gets into each individual vial, so  ~Action~ the cage back and forth until each of the vials is at least partially filled.
When pouring the water back out, make sure to shake the cage so that in interior of all the vials is rinsed.
 ~Action~ the outsides in between rinsing the vial interiors.
 ~Action~ cages upright into a 1N HCl bath.
Once or twice during the week,  ~Action~ and/or  ~Action~ all of the cages (vials and caps) to make sure all surfaces are exposed.
 ~Action~ vials and caps from the bath and  ~Action~ each cage 7 times to remove most of the HCl.
 ~Action~ an area in the drying bench with a clean wipe, and  ~Action~ cages into the drying bench.
With thoroughly cleaned and rinsed poly gloves,  ~Action~ each vial from the cage and individually rinse the vial plus one cap three times.
 ~Action~ in front of the flow bench to  ~Action~ excess water,  ~Action~ vial, and  ~Action~  ~Action~ about 60 vials (a bit more than one bag) into a single cage.
Extracting DNA from viruses embedded in agarose

 ~Action~ the viral concentrate to 37°C in the water bath, then immediately  ~Action~ with an equal volume of molten agarose and quickly  ~Action~ the mixture to casting molds.

 ~Action~ at room temperature overnight.
 ~Action~ the lysis buffer, being careful not to lose the plugs.
Optional:  ~Action~ the plugs twice, each time  ~Action~ 25 volumes of fresh TE containing 1 mM PMSF,  ~Action~ for 1 h with gentle agitation, then  ~Action~ the rinse fluid.
 ~Action~ the plugs, add 50 volumes of fresh TE with no PMSF,  ~Action~ for 30 min.
with gentle agitation, then  ~Action~ the rinse fluid.
Once more,  ~Action~ the plugs,  ~Action~ 50 volumes of fresh TE with no PMSF,  ~Action~ for 30 min.
with gentle agitation, then decant the rinse fluid.
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ to  ~Reagent~ for a final concentration of 1.5% (wt/vol).
Isotopic labeling of freshwater mixotrophic algae using isotopic labeled inorganic nitrogen and carbon
 ~Action~ modified DY-V media with labeled substrates. 
Media used for Ochromonas growth was a modified version of DY-V media.
Modifications were:No MES was used, as it can be used as a source of carbon (bicarbonate and heat-killed bacteria are the only sources of carbon used in this media).
No Na2SiO3 was used (Ochromonas does not need silica).
No NaNO3 (ammonium and heat-killed bacteria were the only sources of nitrogen used in this media).
Sodium bicarbonate added at a final concentration of 95 µM.
Bicarbonate addition is done before algal inoculum by 0.2 µm filtration of a stock solution (do not autoclave).
In order to ensure isotopic labeling of the mixotrophic algae, 50% of the ammonium chloride added to the media is ammonium-15N chloride (98% atom 15N) and all bicarbonate added to the media is 13C-bicarbonate.
NOTE: depending on the degree of labeling that wants to be achieved, the % of labeled ammonium and bicarbonate can be modified.
 ~Action~ heat-killed bacteria (HKB) to the media (HKB were obtained following this protocol).
 ~Action~ an inoculum of the mixotrophic algae (volume of inoculum should be low as to avoid dilution of the isotopic label and carry over of nutrients).
NOTE: as an example, values commonly used were ~5x103 Ochromonas mL-1 and ~5x107 HKB mL-1 as starting concentrations for the cultures.
Mixotrophic growth of the algae Let the algae grow so it incorporates the isotopic signature in its biomass.
 ~Action~ the algae growth through microscopy (live samples and/or fixed samples) and the decline of heat-killed bacteria (fixed samples and staining with DAPI to assess HKB concentrations through epifluorescence microscopy.
Sampling for assessment of algal isotopic signature Ochromonas was allowed to grow for 2-3 generations before sampling for isotopic signature.
Two kind of samples can be collected: Bulk measurements: filter 30-50 mL of the cultures onto pre-combusted glass fiber filters and dry at 60 ºC over night to stop all biological activity.
Afterwards, filters can be  ~Action~ in glass vials at room temperature.
Further processing of the sample included an acidification step with HCl to remove inorganic carbon and the C- and N- isotopic composition of the sample was determined by an isotope rato mas spectrometer (IRMS).
Cell-specific measurements:  ~Action~ 2 mL of sample and  ~Action~  ~Modifier~  ~Reagent~ with  ~Device~  
Media used for Ochromonas growth was a modified version of DY-V media.
Modifications were:No MES was used, as it can be used as a source of carbon (bicarbonate and heat-killed bacteria are the only sources of carbon used in this media).

MojoSort™ Human CD4 Nanobeads No Wash Protocol
 ~Action~ cells from your tissue of interest without lysing erythrocytes. 
In the final wash of your sample preparation,  ~Action~ the cells in MojoSort™ Buffer by adding up to 4 mL in a 5 mL (12 x 75 mm) polystyrene tube.
Note:  ~Action~ MojoSort™ Buffer on ice throughout the procedure. 
 ~Action~ the cells with a 70 μm cell strainer,  ~Action~ at 300 x g for 5 minutes, and  ~Action~ in an appropriate volume of MojoSort™ Buffer.
 ~Action~ and  ~Action~ the cell concentration to 1 x 108 cells/mL.
 ~Action~ 100 μL of cell suspension (107 cells) into a new tube. 
 ~Action~ the beads by vortexing, maximum speed, 5 touches.
 ~Action~ 10 μL of Nanobeads,  ~Action~ well and  ~Action~ on ice for 15 minutes.
Scale up the volume accordingly if separating more cells; for example,  ~Action~ 100 μL for 1 x 108 cells.
When working with less than 107 cells, use indicated volumes for 107 cells.
 ~Action~ the cells in 3 mL of MojoSort™ Buffer.
Optional:  ~Action~ an aliquot before placing the tube in the magnet to monitor purity and yield.
 ~Action~ the tube in the magnet for 5 minutes  ~Action~ the liquid.
 ~Action~ labeled cells in appropriate buffer. 
 ~Action~ steps 6 – 8 on the labeled fraction 2 more times, for a total of 3 magnetic separations.
Optional:  ~Action~ a small aliquot to monitor purity and yield.
If desired,  ~Action~ the unlabeled fractions and  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ from your  ~Reagent~  ~Method~

OmniPrep™ For High Quality Genomic DNA Extraction From Solid Tissue (Fresh or Frozen)
 ~Action~ for 1 minute at 14,000xg.
For optimal yield, rapidly  ~Action~ tissue and  ~Action~ with DNA extraction immediately, keeping samples on ice or freeze in liquid nitrogen and  ~Action~ at -70°C until required.
On ice,  ~Action~ 1-10mg ground frozen tissue or fresh tissue to a microcentrifuge tube containing 250µl Genomic Lysis Buffer.
 ~Action~ the sample with a microfuge pestle until a homogenous suspension is acquired.
 ~Action~ an additional 250µl Genomic Lysis Buffer.
 ~Action~ the sample at 55-60°C for 15 minutes.
Do not heat higher than 60°C.
OPTIONAL: For maximum DNA recovery,  ~Action~ 1µl Proteinase K solution for every 100µl Lysis Buffer and  ~Action~ at 60°C for 1-2 hours.
 ~Action~ the tube periodically each hour.
This step will digest hard to handle tissues and significantly improve the yield.
Allow the sample to  ~Action~ to room temperature.
 ~Action~ 200µl chloroform and mix by  ~Action~ the tube several times.
 ~Action~ for 10 minutes at 14,000xg and carefully  ~Action~ the upper phase to a clean microcentrifuge tube.
 ~Action~ 50µl DNA Stripping Solution to the sample and  ~Action~ several times to mix.
 ~Action~ the sample for 5-10 minutes at 60°C.
 ~Action~ 100µl Precipitation Solution and mix by  ~Action~ the tube several times.
 ~Action~ the sample at 14,000xg for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ the supernatant to a clean tube and  ~Action~ the genomic DNA with 500µl isopropanol.
 ~Action~ the tubes 10 times to precipitate the DNA.
OPTIONAL: For increased DNA recovery,  ~Action~ 2µl Mussel Glycogen as a DNA carrier.
 ~Action~ at 14,000xg for 5 minutes to pellet genomic DNA.
 ~Action~ the supernatant.
 ~Action~ 700µl 70% ethanol to the tube and  ~Action~ several times to wash the DNA pellet.
 ~Action~ or  ~Action~ the ethanol wash.   ~Action~ the tube on a clean absorbent surface for several minutes to allow any excess ethanol to drain away.
 ~Action~ 50µl TE Buffer to the pellet.
 ~Action~ at room temperature for at least 15 minutes to rehydrate.
OPTIONAL: 1µl LongLife™ RNase for every 100µl TE Buffer can be added at this stage.
 ~Action~ DNA at 4°C, for long term storage  ~Action~  ~Time~ at  ~Speed~

We recommend performing the reactions in duplicate.

Lysin purification protocol
Pellet 500ml cells (5min x 5000RPM).
 ~Action~ in 20ml MBBM,  ~Action~ 20µl tetracyline.
 ~Action~ 150µl purified PBCV incubate 16hrs under fluorescent illumination with a 16 hr light/8 hr dark cycle at 25°C on an orbital shaker (~95 rpm).
 ~Action~ cells and virus by centrifugation at 25,000RPM (50.2Ti) for 17 min at 20°C.
 ~Action~ cells in 20ml 25mM KOH, 50mM MOPS, 2mM Na2EGTA, 0.1M LiCl(pH 7) (wash).
 ~Action~ 25,000RPM for 17 min at 20°C,  ~Action~ supernatant.
 ~Action~ pellet in 1.5ml 25mM KOH, 50mM MOPS (pH 7), 60µl 10M LiCl, 30µl 0.1M Na2EGTA  ~Action~ 50 min at 37°C.
 ~Action~ 25,000RPM for 17 min at 20°C.
 ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~ (5min x 5000RPM).
Cell Surface Immunofluorescence Staining Protocol
 ~Action~ desired tissue (e.g. spleen, lymph node, thymus, bone marrow) and  ~Action~ a single cell suspension in Cell Staining Buffer (BioLegend Cat. No. 420201).
 ~Action~ Cell Staining Buffer up to ~15 ml and centrifuge at 350 x g for 5 minutes,  ~Action~  ~Action~ at 350 x g for 5 minutes, discard supernatant.
If necessary (e.g. spleen),  ~Action~ 10X Red Blood Cell (RBC) Lysis Buffer (BioLegend Cat. No. 420301) to 1X working concentration with DI water and  ~Action~ pellet in 3 ml 1X RBC Lysis Buffer.
 ~Action~ on ice for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ by  ~Action~ 10 ml Cell Staining Buffer to the tube.
 ~Action~ for 5 minutes at 350 x g and  ~Action~ supernatant.
 ~Action~ Cell Staining Buffer up to ~15 ml and  ~Action~ at 350 x g for 5 minutes,  ~Action~ supernatant.
 ~Action~ viable cells and  ~Action~ in Cell Staining Buffer at 5-10 x 106 cells/ml and  ~Action~ 100 μl/tube of cell suspension (5-10 x 105 cells/tube) into 12 x 75 mm plastic tubes.
 ~Action~ appropriately conjugated fluorescent, biotinylated, or purified primary antibodies at predetermined optimum concentrations (e.g. anti-CD3-FITC, anti-CD4-Biotin, and anti-CD8-APC) and  ~Action~ on ice for 15-20 minutes in the dark.
 ~Action~ with at least 2 ml of Cell Staining Buffer by centrifugation at 350 x g for 5 minutes. (1/2). 
If using a purified primary antibody,  ~Action~ pellet in residual buffer and  ~Action~ previously determined optimum concentrations of anti-species immunoglobulin fluorochrome conjugated secondary antibody (e.g. FITC anti-mouse Ig) and  ~Action~ on ice in the dark for 15-20 minutes.
 ~Action~ with at least 2 ml of Cell Staining Buffer by centrifugation at 350 x g for 5 minutes. (1/2). 
 ~Action~ cell pellet in 0.5 ml of Cell Staining Buffer and  ~Action~ 5 μl (0.25 μg)/million cells of 7-AAD Viability Staining Solution (BioLegend Cat. No. 420403) to  ~Action~ dead cells.
 ~Action~ on ice for 3-5 minutes in the dark.
 ~Action~ with a Flow Cytometer.
 ~Action~ with at least 2 ml of Cell Staining Buffer by centrifugation at 350 x g for 5 minutes. (2/2). 
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ (e.g. spleen, lymph node, thymus, bone marrow) and prepare a single cell suspension in Cell Staining Buffer (BioLegend Cat. No. 420201).
CviJI Purification From IL-3A Virus Infected NC64A Chlorella
 ~Action~ Buffer A: 
 ~Action~ Buffer B: 
 ~Action~ Buffer B, pH 8.5: 
 ~Action~ Storage Buffer: 
 ~Action~ 1X CviJI Assay Buffer: 
 ~Action~ the enzyme at -20°C.
 ~Action~ 7 hour IL-3A virus infected NC64A chlorella and  ~Action~ in MSK flasks with Buffer A.
 ~Action~ the homogenate to clean tubes.
 ~Action~ the homogenate supernatant to 70% saturation with (NH4)2SO4 at 4°C with gentle stirring.
 ~Action~ the material in the Sorvall SS34 rotor at 10,000 rpm 10 min, 4°C.
 ~Action~ the pellets with Buffer A.
 ~Action~ the material in the Sorvall SS34 rotor at 10,000 rpm, 10 min, 4°C.
 ~Action~ the supernatant with 10-15 volumes of Buffer B to reduce the NaCl concentration.
 ~Action~ the Heparin-Sepharose column with Buffer B using a 0-2.0 M KOAc gradient.
 ~Action~ the Blue-Sepharose column with Buffer B using a 0-2.0 M KOAc gradient.
 ~Action~ the pooled fractions with 10-15 volumes of Buffer B, pH 8.5 to reduce the salt concentration.
 ~Action~ the Q-Sepharose column with Buffer B, pH 8.5 using a 0-2.0 M KOAc gradient.
 ~Action~ the pooled enzyme by dialysis overnight into storage buffer at 4°C.
 ~Action~ the cells in the MSK mechanical homogenizer with 15 gm of 0.3 mm glass beads at 4,000 rpm for 90 sec (2 X 45 sec) with CO2 cooling.
 ~Action~ the glass beads 3X with 5 mL of Buffer A and  ~Action~ with the homogenate.
 ~Action~ the homogenate in the Sorvall SS34 rotor at 10,000 rpm, 20 min, 4°C.
 ~Action~ the supernatant.
 ~Action~ at 4°C for 60-90 min without stirring.
 ~Action~ the pellet.
Per mL of suspension  ~Action~  0.45 mL of 4 M NaCl and 0.45 mL of 28% PEG 8000 (heated to 65°C).
 ~Action~ gently by inversion for 5-10 min.
 ~Action~ the supernatant.
 ~Action~ the material overnight onto a Heparin-Sepharose column equilibrated with Buffer B in the cold room.
 ~Action~ the column fractions and  ~Action~ the active fractions.
 ~Action~ the pooled fractions with 10-15 volumes of Buffer B to reduce the salt concentration.
 ~Action~ the material overnight onto a Blue-Sepharose column equilibrated with Buffer B in the cold room.
 ~Action~ the column fractions and pool the active fractions.
 ~Action~ the material overnight onto a Q-Sepharose column equilibrated with Buffer B, pH 8.5 in the cold room.
 ~Action~ the column fractions and  ~Action~  ~Action~ the active fractions.
Load the material overnight onto a Q-Sepharose column equilibrated with Buffer B, pH 8.5 in the cold room.
Protocol for STO Cell Transfection by FuGENE HD
STO cells were seeded the day before transfection with the density 15,000 cells per well in 100 μl complete growth medium DMEM+10% Fetal Bovine Serum.
 ~Action~ 0.02μg/μl pCMVβ plasmid DNA solution in OptiMEM®.
 ~Action~ 6μl of reagent to 100 μl of OptiMEM® /DNA solution.
 ~Action~ carefully by pipetting (10-15 times).
 ~Action~ 5 min at room temperature.
 ~Action~ 5μl complex per well to the cells, and mix thoroughly.
 ~Action~ the cells into CO2 incubator for 26-28 hours.
 ~Action~ the medium from the well and wash the cells once with 100μl per well PBS.
 ~Action~ the cells in the well with 50μl solution of 4% formaldehyde in PBS for 5min at room temperature.
 ~Action~ each well with 100μl PBS.
(1/2)  ~Action~ 50μl per well of substrate/stain solution and incubate the plate overnight at 37°C.
 ~Action~ the cells under microscope and evaluate the proportion of blue (β-gal-positive) cells.
 ~Action~  ~Action~ the cells once with 100μl per well PBS.
Fix the cells in the well with 50μl solution of 4% formaldehyde in PBS for 5min at room temperature.

 ~Action~ inverted capped acid-washed glass below the surface of the B2 ocean.
 ~Action~ cap while submerged and allow water to fill glass bottle.

 ~Action~ a petri-dish.

 ~Action~ on a kimwipe.

 ~Action~ slide to individual chamber yet.

Sequential Double Digest
 ~Action~ the following reaction using the restriction endonuclease that has the lowest salt concentration in its recommended buffer (total reaction volume 50 µl).
 ~Action~ components by  ~Action~ the reaction mixture  ~Action~  or by " ~Action~  the reaction tube.
Quick ("touch")  ~Action~ in a microcentrifuge.
Do not vortex the reaction.
 ~Action~ for 1 hour at the enzyme-specific appropriate temperature.
 ~Action~ the salt concentration of the reaction (using a small volume of a concentrated salt solution) to approximate the reaction conditions of the second restriction endonuclease.
 ~Action~ the second enzyme.
 ~Action~ components by  ~Action~ the reaction mixture  ~Action~  or by " ~Action~  the reaction tube.
Quick ("touch")  ~Action~ in a microcentrifuge.
Do not vortex the reaction.
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ using the  ~Reagent~ that has the lowest salt concentration in its recommended buffer (total reaction volume 50 µl).
DNA Extraction Protocol.

RNA sequencing library construction for Illumina GA II
 ~Action~ 400ng of amplified mRNA to 10‐200nt using 10x RNA fragmentation buffer (Ambion). 
 ~Action~ using regular ethanol precipitation method with 0.35μl of GlycoBlue (Ambion).
 ~Action~ the 3’ end the RNA samples using 10x Antarctic Phosphatase Buffer and 0.5 μl Antarctic Phosphatase (NEB) at 37 °C for 20 minutes.
 ~Action~ inactivate at 75°C for 10 minutes.
 ~Action~ the 5’ end of RNA samples was using 10x T4 DNA ligase buffer (it has 1mM ATP final) and T4 PNK (NEB) at 37 °C for 30 minutes.
 ~Action~ the RNAs in the reactions using ammonium acetate and ethanol precipitation with 2μl of GlycoBlue (Ambion).
 ~Action~ the RNA samples at 37 °C for one hour to 3’ linker (5’‐/5rApp/CTG TAG GCA CCA TCA AT/3ddC/‐3’) (synthesized by IDT) using: T4 RNA ligase 1 (NEB), 5X ATP‐free T4 RNA ligase buffer (16.5 mM DTT, 41.5% glycerol, 250 mM HEPES‐KOH, pH8.3, 50 mM MgCl2, 50 μg/ml acetylated BSA), and 10% DMSO .
 ~Action~ the RNAs in the reactions using ammonium acetate and ethanol precipitation with 2μl of GlycoBlue (Ambion).
 ~Action~ the RNA samples on 6% TBE‐Urea PAGE Gel (Invitrogen).
 ~Action~ 100‐200nt bands and elute overnight with 400μl stop solution (1M ammonium acetate and 10mM EDTA) at 4°C.
 ~Action~ the RNAs in the supernatant using regular ethanol precipitation method with 2μl of GlycoBlue (Ambion).
 ~Action~ the RNA samples at 37°C for 1 hour to 5’ linker (with bar code) using: T4 RNA ligase 1 (NEB), 10x T4 RNA ligase 1 buffer (NEB), and 10% DMSO .
 ~Action~ the RNAs by ammonium acetate and ethanol precipitation and gel purification as described in steps 8-11.
 ~Action~ cDNA of the RNA samples using SuperScript III (Invitrogen) following manufacture’s protocol.
The primer sequence used for reverse transcription is 5’‐ATT GAT GGT GCC TAC AG‐3’.
 ~Action~ the cDNA samples using Taq (NEB) following manufacture’s protocol.
 ~Action~ the PCR products (200‐300nt) using Qiagen PCR purification kit.
 ~Action~ the purified PCR samples to 10nM and  ~Action~  ~Amount~ of  ~Modifier~  ~Reagent~ to  ~Generic-Measure~ using  ~Concentration~  ~Reagent~ (Ambion). 
96-well DNA Extraction Protocol from 25mm 0.2µm filters
 ~Action~ lysis buffer. 
 ~Action~ Lysozyme & RNase Aliquot. 
 ~Action~ ProK Aliquot. 
 ~Action~ filters on ice. 
 ~Action~  
 ~Action~ each filter to screw top, O-ringed eppendorf tube, also on ice. 
 ~Action~ 250 µl lysis buffer with RNase and lysozyme to each tube. 
 ~Action~ 37°C for 30 min., rotating end over end at angle, for optimal mixing with minimal frothing. 
 ~Action~ 18.75 µl of Proteinase K solution (10 mg/ml made up in lysis buffer) to a final conc. of 0.65 mg/ml. 
 ~Action~ 29.9 µl 10% SDS to a final conc. of 1%. 
 ~Action~ at 55°C for 2 hours, rotating end over end at angle. 
Towards end of this time,  ~Action~ heat block or hyb oven to 70°C. 
 ~Action~ elution liquid (Buffer AE or water) into 70°C to preheat. 
 ~Action~ 300 µl Buffer AL (=Buffer AL/E without the ethanol added). 
 ~Action~ thoroughly by vortexing and  ~Action~ quickly.  
 ~Action~ 70°C for 10 mins.
 ~Action~ 300 µl 96-100% EtOH. 
 ~Action~ by vortexing vigorously and spin down quickly. 
 ~Action~ of lysate, must be <7 to get max. binding efficiency to column. 
 ~Action~ onto 96 well spin columns, making sure not to wet the rims to avoid cross contamination. 
 ~Action~ the 96 well column plate onto the S-block for flow through collection. 
 ~Action~ plate with Airpore tape sheet Spin 5788 xg for 10 min. at 40­°C. 
 ~Action~ flow through. 
 ~Action~ in new collection tray.  
 ~Action~ additional lysate if needed and repeat spin, etc.
 ~Action~ 500 µl Buffer AW1,  ~Action~  ~Action~  etc.
Add 500 µl Buffer AW1, reseal plate Spin 5788 xg for 5 min. at 40°C. 
 ~Action~ 500 µl Buffer AW2,  ~Action~ plate Spin 5788 xg for 5 min. at 40°C. 
To  ~Action~ columns, either  ~Action~ plate with new sheet and  ~Action~ 5600 xg for 15 min. at 40°C atop a new collection tray or  ~Action~ in hyb oven at 70°C for 15 min.
 ~Action~ column plate to top of rack of "elution microtubes RS". 
 ~Action~ 200 µl pre-heated 70°C Buffer AE or water,  ~Action~ plate  ~Action~ 1 min. at RT.  
 ~Action~ 5788 xg 2 min. to elute. 
 ~Action~ with second 200 µl (will increase total yield up to 25%) or if you wanted to keep the column small, you could use the first 200 µl elution,  ~Action~ it back to 70°C, and  ~Action~ it through the column again (will increase total yield approx. 15%). 
Can  ~Action~ elutants and  ~Action~ here overnight, or for a while, before proceeding with Final DNA clean up step, particularly if DNA is in Buffer AE which is TE, so will keep the DNA relatively stable. 
 ~Action~ the eluted DNA to the 96 well PCR purification plate (no more than 300 µl at a time). 
 ~Action~ vacuum at 20 inches Hg until dry (~20-30 min.)
 ~Action~ DNA with 100 µl Ambion water,  ~Action~ vacuum 5-10 min. until dry. 
 ~Action~ a second time with water if you want to make sure all Buffer TE removed. 
 ~Action~ 20 µl dilute TE. 
OmniPrep™ For High Quality Genomic DNA Extraction From Mouse Tail Tissue
Add 0.5-1cm, approximately 50-100mg, mouse tail in to a 1.5ml microcentrifuge tube with 500µl Genomic Lysis Buffer.
Add 10µl Proteinase K solution and incubate at 60°C for 3-4 hours to overnight.
Invert the tube periodically if possible.
Allow the sample to cool to room temperature.
Add 200µl chloroform and mix by inverting the tube several times.
Centrifuge for 10 minutes at 14,000xg and carefully remove the upper phase to a clean microcentrifuge tube.
Add 50µl DNA Stripping Solution to the sample and invert several times to mix.
Incubate the sample for 5-10 minutes at 60°C.
Add 100µl Precipitation Solution and mix by inverting the tube several times.
Centrifuge the sample at 14,000xg for 5 minutes.
Transfer the supernatant to a clean tube and precipitate the genomic DNA with 500µl isopropanol.
Invert the tubes 10 times to precipitate the DNA.
OPTIONAL: For increased DNA recovery, add 2µl Mussel Glycogen as a DNA carrier.
Centrifuge at 14,000xg for 5 minutes to pellet genomic DNA.
Remove the supernatant.
Add 700µl 70% ethanol to the tube and invert several times to wash the DNA pellet.
Centrifuge for 1 minute at 14,000xg.
Decant or pipette off the ethanol wash.  
Invert the tube on a clean absorbent surface for several minutes to allow any excess ethanol to drain away.
Add 50µl TE Buffer to the pellet.
Incubate at room temperature for at least 15 minutes to rehydrate.
OPTIONAL: 1µl LongLife™ RNase for every 100µl TE Buffer can be added at this stage.
 ~Action~  ~Reagent~ at  ~Temperature~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Amount~  ~Reagent~ to the  ~Reagent~ 
Immunohistochemistry Protocol for Frozen Sections
 ~Action~ the tissue sections with a suitable fixative.
One of the commonly used fixation methods for frozen tissue sections is to  ~Action~ the slides in pre-cooled acetone (-20°C) for 10 min.
 ~Action~ a freshly dissected tissue block (<5 mm thick) on to a pre-labeled tissue base mold.
 ~Action~ the entire tissue block with cryo-embedding media (e.g. OCT).
Slowly  ~Action~ the base mold containing the tissue block into liquid nitrogen till the entiretissue block is submerged into liquid nitrogen to ensure tissue is  ~Action~  ~Action~ into liquid nitrogen to ensure tissue is frozen completely.
 ~Action~ the frozen tissue block at -80°C until ready for sectioning.
 ~Action~ the frozen tissue block to a cryotome cryostat (e.g. -20°C) prior to sectioning and allow the temperature of the frozen tissue block to  ~Action~ to the temperature of the cryotome cryostat.
 ~Action~ the frozen tissue block into a desired thickness (typically 5-10 µm) using the cryotome.
 ~Action~ the tissue sections onto glass slides suitable for immunohistochemistry (e.g. Superfrost).
 ~Action~ the tissue sections overnight at room temperature.
Sections can be  ~Action~ in a sealed slide box at -80°C for later use.
 ~Action~ the fixative and allow acetone to  ~Action~ from the tissue sections for ≥ 20 min at room temperature.
 ~Action~ the slides in 300 ml of 10 mM phosphate buffered saline (PBS) at a neutral pH for 5 min (1/2).
 ~Action~ the slides in 300 ml of 10 mM phosphate buffered saline (PBS) at a neutral pH for 5 min (2/2).
 ~Action~ the slides in 0.3% H2O2 solution in PBS at room temperature for 10 min to  ~Action~ endogenous peroxidase activity.
 ~Action~ the slides in 300 ml PBS for 5 min (1/2).
 ~Action~ the slides in 300 ml PBS for 5 min (2/2).
(optional)  ~Action~ 100 µl blocking buffer (e.g. 10% fetal bovine serum in PBS) onto the sections of the slides and  ~Action~ in a humidified chamber at room temperature for 1h.
 ~Action~ the blocking buffer from the slides.
 ~Action~ 100 µl an appropriately diluted primary antibody (in antibody dilution buffer,e.g. 0.5% bovine serum albumin in PBS) to the sections on the slides and  ~Action~ in a humidified chamber for 1 h at room temperature or overnight at 4°C.
 ~Action~ the slides in 300 ml PBS for 5 min (1/2).
 ~Action~ the slides in 300 ml PBS for 5 min (2/2).
 ~Action~ 100 µl an appropriately diluted biotinylated secondary antibody (using the antibodydilution buffer) to the sections on the slides and  ~Action~ in a humidified chamberat room temperature for 30 min.
 ~Action~ the slides in 300 ml PBS for 5 min (1/2).
 ~Action~ the slides in 300 ml PBS for 5 min (2/2).
 ~Action~ the slides in 300 ml PBS for 5 min (1/2).
 ~Action~ the slides in 300 ml PBS for 5 min (2/2).
 ~Action~ 100 µl DAB substrate solution (freshly made just before use: 0.05% DAB - 0.015%H2O2 in PBS) to the sections on the slides to reveal the color of the antibody staining.
Allow the  ~Action~ for ≤ 5 min until the desired color intensity is reached.
 ~Action~ slides in 300 ml PBS for 5 min (1/2).
 ~Action~ slides in 300 ml PBS for 5 min (2/2).
(optional) Counterstain slides by immersing sides in Hematoxylin (e.g. Gill’s Hematoxylin) for 1-2 min.
 ~Action~ the slides in running tap water for ≥ 15 min.
 ~Action~ the tissue slides with  95% alcohol change (1/4).

RNA extraction using the 'home-made' Trizol substitute
Prepare the components for the home-made Trizol substitute. 
 ~Action~ the components and  ~Action~ at room temperature until completely dissolved (30-60 minutes).
 ~Action~ the solution.
 ~Action~ at 4 °C in a glass bottle protected from light.
 ~Action~ 5 volumes of the home-made Trizol substitute to the sample.
When working in 1.5 mL tubes, for practical reasons, the minimal and maximal volume of the sample is 30 and 200 µl, respectively.
 ~Action~ vigorously for 10-30 seconds (depending on the viscosity and protein and nucleic acid concentration of the sample).
 ~Action~ at room temperature for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ 1 volume of chloroform (relative to the original volume of the sample).
 ~Action~ vigorously 10-20 times by inverting the tube.
 ~Action~ to avoid breaking DNA.
 ~Action~ at room temperature for 5 minutes.
 ~Action~ for 10-15 minutes at >12,000 g and 4 °C (depending on the viscosity and protein and nucleic acid concentration of the sample).
 ~Action~ the upper aqueous phase into a new tube.
 ~Action~ the white DNA precipitate at the interphase.
If the sample volume was 100 µl, the aqueous phase should be ~450 µl.
 ~Action~ 1.1 volumes of isopropanol (relative to the volume of the aqueous phase).
If low RNA content is expected in the sample, prior to isopropanol,  ~Action~ >10 µg of glycogen to facilitate precipitating nucleic acids and spotting the pellet.
Recommended final concentration of glycogen is ~50–150 µg/ml.
 ~Action~ well by inverting the tube.
 ~Action~ 30-60 minutes at 4 °C or at room temperature.
 ~Action~ for 30-45 minutes at >12,000 g and 4 °C.
 ~Action~ the supernatant.
 ~Action~ 1 volume of 70% (aq.) ethanol (relative to the volume of the aqueous phase).
 ~Action~ gently.
Ensure that the pellet is submerged in the solution and not sticking to the tube wall.
 ~Action~ 10 minutes at room temperature.
 ~Action~ for 10 minutes at >12,000 g and 4 °C.
 ~Action~ the supernatant.
Let the pellet dry at room temperature, so that no traces of 70% ethanol remain.
Drying under vacuum is not recommended because of overdrying that makes it harder to dissolve the pellet.
Completely  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Action~  ~Reagent~ and stir at  ~Temperature~ until completely dissolved ( ~Time~ .
